HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

INTERNATIONAL A3-11
 
U.S.-Led Agreement Averts Serbia Bombing
The American envoy Richard C. Holbrooke announced an agreement with President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia that averted the immediate threat of NATO air strikes and that could lead to a form of autonomy in Kosovo. A1 

President Clinton demanded serious progress toward compliance from Mr. Milosevic within the next four days to avoid air strikes. American officials asserted that they had used NATO successfully to avert a human disaster, do justice to the Kosovar Albanians and increase the Albanians' ability to control their lives. A10
 
The diplomatic career of Mr. Holbrooke remains in the hands of a group of Justice Department lawyers who are trying to determine if he violated Federal ethics rules. The inquiry has sidetracked Mr. Holbrooke's nomination to be the next chief United States representative at the United Nations. A10
 
Violence as Mideast Talks Near
Gunmen believed to be Palestinian militants shot and killed an Israeli and seriously wounded another outside Jerusalem two days before an Israeli-Palestinian summit meeting near Washington. A8
 
U.N. Pressure on Iraq
The Security Council called on Iraq to resume cooperation with United Nations weapon inspectors, alluding to prospects for faster progress on the easing of economic sanctions if it heeded the call. A7
 
Deal Close on I.M.F. Financing
The Clinton Administration and Congressional Republican leaders met to hammer out the final details of compromise legislation that would provide the I.M.F. with $18 billion in exchange for new restrictions on loans to foreign governments. A11
 
Charge of Spying for Moscow
A former code-breaking analyst at the National Security Agency was charged with spying for Moscow for the last three years of the Soviet Union's existence. The Government charged that from 1988 until 1991 David Sheldon Boone passed top secret documents to a K.G.B. officer and was paid more than $60,000. A5
 
Prodi to Try to Form Coalition
Acting Prime Minister Romano Prodi of Italy said he would try to form a government, four days after he was ousted after narrowly losing a confidence vote. Mr. Prodi will most likely try to form an alliance with a small center-right party to make up for Communist votes that split away last week, causing him to lose the confidence vote. A9
 
U.S. Lags in Panama Cleanup
The United States is balking at cleaning up some of the most hazardous of the jungle terrain surrounding the Panama Canal, ranges used for nearly a century to test explosives and chemical weapons. The United State is supposed to return the land to Panama in a little more than a year. A3
 
World Briefing A6
 
NATIONAL A12-19
 
Budget Talks Continue To Avoid a Shutdown
Congressional Republicans and White House officials continued negotiations on a Federal budget as they faced their fourth deadline to avoid a Government shutdown. Sticking points included education, census sampling and contraceptive coverage in Federal health plans. Other issues, like I.M.F. financing, seemed close to resolution. A1
 
The White House reached an understanding with Congressional Republicans on the use of statistical sampling for the 2000 census, but Congressional Democrats were not sure they would go along with it. A18
 
Streamlining Clinton Inquiry
Republicans on the House Judiciary Committee are considering folding most of the 15 counts outlined as impeachable offenses against President Clinton into two basic categories: lying under oath and obstruction of justice. A19
 
G.O.P. Pursues an Old Rival
The Republican whip, Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, left, has urged the Electronic Industries Alliance to reconsider its hiring of a prominent Democrat, former Representative David McCurdy, as the lobbying group's president. Mr. Delay's action is part of a push to enforce greater Republican loyalty among Washington lobbying groups. A13
 
Ban on Gay Protection Upheld
The Supreme Court let stand a Cincinnati measure barring protective legislation for homosexuals. A Federal appeals court had ruled the measure unconstitutional. A19
 
Colorado State University began an investigation of the Pi Kappa Alpha fraternity after a homecoming float mocked the fatal beating of a gay student in Wyoming. A19
 
Restoring the Everglades
The Army Corps of Engineers proposed its comprehensive plan for replumbing the Everglades, an $8 billion, 20-year project that proponents called the most ambitious restoration of an ecosystem ever tried. A12
 
Expanding Women's Roles
A committee of Roman Catholic bishops declared that church authorities should do more to promote qualified women to positions of lay leadership in the church. A12
 
5 in U.S. Receive Nobels
Five university professors in the United States received Nobel Prizes in Physics and Chemistry. A16
 
Fire Sprinkler Heads Recalled
The maker of a fire sprinkler agreed to recall millions of the devices already installed in schools, hotels and other buildings. The sprinkler heads, called Omega and produced by Central Sprinkler of Lansdale, Pa., have failed to activate in at least nine fires in three years and have high failure rates in tests. In March, the Consumer Product Safety Commission filed a lawsuit to force the recall of 10 million Omega heads. A company official said production of the Omega heads ended last month. (AP)
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-8
 
Veterinarian Arrested In Ex-Employee's Death
An Upper East Side veterinarian, Dr. Marco Zancope, 43, was arrested and charged with helping a friend, a former receptionist, commit suicide last year as she lay in a hospital gravely ill with breast cancer. B1
 
Septic Tank Rules Draw Fire
Environmental groups said they would file suit against New York City today to reverse a decision to allow developers around the city's upstate reservoirs to install septic systems on steeply sloping hills. B5
 
Kickback Investigation
Prosecutors are looking into whether contractors and managing agents took part in kickback schemes that inflated the cost of repairs at thousands of apartment houses. B1
 
Protest Outside Disputed Play
About 2,000 demonstrators outside City Center protested the opening of "Corpus Christi," a play about a gay Christ-like figure. About 300 people marched in support of the play. B3
 
Panel Backs Halloween Parade
The Community Board committee that supervises the Halloween parade in Greenwich Village voted to recommend that it go forward, but with a few changes. B3
 
No Ruling on Stadium Dispute
A Federal judge declined to enter the battle over a referendum on keeping the Yankees in the Bronx. B4

SPORTS D1-8
 
Yanks Clinch A.L. Pennant
The Yankees defeated the Cleveland Indians, 9-5, in Game 6 of the American League Championship Series. They will face either Atlanta or San Diego, which play tonight. A1
 
Early N.B.A. Games Canceled
The N.B.A. canceled the first two weeks of its season, a result of the labor dispute with the players. A1
 
Tyson Judged Fit to Fight
Psychological evaluations concluded that Mike Tyson suffers from depression, anger, low self-esteem, irritability and that he has trouble controlling his impulses. But they also said he is mentally fit to box. D1
 
BUSINESS DAY C1-22
 
Merrill Lynch Cutting Jobs
Merrill Lynch, the nation's biggest brokerage firm, will eliminate about 3,400 jobs, or just more than 5 percent of its work force, because of global economic turmoil. It is the first big financial company to announce cutbacks linked primarily to the world's troubled markets. A1
 
BankAmerica Hedge Fund Loss
BankAmerica, the nation's fifth-largest bank, is expected to announce a big hedge fund loss today. C1
 
No Pharmaceutical Merger
American Home Products and Monsanto abandoned their $34.4 billion merger, the third big combination in the pharmaceutical industry to fail this year. People close to the deal said the merger was a casualty of a power struggle between the two companies' chairmen. C1
 
Cendant Calls Off Big Deal
Cendant, which has been beset by an accounting scandal, announced that a $3.1 billion deal to buy American Bankers Insurance Group was off because it "no longer made strategic or financial sense." C1

HEADLINE: For World's Women, Progress and Loss

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Chinese employers might be accused justifiably of ageism and sexism (front page, Oct. 13), but are American companies very different? Although they may not be so bold as to stipulate in print what they are after, the outcome is probably often the same. As for middle-aged Chinese women's being responsible for the care of the very young and the very old, are things so different here?
 
ANN L. BERRIOS
Stony Brook, N.Y., Oct. 13, 1998

HEADLINE: Kennelly, in Debate, Sees Two States, One Struggling

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Oct. 13

 BODY:
United States Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, who throughout her campaign for Connecticut governor has touched on many issues but never found a theme, tonight unified her concerns about the state's future by asserting that the prosperity trumpeted by Gov. John G. Rowland amounts to only half of "a tale of two states."
Mrs. Kennelly, a Democrat, used the second of four debates to present what amounted to a closing argument for her candidacy, and her staff said she planned to stick to the theme every day through the election on Nov. 3. 
 "In the Connecticut that John Rowland talks about, all is well," she said at the Old State House in Hartford, where she announced her candidacy 13 months ago.
But she said that other residents, particularly those with children, are struggling. "Mr. Rowland doesn't want to talk about that state -- it doesn't fit on a 30-second ad. But more and more people are being pushed into that other Connecticut every day."
Mr. Rowland, 41, who entered the race's homestretch with six times as much cash as Mrs. Kennelly, replied that one of the problems with her campaign was that she had emphasized the negative at a time when polls show most people are happy with the state's direction. He said all residents had benefited from his policies of cutting taxes and encouraging small businesses, which he said would cushion a recession by making the state less dependent on the defense and insurance industries.
"One of my goals as Governor over the next four years is to make sure that everyone enjoys the same quality of life," he said. "We're building up momentum, we're creating excitement, we're putting this state on the map and we're going to continue forward."
Mrs. Kennelly, 62, said her plans included a patients' bill of rights that would allow people to sue health maintenance organizations, and a scholarship plan that would provide a free state education to students who maintain high grades in high school and college. Those plans would improve the lives of people who are forced to work two jobs, find a college education to be out of reach, or have been denied health coverage, she said.
"That's why I'm running for governor: because we shouldn't be two Connecticuts," she said. "We should be one Connecticut."
After last week's debate with Mr. Rowland, which was only the second debate of her 23-year political career, both candidates were more aggressive tonight. Each repeatedly disputed the other's facts.
Sitting on a huge lead in polls, Governor Rowland hung back at the first debate and did not rebut many statements by Mrs. Kennelly that he later confessed had him itching to respond. "During the last debate, I let a few shots slide," he said tonight.
"Mrs. Kennelly has voted for every single major tax increase -- every single major tax increase -- over 17 years," he said. When Mrs. Kennelly tried to interrupt to dispute that statement, Mr. Rowland would not give up any of his time, and cut her off by saying, "It's my minute."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Barbara Kennelly, left, the Democratic candidate for governor of Connecticut, debated Gov. John Rowland last night. From left at tables were their questioners, Steve Kotchko, Chris Keating and Laura Kelly. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Hurt by Market Swoon, Merrill Lynch to Cut Jobs
Merrill Lynch said it would eliminate about 3,400 jobs, or just more than 5 percent of its global work force. About 2,000 of the staff reductions will be in the United States. The brokerage firm was the first American financial company to announce cutbacks primarily in response to the world's economic troubles, but other Wall Street firms are expected to follow.
Merrill Lynch also reported a loss of $164 million, or 49 cents a share, for the third quarter after taking a $430 million charge to pay for the job cuts. Page A1.
 
Intel Profits Surpass Expectations
Craig R. Barrett, president and chief executive of Intel, reported third-quarter results that surpassed analysts' expectations by 8 cents a share. Mr. Barrett said the results at the leading maker of personal computer chips reflected "growth across nearly all of our geographies and product lines, including strong microprocessor sales." C2. 

Results at Drug Companies Mixed
Two leading drug companies reported mixed results. Third-quarter earnings at Pfizer were 6 cents a share, below Wall Street expectations of 51 cents a share. But Johnson & Johnson met expectations with its earnings of 70 cents a diluted share. C4.
 
Stock prices fell after many companies, including Kodak, reported earnings. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 63.33 points, to 7,938.14, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 2.91 points, to 994.80. The Nasdaq composite index decreased 36.63 points, or 2.37 percent, to 1,509.45. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 5.09 percent, from 5.12 percent on Friday. C10.
 
G.M. Lost $809 Million in Quarter
General Motors lost $809 million in the third quarter, mainly because of a nearly eight-week-long strike that crippled its production in North America. C5.
 
Ford Motor announced plans for mass production of a new, gearless car transmission to be produced in a joint venture that could also become a new model for labor relations in the auto industry. C5.
 
Revenues at Kodak Disappoint
Shares of Eastman Kodak fell 13.39 percent, to $72.375, even though earnings rose 72 percent and were a penny above analysts' forecasts. Revenues, however, declined 10 percent, and sales overseas dropped by 17 percent. The market reaction reflects investor impatience with any whiff of bad news in the nervous stock market. Market Place. C9.
 
Bill to Increase Work Visas Revived
Congress revived legislation that would increase the number of employment visas for skilled foreign workers. Lawmakers also passed an act to protect technology and other start-up companies from lawsuits in state courts over stock price fluctuations. C3.
 
Bank Bill Passed in Japan
The lower house of the Japanese Parliament passed a bill that would allow the Government to inject $508 billion into banks. C6.
 
Bank Chief Rejects Rate Cut
Despite growing anxiety that global financial problems might soon affect Europe, the president of the new European Central Bank rejected demands for a reduction in interest rates or other forms of "policy activism" to spur economic growth. C6.
 
Meeting to Hammer Out I.M.F. Deal
The Clinton Administration and Congressional Republican leaders met to negotiate a deal to provide the I.M.F. with $18 billion in exchange for new restrictions on its loans. A11.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 15, 1998, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An entry in the Business Digest column yesterday about drug company financial results misstated the third-quarter earnings per diluted share of Pfizer Inc. in some editions. The earnings were 51 cents, not 6 cents.

HEADLINE: TURF;
For Bottom Fishers, Nary a Nibble

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
AS the stock market lurches like an elevator out of control, a growing number of would-be apartment buyers are seeking to take advantage of the current uncertainty by making "take it or leave it" bargain-basement offers on co-ops and condominiums -- and getting nowhere, brokers say.
In the current market, where many apartments, especially the overpriced ones, have already come down a peg or two in price, brokers say that sellers are feeling squeezed by these bottom fishers. 
 "They've already reduced it, and that's where the insult comes," said Richard S. Orenstein, an agent at the Halstead Property Company.
Neil Binder, an owner of Bellmarc Realty, which has seven offices and 250 sales agents, said that his company's statistics show that apartments are now selling for prices that are 7 to 10 percent lower than they were in June. But for some bidders, he added, that isn't enough of a reduction.
"The buyers are acting like the world is about to end and sellers should be happy to get anything for their apartment," Mr. Binder said. "Well, it's no fire sale out there -- not with interest rates the lowest they've been in 30 years."
No one questions the buyer's right to make a low-ball bid, but their problem is that sellers are rejecting the offers. Elizabeth Stribling, the president of Stribling Associates, said that within the last week, she had even seen two bidding wars for co-ops, one that eventually sold for more than $700,000 and another for around $200,000.
Not only that, she added, "but we're seeing that even when deals fall through, negotiations with someone else begin quite quickly." But she agreed that, over all, apartment owners are becoming "more reasonable" and are negotiating more on prices, which she called a "very desirable thing."
Clark P. Halstead, the managing partner in Halstead Property, noted that after the 1987 plunge in stock prices, it took 18 months before Manhattan real estate dipped in price. He argued that there are many differences between then and now and that no one is sure the same kind of decline will occur. "People are remembering that prices did drop," he said, "but they're not remembering how long it took."
Some would-be buyers are "chumming the waters for spectacular fish, but they aren't catching any," Mr. Halstead said, continuing: "They don't realize that we don't have a ticker tape in the real estate office. People are nervous about the securities market, and they impute that shaky feeling to everything from pork bellies to houses."
Like Ms. Stribling, he recited some good news for sellers, like a $7 million house in the East 60's that sold for full price in the space of two weeks.
He also said that of all Manhattan's neighborhoods, those south of 23d Street, particularly Greenwich Village, TriBeCa and SoHo, have been least affected by nerves.
"Sales there continue unabated," he said. "It's very chic, and the people buying there are leaders, not followers."
Frederick W. Peters, the president of Ashforth Warburg Associates, an Upper East Side company that opened a downtown office almost two years ago, said he had not noticed that any one neighborhood was stronger than another.
"It's spotty everywhere," he said. "It depends on who your buyer is. The people who are financially secure, and know that real estate is a long-term choice, aren't anxious about whether they can save a few dollars by waiting a few weeks. The people who are more anxious are people who are heavily in the stock market and regard real estate as more of an investment than a home."
But Mr. Peters knows about offers that go straight for the jugular.
"It happened just yesterday," he said last Friday. "This was a nine-room estate sale on Park Avenue in the 80's. The listing price had just been reduced to $2,695,000, which is not a bad price for 3,200 square feet. Well, first the wife came; then the husband. They faxed over an offer for $1.6 million. It was just plain silly."
About the same time, another bargain-seeker made an offer on a glamorous Central Park West apartment priced at $4.5 million.
The man made what agents call a very aggressive bid: $2.5 million.
"What do you think the seller did?" Mr. Peters said. "He gave a Bronx cheer, and that was the end of it."

HEADLINE: THE POP LIFE;
Crossing Racial Boundaries, Rap Gains Ground

BYLINE: By NEIL STRAUSS 

 BODY:
"Glam rock is back!" proclaimed The Guardian of London recently. And the newspaper wasn't alone in its excitement. For months, record label executives and other culture watchers have been making similar pronouncements, and the evidence to back them up is legion: movies like "Velvet Goldmine," musicals like "Hedwig and the Angry Inch," acts like Marilyn Manson and Kiss, topping the pop charts, the signing of half a dozen 80's glam-metal bands at Columbia Records. Even theoretically it makes sense: pop musicians have been gloating that people are tired of alternative rock and its reaction against pomp and stardom, and that audiences want to be entertained by flashy anthemic rock spectacles.
So why is there only one rock album in the Top 10 this week? The glam revolution seems likely to follow swing, ska and electronica, all interesting sliver genres capable of sending just a few bands into the mainstream. In the meantime, all these musical styles are being steamrolled by a juggernaut genre that, despite deaths, prison sentences and internal feuding, just keeps growing: rap. 
 According to information released yesterday by Soundscan, a company in Hartsdale, N.Y., that monitors music sales, 9 of the top 15 albums on the pop chart are rap (if one includes the album by Lauryn Hill of the Fugees, which mixes rap and rhythm-and-blues). Last week the three top-selling albums in the country were all by rap acts -- Jay-Z, Outkast, A Tribe Called Quest -- followed by Ms. Hill at No. 4.
And in coming weeks, new records by the rapper Ice Cube, various Master P creations, and the Wu-Tang Clan members RZA and Method Man are expected to top the charts. In the meantime, rock stars aren't selling rock albums anymore. Some of the most anticipated albums of the year -- by the Smashing Pumpkins, Hole and Marilyn Manson -- are quickly sliding down the charts after disappointing first-week sales.
"When you look at Seattle, those bands had the momentum to keep rock going, but Kurt Cobain killed himself and Pearl Jam got into political stuff and Soundgarden broke up," said John McClane, a music executive who brought the rap label Death Row to Interscope Records and has made label deals at A&M Records with Ice Cube and the rapper Kurupt. Noting that hip-hop also sustained serious losses, he said the genre still had the wherewithal to recover and move into popular music.
"Rap is an accessible art form," Mr. McClane continued. "In my day, you listened to Aretha Franklin and Jimi Hendrix and you knew you couldn't emulate what they were doing. Now this generation is in awe of things they can do. Kids can emulate rap. And from a marketing point of view, Madison Avenue is using African-Americans to market their products. White kids are getting their beat on what hipness is from black kids again." For the last two years, black popular music has fueled the industry and rap has reigned supreme economically as well as culturally. Nearly three-quarters of rap albums are sold to white fans, according to Soundscan. Before piano, violin or guitar lessons, children are being schooled in hip-hop production: Toy stores have sections full of $10 plastic gadgets that they can use to sample their voices, trigger sound effects or sing along to crude hip-hop beats; in arcades, along with fighting and shooting games, there is a turntable where children can play at being a rap disk jockey.
On the musical front, rap's influence on suburban youth and mainstream music is nothing new. White popular music has been pillaging from black culture since the 1800's, when songwriters streamlined slave songs into popular tunes. Long before Run-D.M.C. and the Beastie Boys brought rap to the suburbs, punk rock musicians gravitated to its countercultural stance.
It is a tradition continued today in events like the Family Values tour organized by the thrash-rock group Korn, which consists of Ice Cube and several white bands, mostly working-class, small-town former heavy metalheads now dabbling in scratching, break dancing, rapping and hip-hop fashion. What seemed to be part of a passing trend, fitting chronologically between heavy metal and alternative rock as a conduit for youthful suburban rebellion, has not faded.
Rap, meanwhile, has increased its hold on popular music. This is partly because its influence has pervaded nearly every musical genre and partly because ever since Vanilla Ice and M. C. Hammer, there has been consumer quality control insuring that the rappers who rise to the top of the charts are also among the best and, in some cases, the most interesting characters in pop music at the moment.
Mark Shimmel, the chief operating officer of LaFace Records in Atlanta, which released the OutKkast album, also credits rap's ascendency to its ability to market through word of mouth.
None of this is by accident. Most of the recent successful black artists -- Puff Daddy, Master P, Jermaine Dupri, Jay-Z and Babyface -- are also entrepreneurs. Most own their labels, plan their marketing and, even in the case of hardcore records, strategize their career for mainstream success. To expand their audiences, Busta Rhymes is recording a version of Black Sabbath's metal classic, "Iron Man," with Ozzy Osbourne, and Puff Daddy has been working with everyone from Jimmy Page to the Foo Fighters. In the face of Top 40 radio's reluctance to play rap songs, Mack 10 recorded a lightweight ballad with Gerald Levert.
"That song was added by stations that have never played any of our records in 13 years," said Bryan Turner, the president of Priority Records, which releases music by Mack 10, Ice Cube and Master P. "It's scientific, almost. Something that comes right from the street has turned into an analyzed strategy on what records you can make that will give you a better chance to get more radio play to give you more sales."
The problem with rock, he said, is that musicians have no control over their work after they turn it in to the record company. "Why aren't there more rockers who own their own music?" he asked. "These rappers are in control of their own destinies."
Though this may seem like a good time to beat the rock-is-dead drum, popular taste is more complex than that. Billboard's chart of the most-played songs on radio is dominated by rock, with no rap songs in the Top 10. The stations that are thriving, which target an older audience than rap does, are actually Top 40 ones, reflecting the singles chart, which is dominated by pop rhythm-and-blues and rock, rather than rap.
Dave Hoeffel, vice president of the Friday Morning Quarterback, a radio trade publication, said radio programmers played less rap for several reasons: most advertisers don't target its audience, the albums don't last long on the charts, and stations tend to avoid genres like metal and rap, which exist "in their own parallel universe."
"The trend is to play the hits," he continued. "Looking at radio ratings, it's tough to ignore that Z-100" -- WHTZ-FM in Manhattan -- "went back to its roots in Top 40 and went through the roof. It's a situation of play the hits, no matter what they are."
The radio audience is passive: listeners are not buying albums by bands heard on the radio to the degree that rap fans will buy albums with good street buzz, which is one reason the phenomenon of one-hit wonders has returned. With a climate like this, some say, rap's dominance on the album charts shows no sign of abating.
"What we're waiting for is the new generation that says, 'Forget all that, I'm making music that I want to make and who cares about radio,' " Mr. Turner said. "That's the next stage in the cycle."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Ford Says Earnings Rose According to Expectations

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., Oct. 14

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company announced today that its earnings from continuing operations rose roughly in line with expectations during the third quarter, as cost reductions and record sales of high-profit sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks in the United States offset losses overseas.
The General Motors and Chrysler Corporations released their earnings earlier this week, and the overall results show an American auto industry that still has a strong market at home but that is starting to lose money abroad. All of the Big Three have enormous cash reserves to tide them over during the next recession, with Ford announcing today the biggest bankroll of all, a record $22.91 billion as of Sept. 30. 
 Ford earned $1.00 billion, or 80 cents a share, in the last quarter, a penny above the average prediction of auto analysts, according to First Call. Ford stock dropped after the release of the earnings this morning, but then rallied with the rest of the market, closing at $45.8125, up $1.75.
Last spring Ford spun off its 80 percent stake in Associates First Capital, which had been one of the company's most profitable divisions. During the third quarter of last year, when Associates was still part of the company, Ford earned $1.13 billion, or 91 cents a share.
Ford's overall earnings fell 11 percent from that level during the last three months, but excluding Associates' 1997 results, they rose 10.4 percent for continuing operations.
Today's results marked the 10th consecutive quarter in which Ford has shown an increase from continuing operations -- a rarity in the auto industry, which has traditionally had huge profit swings. John Devine, Ford's chief financial officer, said that the company was "comfortable with" analysts' fourth-quarter estimates of $1.22 a share.
But Mr. Devine also warned that Ford was likely to take three one-time charges in the fourth quarter. Ford expects to write off part or all of its $150 million investment in Kia, the insolvent South Korean auto maker that is now being sold by its creditors in an auction that is likely to wipe out the stakes of Kia's previous owners. Ford is also likely to take a pretax loss of roughly $100 million for putting a transmission factory into a joint venture, as well as a still undetermined loss for a recently announced program to reduce white-collar employment through buyouts and early retirement, Mr. Devine said.
Most of Ford's profits in the third quarter came from its North American automotive operations, which earned $900 million, a 45 percent improvement from a year earlier. Mr. Devine said Ford benefited only slightly from the strike that crippled General Motors for nearly eight weeks this summer.
He said that Ford sold a rich mix of profitable sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks in the third quarter, having stopped production of a half-dozen slow-selling car models.
But Ford lost $273 million in Europe from July through September, nearly double its loss a year earlier. The company incurred high costs to introduce its new Focus small car, which replaces the Ford Escort. Ford also lost $44 million in South America, where it earned $133 million a year earlier.
James M. Irwin, an auto analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said that Ford's difficulties overseas were likely to lessen soon but not disappear. "South America is going to stay weak for some time, while Europe is going to bounce back very nicely with the Focus," he said.
Visteon Automotive Systems, Ford's auto parts subsidiary, had a 31.6 percent earnings increase, with profits climbing to $150 million. Ford Credit, which makes car loans and leases, had a 5 percent increase in profits, to $272 million.
Ford also owns 81 percent of the Hertz Corporation, the nation's largest car rental agency, and Ford's share of Hertz's third-quarter profits was $98 million, up 28 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
B ear Stearns Net Falls 60% Amid the Market's Downturn

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

 BODY:
The Bear Stearns Companies became the latest United States brokerage firm to post sharply lower earnings as the sudden reversal in stock and bond markets worldwide cut into the firm's trading and investment banking profits.
Net income for the three months ended on Sept. 30, the first quarter of the firm's 1999 fiscal year, fell 60 percent, to $64.1 million, or 40 cents a diluted share, compared with $161.6 million in the quarter a year earlier. The earnings were slightly below analysts' estimates of 43 cents a share. 
 The earnings report was the latest in what is expected to be a string of bad reports from Wall Street banks and brokerage firms. Analysts have described the turnabout in fortunes of big investment banks as one of the sharpest in history as the long bull market in stocks and bonds screeched to a halt.
Though down significantly, the results for Bear Stearns did not tumble as much as some other Wall Street firms that have reported profits this week. Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette said its third-quarter profit fell 79 percent amid $234 million in trading losses. Merrill Lynch & Company, which has a much larger operation than either Donaldson, Lufkin or Bear Stearns, said profit from operations fell 75 percent. Merrill also plans to eliminate 3,400 jobs.
Bear Stearns is the sixth-largest Wall Street firm in terms of capital, but it has a much smaller international business than many of its rivals and does not do as much proprietary trading. It focuses instead on clearing, or processing securities trades. It has the largest such business in the United States.
Officials at the firm said their continued focus on their core client trading and clearing services as well as investment banking meant that they did not suffer the same kinds of losses other firms had, including trading losses in Russia and other emerging markets.
"There are not that many places in our business where you can make money these days," said William J. Montgoris, the firm's chief operating officer. But he said that even during the market plunge in August and September, one of Bear Stearns's main businesses -- arranging trades for clients and collecting the cash for securities sold -- showed better results in the latest quarter than in the last one. That is because clients trade even in down markets, though they are often doing more selling than buying. "Despite the downturn, we had positive revenues in every month," Mr. Montgoris said.
Still, nearly all other areas of the business were weak. Trading revenue fell 50 percent, to $391.5 million. The turmoil in the markets also hurt activity in mergers and acquisition advising and underwriting, sending investment banking revenue down 44 percent, to $121.8 million.
Bear Stearns said it did not expect to lay off any of its 9,400 staff members, though it did not rule out downsizing through attrition if weak markets continued. Mr. Montgoris used as an example the firm's response to the market selloff in 1987, when it shed about 10 percent of its work force over six months by deciding not to fill positions after they were vacated voluntarily.
Guy Moszkowski, a brokerage analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, said Bear Stearns was likely to weather the downturn better than some of its rivals. "Bear does not feel that it's cost structure is out of whack and does not have to do a large staff reduction," he said. "And they did pretty well for this environment.
"They manage their risk positions carefully," he added. "Their clearing business is very profitable even when the fixed-income market is doing poorly. We could see them in position to rebound significantly when the markets come back."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Weaker-Than-Expected Retail Sales Push Bond Prices Higher

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices rose for a second day as a report showing weaker-than-expected retail sales suggested the economy was losing steam, reinforcing expectations for another Federal Reserve interest rate cut.
"The economy is going to slow, and the bond market is going to pay attention to that," said Paul Van Kampen, who oversees $1.3 billion of bonds at NCM Capital Management Group, in Durham, N.C. He favors intermediate-term Treasuries, which he said would rally when the Fed lowers rates again. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 30/32, to 107 10/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.03 percent, from 5.09 percent.
Retail sales rose three-tenths of a percent in September, less than the half a percent increase forecast by analysts. Excluding autos, sales rose one-tenth of a percent.
The bond gains follow a four-day plunge last week that increased 30-year bond yields 43-hundredths of a percentage point. That slide was touched off by a 14 percent decline in the dollar against the yen, and selling by hedge funds -- private investment pools for institutions and wealthy individuals -- which unloaded Treasuries to cover losses in other markets, traders said.
"People feel a little more comfortable" that the bulk of the selling by hedge funds is finished, said Dan Busiel, an analyst at Nationsbank CRT Services in Chicago. Even so, he said that "it's a little premature to think that this is over."
Yesterday, for example, BankAmerica said it planned to sell the $20 billion bond portfolio of D. E. Shaw & Company, a hedge fund that it had invested in and lent more than $1 billion. The portfolio includes $10 billion of Treasury securities.
Still, the reasons behind the rally that drove 30-year yields to 31-year lows of 4.72 percent Oct. 5 are intact, investors said. The United States economy is slowing, inflation is tame, and the Fed is likely to cut rates again soon.
In addition, turbulence in other financial markets will probably continue, forcing investors to seek the relative safety of Treasuries. "There is no strong reason to doubt that bonds remain the quality asset class," Michael Derks, the chief bond strategist at Nomura International P.L.C., said.

HEADLINE: U.N. Votes, 157-2, in Referendum to End U.S. Embargo of Cuba

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 14

 BODY:
In a General Assembly vote a record 157 countries today favored an end to the United States economic embargo of Cuba.
Only the United States and Israel objected. Twelve countries abstained. 
 Although the resolution is not binding, it reflected what experts described as "astonishing unanimity" by many of America's allies and friends against the use of sanctions as an instrument of foreign policy.
The vote also illustrates the erosion of support for the United States policy toward Cuba, the experts said.
"As a general principle when a country finds itself totally isolated and has virtually no allies, it should be an occasion for reflection on its policy line," said Jeffrey Laurenti, executive director of Policy Studies at the United Nations Association of the United States, a grass-roots organization in Washington.
Mr. Laurenti echoed the views of other experts when he said support for sanctions diminished dramatically after Congress passed the Helms-Burton Act in 1996, extending sanctions to countries and foreign companies that do business with Cuba, Iran and other nations with which the United States has disputes.
"The United States has a perfect right to prohibit trade by its own nationals or companies with a country it deems a threat to its own security," Mr. Laurenti said in a telephone interview today. "But the extraterritorial nature of such laws has turned a great deal of friends like Canada and the European Union against us."
Last year 143 nations supported the resolution, and the United States, Israel and Uzbekistan opposed it. This year a diplomat from a country friendly to the United States said, "The Cubans did not even have to lead the fight."
The number of those opposing the American position has steadily increased in annual votes for seven years.
The resolution cited the Helms-Burton Act, which many here saw as an attempt to impose American laws on other countries.
But the United States representative, Ambassador A. Peter Burleigh, said that "the Cuban Government's systematic denial of universally recognized human rights and fundamental freedoms to the people of Cuba" was reason enough to maintain the embargo.
"The United States," Mr. Burleigh added, "believes that economic sanctions are an important foreign policy tool to be used in certain compelling cases."
The Helms-Burton law has stretched the limits of the 35-year-old embargo by allowing United States citizens who were Cuban citizens before Fidel Castro took power in 1959 to sue foreign companies or individuals. The defendants have to be conducting business from property that Cuba confiscated.
The law also denies visas to the United States to shareholders in the companies and their executives, and it caused a severe disagreement with Canada and the 15 nations of the European Union.
"Congress has been sanction happy for some time, and the U.S. has kept these sanctions on Cuba for domestic reasons," an expert with the Council on Foreign Relations, Judith Kipper, said. "Obviously in some cases sanctions don't serve American interests. At this stage they are not helpful in places like Cuba and Iran. We can accomplish a great deal more of what we want in Cuba by opening tourism and trade."
The General Assembly resolution was introduced by Foreign Minister Roberto Robaina of Cuba.

HEADLINE: Residents' Views on City Life Improve, and Giuliani Gets Credit

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH with MARJORIE CONNELLY 

 BODY:
For the first time since Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani won election in 1993, more than half of New York City residents say that life in the city has improved, a New York Times/CBS News Poll has found.
Nearly two-thirds of city residents who were polled earlier this month said they approved of the way that Mr. Giuliani, a Republican who easily won a second term last fall, was handling his job. And 59 percent said that life in New York City had improved in the last four years, up sharply from 39 percent in a poll last fall that asked the same question. 
 But while most respondents said that Mr. Giuliani had succeeded in reducing crime, few could cite other areas he had handled well.
Perhaps most striking, at a time when Mr. Giuliani is striving to raise his national profile, is that only 19 percent of those polled said he should run for President in 2000. Even fewer -- 12 percent -- said he should run for Vice President. The overwhelming majority of New Yorkers, 61 percent, said Mr. Giuliani should not run for the White House.
Gov. George E. Pataki, a fellow Republican who has also expressed interest in higher office, fared even worse on those questions -- 10 percent supporting a run for President, 10 percent behind a run for Vice President but 69 percent saying that he should not run for either office.
Asked to choose between the two men as a Presidential or Vice Presidential candidate, 40 percent of New York City residents said they would select Mr. Giuliani, compared with 39 percent for Mr. Pataki. (The Governor was an easy favorite among statewide respondents, with 47 percent backing him, compared with 33 percent for the Mayor.)
As in past polls, more white respondents had positive opinions of Mr. Giuliani and his job performance than did black respondents. Only 36 percent of black respondents said they approved of how the Mayor was handling his job, compared with 70 percent of whites.
When asked to choose between "tough" and "too abrasive" as a description for the Mayor, most of the black respondents, 61 percent, said Mr. Giuliani was too abrasive. Most whites held the other view, with 54 percent describing him as a tough leader.
The telephone poll of 478 residents of New York City was conducted between Oct. 1 and Oct. 6 as part of a larger, statewide survey. The margin of sampling error was plus or minus 4 percentage points.
Of the black respondents who said they were registered voters, 19 percent held a positive view of Mr. Giuliani, while 68 percent had an unfavorable opinion. By comparison, two-thirds of white voters -- 66 percent -- said they had a favorable opinion of the Mayor, while 18 percent held an unfavorable view.
The poll found that the percentage of city residents who approved of Mr. Giuliani was the same as last fall, when a Times poll that was conducted about three weeks before he was re-elected found that 63 percent liked the way he was handling his job.
In a year when Mr. Giuliani has cracked down on jaywalkers, taxi drivers and sex shop owners, almost half of those polled said that he had concentrated on quality-of-life issues "to avoid dealing with more serious problems." Fifty-eight percent of black respondents said Mr. Giuliani had focused too much on quality-of-life issues, compared with 38 percent of white respondents.
The new poll suggests that New Yorkers especially approve of Mr. Giuliani's handling of crime. Forty-six percent of the respondents offered that reducing crime was the best thing he had done since becoming Mayor, compared with 34 percent last fall. Increasing the size of the police force was the next most frequent response, mentioned by 6 percent.
Asked to credit Mr. Giuliani with something other than reducing crime, almost half were unable to come up with a response. Of those who did, 6 percent said he had cleaned up the streets, 3 percent said he had improved the quality of life, and 3 percent said he had improved the economy.
Asked to name "the worst thing" about Mr. Giuliani, 40 percent said they did not know. Twelve percent said he was "too outspoken," and 5 percent said he had "increased racial tension." One percent answered, "everything."
The poll showed that nearly two-thirds of New Yorkers felt that the police "favor one race over the other." The survey was taken about a month after officers clashed with some of the participants in a black youth rally in Harlem (an incident that 2 percent named as the worst thing that Mr. Giuliani had done since becoming Mayor). But the results were similar to those in the poll taken last October.
In street interviews yesterday, several city residents offered opinions that mirrored the poll's findings. They said that Mr. Giuliani was doing a good job and that crime reduction was his most notable accomplishment. But they also said that he was too abrasive and that he should not seek higher office.
"I think he should be satisfied with what he has accomplished as Mayor," said Thomas Scotto, 70, a retired civil engineer from Staten Island. "If he ran for President, he'd never make it west of Chicago. He'd be a dead duck."
Laura Torres, a respiratory therapist from Brooklyn, praised Mr. Giuliani's handling of crime but said he should be less belligerent.
"The Mayor's done a good job with police and crime, but he needs to be less of a bully," Ms. Torres, 46, said. "It's either his way or no way. He should learn how to negotiate better."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Mexican Business Giant Begins Transition to Sons

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Carlos Slim Helu, the billionaire Mexican businessman, has handed two of his sons the leadership of Grupo Carso S.A. de C.V., the company where he began the climb that made him the richest man in Latin America.
According to an announcement late Monday, Carlos Slim Domit, 31, the oldest son, will be Grupo Carso's chairman, and his brother Patrick, 29, will occupy a new position equivalent to chief operating officer. The company produces everything from chocolates to fiber optic cable and owns the Mexican chain of 40 Sears stores. 
 Analysts said the elder Mr. Slim, 58, who had cardiac surgery a year ago, was putting the new generation in place in case he should suffer further ailments and also to prepare for the economic storm hanging over many of the emerging markets.
Mr. Slim Domit, however, denied that, saying, "His health had nothing to do with it," and adding: "He is perfectly fine. He did it now because he feels the company is well structured, it runs efficiently and no major unfinished business is hanging over it. He wants to dedicate more of his time to telecommunications."
The senior Mr. Slim will remain as chairman of Carso Global Telecom S.A. and of the nation's phone giant, Telefonos de Mexico, or Telmex, as well of as his financial company Grupo Financiero Inbursa S.A. Mr. Slim named one of his oldest associates, Jaime Chico Pardo, 48, to become the second in command at Carso Global Telecom.
He built his reputation and his fortune -- the family's net worth is estimated by Forbes magazine at $7.2 billion -- through smart purchases of ailing companies, which he turned around with shrewd management. Now he seems to want to explore new areas like the Internet and digital communications.
Unlike most successful Mexican companies these days, which are oriented toward exports, about 80 percent of Grupo Carso's production is for domestic markets. Mr. Slim Domit said the company was not planning major changes.
Analysts said they also expected little change at Telmex, the bellwether Mexican stock, whose American depository receipts are traded in New York, as are several other companies in which the family has held stakes. "Telmex is probably one of the best-positioned companies in Mexico to weather the new crisis," said Simon Flannery of J. P. Morgan Securities. "It has low levels of debt and generates significant amounts of cash."
Under the stern eye of Mr. Slim, his sons have received more than a decade of training to run his companies. The older son has been running the Mexican Sears chain, which his father bought two years ago. Floor-to-ceiling remodeling of several decrepit stores and radical changes to make the company more efficient have begun to attract customers. The younger son has run Nacobre S.A., a mining company.
The generational shift follows a recent pattern in Mexican business. Last year, Emilio Azcarraga Jean, now 30, took control of the vast Grupo Televisa media empire after the death of his father, Emilio Azcarraga Milmo, and Ricardo Salinas Pliego, son of a family of department store owners, who is now 41, is running TV Azteca, the rival television network.

HEADLINE: Budget Deal in Congress to Give Clinton the Full $18 Billion Sought for the I.M.F.

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
The budget deal being worked out tonight on Capitol Hill provides the full $18 billion requested by the Clinton Administration for the International Monetary Fund, apparently ending a months-long struggle by the Administration to persuade Congress that the money is vital to the fund's efforts to stem a global financial crisis.
Administration officials and Republican Congressional leaders said the deal would require the fund to open many of its deliberations to public scrutiny and to impose new conditions on its loans to foreign governments. 
 The compromise, they said, is expected largely to end the fund's practice of lending money to troubled nations at below-market interest rates. It would also require that most loans be repaid to the I.M.F. within two and a half years; the average payback period now is closer to 10 years.
Republican lawmakers and senior officials at the Treasury Department, which managed the negotiations for the Administration, said they would not discuss other details of the legislative package until the budget deal is formally approved by both houses of Congress. The vote in the House and Senate could come as early as Thursday.
But officials on both sides of the negotiations said that the agreement on I.M.F. financing would not put onerous restrictions on the 182-nation organization as it tries to deal with the financial crisis that has devastated the economies of Russia, South Korea and Southeast Asia and that now threatens the economic stability of the rest of the world.
"We would never have agreed to this if it significantly hindered the ability of the fund to operate," said an Administration official involved in the negotiations.
The $18 billion had been requested by the I.M.F. to replenish reserve accounts depleted by the fund's attempts over the least year to bail out the economies of Russia, South Korea, Thailand and Indonesia.
The fund's leadership had waited anxiously for Congress to approve the money, since other large donor nations had said they would withhold billions of dollars in additional contributions until the United States acted. At the fund's annual meeting here this month, several speakers pointedly questioned Washington's commitment to solving the international crisis so long as Congress refused to approve the I.M.F. payment.
Last month the Senate approved the full $18 billion requested by the Administration. But the money had been blocked by Republican leaders in the House, notably Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Speaker, who said they would not approve additional money for the I.M.F. unless it agreed to the lending restrictions and an end to the secrecy that had long shrouded the fund's loan deliberations.
Republican Congressional leaders -- and more than a few Democrats -- have accused the fund of bungling the economic crisis, possibly even worsening the plight of several developing nations that now teeter on the edge of economic collapse.
The Republicans had sought an end to liberal lending policies by the I.M.F., which, they said, had encouraged some nations to pursue reckless economic policies in the knowledge that low-interest, long-term bailout loans were readily available.
The debate over I.M.F. financing led to an angry rhetorical clash between President Clinton and senior Republicans, with the President last week comparing the I.M.F. to a team of firefighters who were being deprived of water to battle a growing blaze. The House Republican majority leader, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, responded this week by comparing the I.M.F.'s managers to "arsonists" who were being denied the gasoline that would permit them to do more damage.
I.M.F. officials said that they had not been formally notified of the exact language in the legislation, but they said they expected that the Treasury Department would not allow the compromise bill to limit the fund's powers to disburse money to nations in crisis, given the severity of the global worries.
Administration official have said in recent days that the fund's management and several of the most prominent donor countries might even welcome some of the reforms imposed under the compromise bill.
Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers said earlier this week that he did not expect complaints from the leaders of the Group of Seven, or G-7, which together are responsible for nearly half of the financing of the I.M.F. "These are priorities we've worked on with the G-7, and I think we're likely to end with an agreement that everyone can feel good about," he said on CNBC, the cable network.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Operating Income Plunges at BankAmerica

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
The BankAmerica Corporation surprised analysts and investors yesterday by reporting that operating earnings fell 50 percent in the third quarter to $893 million, or 50 cents a share -- well below the 90 cents a share expected by analysts.
The declines reflected charges related to Nationsbank's recently completed merger with BankAmerica, and a larger-than-expected $372 million charge related to an investment in D. E. Shaw & Company, a New York-based hedge fund. 
 In addition to taking the charge, BankAmerica said it would reduce its risk from the fund by purchasing Shaw's entire fixed-income portfolio, which contains about $20 billion of securities -- primarily United States Treasury bonds -- and "related hedge positions." It also includes about $4 billion to $5 billion of Japanese bonds, as well as mortgage-backed and municipal securities.
"We had no idea that this bombshell was coming," said Michael Mayo, an analyst with Credit Suisse First Boston. "The old BankAmerica prereleased earnings indications twice for the third quarter and still didn't include the bad news that came today about hedge funds and mortgage-servicing fees."
Although other financial services companies have also reported losses related to hedge fund exposure, analysts said BankAmerica's problems were unlikely to herald similar bad news from other banks as they report third-quarter earnings.
Investors reacted to the news by pushing the stock of BankAmerica, now the nation's largest domestic bank, down as much as 13 percent. It picked up slightly to close yesterday at $48.0625, down $5.875 a share, an 11 percent decline.
Several Wall Street analysts lowered investment recommendations on the bank yesterday, while others criticized managment for giving little advance indication of the scope of the D. E. Shaw charge, which some considered an unsually large exposure to an outside hedge fund.
The bank also reported a $519 million after-tax charge to cover costs associated with the merger of the San Francisco-based BankAmerica Corporation and the Charlotte, N.C.-based Nationsbank, which was completed on Sept. 30. The new BankAmerica has its headquarters in Charlotte.
After the $372 million Shaw-related charge, BankAmerica said it had $1 billion of exposure to the company, which it said it did not consider to be a hedge fund. Over time the bank will sell the $20 billion of fixed-income securities it is acquiring, and expects that its greatest loss on the portfolio will be about $175 million, a spokesman, Robert Stickler, said.
"This was a fund that traded in spreads," Mr. Stickler said. When Treasury bond yields fell sharply, "it was very damaging to firms that traded on those spreads. These problems developed very late and very rapidly at the end of the quarter. We don't feel we misled analysts."
The company has an additional $400 million in hedge fund exposure, which is substantially collateralized, it said.
But Thomas H. Hanley, a managing director and banking direcor at Warburg Dillon Read, maintained, "These problems were unexpected, poorly communicated and could indicate much deeper issues within the company."
Mr. Hanley, who lowered his investment recommendation on the bank's stock from strong buy to reduce, added, "In our assessment, BankAmerica was very close to this company, so it should have understood its businesses much better."
The old BankAmerica established a strategic alliance with D. E. Shaw in January 1997, to use Shaw strategies for proprietary trading and to provide equity derivatives for sale to customers, Mr. Stickler said.
In reportings its earnings, BankAmerica also said that fee income, in such areas as trading and investment banking, was hurt by the deterioration of overseas economies and the volatility of domestic financial markets. The bank added $500 million to reserves already established for losses related to global and domestic market volatility. But the company's core consumer and commercial banking activities, which are centered in the United States, continued to perform well, it said.
BankAmerica said income in the third quarter was $374 million, or 21 cents a diluted share, down 78.4 percent from $1.73 billion, or 96 cents a diluted share, a year earlier.
Last month, BankAmerica, which recently disclosed large trading losses in Russia, said that it had pretax trading losses around $330 million so far in the third quarter and that it expected its net-interest income in the quarter to be reduced by $65 million, primarily because of "one borrower."
Sally Pope Davis, a senior analyst at Goldman, Sachs, praised BankAmerica for reporting its hedge fund losses. "I think the company tried to take the most conservative view that it could," she said. "Adding $500 million to uncollateralized reserves was a conservative thing to do. Almost all of the surprises this quarter came from" the old BankAmerica, she added. "But this is Nationsbank taking a pretty pro-active role to fix as many things as it can, and clear the deck for future quarters.
Despite the third-quarter problems, BankAmerica's chief financial officer, James Hance, told analysts yesterday that the company had a goal of providing returns of 18 percent to 21 percent on shareholders' equity each year.
Among other banks reporting earnings yesterday, the First Union Corporation said third-quarter operating income rose 35 percent to $1.01 billion, or $1.02 a diluted share, from $748 million, or 78 cents, last year. The earnings were higher than analysts' forecast of 96 cents a share.
After merger and restructuring charges, the bank said it earned $995 million, or $1.01 a share.
"I think it demonstrates the superior risk management skills and diversification of the company," said Sandra J. Flannigan of Merrill Lynch. "They don't have any real hedge fund exposure, and there's minimal exposure to emerging markets."
First Union's stock rose 18.75 cents, to $50.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: COMPANY REPORTS;
Profits at New York Times Co. Rose 18.9% in Third Quarter

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
The New York Times Company reported yesterday that its net income rose 18.9 percent in the third quarter, as cost-control measures helped compensate for a slight weakness in advertising revenue.
For the three-month period that ended Sept. 27, the company earned slightly less than $55 million, or 29 cents a diluted share, compared with $46.3 million, or 24 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier. Revenue totaled $682.7 million, down from $683.6 million. 
 Weakness in advertising revenue has hit newspaper markets around the country, particularly those in high-technology centers like Boston, the home market of The Boston Globe, which is part of The New York Times newspaper group. The world economic turmoil was felt early in high-technology centers, so fewer companies turned to newspapers to advertise their available jobs.
Still, advertising revenue at The New York Times, the company's flagship newspaper, rose 4.62 percent, to $235 million.
The New York newspaper paid 7.9 percent more for newsprint in the quarter, the result of a rise of about 4.5 percent in the average per-ton price as well as increased consumption. That greater consumption of newsprint is a consequence of expanded coverage like the new weekly Circuits section, which specializes in technology news, as well as increased advertising volume in the newspaper as a whole.
But several Wall Street analysts said that newsprint prices are expected to steady or drop. The analysts said that slack demand for newsprint in Asia is creating surplus supplies.
Aside from The Times and The Globe, the company publishes 21 regional newspapers and three magazines, and operates eight network-affiliated television stations and two New York City radio stations.
Shares in the New York Times Company fell 56.25 cents yesterday, to $22.25, and are now down 45 percent from the high of $40.6875 reached July 6.
Douglas Arthur, an analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, said he believed the stock's weakness partly reflected Wall Street's fears about its own financial health. As major brokerage houses lay off hundreds of employees, he said, the expectation is building that advertising -- particularly high-margin classified advertising -- will decline.
The company also said yesterday that John M. O'Brien, its acting chief financial officer since April, had been named the new chief financial officer.
That announcement came at the end of a six-month search for candidates to replace Diane P. Baker, who left the job earlier this year to care for her new son.
Mr. O'Brien, who is 56, began work at The New York Times newspaper in 1960 as a messenger. He has previously served as the chief financial officer of The New York Times newspaper. In a series of other executive posts during the last decade, he has supervised the newspaper's finances, production and electronic publishing efforts.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Globaloney Crisis

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Every economic seer, sage and pundit has an incentive to predict what Jimmy Durante used to call a "catastrostroke."
If disaster comes, you can boast of your prescience to those still around. If, however, the sky does not fall, you need not confess to false alarmism; you say smoothly that tragedy was averted because the world took your warning to heart. 
 That's what we see in panicked assessments of "global economic crisis," or "meltdown in Asia spreading to Brazil," or "financial collapse and hyperinflation in Russia," or last week's Newsweek cover, "The Crash of '99?"
Harvard's Prof. John Kenneth Galbraith declares Japan to have been in a depression for years. Times may be tough in Tokyo, but I always thought that when economists used the word "depression" they meant 25 percent unemployment, bread lines, Okies fleeing the Dust Bowl, etc., none of which has been happening in the world's second-largest economy. Instead, slug it "sluggish."
Global crisis-itis is the palpitation du jour. Because default, dear Brutus, is in our stars, Velikovskian catastrophists will next predict solar-systemic breakdown.
(Time out for the to-be-sure graph.) To be sure, a 30 percent drop in small stocks in the U.S. and a hangdog Hang Seng abroad augur ill for consumer spending. The spectacle of bankers stuffing money blindly into loopy-leveraged hedgehogs calls for fuller disclosure and higher margin requirements. And feared loss of American export sales induces Alan Greenspan to recite John Donne's "No man is an Island. . . ."
But global crisis-itis is no excuse for puffing up the International Monetary Fund into some New World Financial Order -- the newest dream of regulatory globocrats. Nor is today's bailout fever any reason to stop the free flow of capital. If investors cannot take their money out of a country, they won't put it in.
Welcome to Contrarian Corner. Last October, here is where the New- Age, new-paradigm new-economists, gaily waltzing with Goldilocks and Rosie Scenario, were admonished that markets went other ways besides up. This October, the contrarian message is: That pail of cold water in the face can be good for you.
Take the Russian economy. Pojaluista! The I.M.F. is Primakoving the pump with billions that will slip out the back door. But Russians keep dollars in mattresses, not rubles in banks. Disintermediators in babushkas barter goods cash-free. Someday they'll elect a leader who understands capitalism under contract law. Prices of Russia's huge national resources will rise, and private investment will pour in.
Now take the American economy. We're the locomotive that pulls along the world, the great consuming blotter that sops up the products of needy nations. With our full employment and price stability, the misery index has become the ecstasy index. That's why Congress and the President get high poll ratings. The same forecasters who a couple of years ago envisioned deficits "as far as the eye can see" now smell surpluses as far as the nose can sniff.
They're wrong again. One of these years we'll go into recession, and farewell surplus. Although we've successfully amended Joseph's interpretation of Pharaoh's dream -- eight fat years are now followed by two lean years -- we have not repealed the business cycle.
How, then, do we counter the hand-wringing hoo-hah of the crisis-mongers? Because the world depends on America's engine for its locomotion (and because we all much prefer the fat years), we should act now to soften the inexorable slump.
But we're not. Though the Fed has shaved a smidgen off interest rates for stimulus, Clinton fiscal policy is pulling us in the opposite direction -- toward slowdown. Beware the fervor of the convert: Clinton's got such budget religion he doesn't know when to stop praying.
To cushion a downturn and save jobs, we should stimulate now with solid tax reduction. But Republicans, fearful of Clinton sloganeering that the surplus must be "saved," await Election Day to bring the votes to override a veto of tax cuts.
No global catastrostroke hysteria needed. If we want to help our neighbors and ourselves through a rough patch, we should stimulate the growth that lifts the world.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Indian Wins Nobel Award In Economics

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
Amartya Sen won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science yesterday for work on human rights, poverty and inequality that has changed the way governments deal with famines and for what the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences said had "restored an ethical dimension to the discussion of vital economics problems."
Professor Sen, 64, whose given name means "one who deserves immortality" in Bengali, is master of Trinity College in Cambridge, England, and professor emeritus at Harvard University. He was president of the American Economics Association in 1994, still teaches part time at Harvard and is finishing a book on democracy and capitalism that will be published by Knopf next year. 
 Just a decade ago, a member of the economics prize committee of the Swedish Academy confidently predicted that Professor "Sen will never get the prize." His unfashionable concerns with values and his equally unfashionable style (highly influential, but wide-ranging, diffuse, lacking a single killer theorem) seemed out of step with the value-free, specialized approach that the economics profession values so highly.
But times have changed, including inside the secretive Swedish Academy that administers the economics prize. The economics prize was created in 1969 and has grown increasingly controversial within the academy, which is dominated by hard scientists. In a seismic yet unannounced shift three years ago, the academy, reacting to internal criticism over the quality of past and prospective recipients, essentially broadened the economics prize into a social science prize encompassing contributions to political science, psychology and sociology. At the same time, in a sweeping rule change, the academy also purged the prize committee of the generation that had controlled the prize since its inception and demanded that noneconomists be included in the seven-member prize committee.
A scholar who has sometimes been criticized for spreading himself too thin, Professor Sen has always responded by decrying the narrowness of modern economics and by asserting that juggling many balls badly is better than displaying virtuosity with one ball. And his view is the one that seems to be shared by more and more scholars.
Professor Sen's contributions to welfare economics, the basic theory of how societies make choices that are both fair and efficient, have become part of every graduate student's training in economic theory. And his critiques of economic concepts that were once taken for granted are among the most quoted in economics, including his essay "Rational Fools" in which he takes on the classical presumption that people are motivated primarily by self-interest.
But Professor Sen is best known for his work on the causes of famine, on inequality and on the measurement of poverty, work that many believe has saved many lives.
His 1981 book "Poverty and Famine" (Oxford University Press) influenced the way international organizations and governments deal with food crises. He showed that famine was not just a consequence of nature, but also an avoidable economic and political catastrophe. Drought and flood often precede starvation, but declines in food production rarely account for it. Typically, even if many thousands die, there is enough food in the country to go around or enough money to import it.
Disaster strikes, Professor Sen found, when the poorest people can no longer afford to buy food because they lose their jobs or because food prices soar. In the Bengal famine, in which three million perished, India's food supplies were not unusually low. Colonial rulers, immune to democratic pressures, simply stood by.
Partly because of Professor Sen's finding, governments now focus less on direct distribution of food and more on replacing the lost income of the poor, through, for example, public works projects.
Professor Sen's theoretical work on inequality shows that all commonly accepted measures of inequality involve hidden, sometimes surprising value judgments. One of the most dramatic insights to grow out of his research was the devastating consequence of inequality between men and women. Demographers have long been aware that there were fewer women than men in some poor countries, instead of more as in most of the developed world. And economists, including Professor Sen, have documented that girls and women got less food and medical care than men and boys. But nobody had calculated how many more women would have been alive if the ratio of men and women more closely resembled that of other countries. Professor Sen came up with the startling figure of 100 million "missing" women, most of them in India and China, killed, as it were, by discrimination.
 The questions that Professor Sen has asked in the course of his career, listed by the academy in its press announcement and often posed in dense, mathematically demanding treatises, convey the flavor of his work. How can societies make majority decisions without infringing the rights of dissenting minorities? What measures of inequality are meaningful? How can we decide whether poverty is declining or increasing? What causes famines?
The questions go back a long way. As a child, during the Bengal famine of 1943, Professor Sen handed out cigarette tins of rice to starving refugees as they passed his grandfather's house. The grandfather, a scholar and author of a book on Hinduism, engaged the boy in hours of serious discussion on his beliefs about life. As a teen-ager, Professor Sen considered becoming a Buddhist but turned to economics, mathematics and philosophy instead.
Professor Sen was a student at Cambridge in the 1950's under the economist Joan Robinson. She urged him to forget all that "ethics rubbish," but he did the opposite.
"Amartya has thought more deeply than anyone about the nature of the judgments we make about economic welfare," said the Nobel Laureate Kenneth Arrow, a lifelong friend. "What do we mean when we say that some group is better off."
A frequent contributor to The New York Review of Books, Professor Sen has long communicated with an audience beyond his fellow economists and often about his native India -- he keeps his citizenship there despite many years in the United States and Britain.
"Amartya has a cosmopolitan international and broadly conceived vision of India" that defies both Asian and Western stereotypes, said Robert Silvers, co-editor of the Review.
Professor Sen was in New York to attend a memorial service for a friend yesterday and was frightened when he was awakened at his hotel by a 5:30 A.M. phone call (from Stockholm, not home, as it turned out). After being told the good news about the prize, he confessed, he was "very touched." He said that he was especially pleased that the Academy had highlighted the issues of welfare, inequality and poverty in its press release. "I'm very keen to emphasize the importance of these issues," he said.
For all his moral and intellectual concerns, Professor Sen is remarkably down to earth. His wife, Emma Rothschild, an Oxford economic historian who has just completed a book on 19th-century economic thought, talks about his "great big laugh," his fondness for good wine and conversation, and his devotion to his friends and family, including his four children. Professor Sen also happens to be one of the most popular people in the profession, regarded fondly by those from John Kenneth Galbraith to Gary Becker. "He's accessible, he supports the underdog, he sticks up for what he believes," said an old friend, Geoffrey Heal, at Columbia Business School.
A Harvard philosopher, Robert Nozick, who has taught seminars with Professor Sen on everything from social choice theory to the philosophy of evolutionary biology to the so-called mind-body problem, said, "His work transcends the limits of economics and expands its domain."
Phillip Griffiths, the mathematician who is director of the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, where Professor Sen was a member and then a trustee in the late 1980's and early 1990's, said, "To someone outside of the profession like me, Sen appears deeper than other professional economists."
The Economics Nobel Laureate Robert Solow once called Professor Sen the "conscience of our profession."
Last year the winners of the Nobel prize for economics were Robert C. Merton and Myron S. Scholes, financial theorists whose work helped power the explosive growth in financial markets since the 1970's. Last month's near-collapse of Long-Term Capital Management, the giant hedge fund in which they are partners, rocked financial markets around the world.
Mr. Merton and Mr. Scholes were honored for their work on how to measure the worth of an option.
Professor Sen will receive his prize, which includes a check for 7.6 million kronor (about $964,000) in Stockholm on Dec. 10.

HEADLINE: Volcker Sees Recovery in U.S. Coming SoonerThan Elsewhere

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The former Federal Reserve Chairman Paul A. Volcker said yesterday that he expected United States financial markets to recover more quickly than emerging markets, which will take longer to resolve their problems.
"In the United States, we'll do better," Mr. Volcker said when asked if he expected United States financial markets to overcome their current difficulties stemming from the global financial crisis. 
 He declined to give a time frame for the end of the financing crunch affecting the nation's capital markets, except for Treasury securities.
"For emerging markets, it's a different issue," he added. "The problems are much more serious."
Mr. Volcker made the comments at the annual meeting of the Conference Board, a global consulting and economic research firm.
The keynote address was delivered by the World Bank president, James D. Wolfensohn, Mr. Volcker's former investment firm partner, who warned about the social crisis facing emerging market economies now engulfed in a financial crisis.
"Beyond all these numbers, you need to look at the social consequences," Mr. Wolfensohn said, referring to the financial crisis's ultimate toll on living standards and the environment.
The World Bank president stressed the importance for Japan to restore the health of its banking system and economy, a crucial factor toward Asia's recovery.
The World Bank president also stressed that Russia's problems were as much economic as political, as shown by repeated shifts in economic strategy.
Mr. Wolfensohn also noted the instability in some emerging markets led to a global crisis of confidence that abruptly reversed the tide of investments to developing economies.
"There is a global squeeze going on at the moment," said Mr. Wolfensohn, who said that about $150 billion worth of foreign investments left emerging market economies this year, compared with inflows of $300 billion to those same economies before the crisis started last year.
Mr. Wolfensohn said the reversal of that trend could not be solely made up for by capital injections from international organizations and would result in a global economic slowdown.
