HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Economists raise questions about educational priorities.

BYLINE: By Michael M. Weinstein 

 BODY:
President Clinton has fought hard this week, in the final stage of budget negotiations, to protect his proposal to spend $1 billion as the first step in hiring 100,000 additional teachers to reduce class size in early grades. Mr. Clinton linked his proposal to the grand ambition of preparing the economy for the 21st century.
But critics of the plan point to research that casts doubt on the Administration's predictions of its likely impact. According to this line of argument, this is not the first time that the Administration has inflated the value of training and education initiatives. If the critics are right, the Administration's lobbying could channel money into the wrong places, starving quiet programs that might work better. 
 Prof. Alan Krueger of Princeton University, who served as chief economist at the Labor Department under Mr. Clinton, provides some of the research results that the Administration uses to bolster its case for smaller class size. He cites Tennessee, the only state to run a carefully controlled experiment, begun in 1986, to reduce class size in early grades. Mr. Krueger estimates that the program lifted scores on standardized tests by about 5 percentile points -- students who would score better than 50 percent of their peers if placed in classes of 22 would score better than 55 percent if placed in classes of 15.
But Mr. Krueger says the Tennessee results hardly settle the issue. He notes the higher test scores occurred by the end of the first year. Are smaller classes useless thereafter? Would class size of 18 -- the President's plan -- work as well?
Prof. Lisa Lynch of Tufts University, who also served as chief economist of the Labor Department, wonders whether the Tennessee program worked because it was small, and did not force Tennessee to dilute the quality of its teaching staff. Would a national program pose at least a temporary problem of finding qualified teachers? And would parents, Ms. Lynch asks, "prefer their children in classrooms of 25 or so students with a crackerjack teacher or in classrooms of 15 with a mediocre instructor?"
Here's an odd couple. Mr. Krueger argues that "the view that American schools perform poorly and that more public money will not help is contradicted by the data." Prof. Eric Hanushek of the University of Rochester publishes one study after another arguing that additional spending on schools wastes taxpayer money. Yet they jointly propose that Congress should resolve the many unanswered questions by running careful demonstration projects to figure out whether a national program to cut class size can work.
Some economists raise similar questions about other educational priorities of the Administration. It has already pushed tax credits for college tuition into law even though many economists predict they will do little good. Prof. James Heckman of the University of Chicago estimates that more than 90 percent of the cost of these credits will go to students who would have attended college anyway, missing the goal of lifting workers' skills.
In fact, colleges may try to capture some of the tax savings by cutting financial aid offers to families eligible for the new credit. Besides, Mr. Heckman argues, tuition is less of a barrier to college enrollment than Mr. Clinton seems prepared to admit. About half the nation's college students are enrolled in relatively inexpensive community colleges. Students in four-year public universities are already heavily subsidized, paying only about 20 percent of the cost of their education.
Some economic studies make a solid case for underwriting college enrollment by low-income students. The payoff for society can be huge. But, many economists say, the best way to achieve that goal is to expand Pell grants, which provide a low-cost way to increase enrollment because they, unlike a tax credit, go only to low-income families.
As for subsidies for the training of workers, many economists also agree with Mr. Heckman when he warns: "There is no such thing as cheap training; raising earnings of low-wage workers is extremely expensive." Indeed, he estimates that it would take almost $2 trillion to train high school dropouts and graduates to close the earnings gap that opened between them and college graduates over the last 20 years. His point is that politicians should tone down their promises.
But his larger point is that there are Government programs that do work. "Early intervention -- programs that focus on preschool children and students in early elementary school grades -- have been remarkably successful," he said. Programs in North Carolina, New York, Texas, Wisconsin, Michigan and several other states that provide full-time year-round classes, summer school, weekly home visits, mentoring and individual counseling have increased graduation rates by 20 percent or more and reduced criminal activity by a similar amount.
Early intervention can work, Mr. Heckman says, because it focuses on long-term factors that truly matter -- the influence of a child's family and environment on education expectations and ambitions -- rather than short-term factors, like tuition charges, which matter less than politicians suppose.
Education is an issue important to voters. But Mr. Clinton's critics say his proposals are, at best, useful ideas worthy of some space in the budget, but are hardly the pillar of an education agenda. At worst they may amount to a splashy waste that robs quiet, more useful initiatives of desperately needed money.

HEADLINE: Vallone Assails Debt Under Pataki and Offers Reduction Plan

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
Seeking to revitalize his gubernatorial campaign, Peter F. Vallone criticized Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday over "borrow and spend policies" and his failure to contain New York State's debt, and he proposed several measures, including a two-year moratorium on some new debts, to help remedy the problem.
"George Pataki proved that he is good at borrowing money," Mr. Vallone said in a speech before the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit budget monitor financed by business interests. "He proved that he is good at spending money. He is even good at raising money for his campaign. 
 "But while he is busy laughing all the way to the bank, the experts and credit rating agencies are shaking their heads in disbelief over what can only be described as economics of the absurd."
The state's debt was $27 billion when Mr. Pataki took office four years ago and is projected to reach $41 billion in the next five years.
Mr. Vallone said that if elected, he would impose a two-year moratorium on new debt to pay for voter-approved bond measures, and he would require the state's authorities -- quasi-governmental entities, like the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which are controlled by the Governor -- to finance 30 percent of their spending with cash on hand.
"New York State is facing a fiscal crisis much larger than the one New York City paid for in the 1970's," said Mr. Vallone, the Democratic Speaker of the New York City Council. "It took a Democrat in the White House to get our nation's fiscal house in order; it will take a Democrat in the State House to restore New York's."
Mr. Pataki's campaign spokesman, Michael Marr, dismissed Mr. Vallone's proposals yesterday. "Peter Vallone's performance today was, like the rest of his campaign, beyond embarrassing," he said, accusing the Speaker of being fiscally irresponsible, himself."
Asked to respond to the specifics of Mr. Vallone's proposals, Mr. Marr said, "It's rather difficult to give a substantive response to a proposal which is devoid of substance."
Mr. Vallone's speech was longer on criticism of Mr. Pataki than it was on specifics about his proposals, and economists said that while he had taken on an important subject, his ideas were not guaranteed to reduce the debt. It is also not clear how many of his proposals he would be able to put into effect without the approval of the Legislature.
In trying to stir up some excitement by proposing new fiscal policy before the budget group, Mr. Vallone was following a previously trodden path. Four years ago, then-candidate George Pataki used an address before the same group to lay out a somewhat more exciting campaign proposal: one of the largest personal-income tax cuts in state history.
Mr. Vallone criticized those tax cuts yesterday as disproportionately favoring wealthy New Yorkers, and said that the state should have used the record surpluses of the last two years to retire its debt.
Mr. Vallone has raised the issue of debt reform many times in the past, but his aides conceded that the latest occasion was an attempt to capitalize on the political advertisements of B. Thomas Golisano, the Independence Party candidate for governor, who is putting millions of his own money into the race. Most of Mr. Golisano's ads have accused Mr. Pataki, a Republican, of fiscal irresponsibility and have stressed the importance of debt reduction.
Much as Mr. Pataki did in his 1994 campaign, Mr. Vallone laid out how he would tame an unruly budget process. He said that if the Governor and Legislature could not agree on an estimate of how much revenue the state has to budget -- a contentious negotiation that typically delays the budgeting -- he would shift the responsibility for setting the revenue forecast to the State Comptroller, who is considered to be more neutral.
He also said that if there were no state budget by April 1, he would require the Legislature to stay in session around the clock until a balanced budget was approved.
The Governor can call the Legislature back into session, but it is not clear whether he has the legal authority to force the legislators to work around the clock.
Mr. Vallone's proposed two-year moratorium would cover all new general obligation debt.
"He's getting at an important issue," said Frank J. Mauro, the executive director of the Fiscal Policy Institute, a research group in Albany financed by foundations and labor unions. "If we had done this over the past two years, we would have been better prepared for a recession."
The amount of general obligation debt the state is carrying, however, is fairly small: out of the current budget of $4.42 billion, general-obligation expenses account for only $492 million, or 11.1 percent.
Many financial analysts say the real problem, constituting some 80 percent of the debt, is so-called back-door borrowing by the state through its public authorities. Those agencies owed $71 billion when the Governor took office, but $85 billion today.
To address that, Mr. Vallone said he would require each authority's capital plan to include a "pay as you go" minimum of 30 percent cash.
Financial analysts praised the sentiment of his proposal, but said it was unclear how it would work.

HEADLINE: CONGRESS'S RATING CONTINUES TO SLIP IN INQUIRY'S WAKE

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL with JANET ELDER 

 BODY:
With the midterm elections less than three weeks away, support for the Republican-controlled Congress has eroded significantly in the aftermath of the House vote to open a formal impeachment inquiry into President Clinton, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
The 105th Congress is now widely perceived as having invested too much political capital in impeachment and having accomplished little on a broad array of issues of importance to voters, from protecting Social Security to improving managed health care. 
 Approval of Congress has dropped to 43 percent from a high of 56 percent in September as the House has been consumed by the charges leveled against the President by the independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr. Forty-eight percent of the public now disapproves of the job that Congress is doing.
Nearly half of all voters said this Congress had accomplished less than a typical Congress. Most Americans could not name one accomplishment of this Congress this year. Of the minority who could cite something Congress had done, most mentioned the impeachment issue. The poll was conducted before a budget agreement appeared within reach last night.
Mr. Clinton's support, by contrast, remains as strong as it has ever been in his Presidency, with 63 percent of the public approving of how he is doing his job. On foreign policy, 60 percent approve of his Presidency, and 70 percent approve of his stewardship of the economy.
While no national survey can measure what will happen in individual Congressional districts, the latest poll suggests that Democrats may not be facing the rout in the mid-term elections that they were fearing just a month ago. Yet the polling also shows that, as many strategists have predicted, the election will swing on which group of voters proves the most motivated to come to the polls.
Looking at registered voters, the survey found that if turnout is similar to the last midterm election in 1994, the two parties are in a dead heat, a far better position for Democrats than they could have imagined just a few weeks ago.
But if, as many political strategists expect this year, November proves to be a low-turnout election, drawing to the polls only the most devoted voters, then Republicans do slightly better, favored 48 percent over 44 percent for the Democrats. Registered voters are split on whether their own member of Congress deserves re-election.
What is clear is that the political landscape is unsettled. In contrast to past months of sustained optimism, Americans are now divided on whether the nation is moving in the right direction.
In another sign of trouble for Republicans, Mr. Clinton was widely perceived as trying harder than the Congressional majority to find an acceptable compromise in the budget standoff that has dominated the closing days of this Congress. Fifty-three percent of the public said the Republicans in Congress were not trying to find a solution in the negotiations, while 58 percent credited Mr. Clinton with trying to find a way out of the impasse.
Those are almost the same perceptions that the public had during the fierce budget struggle of 1995, which led to the Government shutdown, although at that point Congress was held in far lower esteem. In December 1995, during the height of the fiscal showdown between the President and Congress, 64 percent of the public disapproved of how Congress was doing its job.
Still, conservative anger at Mr. Clinton's behavior helps explain why the Republicans chose to press ahead with authorizing an impeachment inquiry before the election to energize their core supporters. While 75 percent of the American public thinks that Mr. Starr's investigation was not worth the time and money, 55 percent of Americans who describe themselves as conservative Republicans say the investigation was worthwhile.
Republicans have to take care that they do not set off a backlash that energizes the Democratic base vote as well as the conservative one. The survey shows that should there be a high turnout election, 42 percent of those voting say they would favor a Republican candidate and 47 percent a Democrat.
It may well be that the Clinton scandal has far less of an effect on the election than anyone anticipates. Sixty-five percent of registered voters say the scandal will have no effect on which candidate they support in House elections.
Still, there is a longer-term risk for Republicans that they could damage their credibility as they move through the impeachment process over the next months.
Although most Americans now believe that Mr. Clinton probably committed perjury before a grand jury investigating his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky, there is little public support for impeachment.
Nearly 7 in 10 Americans see the impeachment inquiry as political rather than an investigation into serious crimes. And a majority of Americans say Republicans pushed through the investigation of Mr. Clinton to damage him and the Democrats, not because they think the charges are serious enough to warrant further investigation.
There are many indications that Americans would like the scandal to go away. More than a majority of Americans think it is preventing the President and Congress from doing work that needs to be done.
Republicans, Democrats and independents alike expressed profound discontent with the focus on the Lewinsky matter, and several people in follow-up interviews pointed to the budget standoff as a sign of partisanship and disarray in Washington. The nationwide telephone poll of 926 adults was conducted on Monday and Tuesday and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Pat Hobbs, a retired secretary in Sonoma, Calif., who is an independent, said: "I think they're all too mixed up with the scandal in Washington and they're not doing anything else. They should be working on things that really concern the country like the economy, education, crime, Social Security, Medicare reform, you name it." She said she had not yet decided whom she would support in her local House race.
Fred Taylor, a 58-year-old minister from Plant City, Fla., who is a Republican, was frustrated as well.
"We're facing another Government shutdown," Mr. Taylor said, "and we're playing politics again. We spent a lot of time getting Clinton cornered and it really should have been a side issue for some committee instead of taking it up with the whole Congress. They need to look more into domestic issues like the minimum wage and how our kids are going to make a living, as well as with Bosnia and the global economic situation."
Mr. Taylor said he would vote for the Republican House candidate, but portrayed his vote as a vote for change. "They probably all need to be run out," he said.
Gretchen Nielsen, a Democrat in Tucson, Ariz., vowed that she was going out this Election Day and voting "for every Democrat I can find."
"I feel like Congress has been trying to shoot down everything that Clinton has been trying to do," said Ms. Nielsen, a 66-year-old writer. "I think Congress has a personal vendetta against Clinton in more ways than just the Starr report. They've killed things like campaign financing and the minimum wage, things that are really important."
And Mike Stivila, 53, an unemployed food service salesman from Colts Neck, N.J., longed for the sense of direction the Republicans had when they swept into control of Congress on the Contract With America. Mr. Stivila described that agenda "as the first time a Congressional body actually laid out what they were going to do and the time it would take to accomplish it."
Mr. Stivila, an independent, said he was not a supporter of Mr. Clinton. "What he did was reprehensible," he said, "but impeachment would throw the whole country into additional chaos. There are a lot of things that Congress should be addressing. We don't have a budget agreement. If they'd spend less time politicking, they'd be able to concentrate more on what the country needs."
Indeed, 47 percent of voters said this Congress had accomplished less than a Congress typically does across a two-year period. Only 28 percent said the 105th Congress had accomplished more than past ones.
Asked about specific issues, majorities of Americans said Congress had not made progress on making sure Social Security and Medicare were preserved for future generations, on significantly changing the way political campaigns raise and spend money, or on protecting the rights of patients.
But in one bright spot for Congress, a majority said it had made progress on significantly improving the nation's economy.
When Americans were asked to name something notable that Congress had done in the past year, 16 percent mentioned the impeachment inquiry. Another 16 percent said nothing, 56 percent did not know and 12 percent mentioned other issues.
Public approval of Congress continued to slide from the high of 56 percent in September. In the last New York Times/CBS News Poll in late September, Congress had an approval rating of 48 percent. Now, after the House vote to open an impeachment inquiry, it is down to 43 percent. But that is still good for Congress.
In November 1994, just before the last midterm election, when Republicans took control of Congress for the first time in 40 years, only 20 percent of Americans approved of the way Congress was doing its job. A year later there was a sharp backlash against the Republican Congress because of its budget confrontation with the President. With Americans holding Congress responsible for a shutdown of the Government, approval of Congress fell to 26 percent.
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
 The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted on Monday and Tuesday with 926 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 782 said they were registered to vote.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of more than 42,000 active residential exchanges across the country.
Within each exchange, random digits were added to form a complete telephone number, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to geographic region, sex, race, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
For smaller subgroups the potential sampling error is larger. For example, for likely voters in low turnout election, it is plus or minus five percentage points. Likely voters were defined by a combination of past voting behavior, expressed intention to vote this year and attention paid to the campaign.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Variations in question wording or the order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat different results.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
LSI LOGIC SETS LAYOFFS AND $326 MILLION CHARGE

BYLINE: Reuters 

 BODY:
Hurt by the global slowdown in semiconductor sales, the LSI Logic Corporation, a computer chip maker, said yesterday that it would lay off around 1,200 employees, or 17 percent of its work force, and close several plants. As a result of the revamping, the company, based in Milpitas, Calif., said it would take a third-quarter charge of $326 million, which left it with a quarterly loss of $282.8 million, compared with net income of $44.3 million a year earlier. LSI will close its wafer-making plant in Tsukuba, Japan; a test plant in Colorado Springs, and an assembly plant in Fort Collins, Colo. LSI stock fell 25 cents, to $11.875.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Agrees on Scaled-Back Tax Package

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Their hopes for a big tax cut this year having been blocked by President Clinton and Congressional Democrats, Republican leaders tentatively agreed tonight on a sharply scaled-back package that kept alive several politically popular tax breaks.
After several days in which squabbling among Republicans endangered efforts to pass any tax bill this year, House and Senate negotiators compromised as Congress raced to finish work on the budget and go home to campaign. 
 The package would extend an existing credit for corporate research and development, extend tax breaks for employers who hired welfare recipients and other unemployed people and provide relief for farmers hit hard by falling commodity prices.
The package would also speed an existing plan to allow self-employed people to deduct all of their health insurance premiums.
The package would cost about $5 billion over five years and $9.2 billion over 10 years. But the changes would be paid for by closing loopholes and extending or increasing other taxes.
Congressional aides said the deal must still be approved by Senator William V. Roth Jr., the Delaware Republican who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee. Mr. Roth was still objecting tonight to several details of the package, especially a provision sought by a single Republican Senator, Phil Gramm of Texas, who has threatened to hold up the bill if he did not get what he wanted.
Mr. Gramm was seeking to include a provision, already approved by the House, that would allow Texas to forgive payroll taxes incurred by students enrolled at public universities, a right already enjoyed by most other states.
The bill was little more than a mop-up exercise for Republicans, who had seen this year, the first since 1969 in which the Federal government has run a budget surplus, as their best opportunity in decades to enact a sweeping tax cut.
But at every turn, they found themselves boxed in by Mr. Clinton, who in his State of the Union Message last January laid out a politically powerful dictum: leave the surplus untouched until Congress and the Administration settle on a plan to shore up the Social Security system, which will run short of money in coming decades as the baby boom generation retires.
Fearful of being portrayed by Democrats as putting tax cuts ahead of retirement security, Republicans were forced to backtrack on their tax-cut plans all year long. The most avid tax cutters in both the House and Senate argued that projected surpluses were so huge -- $1.55 trillion over the next decade, according to the Congressional Budget Office -- that there was plenty of money to deal with Social Security and have a tax cut.
They advocated tax reductions worth hundreds of billions of dollars, to be financed almost entirely out of the surplus. But moderate Republicans, especially in the Senate, balked. Even after the House lowered its sights and passed an $80 billion, five-year tax cut last month, the Senate refused to take up the measure, effectively killing it.
The package agreed on tonight does little more than keep expiring tax provisions alive for a few more months. Under a bill passed by the House several days ago, most of the provisions would have been extended until the end of next year; the latest compromise would shorten the extensions for several months.
The deal would also make it easier for middle-income people subject to the alternative minimum tax to claim the full benefit of the child credit and a credit for college tuition.
Separately, budget negotiators working on an emergency farm-relief package agreed to include a provision sought by Senator Charles Grassley, Republican of Iowa, that would let farmers put tax-deductible deposits of up to 20 percent of their income into special savings accounts. The provision is intended to allow farmers to save money in good years as a buffer for bad years.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
INTERNATIONAL PAPER TO CLOSE TWO FIBERBOARD PLANTS

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The International Paper Company will close fiberboard plants in South Carolina and North Carolina and dismiss 336 workers after the company failed to find buyers for the sites. The layoffs come on top of 1,500 job cuts that were announced on Tuesday. International Paper said yesterday that it would shutter a plant in Spring Hope, N.C., cutting 191 jobs, and a plant in Sellers, S.C., eliminating 145. Both make medium-density fiberboard, used in countertops and cabinets. The company put the fiberboard plants up for sale in August 1997. In addition, the company plans to cut 50 jobs from its chemical unit, Arizona Chemical. Shares of International Paper, based in Purchase, N.Y., fell $1.25 a share, to $44.8125.

 BODY:

The cuts, which will occur in the next six to nine months, are intended to increase annual pretax profits by $125 million, Huntington said. Costs associated with the moves will lower pretax fourth-quarter earnings by $90 million, the company said. Shares of Huntington, based in Columbus, Ohio, rose 18.75 cents, to $25.6875.

HEADLINE: Final Details On the Budget Taking Shape

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Congressional Republicans and White House officials appeared near a budget agreement tonight, providing substantial new aid to schools and farmers in a total budget package of $1.7 trillion.
While last-minute details were being hammered out, negotiators appeared to agree on $6 billion in farm aid, more than $1 billion for new teachers and to provide new money for the International Monetary Fund. 
 With the Congressional elections only 20 days away, Republicans can argue that they now have in hand solid accomplishments to take to the voters. Democrats have been lambasting the Republicans for focusing only on the possible impeachment of President Clinton, repeatedly deriding them as a do-nothing Congress.
For Mr. Clinton, the political gains could be greater. By publicly highlighting education issues in the last week, he changed the subject from the Lewinsky scandal to an issue of primary importance to the voters. The apparent tilt of a final accord demonstrated his resurgent power to influence events on Capitol Hill.
At least a handful of areas remained in dispute late tonight. Erskine B. Bowles, President Clinton's chief of staff, said the two sides had failed to resolve a number of environmental issues, how to conduct the 2000 census and two measures regarding contraceptives.
As the bargainers paused for a late dinner break, with plans to reconvene at midnight, Speaker Newt Gingrich told reporters: "All the big things are done." He said there were a few "very, very narrow issues."
In highlighting education, Mr. Clinton sought a down payment of $1.1 billion to recruit and hire 100,000 teachers across the country to reduce the average class size to 18 students.
The tentative budget provides that money. It reflects Republican demands that the money be controlled by local school districts, but it allows them to spend it only on teachers, including special education teachers, and not on books or computers or other materials or activities.
The Republicans blocked a second Clinton initiative that would have provided billions of dollars in bonds for the reconstruction of dilapidated school buildings. Republicans also blocked the President's proposal for the national testing of students.
There were hints that while the leaders may have reached a tentative agreement on numerous items, the rank-and-file Republicans and Democrats might not be so quick to go along.
Conservative Republicans said they had word that they had lost on the contraceptive issues, which emerged today as one of the stumbling blocks to a final accord.
Conservatives were also concerned that the conditions imposed on the International Monetary Fund in exchange for the new money sought by the President were inadequate. The conditions are aimed at getting the I.M.F. to reduce the risk of its loans.
The conservatives, in addition, were worried that the President was seeking too much in so-called emergency spending that was not provided for by offsetting cuts in other domestic programs.
Several aides to Republicans said they believed that their side had been so short-changed in the tentative agreement that the members might defect and not vote to pass the final bill. This would force Republican leaders to search for votes among Democrats.
As negotiators paused in their bargaining, both sides said they would be shopping the tentative agreement among their members to see if there were enough votes to pass a final omnibus bill by Friday night.
"Everyone is going to take a breather and talk to their respective groups," Representative John Boehner of Ohio, a Republican leader, said tonight. "It's been a good day but not as good as we'd hoped."
Congress and the White House did agree today to extend their deadline and provide temporary financing of the Government through Friday night. This was the fourth deadline that they have missed since the Oct. 1 start of the fiscal year.
With each passing deadline, the amount of money in the final omnibus package has expanded as members of Congress and the Administration try to slip in money for their favorite causes.
"The price tag tends to go up with the passage of time," said Representative Bob Livingston, the Louisiana Republican who is chairman of the Appropriations Committee. Asked if he meant the political price tag, he replied, "No, the actual price tag -- the cost of the bill."
But there did appear to be a political cost as well. Members on both sides of the aisle said the Republican leaders were calculating that it was to their political advantage to cede to the President on numerous items in exchange for a resolution to the dragged-out budget negotiations.
"People out there are beginning to get disgusted with all of us," said Representative John Porter, an Illinois Republican.
Representative David McIntosh, an Indiana Republican and leader of a band of House conservatives, said that many conservatives would not support the bill, based on early reports of the tentative agreement.
He said his earlier conciliatory comments about accepting a final package were based on an expected even split with the White House that did not seem to be materializing.
"Our leader, Tom DeLay, told us in conference this morning that we couldn't use the word 'cave,' " Mr. McIntosh said. "So, our leadership has 'bowed' to the President in most of they key issues. It is not a Republican bill, and our leadership shouldn't try to sell it as such. This is something you'd expect Lyndon Johnson and the Great Society Democrats to pass."
Republican leaders boasted about the tentative package tonight and began recasting themselves as "the surplus Congress," as opposed to the "do-nothing Congress" that Democrats had branded on them.
Mr. Gingrich said Republicans had won a crucial political battle on the census by postponing a decision for six months but that he was disappointed that the final package did not contain any serious tax cuts. The few issues still outstanding, he said, involved the regulation of pornography on the Internet, some extensions of minor tax credits and a battle on behalf of businesses to delay new rules on workplace ergonomics.
Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the Republican majority leader, hailed the agreement on the International Monetary Fund, even as conservatives, whom he had led in opposing new money for the fund, said it was inadequate. "Every time they sit down and make a decision, they will make it knowing that they can't keep it secret," Mr. Armey said of one of the conditions designed to end the fund's closed-book proceedings. "The windows are open, the sun's shining in."

Unemployment Rate Gets Closer to Nation's

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
New Jersey's unemployment rate inched closer to the nation's in September, when the state rate held at 4.8 percent compared with a slight rise nationwide, to 4.6 percent from 4.5 percent, the Federal Department of Labor reported yesterday.
The figures reflect the reliance among American manufacturers outside of New Jersey on exports to Asia, where faltering economies have dampened demand, said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University. 
 The state's Department of Labor reported a one-month gain of 7,400 jobs for September.

HEADLINE: Schools Are Talk of California, But Not of the Candidates There

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Throughout this election year, every public opinion poll in California has ranked education as the No. 1 concern among voters in a state whose once-golden public schools have slipped badly.
Two-thirds of likely voters in this famously tax-averse terrain now say they favor a record $9.2 billion bond measure on next month's ballot to repair and replace the state's crumbling schools. 
 That public focus mirrors national trends, and yet both major party candidates for governor seem to spend most of their time talking about everything but education.
Lieut. Gov. Gray Davis, the Democrat, and Attorney General Dan Lungren, the Republican, debate each other's decade-old legislative voting records, character and stands on abortion, gun control and Bill Clinton but hardly touch what politicians had long predicted would be the race's central issue.
"They've both run the standard pictures of them hanging around students in a classroom, but they've really shied away from specifics," said Mark Baldassare, director of a recent survey by the nonpartisan Public Policy Institute of California.
Nearly a third of the residents questioned in the survey cited education as the issue they most wanted candidates to address, while perennial favorites like crime, the economy and taxes all rated in the single digits.
"There's a lot of words about need for improvement but not a lot of details," Mr. Baldassare said. "I think this is one of the key reasons why this race has just been in the doldrums for months."
In fact, pure politics helps explain the relative silence. For months, as Mr. Davis has held a consistent lead over Mr. Lungren to succeed Gov. Pete Wilson, a Republican who is barred from seeking a third term, both candidates have run cautious campaigns aimed at the middle. Neither has been eager to wade into the potentially controversial waters of education overhaul -- or talk much about its cost.
Even today, at a news conference in Pasadena with Senator Dianne Feinstein, called to discuss education, Mr. Davis spent the first few minutes angrily accusing Mr. Lungren of failing to enforce the state's ban on assault weapons. Then he spoke blandly of his "high expectation approach" for raising standards, ending "social promotion" and auditing the state lottery to make sure its proceeds are spent on education as is mandated.
For his part, in his television commercials, Mr. Lungren endorses "school choice for parents," without explicitly saying that he favors vouchers -- government credits that parents could apply to private or parochial school tuition, an idea that voters decisively rejected in a 1993 ballot measure but that appears to be gaining support.
"Gray Davis is really trying not to say anything that's going to offend the teacher's union and the education establishment, which deliver hundreds of thousands of votes and big campaign contributions," said Bruce Fuller, a professor of education at the University of California at Berkeley and co-director of Policy Analysis for Education, a nonpartisan group that studies school reform.
"On the other hand," Professor Fuller said, "Dan Lungren is trying to appeal to his party's conservative base, and he does that by backing vouchers. But that's a double-edged sword. He may pick up some suburban votes and some urban votes from middle-class Latino parents, but I don't think it's going to help him with the ever-present soccer moms, for whom vouchers are a worrisome word."
The need for change is clear enough. Under former Gov. Edmund G. (Pat) Brown, California led the post-Sputnik boom in public education and built a system that was the envy of the nation. But since the passage of Proposition 13, the 1978 ballot measure that capped local property tax rates, the state's 8,000 public schools have had to compete for suddenly scarce resources in an era that saw both a grueling regional recession and a huge influx of new immigrants, many of them speaking little or no English.
In recent national standardized tests, California's fourth-graders surpassed only those in Mississippi and Louisiana in reading proficiency. Studies by a national teachers union and the State Department of Education have found that California ranks 37th in the nation in spending per pupil.
The state educates 1 of every 8 Americans but ranks last in the percentage of young adults who earn high school diplomas and 37th in college S.A.T. scores.
"Whatever their views of government, both Republicans and Democrats think that schools are the one thing government should do something about," said Bill Carrick, a Democratic political consultant who conducted scores of focus groups among voters around the state. "And voters think the schools stink, in every way imaginable, from crumbling infrastructure to lack of textbooks. The depth of the severity of educational deficiency is perceived as so great."
Moreover, in a state whose population is expected to grow by 18 million people -- an entire New York State -- by the year 2025, poll takers say voters tend to see "education" as a kind of proxy for their more generalized concerns about the future.
"I think voters are telling us they're concerned about the future and they feel that while things are going pretty well right now, they feel that their children may not have the skills they need to compete efficiently," Mr. Baldassare said. "They're telling us that technology is running along at a fast pace and they can't keep up with it."
"And most people recognize that in the regions where they live, there's been a phenomenal amount of immigration and there are large numbers of people who need to learn English and basic skills," he added. "And if the state is going to continue to achieve the economic prosperity which it has been used to having, then the schools have an enormous responsibility to teach and train these new Californians."
Yet while voters uniformly see problems, there is little consensus about what to do. For example, polls have shown that a ballot measure conceived by Mr. Wilson as a way to make permanent the class-size reductions previously ordered by the Legislature is failing to draw majority support among likely voters.
Instead, voters seem to be rebelling at 16 years of Republican rule in the Governor's mansion. A recent statewide Field Poll found that voters viewed Mr. Davis as significantly stronger on education issues than Mr. Lungren, and Mr. Davis hammers home that point in a new commercial noting that Mr. Lungren, as a Congressman, opposed creating the Department of Education.
That has frustrated many Republican strategists here, who complain that Mr. Lungren has not focused enough on an issue that could help him, and has not put his advertising money behind his one television commercial that features the issue.
They note, for example, that Mr. Lungren favors lifting the statewide cap on the number of charter schools, a popular system in which schools are publicly financed but governed by independent local boards of parents and teachers, while Mr. Davis favors only a gradual expansion.
"Education could be the key to a Lungren victory," said Dan Schnur, a former senior Wilson aide who now advises Mr. Lungren. "More than on any other issue he's got an opportunity to convince voters that he's an agent of change and that Davis is a defender of the status quo. On other issues, Davis is able to blur the differences."
But Mr. Schnur also knows firsthand the political pitfalls of education issues. In 1993, he managed the campaign for a ballot measure in support of vouchers that received only 30 percent of the vote. Current polls show public support for the idea approaching 60 percent, but experts say that surface number masks deeper public ambivalence.
Still, poll takers say the depth of public support for the costly bond measure shows the intensity of concern about the state's badly outmoded, overcrowded schools. Yet the state's recent experience with laws like the class-size reduction measure -- which quickly ran up against a shortage of qualified teachers -- makes people wary of any promise of a quick fix.
"In a sense, you want to slow down the reform process and see which of these ideas really work," Professor Fuller said. "Each one of these ideas has a silver-bullet quality to it, and then we start rolling out new programs at $1 billion each and we discover they create new problems. There's very little systemic thinking about how they all fit together."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 9, 1999, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Oct. 15 about education as an issue in the election for California governor referred incorrectly to a link between Dan Schnur, a Republican political consultant, and a 1993 campaign for a ballot measure to create a voucher system for public schools. He took no role in the 1993 campaign; it was managed by another consultant, Ken Khachigian.
This correction was scheduled for publication in October but was misplaced.

HEADLINE: Opulence at the Armory, With a Slight Hedge

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL

 BODY:
Over the last decade, exhibitors at the International Fine Art and Antique Dealers Show have seen it all. They remember the flush days of the late 1980's when collectors elbowed one another to be the first through the heavy carved oak doors of the Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan, dropping several million dollars on a chic little table or a pair of unusual chairs. But they also remember the bleak years of the early 90's when the crowds came but almost nobody spent.
Just how this year's show, which opens today and runs through Thursday, will be affected by the worldwide financial crisis is yet to be seen. As usual, the offerings are broad and the booths glamorous. A walk around the show provides a look at everything from a $3 million Cezanne still life to a $100 delft tile and a $40 18th-century silver mustard spoon. Dealers hope the art market will continue to rise as it did in 1987 after Black Monday. 
 "I haven't seen a client yet who says he's feeling too broke to buy," said Edward Munves, owner of James Robinson, a Park Avenue gallery specializing in antique jewelry and silver. "People consider buying silver or jewelry simply moving money from one kind of asset to another. It didn't stop me from bringing good pieces because people today would rather not buy than have lesser quality."
Some dealers take a less sanguine view of the market. Khalil Rizk of the Chinese Porcelain Company in Manhattan is prepared to see a few less sales this season. "Volume will be down, but things that are compelling and essential to a collector won't be passed up," he said. "There's such a shortage of great objects that connoisseurs won't be able to resist them."
The walls of Mr. Rizk's booth are covered with black felt to show off 70 watercolors of Chinese birds, which were made around 1810 for an English nobleman. They are priced at $3,800 each, and Mr. Rizk said he hoped collectors would buy them in interesting groups rather than one or two at a time. These are his purely decorative offerings. The stars of his booth are an 18th-century Chinese painting of a reclining horse, which has a $125,000 price tag, and a seventh-century Vietnamese gold Buddha, which stands 22 inches high and which Mr. Rizk says is one of the largest gold pieces of that period known. It costs $550,000.
It's not unusual to find booths like the Chinese Porcelain Company's that feature both affordable items and very expensive ones. Mark Brady, a painting and drawing dealer from Manhattan, said he brought reasonably priced decorative objects as well as serious, museum-quality works. Over the last several years, Mr. Brady said, he has had a significant rise in sales to American museums. But given the uncertainty of the market, he said he believed careful pricing was crucial.
"People just don't feel like spending excessive amounts of money like they did a year ago," Mr. Brady said. "They want to find works of art that are attractively priced."
One such work is a haunting painting titled "The Emperor Napoleon's Horse, Tauris," which was in the collection of the National History Museum in Paris. Priced at $38,000, it is signed and dated B. Noriac/1908 and depicts the skeleton of a horse being fed by his trainer, who also happens to be a skeleton.
This year's fair seems to offer a wider range of paintings than it has in recent years. Waring Hopkins, a Paris dealer, has a whimsical and colorful Calder from 1974, "The Card Players," which costs $50,000 and comes from a private collection in Paris. Also arresting is a Nabis-period Bonnard, "The Stork," an oil-on-cloth painting with a brilliant red background, which costs $960,000.
Mr. Hopkins just flew in from France after participating in the Biennale des Antiquaires, Paris's big antiques event, which ended last month. "The biennale wasn't as lively as the Fine Art Fair here in May," he said. "But we made many sales, so I can't complain."
One of the four new dealers this year, De Jonckheere, also showed at the biennale and is no stranger to New York fairs. The Paris gallery, which specializes in 16th- and 17th-century Flemish and Dutch paintings, has a booth filled with paintings by masters like Teniers, Bruegel and Cranach. One outstanding Bruegel, "The Return of the Country Fair" (1620), depicts a lively village scene. It is priced at $2 million and came from a private collection in Belgium.
The three other new dealers tried to decorate their booths with flair, and all succeeded. Frederick Schultz, an antiquities dealer from Manhattan, paneled his booth in a blond wood with modular displays that feature all kinds of objects, from a fifth-century B.C. bronze horn with a wonderful patina that costs $475,000 to an Iberian column idol dating from 200 B.C. for $165,000. "I'd like to think that I present antiquities in an intriguing way to people who never thought about them before," he said.
One booth away from Mr. Schultz is Galerie Blondeel Deroyan, another new dealer. The cool gray space features simple, sleek clear plastic display cases that show off a wide variety of objects, including antiquities, tapestries, furniture and artworks. Unforgettable are the booth's three important tapestries. The most striking is a large French embroidered one dating from 1600 that shows scenes of the Old Testament around the border and the New Testament in the middle, with the four Evangelists. It is from a private collection in northern France and costs $360,000. On a simple pedestal in the center of the booth is an impeccably carved figure of an Egyptian dignitary from the period of the Ramses kings, 1315 to 1090 B.C., for $525,000.
Galerie Blondeel Deroyan is based in Paris. So is another new dealer, Maroun H. Salloum. But Mr. Salloum specializes in 19th- and early-20th-century furniture and artworks. "My taste isn't very French," Mr. Salloum said. The walls of his small booth are paneled to resemble an Arts and Crafts room. In the booth, a pair of early cabinets by Adolf Loos, the Austrian architect and designer, face each other; they are priced at $110,000 for both. Other pairs here include 1860 plaster figures and evocative silver scones by Jacques-Emile Ruhlmann, a leading Parisian decorator and designer of the 1920's.
If one trend is evident at the fair this season, it is a proliferation of 1920's and 30's furniture and decorative objects. Vallois, another French dealer, is back for its second year, with a large booth whose walls are covered in parchment-colored undulating paneling. Nearly all the objects -- dining tables, chairs, vanities -- are by Ruhlmann. And an old-timer at the show, Ciancimino from London, used to epitomize English country-house taste until recent years when its booth and Pimlico Road shop have consistently carried Art Deco objects. This year a pair of ebony screens by Jean-Michel Frank flank the booth's back wall. "We feel most of our American decorators are going toward that look," Jean-Claude Ciancimino said.
They're also going for Russian furniture. Some of the best can be found at the booth of another London dealer, Antoine Cheneviere, who is showing a pair of Russian commodes by Heinrich Gambs, a major cabinetmaker of his time. Dated 1810, the pieces are of mahogany and ebony with gilt bronze leopardlike faces for drawer pulls and gilt claw feet. The dealer says he has not priced them yet.
When asked for his predictions about the fair, given the state of the economy, Mr. Cheneviere said: "Some people may decide to buy because it's another sort of investment. But at this point, it's anyone's guess."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Seeking growth, Weiss, Whitten, Stagliano changes its name and adds nine partners.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
A CREATIVELY focused New York agency is reorganizing as the principals seek to spark new growth.
The agency, Weiss, Whitten, Stagliano, which creates campaigns for clients like Allied Domecq, The Economist, Ferrari and Guinness, is being renamed Weiss Stagliano Partners as nine creative, account, production and administrative executives are given stock in the downtown shop. The new partners are gaining the undisclosed minority interest in the agency from Marty Weiss and Adam Stagliano, who will hold the majority of the equity and voting shares. 
 Weiss Stagliano was formed seven years ago as Weiss, Whitten, Carroll, Stagliano with the merger of two small shops that opened in 1989. Of the four principals who joined forces in 1991, the two who remain are Mr. Weiss, creative director, and Mr. Stagliano, president and account planning director.
As for the other two, Tom Carroll, who left in 1993, is a partner at Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG, a unit of Havas Advertising in New York. And Nat Whitten, who left in November, started his own agency, Nat Whitten Inc. in New York.
Weiss Stagliano is part of a new generation of agencies that were founded in the late 1980's and early 1990's by entrepreneurial talents who broke away from such hot shops as Chiat/Day; Fallon McElligott; Goodby, Silverstein & Partners, and Wieden & Kennedy. Though many of the newcomers are thriving, there is a widespread perception, as Warren Berger wrote in an article in the July-August issue of the trade publication Creativity, that they "have not evolved all that far" and "have yet to hit the kind of early home run that promises future greatness."
Progress for Weiss Stagliano, which estimates its billings at $85 million to $90 million, has been impeded by two recent setbacks. The Barnes & Noble Inc. retail and on-line accounts, with billings estimated at more than $40 million, left after less than a year for the New York office of TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group.
And the estimated $35 million Guerlain fragrance account, once shared by Weiss Stagliano with WSP/Australie, part of the Euro RSCG unit of Havas in Paris, was consolidated at the French agency by the French perfumer, which is owned by LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton. Weiss Stagliano does, however, continue to maintain ties with WSP/Australie.
"Do I think we had an aspiration 10 years ago to be bigger?" Mr. Stagliano, 43, said in an interview. "Absolutely."
"I don't think we're quite as brash as we were," he added. "But we still believe in our vision."
Mr. Weiss, 44, who joined Mr. Stagliano for the interview, agreed.
"We didn't lose a lot of sleep over what seemed like 'hits' to the outside world," Mr. Weiss said, because "we've never felt more solid."
"We have more focus and we have more management," he added. "It's all coming together."
One reason Mr. Stagliano gave for describing himself as a "psychopathic optimist" is that, he said, the agency "has never been as busy new-business-wise." He listed a new $5 million account from American Skandia, a unit of the Skandia Insurance Company Ltd., and additional assignments from such clients as Allied Domecq Spirits and the Guinness Import Company.
Weiss Stagliano is also taking part in account reviews, Mr. Stagliano said, that include the Chupa Chups lollipops sold by Chupa Chups USA and the Concord watch brand sold by Movado Group.
"We've weathered partners leaving," he added, "and the leaving of some fairly highly visible clients. We are not the new kids on the block; we have a certain maturity."
The naming of the new partners is meant to encourage their efforts in the Weiss Stagliano advertising operation as well as at units that specialize in film and music, Internet marketing and brand design.
"We wanted to come up with an incentive scheme," Mr. Stagliano said, "and at agencies that can mean only one thing: giving out equity."
The new partners are: Paul Budd, 35, studio director; Jeff Compton, 33, creative supervisor; Neil Cotton, 32, group account director; Louise Fischer, 31, group account director; Todd Gallentine, 34, creative supervisor; Jeff Greenberg, 41, production services director; Gay Holmes, 32, group account planning director; William Livolsi Jr., 39, chief financial officer, and Mark Mendelis, 30, creative supervisor.

HEADLINE: Delta Results Set a Record For Quarter

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Confounding investors worried about a weakening economy, Delta Air Lines reported record quarterly earnings yesterday, easily surpassing Wall Street's estimates.
Delta, the country's third-largest airline after United and American, saw its net income rise 29 percent, to $327 million, or $4.16 a diluted share, compared with $254 million, or $3.26 a share, during the period a year ago. Analysts polled by First Call had estimated that the carrier would earn $3.90 a share. 
 Revenue rose 7 percent, to $3.8 billion, compared with $3.55 billion in the quarter in 1997.
As the first major airline to report earnings, Delta may lead the way for the rest of the industry. But a large percentage of the gains for the company's first fiscal quarter appeared to come at the expense of Northwest Airlines, which was grounded for three weeks during the quarter after its pilots walked out in late August.
Delta executives estimated that because of the Northwest strike, Delta's revenue increased $25 million to $30 million, which equals about 23 cents a share.
Delta's shares soared $7 yesterday, closing at $93.50 on the New York Stock Exchange. Other major airlines also rose sharply for the second consecutive day in anticipation of a strong quarter.
But the increases did little to erase previous steep declines in airline stocks, which have fallen 44 percent from their peaks in July, according to Samuel C. Buttrick, an analyst at Paine Webber.
Because spending on travel is so closely tied to the health of the overall economy, airlines are often seen as leading indicators of economic downturns. Mr. Buttrick told his clients recently that only once before have airline stocks fallen 44 percent without a recession following, and that was during the 1987 stock market crash.
Brian Harris, the airline analyst at Salomon Smith Barney in New York, estimates that every 1 percent decline in consumer spending trims 9 percent from airline earnings.
Delta, like the other major carriers, said that it saw no signs of an imminent recession. It told analysts yesterday that advanced bookings through December for both domestic and international travel were at higher levels than they were at this time last year.
"What they are saying is they are just about locked in for next quarter," said Susan M. Donofrio, an analyst at BT Alex. Brown in New York. "The question mark remains for 1999 because they can't see that far out."
If a recession does come next year, however, Leo F. Mullin, Delta's chairman and chief executive, said the carrier was better positioned to weather it than at any time in its history. "We are cautious about general economic conditions," he said.
Delta has $1.1 billion in cash, even after spending $400 million during the quarter to buy its own shares. It is also putting in a new computer system that it said would produce $200 million in extra revenue in the coming year by enabling the airline to gauge passenger demand more efficiently.

HEADLINE: Salomon Cuts 100 Bond Jobs

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Salomon Smith Barney Inc. said yesterday that it had cut 100 jobs in United States bond trading, research and sales in New York to reduce costs as a result of trading losses in global markets.
The cuts are in all areas of the debt department and began on Wednesday, a spokeswoman, Arda Nazerian, said. The firm is expected to dismiss additional employees in its equities unit the week of Oct. 26 and after that, in investment banking. 
 The third-biggest United States securities firm by capital is dismissing employees after losing about $700 million related to global arbitrage and Russia's default in August, which sent bond markets around the world tumbling. Salomon Smith Barney is expected to report a net loss of about $325 million in its third quarter, its parent, Citigroup Inc., said last week.
The cuts follow Merrill Lynch & Company's decision to eliminate 3,400 jobs earlier this week. Wall Street is undergoing its biggest round of layoffs since late 1994 and early 1995, when the Federal Reserve raised interest rates several times.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Edge Upward; Analysts Call Increase a Fluke

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
Higher costs for new cars and trucks pushed up the prices paid to producers in September at the fastest rate in a year, a statistical fluke that analysts said did not portend a lasting acceleration of inflation.
Prices paid to factories, farmers and other producers for finished goods rose three-tenths of a percent last month, the Labor Department said. That came after a four-tenths of a percent decrease in August and was the largest increase since a rise of four-tenths of a percent in September 1997. Analysts were expecting no change for the month. 
 "It's not as bad as it seems," said Ian Shepherdson, an independent economist based in New York. "It would be very unwise to read any medium-term inflation implications from these numbers."
Rather than seeing an actual increase in auto prices, analysts said the Labor Department had trouble adjusting the Producer Price Index to account for early introduction of some new models, discounted costs on old models and the lingering effects of the strike against the General Motors Corporation.
In addition, other Government indicators released today suggest economic growth is slowing, which should mean fewer inflation pressures.
Sales at American businesses, for example, fell two-tenths of a percent, to $772.5 billion, in August after falling one-tenth of a percent in July, the Commerce Department said. That pushed up business inventories three-tenths of a percent, to $1.074 trillion, in August -- the fastest rate of stock-building since March.
And the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia reported that its general economic index remained negative, posting a reading of minus 6.1 this month. That suggests manufacturing contracted for a second straight month in the Philadelphia region. The report also showed no sign of inflation pressures in the region. Its prices-paid index fell to minus 14.5 in October from minus 2.5 in September -- the lowest in the 30-year history of the survey.
Separately, the Labor Department said the number of workers filing for state unemployment benefits rose by 2,000, to a seasonally adjusted 303,000, for the week ended Oct. 10 after claims rose by 11,000 the previous week, when 40 states or territories reported an increase in new jobless claims.
In its inflation report, the Labor Department said the core rate of the Producer Price Index, which excludes food and energy costs, rose four-tenths of a percent in September after falling one-tenth of a percent a month earlier.
A seasonally adjusted 2.2 percent rise in the cost of passenger cars and a 2 percent increase in the price of light trucks accounted for three-fourths of the September increase in the core rate, the report said.
The September increase in vehicle prices more than offset a 1.7 percent drop in car prices and a one-tenth of a percent drop in light-truck prices in August.
That meant prices did not fall as much as the Labor Department's seasonal adjustment factors expected. The department expected a 2.9 percent decline in auto prices; prices actually fell four-tenths of a percent. For light trucks, the department expected a 2.6 percent price decline; actual prices fell 1 percent.

(Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics); "Inventory-Sales Ratio" shows total month-end business inventories divided by total monthly business sales, from March 1997 through Aug. 1998. (Source: Commerce Deptartment)

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Coca-Cola's Earnings Down By 12.2% in Third Quarter

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
The Coca-Cola Company reported third-quarter earnings yesterday that were in line with what the company previewed earlier this month, when senior executives warned that Coke's business had suffered from economic crises around the world.
The company earned $888 million, or 36 cents a diluted share, down 12.2 percent from $1.011 billion, or 40 cents a share, last year. Revenue totaled $4.75 billion, down 4 percent from $4.95 billion. 
 Worldwide volume for the quarter rose just 3 percent, compared with 11 percent for the period a year ago. In Europe, volume increased just 1 percent, while volume grew 4 percent in the United States. The company's Middle and Far East group recorded volume increases of just 3 percent in the quarter, compared with 10 percent in the 1997 third quarter. The biggest gainer was Africa, which is also Coke's smallest global division, where volume rose 5 percent, compared with 13 percent in the 1997 third quarter.
"It was exactly as advertised at the meeting three weeks ago," said Andrew Conway, a beverage analyst with Morgan Stanley. Mr. Conway lowered his fourth-quarter estimate by a penny, nevertheless, to reflect costs the company may incur from consolidating bottling operations in Russia. "During this time of global uncertainty, our system will continuously demonstrate the mind-set of the industry leader, with determination to stay focused on creating value for our customers, and our share owners," Coke's chairman and chief executive, M. Douglas Ivester, said in a statement.
Among the trouble spots was Germany, where issues as basic as the weather dragged down the performance of the rest of Europe. "You have a weak economy in Germany, and they said the weather wasn't good, and they are going through a transitional period in terms of merging bottlers," said Emanuel Goldman, a global consumer-products analyst for Merrill Lynch. "They are going to be paying especially close attention to Germany. The volume probably won't be up in the fourth quarter."
Additional problems persist in Japan, where volume was flat and up only 2 percent for the year. And in Brazil, where volume rose 1 percent in the third quarter, some analysts expect a dismal fourth quarter.
"What goes on in Brazil over the next few months is important in terms of Coke's total Latin American volume," Mr. Goldman said. "Whatever happens in Brazil, you have spillover effects." Already, Colombia and Venezuela have seen a 6 percent drop in volume, the company reported yesterday.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Fed Action on Interest Rates Sends Treasury Prices Higher

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices surged yesterday, and two-year notes posted the biggest rally in more than three years, after the Federal Reserve unexpectedly cut interest rates to avert a credit crunch and calm financial markets.
The central bank lowered its target for the Federal funds rate -- the rate banks charge each other for overnight loans -- by one-quarter of a percentage point, to 5 percent, after cutting it by the same amount in late September. It also cut the discount rate -- at which the Fed lends to financial institutions -- by one-quarter point, to 4.75 percent. 
 "It certainly caught us by total surprise," said John Burgess, who oversees about $90 billion at the Bankers Trust Company.
The Fed's move may signal deeper problems in the financial system and presage more rate cuts, Mr. Burgess said. It was the first time since April 1994 that the central bank changed interest rates between policy meetings.
Two-year notes, those most sensitive to Fed policy, soared after the Fed's move, driving yields down to 3.83 percent, the biggest rally since June 13, 1995. The bellwether 30-year Treasury bond rose 29/32 , to 108 8/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 4.97 percent, from 5.03 percent on Wednesday.
"It's just a shock," Tom O'Connell, a Treasury note trader at First Chicago Capital Markets, said. "The timing shows how much they are concerned about the market."
The Fed last trimmed rates at a policy meeting on Sept. 29, lowering the Fed funds target a quarter-point, to 5.25 percent.
Investors flocked to Treasury securities in recent months, seeking the safest investments after Russia devalued its currency and defaulted on some debt, shaking financial markets around the world. Thirty-year bond yields fell as low as 4.72 percent on Oct. 5, the lowest for long-term United States debt in 31 years.
The Fed's move "tells me there is significant concern about the financial system and the liquidity being provided by financial institutions," said Richard Schwartz, who oversees $21 billion in bonds at New York Life Asset Management in Parsippany, N.J.
"My belief is that they see significant problems among financial" companies that others may not be aware of, Mr. Schwartz said.
Already, big banks and brokerage firms, including the Nomura Securities Company, Merrill Lynch & Company and the BankAmerica Corporation, have announced trading losses and lower profits in the third quarter. In the case of Merrill, the weaker performance also resulted in job cuts.
Profit shortfalls at other companies, including the Eastman Kodak Company, also point to slower growth and the chance of more rate cuts, investors said.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Ruling Broadens Protection for Renter in a Co-op

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
In a decision that could affect the status of unsold co-op and condominium apartments throughout New York State, a housing court judge in Brooklyn has ruled that a tenant who rented an apartment from a sponsor after a conversion was entitled to the same protection against eviction as tenants who were living there at the time of the conversion.
While the ruling's effect is limited for now to the Brooklyn case, some lawyers are worried that it might set a precedent upsetting a standard assumption of the co-op and condominium market: that the sponsor can refuse to renew the lease of a tenant who sublets after a conversion. 
 The ruling, if upheld, would sharply curtail sponsors' ability to end the tenancy of such renters, preventing co-ops and condominiums from completing conversions while forcing sponsors to keep apartments vacant until they are sold.
"This has the potential of preventing the completion of literally thousands of conversions," said Jim Samson, a lawyer representing about 90 co-op boards in the city. "It would create major economic turmoil in the co-op community."
Stuart Saft, chairman of the Council of New York Cooperatives, concurred. "This case affects every unsold apartment in the city," he said. "It immediately affects all the apartments which the sponsor rented after the conversion, and it will affect every apartment that presently has a rent-regulated tenant as those tenants vacate their apartments.
"When they leave," Mr. Saft said, "the sponsor has to decide whether to sell or deal with giving a new tenant the right to stay forever."
According to Martin Oestreicher, deputy commissioner of the city's Department of Finance, there are at least 420,000 co-op and condominium units in the city, of which about 100,000 are now held by sponsors.
The ruling, in Paikoff v. Harris, was handed down by Judge Marc Finkelstein of Civil Court on Aug. 31. It involved a six-unit co-op, sponsored by Barry Paikoff, at 534 Sixth Avenue in Park Slope.
The tenant, Emil Harris, rented a sponsor-held apartment five years after the 1992 conversion. When the lease expired, Mr. Paikoff started eviction proceedings. But Mr. Harris refused to leave, claiming that he should be considered a "nonpurchasing tenant" under the Martin Act, the state law governing the rights of co-op and condominium tenants. Rent control and rent stabilization are governed by other regulations.
Essentially, tenants protected by the Martin Act cannot be evicted except for good cause, like failing to pay rent, and cannot be subjected to "unconscionable rent increases." The act allows rent-regulated tenants already in the building to retain that status, but does not spell out rent formulas.
Before Judge Finkelstein's decision, it was assumed that only tenants already occupying an apartment during a conversion were protected. People renting after conversion -- either from a tenant-shareholder or a "holder of unsold shares," like the sponsor -- were considered unprotected.
But the judge ruled that the Martin Act applies to any tenant renting from someone other than a "purchaser under the plan." He also ruled that while tenant-shareholders are indeed purchasers under the plan, a holder of unsold shares, like the sponsor, is not -- contrary to a long-held industry assumption that had never been tested in court.
"If the Legislature intended that a holder of unsold shares should be considered a purchaser under the plan," Judge Finkelstein wrote, "the legislation should have contained a provision to that effect."
He also quoted a submission from the State Attorney General's office, which contended that a sponsor is not a purchaser under the plan, and, therefore, "a tenant who rents a vacant unit after the plan's effective date from a sponsor or holder of unsold shares is a nonpurchasing tenant," protected by the Martin Act. On that basis, Judge Finkelstein denied the eviction.
No decision on whether to appeal had been made, said Rand Levin, the sponsor's lawyer. "My view," he said, "is that there is a wealth of legislative history suggesting that the intent of the statute was only to protect tenants in possession at the time of a conversion."
Mr. Harris's lawyer, Ronald Languedoc of Brooklyn Legal Services, called the ruling well reasoned and "clearly reflecting the language of the statute." Mr. Harris, asked if he was aware that his case could set a precedent, said: "I'm very proud of that. Maybe it will give people in my situation a means of stability."
But real estate lawyers said they were concerned.
"Assuming that it's affirmed on appeal, and that's questionable," Mr. Saft said, "it means the sponsor may not be able to sell the apartment in the future because the tenant can't be evicted. From the co-op's point of view, it's good news and bad news. The good news is that it's more likely now that sponsors will sell apartments that become vacant. The bad news is that every tenant who rented after the conversion may have the right to remain permanently."
Mr. Samson, the co-op board lawyer, said he feared that the ruling would give sponsors an excuse to hold on to their apartments and continue collecting free-market rents.
"While it will scare most sponsors so they won't rent," Mr. Samson said, "there is also a group of sponsors who converted buildings with no intention of selling all the units. They simply sold the minimum and are holding the rest for the sole purpose of avoiding rent regulation and renting them out at free-market rents."
Likening those sponsors to Br'er Rabbit manipulatively pleading, "Please don't throw me in the briar patch," Mr. Samson said those sponsors, in truth, "don't want to sell."
"If they are told they can't evict," he said, "then they are protected from having to sell, and they are able to keep charging extraordinarily high and unregulated rents."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Trade Group Faults U.S. on Shrimp Rules

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
The World Trade Organization has ruled that the United States is not evenhandedly applying a law that bans certain shrimp imports, while saying that the law itself does not violate trade rules.
Washington had appealed an earlier ruling by a panel of the trade organization that said that a 1991 American law banning shrimp imports from countries that failed to prove that their shrimping fleets were taking steps to protect endangered sea turtles was illegal. The ban covers shrimps caught in nets without escape pods. 
 The trade group said that the United States applied the law "in a manner which constitutes arbitrary and unjustifiable discrimination between members of the W.T.O." and did not work with other governments to adopt similar protective laws for sea turtles before imposing an import ban.
American trade officials have promised to stand firm. In a statement yesterday, the United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, said, "We disagree with the appellate body's assessment that we have not implemented the law in an evenhanded manner." Nonetheless, she said, "the appellate body has rightly recognized that our shrimp-turtle law is an important and legitimate conservation measure."
The ruling, released earlier this week, leaves the law intact, but the trade organization said Washington must take steps to apply the law more evenly. It did not list specific consequences of failing to comply.
In March, India, Pakistan, Malaysia and Thailand filed a complaint with the World Trade Organization, charging that monitoring of shrimping techniques was illegal because it was not a legitimate trade issue.
Environmentalists had expected the trade group to uphold its earlier ruling against the American law. Peter Fugazzotto, a spokesman for the Sea Turtle Restoration Project in Forest Knolls, Calif., north of San Francisco, said the W.T.O.'s "anti-environmental bias" was known.
Tim Eichenberg of the Center for Marine Conservation said, "We're very disappointed but not surprised with the W.T.O.'s decision."
"We hope that the Administration takes a strong stand," he continued, "and does not weaken any laws."
Analysts have said that the ban prevents the sale in the United States of perhaps $200 million to $300 million in foreign shrimp each year, and that lifting it would probably lower domestic prices of shrimp. That would hurt shrimpers and help packers, distributors and retailers.
The United States imported 113,300 tons of shrimp in the first five months this year, up 20 percent over the 1997 period. The 1997 exports from Thailand alone came to 137,000 tons, worth $1.23 billion, the Thai Frozen Foods Association said.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk
