HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Finding a Balance in the Dollar's Slide

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Many Americans love a strong dollar. After all, a rising currency means lower prices for imports and more bang for the buck when traveling abroad.
But much of American business is a lot happier when the dollar is not so strong. That's because a weaker currency lifts American exports and helps stifle foreign competitors here. So why, with the dollar's recent plunge against the Japanese yen and its longer slide against the German mark, aren't executives breaking out the Champagne? 
 Perhaps because the dollar is not as weak as headlines suggest, even after it fell yesterday when the Federal Reserve, in a surprise move, cut each of its two key interest rate targets by a quarter of a percentage point.
"By easing now, the Fed will be promoting stronger financial markets down the road," said Michael Rosenberg, head of international fixed-income research at Merrill Lynch & Company. "So the hit the dollar is taking now should be an abbreviated one."
Take the case of the Nucor Corporation, an efficient steelmaker based in Charlotte, N.C., that has seen its exports plunge from 700,000 tons just a few years ago to 100,000 tons this year.
Nucor's exports have been depressed because the strong dollar makes its steel products more expensive in overseas markets and because the collapse of Asian economies has cut into sales to that region.
So it was not surprising that F. Kenneth Iverson, Nucor's chairman, was heartened last week when the dollar fell 8 percent against the yen in one day. Bidders he hadn't heard from in months were on the phone. "We've seen more opportunity for quotes," he said.
Trouble is, no new business has yet materialized.
There's a good reason. The dollar has fallen 20.7 percent against the yen and 12.7 percent against the mark from its 1998 highs, but it remains relatively strong against other currencies that play a big role in American trade, including the Mexican peso and the Canadian dollar. Those currencies both set record lows this year against the United States dollar.
Indeed, until last month the trade-weighted dollar, which is intended to reflect each major currency's impact on United States trade, was the strongest it had been since 1985. The trade-weighted dollar had jumped 21 percent since May 1995, when the American currency was at record lows against the yen and the mark. But since September, according to the index by the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, the trade-weighted dollar has fallen only 4.8 percent.
The dollar's overall fall "has not been enough to make a big difference," said John Lipsky, chief economist for Chase Manhattan Bank.
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar fell to 116.75 yen, from 118.98 Wednesday, and to 1.6187 marks, from 1.6426. The Dallas Fed index for the daily trade-weighted dollar dropped to 172.5, from 173.5.
Still, while exporters may not be getting much support, it appears that the weaker dollar could provide significant aid to American companies that have had earnings abroad crimped by a strong dollar during the last year. Eastman Kodak, Gillette and I.B.M., for example, seem poised for a lift from the weaker dollar in the quarters ahead.
"After being a severe negative for earnings this year, it could be a positive," said Thomas Doerflinger, an investment strategist at Paine Webber. This year -- in which he believes earnings gains for the companies in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index will be negligible -- Mr. Doerflinger said that the strong dollar had on average cut earnings growth by about two percentage points.
The hit-and-miss impact of the dollar's recent fall is partly because currency changes show up through the conversion of foreign earnings almost immediately but take much longer to have broader economic impacts. And the global slowdown, which has cut consumer demand worldwide, means that a lift from the dollar may go mostly unnoticed, analysts said.
And every business is different. Some multinational corporations hedge against dollar fluctuations, some don't. Some have operations around the world, others are concentrated in a handful of countries.
A stronger dollar should eventually help the American auto makers, by putting pressure on Japanese and European auto companies to either raise prices in the United States or accept lower profit margins.
American importers, however, will be paying more. What is unclear is whether a weaker dollar will lead to higher inflation or whether an expected economic slowdown in the United States will force all companies to hold down price increases.
Moreover, a lot depends on where the dollar goes from here. Some economists think it will reverse course against the yen, rallying as high as 150 yen, because the Japanese economic outlook is still glum.
The decline seems more lasting against the mark, but that could change after the euro, the new European currency, is introduced in January. Other variables include performances by stocks as well as any further Fed rate cuts.
For other American exporters, like Eastman Chemical, a polyester plastic maker based in Kingsport, Tenn., the story is the same as at Nucor. "Generally, a weaker dollar will make us more competitive," said Larry Munsey, Eastman Chemical's treasurer. "We can lower prices and gain more volume."
That's the theory, anyway. But "it's too early to tell," he said, adding, "It could take several months."
In addition, whatever aid the dollar gives exporters could be overwhelmed by the drag on sales from the recession in Asia and the slowdowns appearing in Latin America, Europe and the United States.
Another problem awaits American steelmakers. Walter Carter, the steel analyst at Standard & Poor's/DRI, said 80 percent to 90 percent of American steel exports go to Latin America and Canada, where the dollar is far stronger than it is compared with the yen and the mark.
On the plus side, American companies with business abroad should show benefits soon. Gillette, which posted a decline in third-quarter earnings yesterday, said it expected the dollar's recent fall to lift earnings in the fourth quarter.
Kodak said this week that it expects a weaker dollar will actually lift its earnings 1 cent a share in the fourth quarter -- if the dollar stays where it was Sept. 30. It is already 14.4 percent below where it stood against the yen then -- and 3 percent below its rate against the mark -- meaning even better earnings news.
I.B.M., which reports earnings Tuesday, is another company that can catch a break, especially with the dollar now 16 percent less than the rate of 139 yen that the company considered a problem when it posted its second-quarter earnings in July.
"We put currency on the negative column, and it has the potential of remaining there for the rest of the year," Douglas Maine, I.B.M.'s chief financial officer, said then.
For company earnings, the dollar's strength is important when compared with its exchange rate in the corresponding quarter the year earlier. Beginning in 1999, those quarterly comparisons are looking very good -- even if the dollar doesn't weaken any more.
One reason for sharp swings in earnings is that many corporations do not hedge against currency fluctuations, partly because of the cost and, in some cases, because of bad experiences. Kodak was a leader in hedging in the 1980's but does not do significant hedging now.
On the other hand, Merck & Company has been doing long-term hedging for years "to insulate the company from periods when the dollar get stronger," said Judy C. Lewent, the drug maker's chief financial officer.
She called the dollar's plunge against the yen a positive for the company. At the same time, though, the increased volatility raises the costs of hedging now against a stronger dollar in the future.
For American auto manufacturers, the dollar's fall -- if it holds -- should be positive. David Bradley, an analyst at J. P. Morgan Securities, said that a third of the cars sold in the United States by Japanese auto makers are imported; of those made at plants here, he said, about a third of the parts are imported.
Auto makers, he said, are already telling analysts that they will cut their incentive programs back in the fourth quarter, in part because the weaker dollar will make it harder for the Japanese to match American prices. In Europe, he said, a weaker dollar will help make American sales there more valuable when they are translated back into dollars.
As for inflation, the dollar's fall is not expected to add much to import prices. Mr. Lipsky of Chase Manhattan said that the dollar's impact would be overshadowed by a worldwide slowdown in demand that should keep prices in check. Chase is forecasting that consumer inflation in the United States will fall to 1 percent next year.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Mixed Signals From the Fed;
If the Water's Fine, Why Are Those Sharks Still Circling?

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve Board's late-afternoon decision yesterday to cut two key interest rates by one-quarter of a point caught traders and investors in all the United States financial markets completely flat-footed. And even though the Dow Jones industrial average soared 330.58 points on the news, the fact that the move came between regularly scheduled meetings at the Fed only served to make already-battered bond investors more nervous than ever. If the Fed was aiming to increase the confidence of financial market participants, the cut did only half the job.
On one hand, the reduction in rates is positive because it clearly telegraphs the Fed's willingness to do what it can to stop a recession from rolling across America. Just after the Fed moved, William Dudley, economist at Goldman, Sachs, said: "Is the risk of recession higher or lower than an hour ago? Probably lower because the Fed is acting. They showed that they're not going to take any chances with the economy." 
 But an unintended consequence of the sudden cut in rates was increased investor anxiety that the worldwide financial crisis may be either closer to home or even worse than anyone but the highest-ranking Fed officials realize. Everyone wondered just what specter the Fed might see on the horizon that mere mortals still find invisible.
Certainly there has been nothing in the recent economic figures that indicated the need for an immediate and drastic move by the Fed. Yes, the United States economy is weakening. September retail sales, for instance, were disappointing, showing an increase of just one-tenth of a percent for the month, excluding auto sales. And the Commerce Department reported that sales at domestic businesses fell two-tenths of a percent in August, after declining one-tenth of a percent in July. Not great news, but not signs of an imminent recession either.
And so, while stock market investors raced to buy equities on the news, bond investors were left scratching their heads. Why did the Fed move at all and why did it move when it did?
The Fed explained itself this way: "Growing caution by lenders and unsettled conditions in financial markets more generally are likely to be restraining aggregate demand in the future." Translation: a credit shortage seems to be developing that could stop economic growth dead in its tracks.
Still, reducing rates between meetings of the Fed's Open Market Committee is unusual; it hasn't happened since April 1994. And, if the reason for the cuts was a possible credit contraction, then why were two of the Federal Reserve Bank presidents in the last two days on record saying the country was not experiencing such a shortage?
On Wednesday, the New York Federal Reserve Bank president, William J. McDonough, said that while he was concerned that the nation's largest banks were cutting back credit, he saw no signs that small and regional banks were doing so. And, yesterday, less than an hour before the Fed announced its cuts, the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond president, Alfred Broaddus, told a Washington & Lee University alumni gathering: "I don't think we're anywhere near a credit crunch at this stage."
Obviously others in the Federal Reserve system felt differently. As Charles W. Peabody, bank analyst at Mitchell Securities in New York, explains: "To get a discount rate cut, the Federal Reserve Bank presidents petition the Fed. They're obviously starting to worry about a domestic recession as they look out to 1999."
There is no disputing that many of the financial markets are frozen, and that the severe lack of liquidity could create additional dislocations like those seen recently at hedge funds run by Long-Term Capital Management, D. E. Shaw and Ellington Management. As Mr. Dudley points out, the Fed funds rate had been slightly above the Fed's target of 5.25 percent recently. "This shows that money is not moving freely in the money markets, that sand is in the wheels," he said. So, rather than wait four weeks to cut rates at its Nov. 17 policy-making meeting, the Fed acted to reassure investors and encourage them to get back into the pool. "We had a shark scare, and Fed is saying O.K. you can come back in," he said. "But nobody believes them."
The sudden cut in rates certainly puts to rest any conflict that may have existed among Fed members over monetary policy. As recently as this summer there was something of a schism within the Fed, with two non-Washington members holding out against rate cuts. No longer.
But the timing of yesterday's rate cut was intriguing on several other counts. First was the fact that the Fed decided to announce its move at 3:06 P.M., relatively late in the afternoon, while the stock market was open but the Treasury bond futures markets were closed. This is interesting because the futures markets -- the world's most liquid -- are where Treasury bond traders execute a large percentage of their trades. With this market closed, bond traders could not react to the Fed move as well as they could have if the rate cut had been announced at 2:15 P.M., as is typical.
Indeed, some traders speculated that the timing of the Fed's move appeared calculated to get a rise out of the stock market. Why? Because it was done late in the day before today's expiration of October equity options. And, if the Fed had moved while the bond futures market was still open, it ran the risk of a negative reaction from bond traders. This could have dampened stock traders' enthusiasm a bit.
In any case, after weeks of turmoil in the financial markets, it is clear that the Fed believes that a rate cut is needed to grease the wheels of the capital markets and get them whirring again. To do this, it must restore investor confidence, especially in all areas of the non-Treasury bond market.
After the Fed moved, some of these markets did react favorably. The difference between yields on Treasuries and other bonds with similar maturities narrowed, according to Steven Eisman, an analyst with CIBC Oppenheimer. For example, the spread between 10-year Treasury notes and the lowest-rated 10-year junk bonds narrowed by 5 basis points, or five one-hundredths of one percentage point, compared with levels at the end of last week. Over the same period, the spread between those Treasury notes and the better grade of junk bonds narrowed by 14 basis points, and the spread between Treasuries and top-quality corporate bonds narrowed by 13 basis points.
But it remains to be seen whether the one-quarter-point rate cut will be enough to stop the hemorrhaging at hedge funds and big brokerage firms and banks that own giant positions in troubled mortgage-backed securities, high-yield bonds and other non-Treasury debt and that have sold short corresponding Treasury securities. When the bond markets open today and traders absorb the full implications of yesterday's rate cut, it could be seen as exacerbating the problems at these already-hobbled firms.
And lower interest rates will make American stock and bond markets much less attractive to foreign investors, big buyers of United States financial assets in recent years. A declining American currency makes foreign investors less willing to hold United States stocks and bonds. The dollar closed yesterday just above its lows for the year against both the yen and the mark.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Stocks Surge InFinal Hour On Rate Cut

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
With stocks already rallying yesterday, a surprise interest-rate cut by the Federal Reserve touched off a huge final-hour surge that drove prices up more than 4 percent on all three major market gauges.
The Dow Jones industrials jumped nearly 380 points at its peak before settling back in the final minutes to close up 4.15 percent at 8,299.36. It was a gain of 330.58 points, the third-biggest point advance on record. 
 The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index surged 4.17 percent, or 41.96 points, to 1,047.49. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index rose 4.55 percent, or 70.04 points, to 1,611.01.
"The A team is on the case," said Richard B. Hoey, chief economist and head of stock research at the Dreyfus Corporation, referring to the Fed action and the Administration's apparent success in winning Congressional approval of its request to replenish the International Monetary Fund, the lender of last resort for numerous distressed world economies.
One of the likely beneficiaries is Brazil, where stocks surged 6.65 percent yesterday on improved prospects for a rescue package. Mexican stocks jumped 6.55 percent.
Banks were among the standout gainers in yesterday's surge, but it embraced nearly every industry, with 446 of the 500 stocks in the S.& P. index and 29 of the 30 Dow industrials -- all but Philip Morris -- posting gains.
Analysts saw the Fed action as driven mainly by a desire to put more cash in the nation's financial system, which has suffered recently from growing caution by lenders in the face of exposure to losses from emerging markets and hedge funds and the possibility that the economy could slide into recession.
Shares of American Express, J. P. Morgan, Citigroup, Chase Manhattan, Bankers Trust and Merrill Lynch were all sharply higher.
The Fed move was seen as insurance against a business downturn as well and the threat this would pose to corporate profits.
"When I see the Fed stepping up like this it makes me less inclined to forecast a recession," said James E. Glassman, senior United States economist at Chase Securities, who said that until this afternoon he had been "toying" with such a prediction.
Nevertheless, there seemed to be little euphoria among portfolio managers and little rush, except by traders, to pile into stocks.
"After a couple of days I think people will pause and reflect a little bit," predicted Hank Herrmann, chief investment officer at Waddell & Reed in Overland Park, Kan. "They're not just willy-nilly going to jump on the train."
Steven Goldman, market strategist at Weeden & Company, said market operators were still scarred from the "psychological damage" from this year's pummeling of many stocks and were unlikely to suddenly become exuberant.
But he did say that the Fed's reduction of the discount rate, as opposed to the Federal funds rate, is especially significant for the market.
Over the last half-century, the first such cut has been followed three months later by an 8 percent rise in the S.& P. index, with the gains expanding to 13.5 percent after six months and 19.5 percent after a year. On only 2 of 14 occasions did stocks fail to climb, Mr. Goldman said.
The jump in the Dow left the industrial average down 11.1 percent from its July 17 peak, but well above the 20 percent drop it flirted with just a week ago.
Shares of General Electric rose 4 3/8, to 82, contributing the most to the jump in the S.& P., followed by Microsoft, which was up 5 1/4, to 105 7/16 . Citigroup rose 4 3/16 , to 39 13/16 ; American International Group was up 8 3/16 , to 82 7/17 , and Coca-Cola, whose profits matched lowered expectations, jumped 3 1/8, to 67 1/2.
Airlines were very strong for a second day, with Delta Air Lines up 7, to 93 1/2, and UAL, the parent of United, and AMR, American's parent, up 4 3/4 and 4 3/8, respectively. General Motors, up 3 7/8, to 56 1/16 , paced a buoyant auto group in which Chrysler gained 3, to 46 1/2, and Ford Motor climbed 2 15/16 , to 48 3/4.
Drug stocks, which were among the best in resisting decline, took off yesterday, with Warner-Lambert up 5 1/4, to 76; Bristol-Myers Squibb up 4 3/16 , to 102 7/8; Schering-Plough up 4 1/8, to 99 3/8; Merck up 3 7/8, to 133 1/4, and Pfizer, whose sales of Viagra have cooled, up 1 3/4, to 97 3/4.
Until the Fed action, stocks had been been spurred by a growing belief that almost any likely negative development had already been factored into prices, including lower profits.
"The market is beginning to believe that third-quarter earnings are shaping up better than the Street has expected," said Peter Cardillo, equity strategist at Westfalia Investments.
On the New York Stock Exchange there were 2,467 issues that rose yesterday, while 682 declined and 386 finished unchanged. But new lows for the year still dwarfed new highs, by 111 to 32.
Volume was 937.6 million shares, trailing only the number that changed hands Sept. 1, when the record of 1.2 billion shares was set, and on two days last week.

HEADLINE: The Fed Acts

 BODY:
By suddenly cutting interest rates yesterday, the Federal Reserve sent a strong message that it is worried about the world economy and determined to prevent a world recession. It was the latest encouraging signal that officials around the world are no longer complacent about the financial storm.
Since the International Monetary Fund's annual meeting ended last week without any clear agreement to act, financial markets have continued to signal distress by increasing the interest rates that must be paid by riskier borrowers, whether they are American companies issuing junk bonds or Latin American nations trying to fund their operations in a hostile financial environment. 
 The Fed rightly decided that the cautious rate reduction it made Sept. 29 was not enough. With yesterday's cut, the rate that banks pay on loans to each other is down to 5 percent from 5.5 percent before the first move. That rate is still higher than market interest rates, and more moves may be needed. But policy makers are showing they can act.
Yesterday's move follows agreement in Japan on a bank rescue plan with enough money to make real progress in dealing with that nation's financial paralysis, although doubts remain about how it will be applied. The cut also came on the same day that Congress approved $18 billion for the I.M.F. A prime goal of world policy makers should be to keep Latin America from following in Asia's footsteps, a goal that seems more achievable with the I.M.F. now able to help Brazil.
Statements by Wim Duisenberg, the head of the new European Central Bank, that he saw no need for coordinated easing of monetary policy were disappointing, but Mr. Duisenberg also emphasized the need for a flexible policy. There is reason to hope that European policy makers will not remain on the sidelines if the situation worsens.
Financial markets soared in reaction to the unexpected rate cut, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising more than 240 points in just 45 minutes. That was an indication that investors did not see the action as a warning that the Fed knew of any imminent disaster, such as a pending financial failure, but rather as a sign of determination to help the global economy.

HEADLINE: Quarterly Profit Down at Gillette

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
The Gillette Company, the world's largest maker of razors and blades, said today that its third-quarter profit fell -- the first quarterly decline in eight years -- because of weak sales in Asia, slowing economies in Latin America and the rising dollar.
Gillette said third-quarter profit before a charge fell 19 percent, to $353 million, or 30 cents a share, from $437 million, or 38 cents, a year earlier. Gillette, which also makes Duracell batteries, Papermate pens and other products, was expected to earn 30 cents, the average estimate of analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation, a research firm in Boston. Sales fell 6.3 percent, to $2.53 billion from $2.70 billion. 
 Gillette, which gets a third of its revenue outside the United States and Western Europe, warned last month of the profit decline because of the drop in international sales, especially in Russia and Brazil. The recent introduction of the three-blade Mach 3 razor also raised marketing costs.
Gillette, which is based in Boston, announced the earnings after the close of New York trading. Its shares rose $2.25, to $42.625, as stocks generally soared.
A charge of $347 million, or 30 cents, for a revamping that includes cutting 4,700 jobs and closing dozens of plants and offices, resulted in net income slightly above break-even.
In a conference call with reporters, Gillette executives said they still expected an increase in fourth-quarter earnings per share in "low double digits."

HEADLINE: Clinton Urges Netanyahu And Arafat to Take Risks

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
President Clinton, promising his own intense involvement to secure agreement, today urged the Israeli and Palestinian leaders to "break the logjam" and take the risks required to provide new hope to their peoples.
Opening a four-day summit meeting between Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, Mr. Clinton warned that "too much time has already been lost" in the search for an interim accord that will provide the Palestinians an additional 13 percent of the West Bank in return for Palestinian steps to fight terrorism. 
 "Concessions that seem hard now will seem far less important in the light of an accord that moves Israelis and Palestinians closer to lasting peace," Mr. Clinton said in the White House Rose Garden, flanked by the two Middle East leaders.
This afternoon Mr. Clinton traveled to the Wye Conference Center near Queenstown, Md., on the eastern shore of the Chesapeake Bay, where Mr. Netanyahu and Mr. Arafat have agreed to be isolated in comfort, with their aides and American officials, in the hopes of finishing the interim deal, now long overdue.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright will continually be at the center. Mr. Clinton said he would go there as needed.
Although American and Israeli officials said much hard work remained, failure on a long-delayed interim accord would be embarrassing to President Clinton just before the Nov. 3 elections. More importantly it would leave the peace effort on the verge of collapse seven months before May 4, when the Israelis and Palestinians are supposed to have completed their final agreement.
Mr. Arafat has threatened to declare Palestinian statehood unilaterally if May 4 passes without a final settlement.
Mr. Netanyahu and Israel's opposition Labor Party have warned him against such a step.
But senior American officials acknowledged that Mr. Arafat had to have "something concrete" to point to by then, with talks on a final settlement proceeding well.
A main task at the talks in Maryland, the American officials said, in addition to finishing the interim agreement for the 13 percent Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank in return for specific Palestinian antiterrorism steps, is to find a way to avoid a more fundamental crisis in seven months.
If the interim deal can be achieved here, after more than 19 months of stalemate, talks on a permanent settlement will immediately restart.
Natan Sharansky, one of Mr. Netanyahu's closest advisers in the Cabinet, said in an interview today that "no date is sacred" and that it could take two years for a final settlement to be negotiated.
The chief Palestinian negotiator, Saeb Erekat, called that unacceptable. Mr. Sharansky tried to play down the stakes for the meeting here, saying Israel could not accept any agreement just to have one.
"We are coming to a summit where expectations are so high," he said. "Yet the most outstanding issues are not resolved. While what we in Israel have to give is clear, what we are to get is not."
The main issues for the Israelis are Palestinian steps to improve security, fight the radical Islamic Hamas movement and stop public and private "incitement" of violence against the Israelis.
An important part of the private violence issue, Mr. Sharansky said, is requiring a public change in the Palestinian charter to remove clauses calling for the destruction of Israel.
"I want it to be hard for Arafat," Mr. Sharansky said. "I want him to have to argue for such a change. To me the heart of the question is not the percentage of land we give, but to change the charter."
Mr. Netanyahu was cautious, saying, "We come with the best intentions and we hope that there will be an accord."
Mr. Arafat was optimistic. But he again mourned Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin's assassination by an Israeli extremist. He reminded Mr. Netanyahu, in a reiteration of their long argument about whether peace flows from security or vice-versa, that "peace is the most important platform for security, and he has to remember this and not to forget that some of his extremist gangsters have killed my partner Rabin."
The old arguments are a prime reason why American officials want to isolate the leaders from outsiders, in particular from the press, and force them to concentrate in secrecy on the hard bargaining needed for a deal. The Wye Center, set amid dense woods along the unspoiled Wye River some 70 miles from Washington, was the next best choice, and a far more elegant one, after the Israelis rejected the Presidential retreat at Camp David in the Maryland hills. Israeli officials did not want the comparison to the 1978 marathon sessions there that led to a peace treaty between Israel and Egypt.
This afternoon at the Wye Center, Mr. Clinton said that the Americans were "ready to do whatever we can." He urged all sides to focus on the talks only.
"Therefore we have agreed to confine our dealings with the media to periodic briefings to be conducted by spokespersons," he said.
But the spokesmen like James P. Rubin of the State Department have pledged to say as little as possible.
Mr. Sharansky joked that he was hesitating to enter the conference Center "because I'm afraid they won't let me out again."
But his presence, combined with the arrival on Friday of the new Foreign Minister, Ariel Sharon, and Defense Minister Yitzhak Mordechai, is a sign of Mr. Netanyahu's seriousness. The three figures make up the "kitchen cabinet" and must themselves agree if Mr. Netanyahu has any chance of getting a deal through his Cabinet.
Mr. Sharon and Mr. Mordechai remained in Israel an additional day for a commemoration of a famous tank battle in the 1973 war. Mr. Sharon will fly directly to Rochester, Minn., where King Hussein of Jordan is undergoing cancer treatment at the Mayo Clinic, for a visit before joining Mr. Netanyahu at the Wye Center.
But with the Israeli delegation unable to work after sundown on Friday because of the Sabbath, American officials acknowledge that the time is short for the breakthrough that Mr. Clinton and Ms. Albright want so badly.
Among the issues to be settled include a third shift of Israeli troops due under previous accords, a move quite likely to be settled by a panel on borders at the final-status talks after they have begun.
There are also arguments about how Palestinians will travel unhindered between the West Bank and Gaza, with the Israelis suggesting buses and even trains. The Palestinians insist on being able to travel in individual cars. An airport and an industrial park in Gaza are essentially settled, but security questions remain on a planned seaport.
The real danger of the summit meeting, said Stephen Cohen, vice chairman of the Center for Middle East Peace and Economic Cooperation, is that "everyone will settle for a very little thing that they call an agreement and that resolves nothing in the region." He urged Mr. Clinton "to aim high," saying, "A fairy-tale agreement about too little will not solve the problems."

HEADLINE: Clinton Officials Say I.M.F. Deal Expands Strategies to Halt Crisis

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
With the final agreement struck today in Congress to inject $18 billion into the depleted coffers of the International Monetary Fund, Clinton Administration officials said they now have more political leeway to attempt new strategies in fighting the continuing global financial turmoil.
For months the Administration has been warning that without an agreement with the Republican majority in the House to provide the added money to the monetary fund, the institution that has acted as the global financial firefighter would run out of water. In the end, perseverance won out. 
 With markets around the world coming unglued, the Republicans dropped a key demand that the fund complete revisions before it receive any of the new American cash.
The accord now paves the way for other nations to increase their contributions, and today the Administration projected that the fund's war chest would swell by $90 billion before the end of the year.
That, in turn, makes it possible for the fund to move ahead with a package of at least $30 billion in aid for Brazil, the world's ninth-largest economy and a critical American trading partner.
It will also give financial teeth to President Clinton's proposal, gradually being embraced by American allies, to set up multibillion dollar lines of credit within the I.M.F. to help nations combat economic contagion and defend their currencies before disaster strikes.
"This will substantially improve the I.M.F.'s capacity and our capacity to respond to and to prevent any escalation of the crisis," an Administration official said today, after days of negotiation that resulted in a list of changes for the fund.
White House officials said that the United States and its largest allies, who together account for 43 percent of the votes on the fund's board, had agreed on the need for many of the revisions that survived in the final legislation.
But it is far from clear that money alone will calm the turmoil. Billions in aid did little to stabilize Indonesia, and it did nothing to solve the political paralysis that grips Russia. In fact, Russia's default set off the latest round of capital flight that has led investors to pull their cash out of emerging markets around the globe, creating waves of financial instability.
That instability has since coursed through the American financial system, and contributed to the Federal Reserve's decision today to cut interest rates for the second time in less than three weeks.
The Fed's move was motivated largely by signs of growing distress in the domestic economy. At the same time, though, it offers Mr. Clinton a chance to argue that the United States is moving on two fronts: Lowering interest rates to spur growth around the globe, and playing a far more direct, aggressive role in preventing financial meltdowns before they occur.
But the entire strategy depended on winning an agreement with Congressional Republicans who portrayed the I.M.F. as incompetent and misguided, an "economic arsonist" in the words of the House majority leader, Dick Armey.
In private meetings in the last two weeks with Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, though, Mr. Armey took a far more conciliatory pose, according to Administration officials and Congressional aides who attended the meetings.
"The world has changed in the past few months," said one Administration official, referring to Russia's default on its debt and the subsequent panic among investors that has spread across the globe. "People sort of get it now that it is a bit scary out there."
The Administration's hope is that the mere act of refilling the fund's fuel tanks will infuse the markets with a bit more confidence that the world's lender of last resort can stay in business.
But the Administration is clearly considering taking steps that go beyond deploying the fund's resources.
There are more and more signals, for example, that once Congress is out of town Mr. Rubin may dip into an American fund under his control, called the Emergency Stabilization Fund, to provide some kind of backup financing for Brazil, in case money from the I.M.F., the World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank proves insufficient.
"We have excluded no options," a senior Treasury official said last week.
In return for the $18 billion, the Administration agreed to a series of conditions, including pressing for higher interest rates for major monetary fund loans, far greater disclosure of information about the economic conditions of member countries and the establishment of two advisory committees to monitor the fund and other elements of the global regulatory structure.
But the Administration was able to steer Republicans away from their first impulse: To make reform of the I.M.F. a condition of American financing. Instead, the Treasury Secretary has to certify that the Group of Seven industrial nations support the revisions, which would virtually assure their passage by the fund's board.
In Paris today, Michel Camdessus, managing director of the I.M.F., said he believed there would be little problem enacting the changes Congress sought, and said several -- especially the publication of more financial data about countries receiving the fund's aid -- had been in place for a year.
"The world needs to know that the I.M.F. has the resources it requires," Mr. Camdessus said. "I hope the rest of the world will all ratify in turn the increase in resources."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "FOR THE RECORD -- Funds for the I.M.F.: The Conditions"
 
After months of debate on Capitol Hill, House Republicans pared down their demands on the I.M.F. Here are the highlights:
 
Greater Public Disclosure
The Treasury will certify to Congress that the seven largest industrial nations, which control 43 percent of the votes on the I.M.F.'s board, will vote for the publication of agreements that the I.M.F. reaches with countries. It will also press for disclosure of the board's discussions, track records of I.M.F. programs and annual economic reviews of member countries.
 
Interest Rates
The U.S. will certify that it and its allies support an increase in interest rates to about 7 percent on I.M.F. loans. This would push countries to repay the I.M.F. quickly and refinance their loans privately.
 
Social Impact
The U.S. will use its "voice and vote" to study the effects of I.M.F. loans on the poor, on the working class and on labor standards.
 
Review of I.M.F.
A congressional advisory committee will review global financial structures.The Treasury will also create an advisory committee on the I.M.F.
 
Reporting Requirements
The Treasury will make a detailed evaluation of I.M.F. operations in a report to Congress.
 
Competition With American Industry
In South Korea, the Treasury will certify that I.M.F. funds are not subsidizing those industries that compete with American manufacturers.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
FEDERAL RESERVE CUTS RATES AGAIN; WALL ST. SURGES

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve unexpectedly cut interest rates today, warning that a growing wave of fear among investors and lenders was threatening to derail the nation's long economic expansion.
The cut, by one-quarter of a percentage point, was the first time in four and a half years that the central bank had changed interest rate policy outside one of its regularly scheduled meetings. Stunned, Wall Street responded with a powerful rally, sending stock prices up more than 330 points, with investors brushing aside concerns about a possible credit squeeze and market instability. 
 Although economists had become increasingly convinced that the Federal Reserve would cut rates at its two remaining meetings this year, the unusual timing of today's move suggested that the central bank sees the economic outlook deteriorating as the financial crisis that began last year in Asia hits the United States even harder. Page C1.
The channel through which the domestic economy is being most affected, moreover, has been a headlong flight by investors from any hint of risk, a psychological shift that can be difficult for policy makers to control and counter.
Acting on his own authority after consulting by telephone with members of the Fed's policy-making committee, Alan Greenspan, the chairman, reduced the Federal funds target for the overnight lending rate between banks by a quarter-point, to 5 percent. The cut was intended to encourage more lending and to bolster the economy by making it cheaper for businesses and consumers to borrow. The Fed had cut the target rate by a quarter-point at its last regular meeting 16 days ago.
The central bank's board also approved a quarter-point reduction in the discount rate on loans from the Federal Reserve to banks. The cut, to 4.75 percent, was the first change in the largely symbolic discount rate since January 1996.
"Growing caution by lenders and unsettled conditions in financial markets more generally are likely to be restraining aggregate demand in the future," the Federal Reserve said in a statement, referring to the likelihood of a slowdown. "Against this backdrop, further easing of the stance of monetary policy was judged to be warranted to sustain economic growth in the context of contained inflation."
Several banks quickly reduced their prime rates on loans to their best customers, setting off a cycle that could lead to slightly lower rates on credit cards, auto loans and other loans to consumers. While the Federal Reserve's action does not directly affect mortgage rates, which have been creeping up from very low levels, it could help push them back down by putting pressure on the long-term rates set in the bond market. The Fed disclosed its action in a news release at 3:15 P.M., just after President Clinton and Republican leaders in Congress announced that they had reached a budget agreement.
The interest rate cut sent stock prices soaring around the world. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 330.58, its third-biggest point gain ever, to close at 8,299.36, its highest level since Aug. 26.
Bond prices also surged. The dollar, which has been sliding sharply against the Japanese yen, fell again.
Economists said the rate reduction was justified by recent signs that the economy, which had been humming along through much of this year at a healthy if somewhat slower pace, was beginning to lose steam and could even lapse into recession next year.
But the abruptness of the reduction led to widespread questions about whether the Fed was acting to head off an as-yet-unpublicized problem at a financial institution or investment fund that might further damage the already-fragile market psychology. The markets have been especially skittish since the near-collapse last month of Long-Term Capital Management L.P., the prominent hedge fund.
"Whenever the Fed does something out of the ordinary, it makes you wonder, and the first thing that comes to mind is whether there is some other financial market land mine out there," said Paul L. Kasriel, an economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. "Obviously they felt a need to move that couldn't wait a month. It's a bit of a mystery."
There were no immediate signs of any bank or investment firm running into deep trouble. But Mr. Greenspan and other policy makers in Washington have been fretting in public for the last week about how the crisis of confidence has affected even the safest haven, the market for United States Treasury securities.
For the last several months, investors worldwide have been dumping stocks and bonds almost indiscriminately and putting their money into Treasury bonds. But in recent weeks economists have noticed that within the Treasury market investors are increasingly buying only the newest issues, which tend to trade most readily, and avoiding older issues, for which there is a less liquid market.
As Mr. Greenspan pointed out in a speech last week, investors are therefore demanding not just safety in their investments but the ability to sell them instantaneously. The development was a troublesome sign, Mr. Greenspan suggested, because companies are already having trouble raising money in the stock and bond markets and banks are showing signs of pulling back on new lending.
If their access to money dried up, businesses would have to cut back on their investments in new technology and equipment, which have driven much of the economy's growth in recent years.
"There was a serious threat emerging," James Glassman, an economist at Chase Securities, said. "What is now a Wall Street problem threatened to become a Main Street problem. What the Fed is doing now makes me less pessimistic about the risks next year."
For much of this year the Fed debated whether it needed to raise interest rates to head off the possibility that the combination of steady growth and very low unemployment would set off a wage and price spiral. Last spring, Mr. Greenspan held off pressure from the Fed's inflation hawks for a rate increase. And when the financial crisis that began last year in Asia rolled through Russia this summer, creating a sense of near-panic among investors, he began laying the groundwork for a rate cut and followed through with a quarter-point reduction on Sept. 26.
In moving today, more than a month before the next scheduled Fed meeting on Nov. 17, Mr. Greenspan again asserted his power at the Fed, sweeping aside any remaining objections from colleagues who think rate cuts could backfire if the economy proves more resilient than it appears. Eight of the 12 Federal Reserve banks requested the cut in the discount rate.
It is unclear whether Mr. Greenspan had specifically requested the authority from the policy-making committee to cut rates another quarter-point before the next meeting.
Mr. Greenspan had room to move, though, precisely because there have been so few signs of inflation in the economy. Although the Government reported today that the prices paid by producers for finished goods rose three-tenths of a percent in September, the biggest rise in a year, economists said that the increase came largely from jumps in automobile and vegetable prices and that there were no signs of price increases in earlier stages of the production process.
The Federal Reserve's action came against a backdrop of efforts by policy makers around the world to bring the financial crisis under control. Japan took a big step this week toward addressing the problems that have paralyzed its banking system, agreeing on a plan to spend up to $500 billion to shore up ailing institutions.
And today, Congress came to a final agreement with the Clinton Administration on new money for the International Monetary Fund, which is assembling a package of financial aid for Brazil. Pressure is growing on Germany's powerful central bank to consider a rate cut; Britain and Spain have both cut rates in the last week.
"It's like a global United Way pledge drive," Mr. Kasriel said.
Some analysts said the rate cuts by the Fed would not have as powerful a stimulative effect on the domestic economy as they would under normal circumstances. That is because the long-term rates set in the markets are already relatively low and the most interest-sensitive sectors of the economy, especially housing, are already booming.
But they said the rate cuts were clearly driving down the dollar's value, especially against the Japanese currency. The fall in the dollar, they said, would help make American goods somewhat more competitive on international markets, giving a slight boost to the economy. And to the extent that the weakening dollar increases the relative value of the yen, it will help inject more confidence into the moribund Japanese economy and avert further devaluations by other Asian countries.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

In a Surprise Move, Fed Reduces Interest Rates
After consulting with members of the Federal Reserve policy-making committee, Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, unexpectedly cut interest rates by one-quarter of a percentage point. The move came against a backdrop of growing fear among investors and lenders that the nation's economic expansion is slowing. 
 The action was the first time in four and a half years that the central bank changed interest rate policy outside of one its normally scheduled meetings. It stunned Wall Street, which responded with a powerful rally that sent the Dow Jones industrial average up more than 330 points. Page A1.
 
Treasury bond prices surged after the interest rate cut. The yield on the 30-year bond fell to 4.97 percent, from 5.03 percent. C4.
 
Merrill Demotes Head of Risk Unit
Merrill Lynch demoted the executive in charge of managing the firm's financial risk taking, two days after the brokerage firm announced a steep quarterly loss related to turmoil in stock and bond markets. C3.
 
Zapata Halts Its Expansion Plan
Zapata, which said it would become the No. 1 site on the Internet by buying up dozens of small Web sites, is backing off that plan and evaluating its on-line strategy because of the decline in Internet stocks. C2.
 
$1.7 Trillion Budget Deal Approved
President Clinton and Congress reached agreement on the final portion of the nation's $1.7 trillion budget, the first in three decades brought forth with a surplus and one that offers the biggest peacetime increase in military spending since 1985. A1.
 
With the final deal struck in Congress to inject $18 billion into the depleted coffers of the International Monetary Fund, the Clinton Administration said it now had more political leeway to attempt new strategies in fighting the continuing global financial turmoil. A8.
 
Producer Prices Moved Higher
Higher costs for new cars and trucks pushed up the prices paid to producers in September at the fastest rate in a year, a statistical fluke that analysts said did not portend a lasting acceleration of inflation. C8.
 
 
U.S. Loses World Trade Group Case
The World Trade Organization has ruled that the United States is not evenhandedly applying a law that bans certain shrimp imports, while saying that the law itself does not violate international trade rules. C8.
 
Delta Earnings Surpass Estimates
Delta Air Lines reported quarterly earnings that easily surpassed Wall Street's estimates. Delta, the country's third-largest airline, said net income rose 29 percent, to $327 million, or $4.16 a diluted share, compared with $254 million, or $3.26 a share, in the period a year earlier. Analysts estimated that the carrier would earn $3.90 a share. Delta's shares leaped $7, to $93.50. C3.
 
Coca-Cola earned $888 million, or 36 cents a diluted share, in line with estimates. C2.
 
Proposal to Simplify Disclosure
The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed rules to let public companies sell their stocks and bonds more quickly and cheaply as part of a move to simplify corporate finance disclosure. The proposal would cut paperwork and streamline how large companies disclose financial information when registering for secondary stock offerings. C22.

INTERNATIONAL A3-13
 
NATO Warning to Milosevic On Kosovo Withdrawal
NATO told President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia that he has until tomorrow to reduce his forces in Kosovo or face a renewed threat of air strikes, though it looked increasingly unlikely that such a threat will be carried out. A1 

Clinton Opens Mideast Summit
President Clinton opened a four-day summit in Maryland between Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat. Promising his own intense involvement and the authority of the United States behind a Middle East peace agreement, Mr. Clinton urged the Israeli and Palestinian leaders to "break the logjam" and take the risks required to provide hope to their peoples. A8
 
A group of ultranationalist Jews established a beachhead for new conflict in East Jerusalem, occupying a vacant house in the heart of a Palestinian neighborhood. Asserting that the house was an old Sephardic synagogue, they planted an Israeli flag on the roof and carted in an ark and a Torah. A8
 
Pope Issues Encyclical
Pope John Paul II issued an encyclical that denounced the "fateful separation" of faith and reason in modern times and set out a Christian alternative to the dominant philosophies of the 20th century -- post-Enlightenment rationalism, Marxism and "postmodern" nihilism. A1
 
U.S. Money for the I.M.F.
Clinton Administration officials said they had more political leeway to try new strategies in fighting the continuing global financial turmoil, now that Congress has agreed to inject $18 billion into the depleted coffers of the International Monetary Fund. A8
 
March in Paris Turns Violent
High school students flooded the streets of France again in a two-week-old campaign for more teachers and better schools. The march in Paris turned violent when troublemakers looted stores, burned cars and clashed with riot police. The police arrested at least 110 youths. Five people, including two policemen, were injured. A3
 
Deal on U.N. Dues Falters
A deal that would have allowed the United States to pay $200 million in back dues to the United Nations as part of the overall Federal budget agreement collapsed after the issue became entangled once again in the politics of abortion, Clinton Administration and Congressional officials said. A5
 
Man With Someone Else's Hand
The world's only person with somebody else's fingerprints is expected to leave a French hospital with the transplanted hand and forearm he received there three weeks ago, his doctors said. The patient, Clint Hallam of Australia, underwent the experimental operation after he lost his right hand in an accident with a circular saw in a jail in New Zealand in 1984. A13
 
World Briefing A11
 
NATIONAL A16-25
 
Capitol and White House Reach Deal on Budget
President Clinton and Congress reached agreement on the nation's $1.7 trillion budget that included the biggest peacetime increase in military spending since Ronald Reagan was President in 1985. Other provisions include money to begin hiring 100,000 elementary teachers and to offer relief for farmers, and $2 billion for medical research at the National Institutes of Health. There is also money for American peacekeeping troops in Bosnia, the tightening of embassy security and the shoring up of depleted I.M.F. reserves. The bill, which Congress is expected to adopt today, also adds money to develop a plan to combat bioterrorism. Federal health plans will have to provide contraceptive coverage for Federal workers, but plans can exempt themselves on religious grounds, and doctors and nurses can exempt themselves on moral grounds. A1
 
Most of the more than $1 billion for new teachers will be given to districts based on need. A25
 
The fight over statistical sampling in the 2000 census was postponed until the Supreme Court rules. A16
 
The White House said it won an additional $476 million for programs involving climate change, water quality and conservation lands, while Republicans won provisions to spend millions more on items like logging and transportation in Alaska. A25
 
About $9 billion will be added to the military budget, including about $2 billion for intelligence programs and $1 billion for missile defense. A25
 
The deal will let 49,000 Haitian refugees stay in the United States legally, increase the number of specialized foreign workers and earmark $171 million to reduce the backlog of citizenship applications. A25
 
Jones Deal Hits a Snag
A financial package intended to settle the Paula Jones lawsuit appeared to fall victim to feuding among her lawyers and Abe Hirschfeld, who had offered Ms. Jones $1 million to withdraw her case. A18
 
Warning on Hepatitis C
Thousands of people will soon receive letters warning that they may have caught the liver virus hepatitis C from transfusions before 1992. A21
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-10
 
Trump Starts a New Tower To Loom Over the U.N.
Donald J. Trump is starting work on what he says will be the tallest residential building in the world, a $360 million, 861-foot, bronze-colored monolith near the United Nations complex. The project, called the Trump World Tower, has rankled some residents, who worry about its effect on the neighborhood. B1
 
Absentee Ballots in Jeopardy
Thousands of New York City voters could lose the chance to vote in the Nov. 3 election because the court battle over a referendum on Yankee Stadium has delayed the printing of absentee ballots, the president of the Board of Elections said. B1
 
Missing Boy Found With Sitter
A 6-year-old Brooklyn boy with cerebral palsy was found unharmed sitting in a car with his former baby sitter near Richmond, Va. The police said the woman, who was arrested, had taken the child in hope of finding a spiritual healer for him. She faces Federal kidnapping charges. B3
 
Arrests in Derelict-Car Scheme
Two dozen sanitation workers in Brooklyn were arrested and accused of using the city's derelict-vehicle program as a ruse to steal hundreds of perfectly good cars. B3
 
City to Pay U.S. $9.5 Million
New York City will pay the Federal Government $9.5 million to settle charges that the city billed Medicare for providing ambulance service to patients who did not need it. B2

BUSINESS DAY C1-22
 
Fed Abruptly Cuts Rates Again
The Federal Reserve unexpectedly cut interest rates by one-quarter of a percentage point, warning that a growing wave of fear among investors and lenders was threatening to derail the nation's long economic expansion. The unusual timing of the action, which was taken outside one of its regularly scheduled meetings, suggested that the central bank sees the economic outlook deteriorating as the Asian financial crisis hits the United States even harder. A1
 
The Fed's action touched off a huge final-hour surge that drove prices up more than 4 percent on the three major market gauges. The Dow gained 330.58 points, to 8,299.36; the S.& P. 500 rose 41.96 points, to 1,047.49, and the Nasdaq climbed 70.04 points, to 1,611.01. Congressional approval of new money for the International Monetary Fund also figured in the rally, experts said. C1
 
Health Giant Claims Conspiracy
Columbia/HCA Healthcare sued one of its former top financial officers and several vendors, accusing them of engaging in a conspiracy over seven years that defrauded the company of millions of dollars. C1

South Africa's largest and best-known company, the Anglo American, said it would reorganize and switch its stock exchange listing and headquarters to London from Johannesburg. C1

HEADLINE: So Many Fans, So Few Tickets;
A Long Line, but Most Series Seats Go to the Connected

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD 

 BODY:
Whether you were one of the true die-hards who could recite the batting averages of even the Yankees' minor league players or someone still unaware that there is a position known as designated hitter, there was passionate unity yesterday in trying to achieve a nearly impossible goal: getting tickets to the World Series.
At 1 P.M. at Yankee Stadium, after a quiz-show-type drama involving plastic wristbands and numbered baseballs plucked out of gym bags, the few thousand tickets ceded to the public went on sale for this weekend's Games 1 and 2. But far more of the tickets were in the grip of corporations, season-ticket holders and scalpers, and throughout the city, New Yorkers mounted frenzied campaigns through every conceivable connection to acquire the most coveted prize in town. 
 Rarely has the gulf between supply and demand been so enormous. The supply is about 57,000. The demand is about 8 million.
There is nothing at all egalitarian about the ticket distribution. The way these things always go, relatively few of the rabid, shout-out-your-lungs fans who have eaten the hot dogs and swilled the beer and rooted for the Yankees week in and week out during the regular season will be inside the stadium for the Series, which begins tomorrow night.
In fact, the seating capacity of Yankee Stadium is just under 57,000. The number of tickets sold to the public yesterday was supposed to have been about 5,000 per game, one-third as many as were sold two years ago when the Yankees last competed in the World Series, and at double the prices. The algorithm that accounts for where the missing seats went was beyond the capacity of baseball fans, who have no problem computing slugging percentages.
Many of this year's seats will go to the roughly 15,000 part- and full-season Yankee ticket holders. Major League Baseball parcels out the rest among the other big-league teams; baseball's national corporate sponsors and licensees; the networks with broadcasting contracts; the Baseball Writer's Association, and the National and American League offices.
Why were the Yankees selling 10,000 fewer seats per game to the public? The explanation by team officials was that there were about the same number of season-ticket holders as two years ago, but that more are full-season ticket holders who are entitled to buy twice as many seats as they hold. And they said that sponsor commitments had multiplied.
The most visible manifestation of the ticket mania was outside Yankee Stadium. People camped on the asphalt outside the stadium for more than a day, enduring rain and cold and raucous sleeping conditions, in the hope of getting seats. Thousands left with little more than sore backs and the prospect of another World Series in front of the television.
Starting at 7 A.M. yesterday, wristbands with four-digit numbers on them were handed out to the people in line, until 5,000 bracelets had been distributed. They were numbered from 5000 to 9999. The supply was exhausted by 10 A.M., with several thousand people left empty-wristed.
At 12:30, four Yankee gym bags filled with baseballs numbered from 0 to 9 were arrayed in front of Joe Torre, the Yankee manager. With circus music playing in the background, he pulled one ball from each bag, and those formed the number for who got first shot at tickets. It was 7427. Whoever had No. 7428 would go second, then 7429 and so forth. Everyone with a bracelet was expected to be entitled to buy two tickets to either of the first two games against the San Diego Padres. As it turned out, however, the tickets ran out well before everyone got to the window.
Damon Sebastian -- a 46-year-old chef from the Upper West Side whose wristband was 6734, putting him 4,306th in order to buy tickets -- said the ticket windows ran out of seats just before 7 P.M., when he was still a few hundred feet from the window. This suggests that more than 700 people with wristbands never got tickets and that the stadium might have sold considerably fewer than it had estimated it would.
"This is a big sham," Mr. Sebastian said, incensed. "Nobody's math could be that bad. There are kids here crying and everything." He said that he had been at the stadium since 7:35 Wednesday morning. "That's 30 hours taken out of my life," he said.
No. 7427 was on the wrist of Jim McDaniel, 26, a telemarketer from Haddon Heights, N.J., who had arrived at the stadium around 2:30 A.M. yesterday with three friends. He bought seats in the tier boxes almost directly behind home plate. He said he was going to take his father. "He doesn't know I'm up here," he said. "I can't believe I'm actually going to get tickets."
The first person in line was the much-interviewed Michael Ansolone, 21, from Stony Point, N.Y. His bracelet carried a heartsick number: 6956. That meant he would be the 4,528th person to buy tickets. But before he got to the window, the tickets were gone. He had called his job and contrived a story about a stomach virus. "I don't think I'd go through this again," he said.
Among the unlucky were Daisy Larson, a secretary from Brooklyn, and her husband, Michael Soto, who has metal rods in his back and can't sit for long. "I was trying," she said. "I got up at 4:30 and we left the house at 5:30." When they got to the stadium, the line was 11 blocks long. "I'm not ashamed to say I cried today," she said.
Considerable vitriol was exchanged about how few tickets were allotted for the ordinary fan. "I've been a Yankee fan since I was 13," said Jim Boggs, who works for Coca-Cola and drove two and a half hours from Somers Point, N.J. "Nine thousand tickets for the general public for two games. That's completely outrageous."
Anthony Ricucci, 24, who lives in the Bronx, said: "I'm a financial consultant trainee at a big brokerage firm. There's people in my company who got tickets because they know somebody, and they don't even want to go, and they're selling them for $600 or $1,000 apiece. I don't have that kind of money."
In these days of no inflation, ticket prices for the Series are up more than 100 percent. They are $150 for a box seat, $100 for reserved seats and $40 for the bleachers, compared with $70, $45 and $25 for the 1996 Series. In looking at other professional sporting events, Major League Baseball said it had concluded that World Series prices were undervalued.
Ticket brokers and scalpers were already advertising choice seats at prices edging into the thousands of dollars. Two brokers contacted from classified ads in The New York Post said they had tickets priced as high as $2,500. The brokers, who refused to give their names, said they got the tickets from various sources, including contacts at the stadium and people hired to stand in line. The police said that during the playoffs, scalpers brought in people from homeless shelters in New Jersey to wait in line. In 1996, counterfeit tickets also made it onto the market.
Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco's office said yesterday that its undercover investigators bought divisional playoff tickets from brokers at inflated prices and that it was going to announce legal action against at least two brokers as early as today. Investigators are now pursuing World Series tickets.
David Corvette, a spokesman for Mr. Vacco, said season-ticket holders and "diggers," the people paid to stand in line, could not account for the volume and quality of the tickets that brokers are pushing. He said investigators were looking into the possibility of "ice" -- money being paid to stadium insiders who are selling tickets being held for V.I.P.'s and players' wives.
Despite a heavy police presence at Yankee Stadium yesterday, dozens of scalpers, most of them teen-agers organized in roving bands, were doing business, both selling and trying to buy seats. To elude capture, they exchanged tickets away from the street, according to fans who said they encountered scalpers in the bowling alley facing the stadium, in coffee shops and even in a portable toilet outside a parking lot on 157th Street. There was considerable bargaining. One scalper offered a box seat for $1,000, then quickly came down to $400 apiece for two seats.
Tickets for Games 6 and 7, if they are necessary, are to be sold only through Ticketmaster beginning tomorrow at 1 P.M. The three middle games are in San Diego.
It is a matter of religious faith among prominent, well-connected New Yorkers that they can get anything with one phone call, two at the outside. And so throughout the city, people were working every network they knew to find their own tickets, many without luck.
For certain people, the pitches and runs are less important than their friends knowing that they were at the game. A 21-year-old designer of computer networks, who would give his name only as John, was shopping yesterday at Cigar Landing, a store in the Morgan Stanley building in Times Square. He said he had managed to land two box tickets on the third-base side for tomorrow's game. He said he paid $750 apiece to a broker. Why? "I like to do it because there are so many people who can't," he said.
A logical person to pester in these desperate hours is Howard Rubenstein, the New York public relations man who is a spokesman for George M. Steinbrenner 3d, the Yankees' principal owner. "I must have had 150 calls between yesterday and today," he said. "From clients, media, people I haven't spoken to in 10 years."
Someone from the theater industry called Mr. Rubenstein and promised seats to an impossibly sold-out show in return for Series tickets. Someone who was involved in treating Mr. Rubenstein's bad back not long ago phoned from a hospital.
There was one answer: Sorry. Mr. Rubenstein does have a suite at Yankee Stadium that holds 26. As he did for the last World Series, he plans to invite media people. But no clients.
Another popular fellow was Rick Cerrone, the Yankees' spokesman. He has a message on his answering machine warning callers that if they are inquiring about tickets, he doesn't have any. It has had negligible effect. He is making a great many apparent new friends and renewing countless long-lapsed acquaintances. As Mr. Cerrone put it, "It's such a coincidence that people pick October to call you and see how you're doing."

HEADLINE: Holdover From Solid South Tries to Defy G.O.P.'s Tide

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: GREENVILLE, S.C., Oct. 14

 BODY:
He is, quite simply, the last of his kind.
Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina, his hair so white that it emits a translucent glow, is the only Southern Democrat of his era remaining in a chamber once distinguished by the breed. For 32 years, he has survived by knowing which backs to slap, which arms to twist and which chits to call in the service of winning highway funds and military appropriations for a desperately needy state. 
 For most of that period, South Carolinians were grateful for any morsels dropped from Washington's table. But South Carolina, like the rest of its region, has been transformed over the years, from a dependent economy into an assertive one, and from a Democratic stronghold into a Republican fortress.
As the 76-year-old Mr. Hollings runs for re-election to a sixth full term, the question is whether the state he has served for 50 years -- as legislator, Lieutenant Governor, Governor and Senator -- will finally leave him behind. Other than the Comptroller General, Mr. Hollings is the only statewide-elected Democrat left in South Carolina.
And thus this year's Senate campaign between Mr. Hollings and his Republican opponent, Representative Bob Inglis, serves as something of a referendum on whether any role remains in the state, and in the South, for a party that went all but unchallenged in the early days of Mr. Hollings's career.
There are now 7 Democrats in the Senate from the 11 states of the old Confederacy, down from 16 in 1980.
"So much rides on this race as far as the South is concerned," said Charles W. Dunn, a Clemson University political scientist. "If the Democrats can't save this seat, what seat can they save and how can they recruit candidates? If Hollings loses, it's almost like Sherman has finished his march."
Polls show the race to be tight, with Mr. Hollings holding a slight lead of 49 percent to 42 percent in a Mason-Dixon survey taken two weeks ago. While political analysts generally commend Mr. Hollings's campaign strategy and work ethic, they note that the Senator failed to put his underfinanced opponent away in September, when he had the advertising airwaves to himself.
They also said that the outcome could be influenced by a number of outside forces. In the race for governor, a surprisingly competitive effort by Jim Hodges, the Democratic challenger to Gov. David M. Beasley, seems to be exciting the Democratic base, a benefit to Mr. Hollings. But Mr. Inglis, a member of the Judiciary Committee who has demanded President Clinton's resignation, may be aided by strong sentiment in South Carolina about the White House sex scandal.
The choice for South Carolinians could not be starker. While Mr. Hollings is best known for his commitment to deficit reduction, he remains an advocate of Federal activism in areas like education, housing and the arts. Mr. Inglis, on the other hand, typifies the South's new Republicanism and its anti-Government leanings.
At 39, Mr. Inglis, a three-term Congressman, is barely half Mr. Hollings's age. He is a father of five who sleeps on an air mattress in his Congressional office. While Mr. Hollings hails from Charleston, the static old seaport of elegant homes and Democratic faith, Mr. Inglis represents the burgeoning Greenville-Spartanburg metropolitan area, which is infused with new foreign investment and fervent Christian conservatism.
Mr. Hollings speaks in a mumbled, sometimes unintelligible drawl, and his acerbic wit has produced a compendium of impolitic comments. The bookish, bespectacled Mr. Inglis, by contrast, reveals virtually no accent and lectures with the measured deliberateness of an economics professor.
While Mr. Hollings campaigns on his ability to get things done, Mr. Inglis rejects the very premise of pork barrel politics and has shaped his campaign around the preachy theme of "principle over politics."
Mr. Inglis has hindered his own campaign by refusing to accept contributions from political action committees, limiting his projected budget to about $2 million, a third less than Mr. Hollings has already spent. And in a state with more seniority in the Senate than any in history -- 74 years between Mr. Hollings and his 95-year-old colleague, Strom Thurmond -- Mr. Inglis argues that tenure counts for little in today's Republican Congress. He has vowed to serve only two terms, just as he promised to serve only three in the House.
"If principle doesn't win in politics, then I'm not very interested in winning," he said in an interview. "Before, we were the redheaded stepchild of the nation and we needed anything we could get to lift us out of this desperate poverty we were in. Now what South Carolinians are realizing is they that prefer free enterprise opportunity to a Government guarantee."
Where was the value of seniority, Mr. Inglis asked, when the Federal Government recently closed military bases in Charleston and Myrtle Beach and eliminated thousands of jobs at the Savannah River Site nuclear plant?
"It's not an attack on the Senator's effectiveness," he said, noting that the Pentagon's base closure commission has usurped the seniority spoils system. "It's not that he was asleep at the switch. It's that the world has changed, for the better."
Mr. Hollings, the highest-ranking Democrat on the Commerce Committee and one of the most senior members on Appropriations, scoffs at this notion. The value of seniority, he said, can be seen in his ability to place other Federal agencies at the Charleston base after the Navy withdrew.
Furthermore, Mr. Hollings said in a debate in Greer on Tuesday night that Mr. Inglis will be "a lame duck by the time he gets up there with this silly term limits thing."
"He won't even get a good committee," the Senator said. "He won't be a voice. He'll be hardly a whisper from South Carolina."
After listing a number of interstate highway projects that he helped secure for South Carolina, Mr. Hollings added: "He continues to call it pork. This is Government. This is the way it works."
Indeed, Mr. Inglis has crusaded against pork, a sustaining staple of South Carolina politics, with both his words and his votes. In the House, he opposed Federal financing for an interstate highway connector in his home district and for a badly needed bridge in Charleston. He did so, he said, because the money was being earmarked for politically influenced projects that bypassed the state's priority list. Instead, a toll road is being built to connect the Interstates in Greenville, prompting Mr. Hollings to refer to his opponent as "Toll Road Bob."
Mr. Inglis's stands may seem noble to those who do not spend rush hours stalled on Interstate 385, said Marc T. Belk, a store manager in Greenville who confronted Mr. Inglis at a campaign stop here this week. "This fellow here is going to Washington and voting against our interests," Mr. Belk said. "He's like the guy in fourth grade who reminded the teacher when she didn't collect the homework."
If South Carolinians perceive Mr. Inglis as moralistic, he does not seem to mind. His strategy centers on making the campaign a referendum on Mr. Hollings, and if his style draws a contrast with that of the tart-tongued incumbent, all the better.
Mr. Inglis regularly asserts that South Carolinians should expect more civility from their representatives. He travels the state in a red motor home emblazoned with the slogan: "Finally, someone's listening!" His aides at headquarters answer the telephone by saying, "It's a great day at Inglis for Senate." At the debate in Greer, as at most appearances, Mr. Inglis said that South Carolinians should "expect a senator to be civil to you, expect him to listen, expect him not to denigrate you, not to humiliate you."
Such comments are a reference to Mr. Hollings's reputation for aloofness and arrogance. To reinforce that point, the State Republican Party recently broadcast an advertisement that included footage of Mr. Hollings giving a speech on election night in 1992. Thinking that he had run his last race, and perhaps bruised by his narrow victory margin of three percentage points, Mr. Hollings blurted: "I don't have to get elected to a blooming thing. And I don't have to do things that are politically correct. The hell with everybody." Then he added: "I'm free at last."
Six years later, Mr. Hollings cannot seem to mask his indignation at being challenged by Mr. Inglis, whom he dismisses as a hypocrite. And in recent days, the Senator has played willingly into Mr. Inglis's strategy. In an interview on Wednesday with The Herald of Rock Hill, S.C., Mr. Hollings mocked Mr. Inglis as "so oozing and goozing and such a nice little choirboy and so pleasant, and everybody's rude, and he wants to be courteous. He is a goddamn skunk. I can tell you that right now."
Mr. Inglis responded: "I guess he's right about me being a choirboy. That's not my style to use that kind of language."
Mr. Hollings is capable of joking about his style, telling a big crowd at a Democratic fish fry in Fair Lawn on Monday night that he and his wife, Peatsy, get along so well because they are "both in love with the same fella." But he also said in an interview that his arrogance pales compared to Mr. Inglis's.
"Here's a fellow that rode in on the Christian right in the big wave we had in '92, done nothing for anybody and all of a sudden he's going to change and give us a new setup," Mr. Hollings said. "Now if you talk about arrogance, egads. I can be a little arrogant, but he's big arrogant. He wins first prize on arrogance."
Defiantly unreconstructed to the end, Mr. Hollings said he was running one more time to stem the Republican tide. On Nov. 3, voters will decide whether his era will end on his own terms.
