HEADLINE: THE 1998 CAMPAIGN: THE INCUMBENT;
Pataki Calls Political Financing 'Dreadful,' but Has No Solution

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
New York State's campaign finance system is "dreadful" and ought to be overhauled, Gov. George E. Pataki said in an interview this week, but he suggested that any real reform would be difficult to achieve and refused to detail what changes he might want to make.
In an hourlong interview on Thursday with editors, reporters and executives of The New York Times, Mr. Pataki did say he would like to change the system in a second term, but not precisely how. "I have some thoughts, but I don't want to talk about them," he said. Moments later, he appeared to retreat from that statement, insisting, "I do not have a plan." 
 Throughout the interview, Mr. Pataki, who is running for re-election, dwelled on the accomplishments of his first term, like cutting taxes, promoting business growth and changing the welfare system. "There were a lot of skeptics around the state who didn't believe that we'd be able to achieve what we set out to do," he said. "But I think if you look back over what we've achieved in the last four years it is truly historic."
But the Governor had little to say about what he would do if voters granted him a second term on Nov. 3, except that it would be more of the same. In addition to his coyness on campaign finance, he was elusive on other topics, including the next state budget, legislative redistricting after the next census, and whether he would run for President or Vice President in 2000.
He also refused to be pinned down as to whether he would debate his Democratic opponent, Peter F. Vallone, or to explain why, a month after Mr. Vallone began demanding debates, none have taken place or been scheduled. He said it was up to the candidates' campaigns to arrange debates, as if he had no say in the process.
When asked to list his agenda for a second term, Mr. Pataki declined. "In '94 I didn't say there were one or two top goals, and I wouldn't say it now," he said. In fact in 1994, when he was running for his first term, Mr. Pataki did campaign on two main issues: reducing taxes and reinstituting the death penalty. He often cites his success in achieving both goals.
Among the few specific objectives Mr. Pataki did cite in the interview were apprenticeships for welfare recipients and removing pollution from the Hudson River.
"The reason why I want to have another four years is that we've just started, and there's so much more to do," he said.
On the way candidates raise money to run for office, the Governor said: "Our campaign finance system is dreadful. I think it's dreadful. And I don't like it, I have never liked it. What we need is a comprehensive approach to solve it."
Such sentiments are notable if only because the Governor has done exceedingly well under the current system, and he has shown no inclination in the past to change it. He raised $14.5 million for his 1994 run, setting a record for New York campaigns that he has shattered this year, raising nearly $20 million.
The Governor said there should be restrictions on "independent expenditure" campaigns that interest groups, from unions to the tobacco industry, run for or against candidates. "They don't even have to file and disclose who they are and what they're spending money on," he said.
There should also be limits, he said, on how much of their own money wealthy people can spend in pursuit of public office, referring obliquely to B. Thomas Golisano, the Independence Party candidate running against Mr. Pataki, who plans to spend $20 million of his money.
But Mr. Pataki acknowledged that so far, no one has found a way to reach either goal without unconstitutionally restricting free speech.
The Governor said any attempt at campaign finance reform should also look at "soft money," the unlimited contributions that parties can accept as long as they do not go directly into specific campaigns, and at transfers from parties to candidates, or between candidates. But he would not say that he opposed either practice.
Looking ahead, Mr. Pataki would not pledge to serve out a second four-year term, or rule out a campaign for national office. "It's flattering when people talk, you know, and say that you could run for national office," he said. "It has never been an obsession of mine; New York State has been."
"But," he added, "you never say never."
He offered some criticism of his party's leaders in Congress, who he said "had a difficult time transitioning from a minority to a majority," and said that in 2000, governors like him ought to become more involved in setting the Republican national agenda.
"I think there's a very real difference between the Republicans who have had to govern and administer governments and those who have had the luxury of legislating," he said.
In reviewing his record, the Governor concentrated on tax cuts and on the ways he has lightened burdens on business, like lowering the cost of worker's compensation and unemployment insurance, and deregulating hospital pricing.
"Every single year we have been number one in America in reducing taxes," he said. The result of his policies, he said, is, "We're seeing economic growth that we haven't seen in years prior to that." The Governor boasted, as he frequently does, that private-sector employment is up by 360,000 jobs since he took office, though New York's pace of growth still lags behind the national rate and been concentrated in the New York City area.
Mr. Pataki defended his handling of state finances, and dismissed warnings from some of the state's independent fiscal monitors that it has become too dependent on Wall Street, and too vulnerable to a sharp downturn. He noted that the state had ended each of the last three fiscal years with a large surplus, and is headed for another surplus this year.
"We have never counted on Wall Street continuing," he said.
Mr. Pataki spoke frequently of the sharp declines in crime and in the welfare rolls, taking much of the credit for both. He asserted that most of the 570,000 people who have left welfare have found work, and grew insistent when asked how he knew that to be the case.
"Well, of course it's true," he said. "If they're not on social services, what do you think?"
A study earlier this year by the State Office of Temporary and Disability Assistance found that of people who had left welfare over a nine-month period in 1996 and 1997, only 29 percent had found even minimal employment. But Mr. Pataki said the State Department of Labor was working on a more detailed effort to track what became of former welfare recipients.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. George E. Pataki during an interview at The New York Times this week. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Mrs. Hume's 'You Got It!' Confirms Prize

BYLINE: By JAMES F. CLARITY 

DATELINE: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 16

 BODY:
On the morning he won the Nobel Peace Prize, John Hume got out of bed, as usual at 8:30, made himself some Alpen and bananas for breakfast and prepared to spend another day in his life's work: trying to permanently end sectarian violence in this predominantly Protestant British province.
But before the news of the prize came, Mr. Hume, the most prominent mainstream Roman Catholic leader in the province, could not help wondering about the award, he said in an interview here this afternoon."They told me I would get a phone call from the prize committee if I won. I never got the phone call," he said. Instead, a journalist phoned from Oslo and said there were reports that he had won. His wife, Pat, turned on the radio at about 10 A.M. in the living room of their house in Londonderry, west of Belfast. 
 "You got it, John!" shouted his wife, who has also been his chief assistant for the 30 years of his relentless campaign for a peaceful settlement involving the Protestant majority, the Catholic minority and the British Army and police.
"I don't know what I thought when I heard," he said. "I was very pleased, of course. But I see it as a very powerful statement that has given international endorsement for the peace process."
Then, he straightened his gold and black patterned necktie and went to work, talking peace to groups in Londonderry and Belfast, acknowledging without a smile that he was pleased with the award.
In public, he used the same old calm, logical words he has used thousands of times, telling an audience of Catholic and Protestant schoolgirls in Belfast that, "We'll spill our sweat together, not our blood. Your generation must lay the foundation for a new society. Did you choose to be born Catholic or Protestant? So why fight with someone from the other community."
And he quoted the words of warning his unemployed father gave him as a boy in persuading him to to shun the violence of the overwhelmingly Catholic Irish Republican Army: 'You can't eat a flag.'
He posed with the girls, opening his too-tight suit jacket revealing that he has grown heavier in recent months. His sometimes unkempt black hair was neatly combed. Some of the girls tittered and squeaked and asked for his autograph.
Being treated like a celebrity was an unfamiliar role. The paternal advice led Mr. Hume, a French teacher in the 1960's, to become a champion of a peaceful settlement. In Washington he urged the Government not to listen to highly vocal I.R.A. supporters in the United States.
But during a day of fielding hundreds of questions, he refused, when asked, to say the prize was a validation of his life's work. However, most ordinary people here, many government officials and experts agree that without Mr. Hume's effort there would be no peace agreement.
The pact, approved in the spring, drastically reshapes political power in the province, giving Catholics more power and giving the overwhelmingly Catholic Irish Republic more influence in northern affairs.
But, the Nobel prize day also underscored the fact that Mr. Hume, 61, and suffering from a nerve disorder, is getting ready to distance himself from the wearying peace effort -- thousands of debates, seemingly endless contentious issues, deals within deals, careful political statements designed to keep the two sides talking, not shooting and bombing.
His gradual withdrawal from the effort began in June when he allowed Seamus Mallow, a colleague in the mainstream Catholic Social Democratic Labor Party, to become the Catholic leader in the Assembly with the title Deputy First Minister.
This afternoon, at the Dominican College here, a girl said he seemed to be drifting away from Northern Ireland after all his years as a peace advocate. No, he said, he would continue to work for the province in London where he is a member of Parliament and in Strasbourg where he has a seat in the European Parliament, as well as in Washington.
But he acknowledged that he had stepped back in the new Assembly, where much work remains, because "I couldn't take on the extra work."
When a reporter for French television asked what he would do with his share of the $960,000 prize money, he said, "Ce n'est pas pour moi, mais pour le peuple. Un prix symbolique." ("It is not for me, but for the people. A symbolic prize.")
As to the money, he smiled broadly and said he would be able to use it "tres bien." ("Very well.")

HEADLINE: THE 1998 CAMPAIGN;
In an Interview, the Governor Stresses Crime, Welfare and Tax Cuts

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from an interview with Gov. George E. Pataki on Thursday with editors, reporters and executives of The New York Times:
What's on my mind, obviously, is the hope that the people of the state give me the opportunity to lead New York for the next four years. I think back to when I sat around here in 1994 and laid out an agenda and talked about what we were going to do. And I know there were a lot of skeptics here, that you were not alone. There were a lot of skeptics around the state who didn't believe that we'd be able to achieve what we set out to do. 
 But I think if you look back over what we've achieved in the last four years it is truly historic. We did what we said we were going to do. And we've done a lot more than that.
And I remember, as I'm sure you do, in 1994 we had three cornerstones of what we talked about.
One was crime. The most important thing government does is provide for the safety of its people. No state has done more. We have dramatically transformed the laws of this state in ways that people thought couldn't be done. And our streets are the safest they have been in over a generation. And we are leading the nation in reducing violent crime.
The second area I talked about was welfare reform and how 1 of 11 residents was trapped in welfare and how we were going to replace it with workfare. And I'm sure a lot of you thought that was good rhetoric but nonsensical policy. Well, the fact is it was more than good rhetoric. It's been tremendous policy, and it has resulted in a dramatic change in our system that not only has saved the taxpayers money, but, more importantly, has changed people's lives and replaced a system that encouraged dependency with one that requires responsibility. And today we have 571,000 fewer people on welfare than in January of 1995, an absolutely historic number. And we didn't throw anybody off by saying that this category or another category is not going to be eligible. We didn't raise the eligibility standards. We just said that there are going to be certain requirements for those of you who look to participate in that system.
And we talked about tax cuts. And I said we'd cut the personal income tax by 25 percent because we had to restore an economic climate where people felt they could invest and create jobs. And we not only did, we've cut the income tax by more than 25 percent for the vast majority of New Yorkers. But every single year we have been number one in America in reducing taxes -- business taxes, energy taxes, transportation taxes, real estate taxes. We are now in the process of repealing the estate tax so that you won't have to go back to Alabama for six months and a day. You'll be able to stay in New York year-round.
And the results have been what we would have thought. We're seeing economic growth that we haven't seen in years prior to that -- more than 360,000 new private sector jobs.
The reason why I want to have another four years is that we've just started, and there's so much more to do.
In 1994 I didn't even talk about the environment. I didn't talk about the arts. I didn't talk about reforming the health care system and other areas where we felt it was important to do things simply because we had to have a focused agenda for a limited period of time in the campaign. But since that time, not only have we done more in the areas that we focused on during the course of the campaign than we said we would do -- far more in every single area -- but we've also taken areas like the environment where we are transforming what New York State does and again reclaiming national leadership. And we have dramatically changed the entire method of health-care delivery in New York State in a way that hasn't gotten public attention and at the same time done things like create a historic program: expansion of the Child Health Plus program where we are the best -- we have the best system in America to guarantee affordable, basically free, comprehensive health care to every single child of New York other than those who can afford to make the payments.
So it's been, I think, a successful four years. There's a lot more that we want to do and we hope to have the opportunity to continue to do.
 
State's Fiscal Health
When I took office in January of '95, we had a brutal budget fight. In 1995, no one disputed the fact that we had a $5 billion deficit in the fiscal year. Democrats, Republicans, they all said yes, we have a $5 billion deficit. By our fiscal policies we've not only led the nation every year in cutting taxes, but every year we have created a surplus, and then increased the surplus. Four hundred million surplus the first year. A billion two surplus the second year. A $2 billion surplus the third year. And this year we are on track -- and we just got the recent numbers for the first six months of the year -- notwithstanding what has been going on on Wall Street in the last three years, for a more than billion dollar surplus again. In fact, our numbers are better than that.
A more than billion dollar surplus, and, in fact, after the first six months our numbers are at least $150 million better than projected when the budget was adopted.
We have never counted on Wall Street continuing. We have never counted on the global rate of economic growth continuing to explode the way it was. And that's why we built in, consciously, surpluses over these years. Because what I've always said is I'd rather be pleasantly surprised by a continuation of a boom or an expansion that we know will not continue forever.
 
New York State Debt
 There are three parts of state debt. The state-supported debt: That is where the state issues bonds and directly is responsible. Then there's state-related debt: That is what used to be called the moral obligation debts. When the U.D.C. Urban Development Corporation floats $500 million in bonds, the U.D.C. doesn't have a revenue stream to pay it off. It is a moral obligation of the state to pay off those debts. And then there is authority debt, public authority debt. Public authority debt is not counted by the rating agencies because it's backed by revenue. So the Power Authority, the Long Island Power Authority, the M.T.A. State-supported debt has gone from about $28 billion to about $34 billion.
State-related debt has gone from a little over $7 billion to about $1 billion because we have paid off almost $6 billion in the pre-existing moral obligation debt. So that total state-related debt, which is what the rating agencies base their analysis on, is up significantly less than $1 billion in over four years. And I know that's not the perception. But those are in fact the numbers.
The authority debt, our authorities, a number of them have been upgraded, as well as the state. And that the Standard & Poor's for the first time in I think, it's 12 years, upgraded the state's ratings in September of '97 specifically stating that we have done a much better job in managing debt. And every, I believe, it's every single authority today has more net operating revenue after debt service than they did when I took office.
 
Election-Year Budget Increases
The first priority is to make sure that the state budget is soundly balanced in a way that provides for stability and a cushion. . . .
You look at the budget, we are accessing a lot more Federal funds. So it's one of the reasons why we are expanding, why the budget numbers have gone up. The state fund numbers have not gone up as much. The state fund numbers did go up because we had the revenues, we had the surplus. Even with the tax cuts, we believe we're soundly balanced going forward prospectively, and we're investing it in sound programs like education.
There's a projected $1.8 billion deficit in the upcoming fiscal year. But we'll have more than a billion dollar surplus. Let me just say, there's a huge difference between starting your fiscal year with a $5 billion deficit as we did in 1995 and starting your year with a $2 billion surplus as we did in 1998. And that is, I believe, a significant part of the direct result of our intelligent policies and managing both the finances and the economic condition of the state.
 
Goals in a Second Term
In '94 I didn't say there were one or two top goals, and I wouldn't say it now. The basic concept that has driven me from the beginning is we want people to have confidence in the future of their community and of their state. We want them to take a look -- whether it's where do I send my kid to school, where do I buy a home, where do I invest and create jobs, where do I retire, where do I locate next to a program, a playground. We want them to believe. And have a sound rational basis to believe that this is the right place.
And that comes down to criminal justice. People have to feel safe in their community, and people have a right to feel safe in their community regardless of where they live and shouldn't have to live behind an iron gate with a private guard to feel safe. We're proud of what we've done with criminal justice. And everybody's saying, and it's true, the streets are the safest they've been since 1970. In 1970, I lived in Washington Heights, and I remember thinking, my God it's awfully dangerous here, because I used to take the A train from 168th Street down. And I'm kind of a big guy.
I don't think we can sit back and say that our efforts to make the streets safer are over. We'd have to do more.
We've dramatically restructured the welfare system, and we're 571,000 fewer. But we can't just sit back and say to those people who still have talent and ability and a desire to participate and develop their own skills that we've done enough. . . .
On the economic side, we are always in competition. Yesterday, those four companies announcing the 1,200 manufacturing jobs, every one of them was solicited by at least one other state actively trying to get them to leave New York or to locate in their state instead of locating in New York. We beat them. But you have to continually look to see -- whether it's reducing the regulatory burden or lowering energy rates, or continuing to push down workers compensation rates -- how you can do better. And on the environment, which has always been one of the areas that I've been extremely committed to for future generations, we've done more than this state has done in decades. But there's still so much more to do.
You know, I signed a legislation creating the Hudson River Park. It's not there. We have to make sure that it's done and that it's done right. We have to make sure that the Hudson River is clean.
 
National Ambition
It's flattering when people talk and say you could run for national office. It has never been an obsession of mine; New York State has been. I really am proud to be a New Yorker and love this state. And if the people give me the opportunity to run the state for the next four years I will do my best. But you never say never. You know, what I want to do is be in a position where I can do the most to make this a better state. And there's no question in my mind that as of now that's as Governor.
 
Campaign Finance Reform
Our campaign finance system is dreadful. I think it's dreadful. And I don't like it. I have never liked it. What we need is a comprehensive approach to solve it. . . .
But it's not simple. One of the phenomenon that I think is most dangerous and distressing to me that we're seeing is that so much of a political campaign is run outside of the candidates' campaign. I don't have any qualms taking responsibility and accountability for my ads or my campaign's positions on an issue, but what we're seeing is a proliferation of independent expenditures by interest groups, by political parties, by individuals that are unaccountable. And they not only are unaccountable for the candidate, but they don't even have to file and disclose who they are and what they're spending money on. And whether it's the teachers' union going after Senator D'Amato or the Republican State Party going after somebody else, I think we have to have some method where they are held accountable and subject to some reasonable restraints. And that also goes for individuals like an individual who is spending $20 million complimenting me on my leadership of the state over the course of the last four years.
But the problem is the United States constitutional restriction on freedom of speech. How do you come up with a comprehensive approach that doesn't just say Candidate X, instead of getting $5,000 from this group, he can now only get $2,000 from this group. Meanwhile that group can spend $5 million in an unaccountable way. The question is how, given the Supreme Court restraints, can you have a comprehensive approach that deals with everything from independent expenditures to soft money. I have some thoughts, but I don't want to talk about them...
I do not have a plan...
It's something where I certainly understand the need to change it. I think any change has to deal with all the different elements and not simply reduce the contribution limit and then force more into the ether of independent expenditures or advocacy campaigns. But I certainly, not only am willing to listen to ideas, but hopefully I'm going to be proposing -- suggesting -- some ideas that I will come up with if I'm around as we go forward.
 
The Budget Process
I think we actually finally made progress towards that this year. That with the open budget process. It's something I have been calling for for, that the Governor, whether it's me or any other governor, lays out your budget and people know what you're trying to get for better or for worse. In 1995 for a lot of the groups it was for worse. But they knew what I was trying to do, knew what my position was, and I had no qualms talking about it from one end of the state to the other. Behind closed doors people can take positions that are very different from what they might advocate in the open. And what I've said from the beginning is the Assembly should pass their own version of the budget in the open, in the light of day, then in the open, in the light of day have joint conference committees. Do it. They did it in 1998. I think it was a great process.
 
Gubernatorial Debates
I'm really proud of my effort. And I'd like the opportunity to go across the state talking about it. And I'm also confident of my ideas as to what we can do in the future going forward. But we want to make sure that's what it really is. That it's a debate about the issues affecting the future of the state and the campaigns have met and I would hope would continue to meet and could come to a resolution so that we can do it.
 
Role in National G.O.P.
I think there's a very real difference between the Republicans who have had to govern and administer governments and those who had the luxury of legislating. There's a very real difference. And I think if you look at where the Republican Party has been successful, it has been with those objectives. Governors across the country from the largest states to the smallest states successfully changing their states and governing well. I think it's 32 states now have Republican governors, and there's a reason for it. Because I think we have shown that we can change things and improve people's lives and make for more responsive and intelligent government.
I think part of the reason is when you govern, it's fine to be philosophical, but ultimately you have to be practical and you have to solve problems. You can't just have abstract positions. You have to, in fact, make sure those positions are practical and will work on the streets of the communities you lead.
And I think there has been a difference between the Washington party, which I think has had a difficult time transitioning from a minority to a majority, and those of us who have been governing and governing successfully. So I would intend in 2000 -- and don't read anything into this -- but to be far more active. Because I think part of the problem and one of the reasons the Republicans did poorly in 1996 is it was largely a Washington-oriented convention.
 
Anti-Bias Law for Gay People
 It's something that I think is very, very important. I think that New York state is a special state, and one of the reasons is because we have always expressed a caring and compassion for each other and a level of tolerance. And I think that passing the bias-crime legislation, including a provision protecting those who would be discriminated against based on sexua orientation, is very important. And I have said that time and again to the Senate and will continue to urge them, even if they disagree, to allow a vote.
 But I can no more force the senate to vote on that than I can force the assembly to vote on the dairy compact. Some legislators, legislatures are very jealous of the balance of the constitutional seperation of powers

HEADLINE: Caterpillar Profit Is Down 12.7%

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 16

 BODY:
Caterpillar Inc., the largest manufacturer of construction and earth-moving equipment, said today that third-quarter profits fell 12.7 percent because of weaker sales in Asia and global competition that forced the company to lower prices.
The results, well below Wall Street forecasts, helped deepen the gloom surrounding Caterpillar and other companies that continue to suffer from a global economic crisis that is slowing worldwide demand for farm and construction equipment. 
 Shares of Caterpillar, which is based in Peoria, Ill., fell $1, or 2.1 percent, to $47.
"It certainly looks like the competitive landscape has gotten worse," said David A. Bleustein, an analyst at Paine Webber. "There is much more pricing pressure than there was three months ago."
Caterpillar said, however, that revenue growth was strong, with sales of $5.17 billion in the third quarter, up 12.5 percent from a year earlier, largely because of rising sales spurred by lower prices, huge discounts and strong demand in the United States and Europe.
Profits for the quarter were $336 million or 92 cents a share, down from $385 million or $1.01 a share a year earlier. Wall Street analysts had forecast $1 a share.
Slowing demand for farm and construction equipment in Asia and Latin America and Caterpillar's acquisition of Perkins Engines in February cut into profits. Caterpillar was also hurt by its foreign currency exposure, because of the strong dollar, and by a heavier sales mix of equipment that had lower profit margins.
Another reason for the slowdown, according to Marsha Hausser, a spokeswoman, was Caterpillar's large investments in future growth. She said the company had fought hard in recent months to retain its market share in equipment sales.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Shares Rise for Second Day on Euphoria Over a Rate Cut

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Confidence stemming from the Federal Reserve Board's second interest rate cut in three weeks spread further through financial markets yesterday, as stock prices registered strong gains in heavy trading and bond yields fell.
By the close of trading, the Dow Jones industrial average, which soared more than 330 points Thursday in an enthusiastic response to the rate reductions orchestrated by Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, advanced another 117.40, or 1.41 percent, to 8,416.76. For the week, the blue-chip index was up 6.55 percent. 
 Broader market averages also posted healthy gains.
Capping its best week in 14 years, the Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 8.93 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,056.42. For the week, the index gained 7.31 percent, its best showing since the week of Sept. 3, 1984, according to Birinyi & Associates.
And the Nasdaq composite index concluded its best week in 24 years, rising 9.94 points, or six-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,620.95. For the week, the technology-heavy Nasdaq soared 8.6 percent.
"The benefit of what Mr. Greenspan did for stocks on Thursday is not so much an indication that the Fed will provide liquidity to the system, but to instill a sense of confidence in the system again," said Jonathan Olesky, head of block trading at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.
"To some degree, things have shut down in financial markets, due to a loss of confidence, " Mr. Olesky said, referring to what has happened since Russia defaulted on its sovereign debt in August. "You don't have to look very far now to realize that people are much more constructive on the market."
The gains left all three major indexes in positive territory for the year. Since the first day of trading in January, the Dow is up 6.4 percent, the S.& P. 500 is up 8.9 percent and the Nasdaq composite is up 3.2 percent.
Shares of small companies, which have been battered so far this year, also finished with strong gains.
Two stocks rose for every one that fell in price. The Russell 2000 index of smaller-company shares gained 8.06 points, or 2.4 percent, to 342.87. At more than 1 billion shares, volume on the New York Stock Exchange was the fourth busiest in the history of the Big Board.
In large measure, the interest rate cuts by the Fed over the last two weeks have generated hope among investors that the central bank will do all it can to avert a downturn in the American economy by cutting interest rates further.
The sense that the Fed is prepared to cut the overnight Federal funds rate, currently at 5 percent, still further is readily apparent in the credit markets.
Although yields on 30-year Treasury bonds rose marginally, to 4.98 percent, from 4.97 percent Thursday, the rate on three-month Treasury bills, the rate most sensitive to changes in the overnight Federal funds rate, fell by 30 basis points, to a bond-equivalent yield of 3.61 percent. It was the biggest one-day drop in the three-month bill rate since the summer of 1992.
"We are going to get more rate cuts, maybe at the next Fed meeting in November," said Alfred Goldman, chief market strategist at A. G. Edwards in St. Louis. "The Fed is our friend."
Short-term rates were also responding yesterday to continued rumors that a big bank or other financial institution is near failure.
As they often have in recent days, the rumors focused on the health of Bankers Trust, which is expected to release its third-quarter earnings report next week.
Yesterday, Bankers Trust came under heavy selling pressure in the stock market, losing 5 1/2, to 51 3/8, on a day when most financial stocks posted good gains.

INTERNATIONAL A3-7
 
NATO Extends Deadline For Kosovo Withdrawal
NATO granted President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia a reprieve, extending by 10 days its deadline for him to withdraw military and police forces cracking down on ethnic Albanians in Kosovo. Despite abundant evidence that Mr. Milosevic had not yet kept his pledges to withdraw the forces, NATO officials gave him until Oct. 27 to comply or face the threat of NATO military attacks. A1 

An exchange of gunfire between Serbian policemen and the Kosovo Liberation Army in Kraljane, Serbia, indicated that sporadic fighting was continuing in Kosovo Province. It also illustrated the kind of difficulties facing the 2,000 unarmed international monitors who will soon begin arriving to insure that the Serbs have withdrawn forces. A6
 
Nobel Winners for Ulster Peace
The 1998 Nobel Peace Prize was awarded to John Hume and David Trimble, leaders, respectively, of the largest Catholic and Protestant political parties in Northern Ireland, for their efforts to bring peace to the long-polarized British province. A7
 
Moving Slowly on Mideast
Israeli and Palestinian leaders, under the prodding hand of American officials, were said to be making some progress toward an interim accord while gathered in seclusion at a conference center in Maryland. Officials described the going as slow and the mistrust as still deep. A3
 
Embassy Bombings Inquiry
The F.B.I. said two vehicles had been used in the attack last summer on the American Embassy in Dar Es Salaam, Tanzania. The agency also said it had identified new suspects in the blast in Tanzania and that they were at large. A6
 
Italy Looks to the Left
Massimo D'Alema, a former Communist and leader of the largest leftist party in Italy, will try to form a government. Mr. D'Alema was chosen after Acting Prime Minister Romano Prodi failed to gather enough support to form a new government. A5
 
Pope's 20th Anniversary
John Paul II celebrated his 20th anniversary as Pope and appeared at a window at St. Peter's Basilica in Rome. Tens of thousands of people gathered below to hear and watch by live television hookup the ringing of the bells of Crakow Cathedral, just as they had rung at the same time on Oct. 16, 1978. A4
 
Nigerian Dissident Speaks Out
Wole Soyinka, the Nobel laureate and long a bold critic of the military Government, made his first public address since returning from four years in exile. A6
 
In Brazil, a Plan and a Delay
Brazilian officials put the finishing touches on an ambitious package to raise $20 billion through spending cuts and tax increases next year. But public announcement of those measures, eagerly awaited by international investors and markets, seemed likely to be delayed. A4
 
NATIONAL A8-11, 16
 
Congress Puts Off Vote On Final Budget Measure
Congress postponed its vote on a $500 billion spending package until next week. Most lawmakers headed home to campaign, with some conservatives grousing, some areas of dispute still remaining and much of the bill still unwritten. No vote can be held until the final language is drafted for the bill, which could run to more than 3,000 pages. The Government will continue to operate with temporary financing. A1
 
The Federal budget agreement contains a provision to restrict children's access to pornography on the Internet. The Republicans who wrote it said it overcomes free-speech objections that led the Supreme Court to overturn a previous measure, but the groups that defeated the last effort say they will sue again. The possibility that impeachment proceedings against President Clinton could weaken the Democrats this year and again in the Presidential election in 2000 has helped bring together the two leading potential Democratic candidates for that race, Vice President Al Gore and the House minority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri. A9
 
A Small Rise in Benefits
Social Security benefits for more than 44 million Americans will rise 1.3 percent next year, the Government said, the smallest cost-of-living increase since 1987 because inflation has been so low. A10

Funeral for Gay Student

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Timing a Rate Cut: The Fed Acts Quickly

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16

 BODY:
He is revered in the financial markets these days as omnipotent and omniscient, but Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, has not always gotten it right.
In 1990, the American banking system was seizing up. Many institutions had been hit hard by losses on real estate loans, and regulators were demanding that they keep more capital on hand. Banks became reluctant to lend, and the credit shortage helped push the economy into recession. 
 Mr. Greenspan and his colleagues at the Fed largely missed the problem, cutting interest rates aggressively to stimulate more lending only after the economy began to contract. And as he confronts another credit shortage that could put the nation's long business expansion at risk, Mr. Greenspan is determined not to make the same mistake again, as evidenced by his unusual decision on Thursday to cut rates by a quarter percentage point between the central bank's regularly scheduled policy meetings. Economists now expect a series of further rate reductions this year and possibly into next year.
"Virtually the only blemish on Mr. Greenspan's record as chairman was in not acting forcefully enough to offset the 1989-1990 credit crunch, which was the fundamental cause of the 1990 recession," said G. David Orr, an economist at First Union Capital Markets. "He will not want to be caught in that situation again."
In acting assertively, Mr. Greenspan was trying to break a psychology within the markets that more bad news was almost inevitable and that the risks to investors and lenders were only growing. In doing so, however, he may have had to sidestep reluctance among some members the Fed's policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee who remain concerned that lower rates could fuel inflation by stimulating an economy that by some measures, including a very low unemployment rate, is already running hard.
The committee voted just over two weeks ago to cut its Federal funds target rate on overnight lending between banks by a quarter-point, to 5.25 percent, turning aside pressure from the financial markets and many economists for a half-point cut.
That Mr. Greenspan then cut rates on Thursday by another quarter- point suggested to many analysts that the Fed chairman had wanted a half-point cut in the first place, but had not been willing at that time to force a showdown over the issue with committee members who still see a potential threat from inflation.
Mr. Greenspan announced his decision after convening a conference call among the committee's members early Thursday afternoon. A spokeswoman for the Fed said no vote was taken and that Mr. Greenspan acted on his own authority, which is routinely granted to him by the committee but rarely used.
Mr. Greenspan appears to have had widespread support within the Fed, since 8 of the 12 regional Federal Reserve Banks requested that the central bank also reduce the discount rate on their short-term loans to commercial banks. Among the banks requesting the discount rate cut was the St. Louis Fed, whose president, William Poole, was among those most concerned earlier this year about the inflation risks.
But analysts said Mr. Greenspan prefers to develop a consensus before acting. Determined opposition from even one or two members of the committee, such as Jerry L. Jordan, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, who has been concerned that growth in the money supply is signaling a possible upturn in inflation, would be enough to give Mr. Greenspan pause, they said.
"Greenspan has been wanting to cut interest rates earlier and faster, but the inflation hawks on the Federal Open Market Committee held him back," said Sung Won Sohn, an economist at the Norwest Corporation, a Minneapolis banking company. "At the September meeting Greenspan was able to convince the hawks that the global situation indeed is dangerous. But at that point the hawks were not willing to let Greenspan go more than a quarter of a point."
Since then, Mr. Sohn said, there have been new indications that the economy is slowing and that inflation remains dormant. Today, for example, the Labor Department reported that the Consumer Price Index was unchanged last month, leaving the inflation rate for the last 12 months at just 1.5 percent. Earlier in the week the Government had reported weakening retail sales and subdued price increases at the producer level.
"My belief is that Chairman Greenspan basically called the members and gave them the appearance of consulting," Mr. Sohn said. "But it was clearly more of a formality, especially in light of the more negative economic numbers."
In trying to avert a credit shortage, Mr. Greenspan is dealing with market psychology more than a mismatch between demand and supply in the economy. His decision to cut rates at an unexpected time may have been calculated to give a maximum boost to the markets, where fear about recession at home and a further meltdown in the world financial system has led investors and lenders to shy away from the merest whiff of risk.
In the short run, at least, the rate cut succeeded on that score. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped a further 117.40 points today after a 330.58-point gain Thursday, and is nearly 12 percent higher than the low of 7,539.07 reached Aug. 31. The Standard & Poor's index and Nasdaq index also ended the week with strong gains.
"Dr. Greenspan, ace psychologist, knew his clients needed some positive reinforcement," Mr. Orr said.
But it is still too early to know whether interest rate cuts will convince investors that high-grade corporate bonds are not so risky after all, or reassure banks that the business outlook is sufficiently bright that it is reasonable to provide new loans. While the Fed has some tools, like the discount rate, that can directly help to encourage more lending by banks, it can only indirectly stimulate greater availability of capital in the financial markets, where most big companies turn for funds.
In a report today, Robert V. DiClemente and David Hensley, economists at Salomon Smith Barney, said "new issuance of investment-grade corporate bonds remains sporadic and hesitant," with the volume, at $3.5 billion for the first half of October, far behind July's $19 billion.
Mr. Greenspan has several important factors working in his favor. The almost total lack of inflation gives him considerable room to push rates down further in coming months. When adjusted for inflation, in fact, the Fed funds target rate is still relatively high -- about 3 percent. Because the Federal Government is running a budget surplus there will be no inflationary pressures from fiscal policy.
Compared with 1990, Mr. Greenspan has also gotten off to a much faster start in dealing with the evolving problem, said Maury N. Harris, an economist at Paine Webber. By the time the Fed started easing rates in the summer of 1990, 43 percent of banks had already tightened lending standards on loans to small companies, compared with 23 percent last month, Mr. Harris said.
"In 1990, the bank credit crunch had become more serious than the current credit situation before the Fed started to let the investing public and American business leaders know that it was plugged into the problem and willing to ease," he said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Cut in U.S. Interest Rates Helps Markets Rally Abroad
Stock markets in Asia and Europe surged in response to Thursday's interest rate reduction by the Federal Reserve. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index jumped 9 percent, to 9,777.01, its highest level since early May. 
 Shares in Singapore, Bangkok, Jakarta and Manila all rose more than 5 percent. The Nikkei index of 225 issues in Tokyo gained 2.19 percent. The German DAX index climbed 1.76 percent, and the main market gauge in London increased 1.38 percent. Page C2.
 
Wall Street's Advance Is Extended
Stocks registered strong gains as confidence stemming from the Federal Reserve's second interest rate cut in three weeks spread. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 117.40 points, or 1.41 percent, to 8,416.76. The Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 8.93 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,056.42. And the Nasdaq composite index rose 9.94 points to 1,620.95. For the week the Nasdaq index rose 8.6 percent, its best performance in 24 years. C3.
 
Mild Gain in Social Security Benefits
The Government said Social Security benefits will rise 1.3 percent next year, the smallest cost-of-living increase since 1987, because of exceptionally low inflation. More than 44 million Americans, most of them elderly, receive Social Security benefits. A10.

Budget Agreement Still Needs Work
Some Republicans sounded notes of discord over the $1.7 trillion Federal budget deal, but they also said they would probably vote for the package because it increased defense spending and provided aid to farmers. However, no one can vote on the package just yet because there are still disputes to iron out. A1.
 
Tucked into the $1.7 trillion Federal budget agreement is a measure that would restrict children's access to pornography on the Internet. The measure says Internet merchants and others will be in violation only if they give children access to material that is "harmful to minors." A10.
 
Production Declined Last Month
Output at the nation's factories, mines and utilities fell three-tenths of 1 percent in September and consumer prices were unchanged last month for the first time in six months, further signs that the economy is slowing. A third economic indicator, the University of Michigan's index of consumer confidence, fell to 98.9 this month from 100.9 in September. C2.
 
Shake-Up Continues at Merrill Lynch
A shake-up in the executive suite continued at Merrill Lynch. The leading brokerage firm, led by David H. Komansky, left, named G. Kelly Martin, 39, as chief of the debt business, replacing Seth Waugh, who will become Mr. Martin's deputy. Mr. Waugh had been co-head of the global debt unit since 1997. The change is the second in two days. On Thursday, Merrill named Richard A. Dunn to replace Daniel T. Napoli as head of its risk management team. Both Mr. Waugh and Mr. Napoli were demoted, but the firm said it was not assigning blame to them and that both would stay on the job. C14.
 
Hoechst Calls Off Sale of Herberts
The German chemical maker Hoechst has ended talks to sell its Herberts paint unit to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts. The buyout firm was offering a price below what Hoechst was willing to accept. C3.
 
Nissan Motor Expects a Net Loss
Nissan Motor, Japan's second-largest auto maker, said that it expected to post a net loss of 33 billion yen ($284 million) for the first half of the current business year because of huge losses on its securities holdings. C2.
 
Profits Decline at Caterpillar
Caterpillar, the manufacturer of construction and earth-moving equipment, reported that third-quarter profits fell 12.7 percent, to $336 million, or 92 cents a diluted share. Sales jumped 12.5 percent, to $5.17 billion. C2.

HEADLINE: At Penn Station: Rider Egression

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Albany to Make Trucks Pass Emission Tests" (news article, Oct. 15): New York State's concern about vehicular emissions deserves applause. However, mandated emission testing needs to be balanced by incentives to induce private fleets to purchase alternative-fuel vehicles.
The Alternative Fuel Vehicle Act of 1997 offers tax credits toward the purchase of clean trucks and buses. The State Legislature needs to augment its 1997 effort by reducing the taxes on alternative fuels like natural gas. New York City, in turn, should offer "green curbs" -- preferred curb-side parking for clean-fuel delivery trucks. 
 New York can follow the examples of California, Connecticut and Rhode Island, balancing mandates with incentives. Private truckers will respond to comprehensive incentives that yield economically viable clean-fuel fleets.
 
DAVID VANDOR
Tarrytown, N.Y., Oct. 15, 1998
 
The writer is a consultant to truck fleet owners.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
KELLOGG EXPECTS '98 PER-SHARE EARNINGS TO FALL 20%

BYLINE: Reuters 

 BODY:
The Kellogg Company, the nation's largest cereal maker, said yesterday that it expected its 1998 earnings per share to fall about 20 percent from 1997 because of global economic turmoil and weakness in its two largest cereal markets: the United States and Britain. The forecast was ever gloomier than a projection by Kellogg in July, when it said it expected a decline in 1998 per-share earnings of up to 15 percent. Kellogg, which makes 12 of the world's top 15 cereal brands, reported a profit of $1.70 a share for 1997. Kellogg has been grappling with fierce competition from its branded cereal competitors and lower-priced bagged cereals. On the New York Stock Exchange, Kellogg's shares dropped $3.5625 yesterday, to $34.0625.

HEADLINE: New Stock Exchange Site Under Discussion

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
City and state officials told the New York Stock Exchange yesterday that they were on the verge of securing a site for a new headquarters and trading complex for the market directly across the street from its historic home on Wall Street, according to people involved in the discussions.
But in what has become a high-stakes poker game, the Stock Exchange did not immediately embrace the proposal, saying it was exploring all of its options. 
 In an effort to insure that the financial district in lower Manhattan remains the financial capital of the world, officials have been scrambling to come up with a real estate deal for the exchange, which has threatened to move to Battery Park City or New Jersey unless the city comes up with an alternative by Nov. 4.
In a meeting at the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Deputy Mayor Randy L. Levine and Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, told the chairman of the exchange, Richard A. Grasso, that they were confident a deal could be struck for the site, according to people who were there. Four office buildings owned or controlled by J. P. Morgan & Company now sit on the block, along with an apartment building. The site is bound by Wall Street and Exchange Place, between Broad and William Streets.
Under the terms of the proposal, the state would condemn the property and acquire the land, which would be ready for demolition and construction in 2001.
Officials at the Stock Exchange expressed reservations about the proposal, yet another indication that they may favor moving to vacant land at Battery Park City. The exchange has no desire to antagonize city and state officials, however, because it wants hundreds of millions of dollars in public funds for a new headquarters.
"As currently presented, the economics have yet to justify building a new New York Stock Exchange trading facility on the old J. P. Morgan site," Richard Adamonis, a spokesman for the exchange, said yesterday. "We continue to keep all options open."
The so-called J. P. Morgan site first surfaced as a possible home for the stock exchange in 1991, when Morgan and city and state officials proposed building a $1 billion super exchange for the New York Stock Exchange, the American Stock Exchange and the city's commodities exchanges.
Negotiations dragged on for a year. But in the midst of a severe recession that left a quarter of the office space vacant in lower Manhattan, the New York Stock Exchange decided not to go forward.
Six years later, historic preservationists blocked a plan by the New York Stock Exchange to build a new trading floor on the Morgan site and a glass atrium over Broad Street that would have connected the old and the new buildings.
Desperate to get out of its cramped space on Wall Street, the Exchange told city officials in April that it wanted to move to Battery Park City, where it could build a modern complex on vacant, state-owned land.
And when the stock exchange felt that City Hall was not paying sufficient attention to its problems, Mr. Grasso announced that New Jersey was offering all kinds of enticements to move to Jersey City.
Ultimately, the exchange agreed to give New York officials six months to come up with an alternative that would keep the market in the financial district. Landlords and businesses were alarmed that the loss of the exchange would undercut the downtown renaissance and spark the exodus of many financial companies.
For four months, city officials negotiated with property owners on a block bound by Broad and William Streets, between Beaver Street and Exchange Place. The most difficult problem was at 25 Broad Street, where a developer, Crescent Heights Investments, had spent $100 million converting the vacant office building into 345 apartments -- a move the city encouraged.
Bruce Menin, the president of Crescent Heights, said yesterday that he had been in negotiations with city officials but had not heard from them recently.
In recent weeks, city officials suddenly resurrected the old J. P. Morgan proposal, hoping to strike a less complicated deal with J. P. Morgan, which has more than 2,500 employees in four buildings on the block, and the Elghanayan family, which owns the apartment house at 45 Wall Street.
Real estate executives say that Morgan believes it is imperative that the stock exchange remain in the financial district.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk

HEADLINE: Brandeis at 50 Is Still Searching, Still Jewish and Still Not Harvard

BYLINE: By ETHAN BRONNER 

 BODY:
Half a century ago, when a group of uneducated immigrant Jews scraped together enough money to buy a bankrupt medical and veterinary school in Waltham, Mass., west of Boston, they named it Brandeis University and set out to found the Harvard of the Jews.
The plan was dismissed by many as pie in the sky. But it was a propitious moment. The Nazis had been defeated, Israel had been created, the civil rights era was in its infancy, higher education was on the brink of explosive growth and American Jews were still restricted in their access to many institutions. 
 So when the new university named after Louis D. Brandeis, the first Jewish Justice of the Supreme Court, quickly became home to renowned intellectuals like Leonard Bernstein, Max Lerner and Herbert Marcuse, the plan seemed on track.
In the intervening decades, however, something happened that Brandeis's founders did not foresee. The Jews' fervent drive for acceptance, prosperity and a role in shaping American culture succeeded so well -- partly through the efforts of Brandeis -- that Brandeis never became the Harvard of the Jews.
Harvard became the Harvard of the Jews as did Yale, Columbia, the University of Pennsylvania and the rest of elite American colleges, where Jews, who make up 2 1/2 percent of the American population, typically make up 20 percent of students and faculty members.
"Jews are no longer trying to get into the American academic establishment," said Rabbi Arthur Hertzberg, a historian of American Jewry. "They are the academic establishment. The problem Brandeis had come to solve has been solved."
But solutions are sometimes new problems in disguise.
As Brandeis alumni and friends gathered this weekend to celebrate the 50th anniversary of their Jewish-sponsored, non-sectarian university -- the old broken buildings and dirt paths now a groomed 235-acre campus -- they are struggling with how to position their institution in its middle age.
Other universities created to serve specific groups at certain historical moments, like black and women's colleges and even some small religious schools, are also struggling to reinvent themselves.
In the case of Brandeis, as Israel has become secure, as the generation that suffered the Holocaust dies, as Jews continue to rise freely through the ranks of politics, industry and the media, Brandeis and American Jewry together face a challenge unprecedented in Jewish history: How to forge an identity divorced from persecution?
"What do you do when all the choices are yours?" asked Gary Tobin, a Brandeis professor of Jewish studies. "When you can't blame external forces? When there is no hostile environment to mold your ideology?
"The American Jewish community has achieved a remarkable degree of integration into society," Professor Tobin said. "It was purposeful, deliberate and achieved through enormous effort. We tried very hard to get where we are. Where does that leave Brandeis?
"It doesn't want to be thought of as reclusive, separate, disintegrated from American life. It has to find a balance. In the same way that a Jew has to decide what it means to be an assimilated Jew, Brandeis has to decide what it means to be an assimilated university."
Part of the chosen solution is through a conscious internationalism and emphasis on ethics that officials like Jehuda Reinharz, president of Brandeis, believe can be illuminated by the Jewish tradition.
So yesterday, right after the Brandeis festivities began with a picnic lunch, the first event was a symposium on "Human Rights: The Unfinished Agenda." Among the speakers was Shen Tong, a Brandeis graduate and an organizer of the 1989 Tiananmen Square protest in Beijing. The university has also just opened a $13 million international center on the study of ethics and social justice.
Last spring, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany was the commencement speaker, and the Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader of Tibet, was a campus guest.
Such internationalism has been accompanied by an increased Jewish emphasis. The neglected Jewish studies department has been rebuilt, kosher food areas have been expanded and there are a couple hundred modern Orthodox Jews among the university's roughly 3,000 students. There are even a few strictly Orthodox students, in somber dark dress, who had, until recently, never considered Brandeis because it was seen as insufficiently Jewish.
The diversity of Jewish life on campus might be expected to produce tensions, as it has in Israel. But one of Brandeis's goals is to find a way for different kinds of Jews to live together.
Organized Sabbath dinners on campus are an example. On Friday nights, several hundred young Jews celebrate together: Reform men with earrings sitting near black-coated Orthodox men and Conservative women in colorful yarmulkes.
 
A Role as an Advocate Of Jewish Pluralism
Such dinners, with their singing and high-minded discussions afterwards, suggest a role for the university in the debate over identity: as an advocate of Jewish pluralism.
"I think most of us agree that for Brandeis to flourish in the 1990's, it must give expression to its Jewish character," said Michael J. Sandel, a professor of government at Harvard who is a Brandeis graduate and board member. "There are many ways to do that but one is to serve as a forum for debate over competing visions for Jewish life. Brandeis should be a convener of different voices."
For non-Jews, the Jewish emphasis can be both intriguing and alienating. Sucheta Puranik, a junior from Wallingford, Conn., said it was fascinating to watch Jews, who are so used to being in the minority, feel in charge. But she said she joined the campus intercultural center to find others who feel a bit left out during Jewish holidays.
Brandeis has trouble attracting African-Americans despite strenuous efforts to do so, including two programs that bring inner-city youths to campus. Blacks make up less than three percent of the student population.
In its early years, Brandeis's goal was not Jewish pluralism but the purest assimilation. Again, Harvard and other elite universities founded by religious communities were the models. Until 1937, for example, all presidents of Brown University were Baptists, many of them ministers. Today Brown, like the others, is a center of secularism.
So, the theory went, it would be for Brandeis, which is Jewish-sponsored but non-sectarian, unlike Yeshiva University, which requires students to take a heavy load of courses in Jewish studies. The Brandeis student body began overwhelmingly Jewish but quickly became more diverse, with 40 percent non-Jewish students. The faculty has long had a mix of backgrounds.
Brandeis had become emblematic of major college trends. Not only had it served as a bohemian intellectual center in the 1950's but in the 1960's it became synonymous with the 1960's. For a time, Brandeis became the National Student Strike Information Center. In 1970 two students were on the Federal Bureau of Investigation's 10 Most Wanted list for taking part in an armed robbery that stemmed from their political beliefs. LSD-laced punch was served by half-naked students in the middle of campus.
In the 1970's, when many Jews turned their attention and money toward Israel, Brandeis found itself without the resources or leadership of more established universities. This was partly because, unlike Vanderbilt, Duke, Rice or Vassar, Brandeis was not named for its chief donor but for its main inspiration. Brandeis depended upon, as it still does, what it calls its foster alumni -- American Jews -- for support. But as American Jews became integrated, they patronized other institutions; support for Brandeis waned and the quality of its students declined. Some of the university's supporters began to worry that Brandeis's frank Jewishness was a liability.
In the late 1980's, when Evelyn Handler was president of Brandeis, a committee of students and trustees examined ways to reduce the university's Jewish character. Gustav Ranis, a professor of international economics at Yale and a member of Brandeis's first graduating class, led the committee, which actually bore the name "Dejudification." The idea was to attract more non-Jews, particularly Asians, and the committee decided a relaxation of Jewish dietary restrictions would help.
 
Defining Roots, Improving Vision
"We recommended that there be one place on campus where pork and shellfish could be consumed," Professor Ranis said. "Evelyn Handler ran with it and announced it. There was a huge negative response in the American Jewish community. Jews who didn't themselves keep kosher wanted Brandeis to keep kosher."
Its finances a mess, its reputation sullied, its mission muddied, Brandeis was the subject of major newspaper articles describing its identity crisis. The board urged Ms. Handler to resign.
Salvation appeared in the guise of a physician. Samuel O. Thier, then president of the Institute of Medicine under the National Academy of Sciences, served as Brandeis president for three crucial, stabilizing years. Having served on the faculties of Yale, Penn and Harvard, Dr. Thier said he saw the quality of Brandeis and its faculty.
"Here was this place with spectacular scientists, really first class, yet they were feeling miserable," Dr. Thier recalled. "The institution was young but it was part of a tradition thousands of years old. To me, it looked like a recovery just waiting to happen."
As Jonathan D. Sarna, a professor of American Jewish history at Brandeis, put it: "Brandeis was like a guy named Mendelssohn trying to pretend that he's not Jewish. Once that came to an end, things improved quickly."
Pork and shrimp were removed from the cafeteria. Dr. Reinharz, then a Zionist historian at Brandeis, was named provost. American Jews were told that Brandeis still thought of itself as Jewish and that its future depended on their support.
No one grasped the importance of that support as clearly as Dr. Reinharz, who took over the presidency in 1994. Dr. Reinharz, 54, born in Israel, is fiercely devoted to Brandeis, where he earned his Ph.D.
Traveling around the country, often with his wife, Shulamit, a Brandeis professor of sociology and women's studies, Dr. Reinharz has given a new face to the institution. He has also grasped the value of celebrity, attracting people like Ann Richards and Anita Hill as visiting lecturers and persuading Robert B. Reich, the former Secretary of Labor, to take a professorship.
"What I have done is really clearly define and articulate what we are all about," Dr. Reinharz said. "Tempering our Jewish identity did not work. I have defined our mission very clearly and without embarrassment as having four pillars: Jewish sponsorship, total non-sectarianism, a commitment to social justice and excellence."
It is on the pillar of excellence, that Brandeis sees its work most clearly in the future. Applications are brisk, and Brandeis has drawn some first-class students by offering them hefty scholarships regardless of their parents' incomes. But the university still suffers from being a second choice for many of the brightest on campus. It has been frustrated at not being able to crack the top 25 list in the university rankings put out by such publications as U.S. News and World Report. But a recent book by Hugh David Graham and Nancy Diamond, "The Rise of American Research Universities," (Johns Hopkins, 1997) ranked colleges based on faculty publications and citations. After controlling for institutional size, it ranked Brandeis ninth over all and first among a group of "rising" research universities.
 
Facing Problems With Clear Mission
Eleven faculty members belong to the National Academy of Sciences, and 27 belong to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, high numbers for a small institution.
Yet by not veering far from a Jewish identity, Brandeis faces a potential problem in attracting the very best from all walks of life.
Arthur Levine, president of Teachers College at Columbia University, said Brandeis, from which he graduated, must "find a way to translate the values of religion without making it religious."
"Once Brandeis loses its Jewishness, it becomes just another university and pushes away its donor base," Mr. Levine said. "Moreover, Brandeis faces the same challenges as all research universities. For the first time since the days Brandeis was founded, universities are not a growth industry."
This is the calculation that Dr. Reinharz has made: Money and mission rely on Brandeis's Jewish roots.
"I doubt that at any point we will just decide this is an excellent university and call it a day on the Jewish issue," Dr. Reinharz said. "I see a very strong Jewish link throughout Brandeis's future. There will never be a day when we at Brandeis will say, 'Now we know what we are about.' The process is the point and the process will always go on."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 2, 1998, Monday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Oct. 17 about Brandeis University referred incorrectly to a trustee committee in the late 1980's that examined strategic planning, including ways to attract more non-Jewish students. The committee had no student members and no formal name; "dejudification" was a pejorative term used by critics.

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
THE AMERICAN CENTURY, by Harold Evans with Gail Buckland and Kevin Baker. (Knopf, $50.) An accessible political history, elegantly and copiously illustrated; it argues that American democratic ideals, however many times they have led to grief for ourselves and others, on balance have made for human rights, here and abroad.
 
DANCING NAKED IN THE MIND FIELD, by Kary Mullis. (Pantheon, $24.) The darkly joyous autobiography of a brilliant chemist (Nobel Prize, 1993) whose views on global warming, H.I.V., the ozone layer and many other issues are either unusual or bizarre (maybe time will tell).
 
EUCALYPTUS, by Murray Bail. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $23.) A magic novel from Australia, in which a homesteader's daughter must marry, fairy tale fashion, the first suitor who can correctly identify every eucalyptus species; a wandering storyteller breaks the rule.
 
EVENING, by Susan Minot. (Knopf, $23.) An elegant, assured novel that tells the story of a woman's life in two narratives: one as she remembers her life, one as she passes from it.
 
THE EVOLUTION OF JANE, by Cathleen Schine. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.) A character named Jane and the principles of evolution are both shrewdly rendered in a novel that unconventionally uses large principles to illuminate a particular life.
 
THE FARMING OF BONES, by Edwidge Danticat. (Soho, $23.) A sobering novel by a Haitian-American, set in Hispaniola in 1937 during a bloody eruption of the endless hostility between Haiti and its neighbor, the Dominican Republic.
 
THE GIANT, O'BRIEN, by Hilary Mantel. (Marian Wood/Holt, $22.) An early mad scientist meets a late, unviable, enormous Irish spinner of tales in a novel that grants the future to the scientist but the heart to the bard.
 
I MARRIED A COMMUNIST, by Philip Roth. (Houghton Mifflin, $26.) A tender, harsh, witty novel whose title refers to a bitter, hostile book written by the female half of a ruined marriage (sound familiar?), and whose principal action, recalled in the present, takes place in the dire focus of the age of McCarthyism.
 
LOVE UNDETECTABLE: Notes on Friendship, Sex, and Survival, by Andrew Sullivan. (Knopf, $23.) A meditation, basically religious, on the effects of AIDS in the culture and in individuals, by the former editor of The New Republic.
 
THE VENTRILOQUIST'S TALE, by Pauline Melville. (Bloomsbury USA/St. Martin's, $23.95.) A gleeful fiction that plays the spirit-filled world of South American Indians against the rationalist world of exploitative, "civilizing" Europeans in a novel that is in part an act of revenge on Evelyn Waugh for his 1934 novel, "A Handful of Dust."
