SECTION: Section 7; Page 12; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1459 words

HEADLINE: Just Saying 'No' Is Not Enough

BYLINE: By David F. Musto; David F. Musto is the author of "The American Disease: Origins of Narcotic Control."

 BODY:

THE FIX
 By Michael Massing.
 335 pp. New York:
 Simon & Schuster. $25. 
 Michael Massing has been writing about drug issues in the United States for a decade. He believes the central problem to be the hard-core users of heroin and cocaine, who are "disproportionately poor, unemployed and members of minority groups." Although hard-core users are only a fifth of total users, they consume three-fourths of the cocaine and heroin used in this country and are responsible for most of the pathological behavior that elicits public and governmental responses. If we could provide appropriate treatment to anyone in this population who wanted it, Massing maintains, the whole drug problem would diminish, as would the illness and crime associated with it. The result of Massing's investigation is "The Fix," a balanced and significant analysis of the American drug problem that carries specific, practical recommendations for reform.
He separates himself from the "legalization/harm-reduction camp" that asserts that drug-related diseases and social pathology are the fault of drug-control laws themselves. Having spent long periods observing drug treatment centers, roaming the streets of Harlem and hanging out with drug users, he has experienced a "real-life rebuttal to the rosy accounts of addiction offered by the revisionists." Regardless of the drug laws, addiction and drug use create terrible conditions: child abuse reports in New York rose from 36,000 in 1985 to 59,000 in 1989 when the crack epidemic hit the city. Massing's approach contrasts with recent books like Mike Gray's "Drug Crazy," which calls for a radical revision of our drug laws. Gray describes a golden age of drug use prior to the Harrison Narcotic Act of 1914, when "the country had looked upon addicts as unfortunate citizens with a medical problem." To right current wrongs, he recommends that we put the provision of drugs "back in the hands of doctors and pharmacists."
Massing also distances his position from apostles of draconian penalties and those who put their faith in interdiction. His middle way has one clear emphasis, and that is comprehensive treatment. He knows this would work because we had such a program once; it succeeded wonderfully, but we let it slip away. We were therefore unable to mount a powerful defense against cocaine and crack in the mid-1980's, and now we have 10 times as many hard-core users as we faced during the Nixon Administration.
Nixon's strategy aimed directly at reducing crime in anticipation of the 1972 election. Treatment was part of a broad program that included foreign policy to shut down the Turkish-French connection; the Office of Drug Abuse Law Enforcement to attack street crime; the Internal Revenue Service to go after illicit profits. That crime reduction held first place among Nixon's priorities -- not the care of addicts -- is illustrated by the Administration's surprising willingness to adopt methadone, a synthetic opiate, as its preferred treatment for heroin users. At the time, a high-ranking official in the Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs told me that the bureau would hand out heroin if it thought that would cut crime. This attitude was surprising because the substitution of one addiction by another contradicted the previously adamant stand by Nixon's adherents against any drug use.
How did Nixon come to approve the financing of methadone treatment for tens of thousands of addicts? Massing draws on interviews with key actors and internal Government documents to provide an answer. The most persuasive element was the methadone program developed in Washington by Robert DuPont, later the Director of the National Institute on Drug Abuse. Heroin use was skyrocketing; crime was rampant. In his 1968 campaign Nixon had declared that "D. C. should not stand for disorder and crime." Washington became the laboratory for national drug policies. In 1970 DuPont, with support from the White House, established the Narcotics Treatment Administration, which was soon flooded with applicants. Although nondrug treatment was also offered, methadone appeared to cut the crime rate quickly, and that impressed the President and his aides. By the 1972 election crime had fallen by 50 percent in the District of Columbia, an achievement that was widely broadcast.
Of course, the methadone program was only one of the actions taken to reduce crime in Washington. Even Egil Krogh, the Nixon aide most responsible for creating the political will for this ambitious national treatment program, did not know if the program was responsible for the drop in crime, but he knew that from a political perspective, "it was a slam-dunk great success."
Massing has no doubts about the success of the treatment program. His conviction comes from his encounter with Nixon's drug expert, Jerome Jaffe, a psychopharmacologist and psychiatrist plucked in 1970 from the University of Chicago, where he had established a treatment program that employed a range of options, including drug-free therapy. He was asked first to head a committee of experts from outside the Government to come up with a response to drug addiction. His report was practical rather than theoretical and named methadone as the best treatment for heroin addiction (the major addiction at that time) and the best way to reduce crime. Following the adoption of what was basically his proposal, Jaffe entered Government service.
His first big administrative assignment was to deal with addicted Army personnel coming back from Vietnam. This he did with ingenuity and dispatch, and then began work as the "drug czar," the first head of the Special Action Office for Drug Abuse Policy. Jaffe was neither a good administrator nor an adept politician -- he was a scientist. Many of his psychiatric and scientific colleagues distrusted him for working with Nixon. Some critics lambasted him in the most vitriolic terms for advocating methadone; they described the program as an enslavement of minorities. In Massing he has found a vindicator.
Massing advocates Jaffe's "code," a set of principles that summed up his approach to drug use: "Chronic drug users are at the heart of the nation's drug problem; a diverse array of services is required; Government must assure their availability and efficacy; law enforcement is an adjunct to rehabilitation and, always, reducing demand for drugs through education and treatment must take precedence over law enforcement efforts to reduce the supply of drugs. Massing says the Nixon Administration, following the Jaffe prescription, managed to bring a "serious heroin epidemic" under control "in a few short years."
Massing recommends setting up an organization like the Special Action Office for Drug Abuse Prevention that would engage only in reducing demand for illicit drugs, to be headed by a "C. Everett Koop-type figure" and backed in the White House by a facsimile of Egil Krogh -- that is, a high-ranking White House official whose special province would be drug abuse. A comprehensive national treatment program for drug and alcohol abuse should be established. In Massing's view, the most unfortunate mistake in the recent history of drug programs was the Government's shift of emphasis from heroin to marijuana, in response to increased complaints by parents, during the latter half of the Carter Administration. Treatment for the hard core shriveled. During the Reagan Administration the amount spent for treatment in real dollars fell to less than a quarter of what had been provided in the Nixon Administration.
Massing's powerful arguments for more treatment programs, especially metha-
done, must be put into a larger historical context. The 1970's witnessed the climax of a long-simmering reaction against law enforcement as the chief tool against drug abuse. That era of toleration, however, peaked about 1980, and since then we have been on a slope leading toward intolerance of drug use. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's attack on methadone maintenance is a recent example of opposition to any drug use by former users. As valuable as methadone may be for some (and I believe it can be helpful), it is an uphill battle to justify it to those who have zero tolerance for drugs. Can a national policy that was feasible in 1970 be resurrected three decades later in a less friendly climate?
Finally, remarkable claims for treatment in the early 1970's must be tempered by the knowledge that most people in trouble with drugs were taking heroin, for which methadone is a stabilizing replacement. Today, cocaine users are the vast majority of the hard-core population, a problem for which methadone is useless. Massing's recommendations are too valuable to be oversold.

INDUSTRY: NAICS511130 BOOK PUBLISHERS (58%); SIC2731 BOOKS: PUBLISHING, OR PUBLISHING & PRINTING (58%);

PUB-DATE: October 18, 1998

SECTION: Section 6; Page 74; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 3116 words

HEADLINE: The Agent;
The Most Hated Man in Baseball

BYLINE: By David Samuels; David Samuels, a contributing editor at Harper's, last wrote for the magazine about the private investigator Terry Lenzner.

 BODY:
The only rule of the rude and sprawling sports-entertainment culture that spans the morning drive-time radio hours to the late-night highlights on ESPN is that every fan has a right to his opinion. The second baseman can't hit left-handed pitching? Bench him! Ride the bum out of town! All that is required in exchange is that you back up your opinions with facts, the way the six stone-cold baseball fanatics seated at the conference table are doing this morning in a gray-carpeted office just off the freeway in Newport Beach, Calif.
As familiar as the scene may appear -- a bunch of guys tossing around batting averages and on-base percentages -- this is not your ordinary workplace conversation. For these men are marshaling statistics with a very single-minded intention: to prove that Bernie Williams, a shy and graceful athlete who patrols center field for the New York Yankees, is one of the top five players in the game. 
 "Every year Bernie's average has gone up, his on-base percentage has gone up, his slugging has gone up," summarizes Scott Boras, the man at the center of the table. A former minor-league player, Boras, 44, is today one of the country's most successful sports agents, a lawyer whose aggressive tactics have led critics to call him "the Darth Vader of baseball." Alongside him sit a Harvard economics graduate, two lawyers and a former computer engineer from NASA. After a minute of silent concentration, Boras arrives at a plausible frame for his story. "It's a 'Rise of Bernie Williams' thing," he says. "He's entering his prime. He's opened the door to stardom."
To his detractors, among them major-league owners, general managers and scouts, Boras is the most hated man in baseball, an agent notorious for his market-breaking salary demands and his Svengali-like hold over his clients, including 50 major-league and 35 minor- league players. Beginning in 1984, when he won a record $7.5 million five-year contract for his former minor-league teammate Bill Caudill, Boras has shown an unrivaled
ability to set new prices for talent. Most recently, he won a $65 million contract for the Atlanta ace, Greg Maddux, and an $8.5 million deal for J.D. Drew, a 21-year-old outfielder who had yet to hit a single minor-league pitch.
Seated at the table, Boras looks like the successful Orange County lawyer that he is, with a thick gold watch gleaming from his wrist and a touch of the old-time Western gunfighter around his unblinking eyes. When he is focused on something, the way he is focused on Bernie Williams's career stats right now, his eyes narrow with an unsettling ferocity that recalls photographs of the psychic Uri Geller attempting to bend spoons with his mind. What the numbers show is that, so far this year, Bernie Williams is first in the American League in hitting and on-base percentage. Yet they also show that when it comes to home runs and runs batted in, Williams's numbers, while impressive, hardly rank with those of crowd-pleasing sluggers like Sammy Sosa or Mark McGwire.
"But how many guys have scored a hundred runs and driven in a hundred three years in a row?" Boras asks, hunting for a more effective way to dramatize Williams's place among the top hitters in the game. According to the stat books piled up on the table, around a dozen players make the cut. But when this elite category is narrowed to hitters who also play center field, the list narrows down to a handful, including Bernie Williams, Mickey Mantle and Joe DiMaggio. "That's some tall cotton there!" Boras says. His eyes gleam.
For New York Yankees fans, of course, that gleam is bad news indeed. What it means is that Boras has hit on an argument that is likely to result in Bernie Williams becoming one of the highest-paid players in baseball history later this fall. And if the Yankees owner George Steinbrenner doesn't buy the argument that Bernie Williams is the equal of Mantle and DiMaggio? No matter. The Arizona Diamondbacks, the Los Angeles Dodgers or some other wealthy suitor surely will.
Grieving fans, strident denunciations of mercenary players, accusations by named and unnamed sources that Scott Boras is destroying baseball, all of that will have to wait until the last pitch of the season is thrown. Meanwhile, Boras heads off to his 9:15 spinning class with his wife, Jeanette. With early-morning meetings, 85 players to service and night games to attend, the morning exercise class is often the only time that the agent and his wife spend together during the week.
The Irvine Sports Club, where Boras works out, features floors of state-of-the-art fitness equipment and an Olympic-size swimming pool centered on a lofty sun-filled atrium. It is a gleaming temple to the culture of physical fitness and body worship that has transformed professional sports into a mass entertainment whose selling power dwarfs even that of Hollywood. And just as the Hollywood studios of the 1940's and 50's disintegrated in the face of the emerging star system, professional sports teams now face a similar fate, looking forward to a future in which they will live only in the shadows of their highly paid stars.
And what better place to occupy in the star-driven universe of sports entertainment than where Scott Boras finds himself right now? Like Michael Ovitz in Hollywood during the 80's, he controls access to talent. He is the medium through which stars are made. Sitting by his locker at the gym, he talks about his love for the game and the fact that stars are made through their performances on the field. Yet he admits that the money is the brightest light that shines on achievement in a market society. "Who ever heard of J.D. Drew before we got him the contract?" he asks, pulling on a sleeveless tank top and a pair of tight-fitting Lycra shorts. "No one. That kind of attention follows the money." Boras's own share of the profits is not insignificant, either. While his 5 percent commission on player salaries is hardly exorbitant (other agents receive commissions of up to 20 percent), it also amounts to more than $5 million a year. Impact Sports Marketing, the Atlanta-based company that handles endorsements for Boras clients and of which Boras is part owner, earns 20 percent commissions on the deals his players sign.
Yet it is also true that the big payoff is almost always the hard-won ratification of a 5- to 10-year commitment by the agent to a player whose chances of striking it rich pale next to the risks inherent in an athletic career. Take Bernie Williams, for instance. Thirteen years ago, when he first met Scott Boras at Hiram Bithorn Stadium in Puerto Rico, the Yankees star was a scholarly looking 16-year-old with a sprinter's build and a fondness for playing classical guitar. Coming up through the Yankees minor-league system, where he spent his first five years, the knock on the center fielder was that he didn't hustle. He lacked heart. And with his fondness for the guitar and his glasses, you could see Bernie Williams more easily as a young graduate student in chemistry than as the heir to Joe DiMaggio and Mickey Mantle.
"He wasn't a raw athlete," Boras remembers. "He was an intellect. And his intellect had to be fed before he could adopt the traits the scouts desired. And that was part of our process, where I would sit down with Bernie and say: 'When you make a bad play, you drop your head. Don't just look with a blank stare. Show disappointment. Show your frustration."' Behind such advice is the knowledge that making it out of the minors takes more than talent alone, and even players like Bernie Williams have to act the part. Having Scott Boras on your side doesn't hurt, either.
Through his team of minor-league scouts, Boras tracked Williams's progress through the Yankees organization, had regular face-to-face meetings with the young prospect and even flew to Puerto Rico to visit the player and his parents. All in preparation for the far-off day -- now set to arrive sometime this November -- when the fawnlike center fielder from Puerto Rico would be transformed into a market viper, striking fear into salary-conscious owners, perhaps breaking the hearts of his fans in New York, but almost certainly breaking the bank.
"Look, my opinion has always been that I would rather work for the star than work for the movie house," Boras explains on his way through the parking lot. "The star is always going to be pursued."
Yet if Boras has exploited the star system on behalf of his clients, he is hardly its creator. "The owners have figured out what their fans want," he says. "These fans want exclusivity. They want restaurants. They want private skyboxes with the comforts of your living room. They want seats with computers attached to them. And they are willing to pay a premium, four or five times the going rate." The expression on his face, somewhere between a truth-telling smile and an indulgent sneer, does not make it clear whether he approves or not. What is clear, however, is that waves of money are rolling in to major-league ballparks -- and Scott Boras sees it as his responsibility to get as much of that money for his clients as he can.
Walking down the steps of a near-empty Dodger Stadium in the late afternoon as the players work alone or in pairs before tonight's game, Boras is having a great time. He loves sitting in the stands a few rows in back of the dugout and hearing the smack of balls hitting leather over the bright green grass of the field. Yet to his critics, Boras's professions of love for the game are only a cover for the agent's greed. "He sees all the devious ways you can rip people off," says one baseball executive. Another one, Ron Schueler, general manager of the Chicago White Sox, has suggested that Boras's aggressive style is the result of his time in the minors. "Maybe this is something personal," Schueler told The Chicago Tribune, "but it's not good for baseball. Something must have happened." To Boras, such insinuations of bitterness and greed have a very obvious purpose. "These are merely personal affronts designed to do what?" he asks. "To keep me from the talented player."
Yet if Scott Boras is not in it for the money alone (his office is modest; he stays in cheap hotels on the road; he has never visited Europe; and he looks forward with real enthusiasm to late-night dinners at Taco Bell), it is also clear that he is a driven man who sees major-league baseball teams as the enemy -- at least at salary time. And that at least some part of what drives him results from the experiences of the smooth-faced young man with curly blond hair in a St. Louis Cardinals uniform gazing out from the photograph on Boras's office wall. The last day Boras played professional baseball, in 1978, he had just started law school after three knee operations. "The grass was green, I'm shaking and my knees were killing me," he remembers. "I went home and cried for two days. And then I went back to class on Monday. And they paid me anyway, which meant a lot."
Boras also remembers the first time he ever saw his teammates cut. "It was the shock of my life," he says, "because I had never seen the game of baseball make anyone unhappy. But when I walked into that locker room and saw 40 players get released and the emotion and how they did it -- you walk in and there's a slip of paper and your uniform is gone." After 20 years, his eyes still go wide at the memory. He looks like a boy on the farm who has just been told the truth about what happens to horses when they get old.
"And then you go out into the parking lot and guys are shaking hands and crying," Boras continues, after a moment of reflection. "I remember this one kid sitting there, just crying his eyes out, bent over, and he had been a No. 1 draft pick. He'd been doing this for four years. You saw dreams end. You saw players who didn't know what to do or where to go."
Which is one reason why Scott Boras fights so hard for his players and why he approaches major-league contract negotiations in the same hard-nosed spirit with which he played the game. He will make good on the promise to treat players like family. He will never let his clients down. As he sits in the stands with his briefcase by his side, one arm slung over the back of an adjoining chair, various Dodgers notice his presence and wander over to talk. One client, Charles Johnson, a catcher who set a record last year with the Florida Marlins by playing a full season without a single error in the field, is the first to come over, taking the agent aside to discuss both his personal life and his swing at the plate. The Marlins' World Series victory last year was a triumph for the agent as well. As Boras remembers: Charles came and got me, and he took me into the locker room. And there was Robbie Nen, Alex Fernandez and Kevin Brown. And I've known every one of these guys since they were starting out. I've known Alex since he was 16. I've known Charles since he was 16. And to sit there with four guys in a locker room, and Alex dumping Champagne all over my suit -- that's a very special time."
Boras knows that he is often the only stable element in his clients' careers. He is a lawyer, advocate, big brother, a source of endorsement deals, family counselor, psychologist and coach. After the Marlins won the Series, the owner, H. Wayne Huizenga, insisted that he could not afford his large payroll and scattered Johnson, Nen and Brown to other clubs, along with the rest of his high-priced talent. This year's incarnation of the Marlins lost more than 100 games. Whether the break-up of the team was caused by greedy players and their agent, as some fans believe, or by a mercenary owner depends on who is telling the story. That Scott Boras's clients will make top dollar no matter whom they play for is not in dispute.
But today Boras is worried about another client, a sweet-faced rookie from the Dominican Republic named Adrian Beltre. Projected to be a star player, Beltre has suffered through a shaky first season in which he has played part time while hitting around .200.
Perched on top of the Dodger dugout, Beltre at first says very little. Boras tries to draw the player out, asking awkwardly after the rookie's family back home and his favorite Dominican dishes. Boras decides to test the player by expressing his feelings about the Dominican Winter League. For Dominican-born players, Winter League ball is a chance to go home and perform before family and friends. For managers and executives of American teams, it also presents the risks of injury, bad influences and departures from the teams' conditioning programs. "I don't think you should play winter ball -- no winter ball, O.K.?" the agent says. "You should work on your conditioning here in the States."
Adrian Beltre considers the challenge with care before he responds. "I'll get back to you on that," he says. Then he smiles, a radiant, confident smile, to show that there are no hard feelings but that he will do as he pleases whether his know-it-all agent approves or not.
An hour later, Boras could not be happier. "When you try to take control over something and the player just nods, that means there is a self-esteem issue there. So when Beltre said, 'I'll get back to you on that"' -- he flashes a winning poker-player's grin -- "it told me that this player really, truly wants to be in control of what he does. And that's why this guy is going to be big."
So let the fans curse and the talk-radio hosts foam at the mouth, and let the baseball executives solemnly declare that Scott Boras is destroying the game. Driving out into the California desert beyond the urban sprawl of Los Angeles toward the setting sun, the agent is clearly in his element, fielding calls on his cell phone and looking forward to watching the High Desert Mavericks, the Arizona Diamondbacks single-A affiliate.
The High Desert Mavericks play in a gently sloping concrete bowl with good sight lines and fold-down seats for approximately 4,000 people. Tonight the stadium is probably half full. The crowd has a pleasant blue-collar feel, a mix of senior citizens, young couples and families with children who move out to the desert for the clean air, safer streets and affordable starter homes. There are no luxury boxes here. The fans come to cheer on players whose names are unknown outside of this community and their hometowns. Few on this field will ever make it to the majors.
One likely exception is the Mavericks' starting pitcher, Brad Penny, a raw 19-year- old pitcher from Broken Arrow, Okla., who throws two pitches in excess of 90 miles per hour. Penny is a market viper in the rough. As the game progresses, Boras charts each pitch that Penny throws, admiring his control and his consistent ability to pitch ahead of opposing hitters. By the end of the fifth inning, however, he has spotted a flaw.
"He throws a little bit across his body, which is a concern because of the stress that places on his arm," Boras says. Still, it is clear that he is impressed.
There is something refreshing about sitting beneath the stars in the California desert and watching players who, because the chances of ever making the majors are so remote, must play for something approximating a love for the game. The Mavericks fans are having a good time, too. As the seventh-inning stretch begins, nearly every fan in the stadium rises to his feet to join in the traditional chorus of "Take Me Out to the Ball Game." Scott Boras doesn't sing. He sits in his seat and scribbles notes on his yellow pad, the same pad he used to plot Bernie Williams's free-agent strategy earlier that morning.
For Boras's moment of transcendence, when it comes, will not take place inside a baseball stadium. It will take place on the phone or perhaps in the home of a player he has known for years. Although the hour is late and the road is dark as we drive back through the desert, the agent can imagine what that moment will feel like.
"Last year, when we did Maddux's contract," the agent recalls, "it was the biggest contract in baseball. That was an achievement. But the clear, resounding, overwhelming emotion for me was seeing the comfort in him that was not there before. And to me, it was to be able to deliver to my client, my friend, that kind of feeling, where three days later he could call me on the phone, sitting up in bed with his wife, and go, 'Man, was that ever a lot of fun or what?"'
If Boras's face is invisible now in the darkness, the emotion in his voice is easy to hear. "And I'm going, 'What are you talking about?' And he goes, 'Man, that was just like playing a game."'

SECTION: Section 5; Page 8; Column 1; Travel Desk

HEADLINE: A Town That Big Dreams Built

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER HALL; CHRISTOPHER HALL has traveled extensively in the Pacific Northwest.

 BODY:
IN 1887 in the booming settlement of Port Townsend, Washington Territory, a prosperous Maine-born contractor and occasional rum-runner named George Starrett married Ann Van Boklen, a hometown girl. At the time of the wedding, local Indian uprisings were a none-too-distant memory and Washington statehood was another two years away, but Port Townsend -- on the northeast corner of the Olympic Peninsula -- already seemed destined for prominence.
Designated by the Federal Government as the customs port for all of Puget Sound, largely because it stood at the entrance to Washington's inland sea, the town was crowded with tall ships, sailors and fortune seekers from around the world. A link to a transcontinental railroad appeared imminent, facilities for a city of 21,000 were under construction, and the actual population was climbing toward 7,500, up from 917 seven years earlier. Brick and stone commercial buildings lent an air of respectability to the town, although rampant gambling, drink ing and prostitution along the waterfront earned Port Townsend its reputation as the wickedest city north of San Fran cisco.
In 1889 George Starrett gave his wife a gift entirely in keeping with the times -- a new, large and lavishly appointed house on a windswept bluff 200 feet above the rough and tumble waterfront. The most remarkable feature of the wooden mansion was a four-story, octagonal tower on whose ceiling an artist had painted Mrs. Starrett as each of the Four Seasons. On the first day of each new season, when the sun shone through a pane of red glass in a dormer window, for a quarter of an hour Mrs. Starrett's corresponding seasonal likeness would be bathed in rose-tinted light.
More than 100 years later, the Starrett Mansion and its tower still stand watch over the shipping lanes of Puget Sound, with snowcapped Mount Rainier and the volcanic Cascades to the southeast, across the water, and the peaks of the sawtooth Olympics to the southwest. The restored house -- now an inn known as the Ann Starrett Mansion -- is one of the many preserved Victorian-era buildings that form an entire district listed on the National Register of Historic Places. For decades a regional destination -- Seattle is two hours away by car and ferry -- Port Townsend and its historic district increasingly attract visitors from other states and countries who are touring nearby Olympic National Park.
When I first saw Port Townsend around 1970, as a teen-ager on a family vacation, the town was just beginning to emerge from a long economic slump that followed the sudden end of its boom years. Preservation-minded owners had started to buy and restore the historic buildings, and a couple of inns had opened in old homes. But I recall being struck -- even at a green age -- by how ghostly and still the town appeared for a bright August afternoon. With all the half-vacant commercial blocks and faded turn-of-the-century houses, it seemed a figment of my young, overactive imagination.
Nearly three decades later, I returned last October for an overnight stay and found the renaissance in full swing. On the outskirts of town, I drove past a busy new supermarket. Near the refurbished port, I heard a muffled chorus of rat-a-tats, screeches and bangs -- a machine-made song of prosperity and industry. I saw new paint throughout the historic district, which covers both the downtown waterfront and the uptown residential area on the bluff. The district has been recognized now for 22 years, the same amount of time that George and Ann Starrett lived in their house, raising their only child while witnessing the demise of Port Townsend's ambitious dreams.
Within a few years of the Starretts' wedding, the railroad plan fizzled and the great land speculation that underlay most of the town's wealth came to an abrupt halt. By 1893, in the wake of a national depression, the population had dwindled to less than 2,000 and a large boneyard fleet floated in the harbor. Office buildings were left unfinished, and one of them later sheltered so many birds it was dubbed the world's largest birdhouse in Ripley's "Believe It or Not."
Except, perhaps, during May to September, the height of the tourist season, there is still a timeless, world-apart feel to much of Port Townsend. The community of 8,500 is geographically isolated, perched on a finger of land jutting into Admiralty Inlet -- the entrance to the Sound -- and surrounded on three sides by the waters of the inlet, a harbor and the Strait of Juan de Fuca. Port Townsend is connected to cities along the eastern shore of Puget Sound by a few ferries and a single rural highway that peters out on the far side of downtown. Behind the town is the rugged, rainy and sparsely populated Olympic Penin sula.
ON my most recent midweek visit, I spent an afternoon and the following morning exploring the historic district on foot. On both days, the sea air was bracing, and the autumn weather typically cool and dry. Because it lies in the rain shadow of the Olympic Mountains, Port Townsend receives only 16 inches of rain per year, while in the famous rain forests of the Olympic Pensinsula the average is 140.
During an afternoon walk along tree-lined Water Street, a six-block stretch of which constitutes most of downtown, I joined dozens of people shopping, eating and strolling in the weak sun. On both sides of the street are two- and three-story buildings with elaborate brick and masonry facades pierced by high, arched windows. The upper stories contain offices while the ground floors house shops and restaurants, only a few of which seem geared exclusively to the tourist trade. You can still get keys made on Water Street or buy a length of marine rope, and there are several independent bookstores -- including one, Melville & Company, whose hand-lettered, front-window manifesto promises a "stubborn refusal to stock stupid books just because they're cheap."
As many as 21 saloons dispensed liquor along Water Street during Port Townsend's boom years. While these days there aren't quite that many places to buy coffee, it still seemed that every third pedestrian I passed was sipping an espresso or latte from a paper cup. It's a sight you soon get used to in the java-obsessed Pacific Northwest.
From the end of Union Wharf, a new downtown pedestrian pier, I had a wide view over the water. Just in front of me, pursued by a flock of crying gulls, the Whidbey Island ferry churned toward shore, while in the distance a colossal container vessel sounded a long, low blast of its horn as it lumbered past a gray warship. To my right, a few miles down the waterfront, steam billowed from the slender smokestack of a 1927 pulp and paper mill, the town's largest employer.
The next morning, I wandered for several hours among the historic homes on the bluff -- a quiet world of turrets and gables, old gardens and sea birds wheeling overhead. Although most of the houses are privately owned, I got a good feel for the neighborhood by walking its narrow streets and occasionally stopping to read about a particular house in a book I'd found at the county historical museum.
The Starrett Mansion is perhaps the most ornate residence on the bluff. In addition to the ceiling frescoes, it boasts intricate interior carpentry using costly hardwoods shipped around the Horn. On the downstairs newel post, a cast-bronze goddess holds aloft an electric lamp, which in the late 1800's was a striking touch of modernity in the still-raw territory.
There are, however, other impressive homes. One is the F. W. Hastings House -- now the Old Consulate Inn -- an 1889 Queen Anne that has kept its original barn-red color. From 1908 to 1911, the German consul lived in the stately house while represent ing his government's commercial interests and occasionally providing refuge for German nationals in danger of being shanghaied.
One of the blufftop homes open for tours is the Rothschild House, the 1868 residence of an early Port Townsend merchant that is now maintained by the state and fitted with its original furnishings. The simple white house with yellow trim and brown shutters was closed when I stopped by, but through a window I glimpsed the 1891 wallpaper -- a repeating pattern of ornate tan and cream curlicues. At the nearby First Presbyterian Church (1889), I did have a look inside at the expansive, semicircular sanctuary, with its vaulted ceiling and 692-pipe organ, considered the oldest in the state.
Port Townsend's two most prominent government buildings, the Jefferson County Courthouse and the Customs House, are also on the bluff. The red brick courthouse (1892) is dominated by a 100-foot clock tower that once was an important mariners' landmark. The building and its parklike grounds occupy an entire block. On either side of the south entrance stand 90-year-old monkey puzzle trees, an arboreal oddity popular in temperate turn-of-the-century gardens.
Before leaving town, I spent some time studying the three-story, neo-Romanesque Federal Customs House, which commands a sweeping view of maritime traffic from its edge-of-the-bluff location. The sandstone building is solid and serious, and when erected in 1893, it must have been a potent emblem of national identity in a then-remote corner of the country. As Port Townsend slipped from prominence, however, the Customs House suffered a similar loss of stature. In 1913, nearly all its federal tenants, except for the post office, moved to Seattle.
I walked into the post office intending to have a quick look at the redwood paneling and ornamental ironwork mentioned in the guidebook, but on my way out I was stopped by the sight of townspeople standing at a counter to buy stamps or mail a parcel. Nothing noteworthy about that. But I also saw that each customer stood in two shallow depressions -- one per shoe -- worn into the white marble floor by generations before them.
 
Spending the night in a vintage inn, sampling the local oyster chowder
 
Getting There
Port Townsend is on state Route 20, 13 miles from U.S. 101.
There is direct passenger and car ferry service to Port Townsend from Whidbey Island. The crossing takes about 30 minutes, and the high season fare (from early May to early October) is $8 for a car and driver ($6.25 at other times); pedestrians and automobile passengers pay $1.80 year round. From the Seattle area, several ferry routes cross Puget Sound and hook up with roads leading to Port Townsend. For ferry information, call (206) 464-6400 or, from within Washington State, two toll-free numbers: (800) 843-3779 for automated information, or (888) 808-7977 for an operator.
There is a guide to Port Townsend on the Internet at www.olympus.net/biz/ptguide.
 
Places to Stay
I spent the night at the beautifully restored, 11-room Ann Starrett Mansion, 744 Clay Street, (800) 321-0644 or (360) 385-3205, fax (360) 385-2976. On the Internet, it is www.olympus.net/starrett. My room, formerly Mrs. Starrett's private parlor, was furnished with nice antiques, including a polished walnut deep-well dresser with marble top and an Eastlake canopied bed in mahogany. The room also had a pocket-sized bath with stall shower and a private balcony overlooking Admiralty Inlet. Double rooms, all with private bath, are $89 to $225, including a substantial cooked breakfast in the elegant dining room. For those who simply want to tour the house, it is open every day from noon to 3 P.M. Admission is $2.
The F. W. Hastings House Old Consulate Inn, 313 Walker Street, (800) 300-6753 or (360) 385-6753, fax (360) 385-2097, www.oldconsulateinn.com, has eight guest rooms with private baths. Rates, from $96 to $195 for two, include a seven-course breakfast as well as cordials and homemade desserts in the evening.
 
Places to Eat
At the Silverwater Cafe, 237 Taylor Street, (360) 385-6448, I had a great lunch of mild onion soup and half a tangy salmon salad sandwich, with a glass of crisp Washington fume blanc and a slice of blackberry pie topped with vanilla-bean ice cream. The bill came to about $15, excluding tip. The plant-filled, two-level restaurant is in a renovated 1889 Elks Building on a side street downtown. Open year round for lunch and dinner.
At Lonny's Restaurant, in the port area at 2330 Washington Street, (360) 385-0700, the subdued lighting and pared-down decor give the 66-seat dining room a big-city feel. Seasonal Northwest ingredients are used in dishes including oyster stew, a rich, velvety chowder made with local Dabob Bay oysters simmered in cream with pancetta, fennel, leeks and parsley. A dinner of the stew, house salad and glass of wine was about $24.
The Coho Cafe, 1044 Lawrence Street, (360) 379-1030, is a cozy storefront spot for breakfast and lunch with a vegetarian emphasis. A filling lunch of curried acorn squash soup, sourdough bread, coffee and apple pie was $7.50. Dinner is served in summer and on special occasions at other times of year. Closed for the month of January.
 
Sightseeing
The Port Townsend Visitor Information Center, 2437 East Sims Way, (888) 365-6978 or (360) 385-2722, distributes a free flier about a self-guided driving tour as well as a free visitors' guide. The center also can help travelers find accommodations.
The Jefferson County Historical Museum, 210 Madison Street, (360) 385-1003, occupies the former police court, jail and fire hall of Port Townsend's 1892 City Hall. The exhibits introduce players in the town's history, from American Indians, pioneer women and sea captains to a once-flourishing Chinese community. Open Monday through Saturday 11 A.M. to 4 P.M., Sunday 1 to 4 P.M.; closed weekdays in January. Admission, $2.
The Rothschild House, on the corner of Jefferson and Taylor Streets, (360) 379-8076, is open daily from April 1 through mid-October, from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., then weekends only to Nov. 30. It is closed altogether from Dec. 1 to April 1. Admission: $2. Guided Historical Tours offers two hourlong walks with a guide, one through downtown and the other through the uptown residential district. The downtown tour costs $10 a person; on the uptown tour, which generally includes a visit inside the Starrett Mansion and the Rothschild House, there is an additional admission charge of $1 per house. The downtown tour is offered throughout the year, and the uptown tour during summer only; both require reservations. Information: (360) 385-1967.

HEADLINE: Q&A/Sarwar A. Kashmeri;
Helping Businesses Prepare for the Euro

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
AS many focus on the coming of the millennium and the expected havoc it could play with computers, Sarwar A. Kashmeri is reminding people that a date perhaps even more significant is coming up sooner: Jan. 1, 1999. That is when 11 European countries will replace their currencies with one joint currency, the euro. And the effect will be a shot heard around the world, said Mr. Kashmeri, a resident of Mount Kisco and president of Niche Systems, a Manhattan-based consulting company, which has been offering seminars to help businesses prepare for the euro. He also has a Web site (www.nsinc.com).
The euro will be used by France, Germany, Italy, Spain, Portugal, the Netherlands, Belgium, Luxembourg, Austria, Finland and Ireland, 11 of the 15 members of the European Union. Mr. Kashmeri expects that other countries, particularly England, will eventually adopt the euro. Here are excerpts from a recent conversation with Mr. Kashmeri: 
 Q. Why should Americans who are not doing business with companies in Europe care about this?
A. I think there are two reasons. One is a business reason, and the other is a more basic tourist-travel reason. The biggest reason to me is that enormous business opportunities are opening up for American firms in Europe, and a lot of it is for medium-size and small firms. If they are prepared for it, they can take advantage for it. Two, what's taking place in Europe is the biggest single-currency trading zone in the world. So when the euro comes into being on Jan. 1, 1999 it will start assuming the same predominance as the dollar. What does that mean for interest rates? What does that mean for money supply? What does it mean for invoicing in dollars or euros?
Q. Will business opportunities be created because of the euro or coincidental to the euro?
A. Because of the euro -- and I'll give you some very simple reasons. Right now in Europe if you take all the companies that work in Europe and you take all the money that they spend in managing currency risk, it's roughly $57 billion every year. That $57 billion will now get freed up. Also Europe is very much like the United States used to be before we had a central bank and one currency. If you're a small business and you want to issue stock, let's say, in Belgium, you have very few places you can sell that stock because people outside Belgium really don't want to buy stock in Belgian currency because of the currency risk. But all of that is about to change dramatically. So people will buy stock all over, and there will be a growth in the bond market -- the capital market. They will become almost the size of the United States -- an enormous amount of new capital will be generated. That comes together with the fact that American companies are leaders in so many high-technology disciplines, which are going to be needed in Europe. So both of these are a potent mix, I believe, for opportunity for American companies.
Q. How should this affect travelers?
A. A number of different ways. Interestingly, if you took $1,000 and traveled now through those 11 countries that are adopting this single currency and you didn't do anything but exchange currencies at the airport and kept going, you'd wind up with only $850 because of the exchange rates and commissions. So you will not lose that $150. Prices will also be affected. Prices in Europe can vary as much as 30, 50, sometimes 100 percent for the same product. And it's not readily obvious because they're in all these different currencies.
Now for the first time people will be able to compare prices in the same currency. Sometimes there is no rhyme or reason for different prices except that people in one country just pay more for certain goods. A scarf by a certain manufacturer in France may have a cultural and prestige value that it may not have in, let's say, Portugal. So you can actually compare prices. If your itinerary takes you to two or three European cities, you may not want to buy the scarf in one country but you might want to in the other.
Consumer groups are forming in different Europeans cities, and they're saying, Come across the border, the price on this or that is so different. And remember, some of these are very small countries so it is not so hard to go across the border to shop.
Q. Recount the problem that the McDonald's Corporation faces.
A. McDonald's is trying to figure out exactly -- as are a number of companies, by the way -- how they're going to price their product. Big Mac prices can vary tremendously from one country to another. As you know, the Big Mac is the same size, determined by McDonald's regulations. So they're trying to figure out if they convert the price to euros, people might see a 60 percent difference, or more, from one country to another, in the price of a Big Mac. So they're trying to figure out how to counteract this. Should they change the price in one country versus another? Should they change the size?
Another implication for travelers is with credit cards. Right now, if you go from one country to another and you spend money, all you see on your credit card is an exchange rate. Buried in the exchange rate are two things: the money that is made on the changing of the currency and the credit card charge. Beginning next year, the currency rates will all be fixed, so cards will only be charging transaction fees. So you'll be able to compare the fees on cards, and if there is an exchange rate you could question it.
We should keep in mind that American Express is going to become the first company in the world to issue euro traveler's checks on Jan. 1, 1999. The euro is a wholesale currency. This means it will be used for stocks and bonds and by companies dealing with one another and governments raising debts. But notes and coins don't come into existence until Jan. 1, 2002. So a lot of people have been saying that it really doesn't matter for us folks who travel because we won't have euro notes and coins. That's now no longer true. There are banks that have announced they will issue euro credit cards. There are banks that have announced you can open accounts there. But most important for us, as Americans, American Express has said they will have euro travelers checks. So because prices are being increasingly listed in euros, our travelers will be able to say, I'll pay in euros.
Q. What affect, if any, will the euro have on an individual American's financial investments?
A. I'll give you a personal example: my wife and I had invested in this mutual fund, which dealt with European government bonds. It was a pretty good mutual fund. It made money by buying and selling different currencies and bonds, depending on their prices and interest rates. About a year ago, we got a letter that that fund was being shut down, because one of the things the euro does is make all the interest rates converge.
Q. Are there predictions about what the euro might do to the United States' balance of trade with those countries?
A. There are various scenarios there. At our last conference in September, Paul Volcker, former chairman of the Federal Reserve, gave the keynote address. He said the euro will be good for Europe. The scenario that is being painted is as follows: because the gross domestic product of those countries that are adopting the euro will very quickly become almost the same as ours, the euro will be a very strong currency. The dollar and the euro will be the two dominant currencies in the world. So some banks, like J. P. Morgan, are actually predicting a shift in reserves -- out of dollars and into euros -- equal to our deficit. What does that mean for us if that is all that happens? Would we have to buy oil in euros? Right now we are in the fortunate position of running a trade deficit and borrowing money from everyone in the world because everyone wants dollars.
Q. Will the European Union and its joint currency hold together?
A. I think it's going to hold together. I don't think it's going to be smooth sailing. This is a huge process, but I think the European governments will see it through. A lot of our companies, especially middle-size companies, are fixated on the year 2000. But they should keep in mind that the year 2000 is an event; it will happen and go. The euro is a whole process that will bring significant opportunities, and it's a very strategic issue compared to a very technical issue that the year 2000 is. The year 2000 is a programming issue. It's an expensive one, but it's just a programming issue. Whereas the euro is an entire change in a continent.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sarwar A. Kashmeri, a Mount Kisco resident and president of Niche Systems, in his Manhattan office. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: DANCE;
Dancing Away the Havana Blues

BYLINE: By SUKI JOHN; Suki John's ballet "Sh'ma" will have its American debut at the 92nd Street Y on Nov. 1.

DATELINE: HAVANA

 BODY:
A tropical rain cleanses the crumbling structures of old Havana as a motley group of dancers repairs to an underground sanctuary. Carrying donated costumes and worn audiotapes, they filter into an empty cabaret and begin to structure the afternoon lineup. A powerhouse modern dancer will present a new solo, a group of grade-school children will show a reconfigured mambo, a virtuosic teen-ager will accept a choreography prize and an ecstatic deejay wields a bootleg copy of last year's London techno hit. Two North American dancers will perform contemporary solos, making for truly exotic entertainment. Welcome to an Afternoon of Dance at the Cafe Cantante, where for a few hours the daily struggle is forgotten with the distinctly Cuban antidote to black-market blues: dance.
The Cafe Cantante is housed in Havana's Teatro Nacional, a post-revolutionary structure nestled in the Plaza de la Revolucion, guarded by a three-story-tall wire relief of Che Guevara in his beret. The theater complex is a shrine to Cuban culture, built to foster art by and for the people. A kind of miniature Lincoln Center, it contains once-beautiful studios and workshops, two large proscenium stages and the Cafe Cantante. 
 Theater and dance are still accessible to ordinary people, but the nightly cabaret cover charge at the Cafe Cantante is $10 American, prohibitively expensive for workers paid in Cuban pesos. Featuring some of the hottest bands in the country, the cafe harks back to the days of big daddies and fat cigars. Nocturnal tourists pay big money to be thronged by women whose intelligence and charm are matched only by their desperation. But once every two weeks, on Saturday afternoon, the cafe is reclaimed by the masses. The entry fee is 2 pesos (about 10 cents), and the crowd is decidedly local.
Afternoons of Dance, as these Saturdays are called, was started three years ago by Narciso Medina, one of Cuba's most highly regarded contemporary choreographers. Mr. Medina, 35, opened the first self-supporting dance school since the revolution, building a studio out of what used to be his family's modest apartment in Havana's Vedado district. His company is known for involving the neighbors: half the barrio works on the production crew in one capacity or another. His company performs frequently on the street, where they focus on the dances of Santeria ritual, based in the Yoruba tradition of West Africa.
Mr. Medina began the afternoons as a way to prepare emerging dancers for the stage and to further involve local residents in the making of art. The series combines polished performances, works in progress, improvisation, children's recitals and social dancing. "The cafe audience is better than in the theaters; they're more opinionated and enthusiastic," Mr. Medina says. "The conditions aren't perfect, but creativity abounds."
Rudimentary spotlights and tacky nightclub decor surround a small carpeted stage. The cheap tiles of the low ceiling are sometimes dislodged by dancers jumping high or being lifted. In front of the stage, a concrete floor provides space between tables for improvisers, brave souls who dance together without plan or structure. Drinks are sold in dollars, but black-market rum is the libation of preference.
The afternoons are dance jams in which everyone participates, effectively blurring the boundary between audience and performer. In Cuba, where dance is central to culture and religion, aficionados are unafraid to share the floor with professionals. The whole intergenerational crowd jumps up to boogie between the acts, the most extroverted leaping to the stage while the merely enthusiastic flood the floor. By late afternoon the underground cave feels more like a huge party than a performance, with heat and rum burning off any remnants of stage fright that might hold back the timid few.
One recent Saturday, the program began with a group of children from Mr. Medina's company school. Dressed in red and black, they depict Eleggua, one of the Orishas, or deities, of Santeria tradition. The dance is a study in simple technique, rhythm and floor patterns, designed to integrate performance skills into a lesson in Cuban folklore. The smallest dancer loses his way and, unfazed, creates his own variation of the dance.
Throughout the day children of both sexes perform with natural ease. In Cuba there is little stigma attached to boys dancing, and many of the country's most celebrated dancers are men. But the division of labor is apparent from an early age: boys dance with strength and weight while girls wiggle and shake provocatively.
Tomas Guidante, 28, a masterly soloist in Mr. Medina's troupe, performs a solemn, sculptural work in progress. Interrupting his ovation, he initiates a group improvisation set to imported New Age sounds. (Though their music is captivating, Cubans are fascinated by foreign recordings, perhaps because a decadeslong drought has been replaced by a glut.) Serendipity guides two women in black to the lip of the stage, where their eloquent gestures mingle in a celebration of the spontaneous. Suddenly the music changes to an explosive salsa. Three couples converge in a wheel, spinning through the latest version of "salsa rueda." They change partners, dos-a-dos and bump pelvises, grinning. Men duck their heads under women's elbows, unwinding limbs just in time to change partners again.
Los Morenos del Son, an ebullient band brandishing myriad percussion and brass instruments, launches into an infectious, updated folk song. The crowd responds energetically, old and young coordinating their moves. One hotshot after another embellishes a roosterlike strut, spinning, grabbing the air, twisting to the floor on one leg and rising up again. The wily lead singer creates a rap about the vicissitudes of life in Cuba. Several dancers hop on the stage and begin a Supremes-style chorus. They shimmy together and sing out: "O la Habana! O la Habana!"
When it's all over, the spent crowd spills out into the wet Plaza de la Revolucion. The Cafe Cantante turns back into a pricey nightclub. Dancers begin the long trek home, hitchhiking, walking or riding bicycles because buses overflow with passengers and taxis accept only dollars. They keep their eyes out for the rare snack they can afford, in pesos. O, la Habana, so rich and so poor.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Students from Academia de Danza Narciso Medina performing onstage at Cafe Cantante in Havana, where Saturday afternoon dance jams attract a crowd. (David Garten)

HEADLINE: THEATER;
A Detour in the Theater That No One Predicted

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH; Frank Rich, an Op-Ed columnist for The New York Times and its former chief theater critic, is the author of "Hot Seat: Theater Criticism for The New York Times, 1980-1993," being published this week by Random House.

 BODY:
IF you love the theater, or are part of it, or even writing about it, then everything's a drama.
When I joined The New York Times as a drama critic in 1980, I had no idea that there would be so many offstage events that would be part of my beat. I couldn't have imagined that the director Gower Champion's death would be announced from the stage by the producer David Merrick on the opening night of "42d Street." Or that Joseph Papp would lead a fierce protest two blocks from my office to try (unsuccessfully, of course) to halt the demolition of three theaters, including the Morosco (hallowed site of the premiere of "Death of a Salesman"), to make way for a towering Marriott hotel. Or that the theatrical community would be decimated by an epidemic, as yet unnamed and unremarked, like AIDS. 
 When 13 years later I moved on, somewhat sadder and (I hope) more than somewhat wiser, the landscape was unrecognizable -- and not just because of the vanished old theaters. The hottest play in town was a two-part, eight-hour "gay fantasia" known as "Angels in America," Disney was toying with sticking its first toe ("Beauty and the Beast") into Broadway, and Neil Simon, whose plays for better and worse had defined Broadway for three decades, was being exiled by economic realities to a small playhouse dozens of blocks from Times Square.
Now nearly another five years have passed, and the American theater seems poised for an even more dramatic and far more rapid shift -- perhaps the most momentous systemic change since the rise of Off Broadway and the regional theater movement in the 1950's, or even since the onslaught of television in the decade before that. And again, the biggest story is happening offstage.
After generations of being a backwater to the big-money, mass-audience show business mainstream of movies, television and the recording industry, the American theater is no longer secluded in its own idiosyncratic world where it can be entirely the master (however erratic and self-destructive) of its own fate. Like book publishing before it -- until the last decade, another quaint holdout against the forces of media consolidation -- the theater is now becoming "content" suitable for synergistic annexation and exploitation by our new entertainment conglomerates.
What prompts me to take stock of the theater's recent past and looming future is the time I recently spent compiling "Hot Seat," an anthology of the drama reviews I wrote for The Times. Confronting an avalanche of old clippings for the first time in years, I re-encountered some great nights and artists that remain indelible, as well as some fabulous fiascoes, like "Moose Murders" and "Carrie," that linger almost as brightly as triumphs like "Sunday in the Park With George" and "Glengarry Glen Ross." I also discovered that other plays, including some I had praised, had vanished entirely from memory.
MY editor suggested that I acknowledge this new perspective by adding retrospective afterthoughts to my reviews and, for fun, create an appendix with lists not just of bests and worsts but also of plays that I now feel I had overestimated (starting with Sam Shepard's "Lie of the Mind") and underestimated ("Nicholas Nickleby") the first time around. Rocco Landesman, the rare Broadway producer who is actually a reformed drama critic, has long griped that one of the worst things about critics is that they never admit to making mistakes. He's right. It was certainly liberating to admit to mine, now that I had some historical distance that allowed me to look at the record fresh and recognize them. (Though some of that historical perspective is simply the vicissitudes of age; in another 20 years, maybe I'll even look back fondly on "Aspects of Love.")
But the biggest, most humbling mistake I discovered -- and I feel only slightly defensive about it, since everyone else in or around the theater made it, too -- was my utter failure to anticipate the single most important change on Broadway in decades: the arrival of Disney as a redevelopment force, which led in turn to the happy revival of 42d Street and the entire Times Square neighborhood but, less happily, to the impending corporatization of the American theater, on Broadway and beyond. From this discovery it was only a sobering moment until I realized that, whatever my lists of bests and worsts, there was only one candidate for the honor of "most influential" production during my time as drama critic.
The winner, without question, is "Cats."
I am not talking about the quality of this musical or lack of same -- a mirthless debate even in 1982 -- or its marathon run, now and perhaps forever the longest in Broadway history. Rather, "Cats" is "most influential" in terms of its mega-influence on the national theatrical culture. "Cats" outlasted its critics, outlasted umpteen casts, outlasted English-speaking audiences, even outlasted the career of its principal creator, Andrew Lloyd Webber, who hasn't had a hit in more than a decade. But now, 16 years after its New York opening, the new world that the American theater is entering -- the world typified but not exclusively represented by Disney -- is the one that "Cats" has made.
"Cats" proved as no production had before that there was an infinite tourist audience for a theatrical attraction (as opposed to, say, a circus, Las Vegas revue or Radio City Music Hall pageant) in which spectacle trumped (or perhaps Trumped) content and no English was required for comprehension, whether by young children or foreign visitors. In conjunction with the rise of ticket prices into the stratosphere during its run, "Cats" soon made it difficult for adult, conventionally scaled musicals to compete in the commercial theater's marketplace. Why pay the same high ticket price for a show, consumers asked, that didn't have a levitating spaceship or a falling chandelier but only good songs, compelling characters or provocative drama?
A very few smaller-scale musicals, like "Rent" and "Bring In da Noise, Bring In da Funk," have bucked the odds, but they are anomalies. Straight plays, already an endangered species when "Cats" opened, have fared even worse. Drama on Broadway now pretty much means exclusively British imports and one-person shows. There is no major (or even semi-major) American playwright with a new work scheduled for Broadway this season -- and it's not because American playwrights aren't writing.
The lasting influence of "Cats" is felt not just in the ascendancy of spectacles. With its environmental set and audience-pawing performers, "Cats" (and its immediate Lloyd Webber sequel, the roller-skating "Starlight Express") also anticipated the kind of national theatrical franchise, from "Tony and Tina's Wedding" to "Late Nite Catechism," in which the "interactive" theatrical experience becomes virtually indistinguishable from theme parks and theme restaurants.
Most of all, "Cats" is the show that led indirectly but inexorably to Disney's arrival on Broadway a decade later by proving, first, that Broadway musicals could be marketed in a big-budget, Hollywood-style "branding" blitz (previously unknown in an industry that was suspicious of television commercials until the 1970's) and, second, that there was a huge profit to be made in exploiting animated characters on a Broadway stage. The characters of "The Lion King," at the gorgeously restored Ziegfeld palace the New Amsterdam, are literally descendants of the cats of "Cats," with the gifted director Julie Taymor providing the illusion of highbrow gloss to the kiddie show that the British director Trevor Nunn and (involuntarily) T. S. Eliot lent to their feline ancestors at another former Ziegfeld roost, the Winter Garden.
There is nothing wrong with a "Cats" or a "Lion King" as part of the Broadway mix -- if it actually were a mix -- but what "Lion King" helped bring to Broadway (as "Cats" did not) is a corporate sensibility in the work itself, not just its marketing. Whatever its merits, "Cats" was produced by individuals as an original piece for the theater, while "Lion King" is but the stage incarnation of an already existing product line (the movie, the tchotchkes, the video, the Disney World representations, etc.) manufactured by the most sophisticated entertainment giant on the planet.
The corporate mentality extends to the "Lion King" score, which is by an assembly line of disparate songwriters ("Cats" had only Mr. Lloyd Webber and his unacknowledged alter ego, Puccini). The performances at the New Amsterdam are often unspontaneous, as if they were audio-animatronic carbons of the animated movie's prototypes. There is synergistic cross-product-plugging not just in the Disney store off the lobby but onstage (a gag promoting "Beauty and the Beast").
Disney is not alone in bringing a corporate approach to the theater. It is merely the corporation with the biggest marquee name, deepest pockets and, in truth, the most skill.
A similar sensibility infuses "Ragtime," the product of Livent, the first publicly traded company to devote itself to theater. Though based on a nuanced, indisputably adult novel by E. L. Doctorow, this musical has the same look and feel as the previous Livent product, "Show Boat" -- even though the shows have different authors and were staged by very different directors (Frank Galati and Harold Prince, respectively). "Ragtime," like "Lion King," comes to a halt for a gratuitous corporate plug (a number about the Ford Motor Company, whose cash donation bought it the name of the new theater where the show is playing). And, like "Lion King" as well, "Ragtime" is suffused with a bland political correctness designed to appeal to all markets and offend no one. (In retrospect, the vulgar sexism of "Cats," with its whore-kitty-with-a-heart-of-gold heroine, seems almost daring.)
Since Disney still (rightly) regards theater as a small-potatoes part of its empire, and Livent is on the ropes in the midst of declining revenues and rising fraud investigations, they may actually end up as relatively minor players in the new corporate theater. The real power could turn out to be a newcomer few have heard of: SFX Entertainment.
The brainchild of Robert F. X. Sillerman, a radio mogul, the publicly traded SFX has swallowed up a bevy of pop-music concert presenters and venues, now controlling more than half the national market, including 31 of the country's 37 amphitheaters. Late last year, it bought Pace, the leading producer of theatrical touring shows in America, then went shopping for other theatrical properties across the map. Since theater on the road is now a far larger business than Broadway, SFX is de facto the most powerful theater producer in the country. We have come a long way from impresarios like David Merrick and Joseph Papp, who produced both high art and schlock but who ventured from theater only to dabble in movies or television. SFX's nontheatrical enterprises include not just pop concerts but the staging of monster-truck rallies, demolition derbies and the career management of Michael Jordan.
On the new road dominated by SFX, not only are straight plays extinct but even a Disney or Livent musical may prove to be a relatively rarefied theatrical offering. Much of the schedule at gargantuan touring houses around the country is filled out by what Variety has called "pseudo" theatrical attractions: multiple companies of "Riverdance," "Stomp," "Tap Dogs" and their many imitators and variations.
Meanwhile, Broadway more than ever tailors itself to this same huge and lucrative market. This explains not only why there are no major American plays on Broadway's schedule this season but why most of the announced shows are chestnuts with familiar, instantly saleable titles ("Footloose," "Peter Pan," "Annie Get Your Gun," "You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown").
The only antidote to this new commercial theater, which has more in common with the values of special-effects American movies and network television than did even old Broadway at its most commercial, remains the nonprofit theater of Off Broadway and resident theaters nationwide. As has been true since the 70's, the most exciting new plays originate in such companies -- but now they are ghettoized there. Nonprofit theater hits like "How I Learned to Drive," "Wit" and "The Dying Gaul" -- which once might have moved to Broadway (and from there, possibly, to the road), as "Glengarry Glen Ross," "Driving Miss Daisy" and "Angels in America" once did -- now remain in small houses for their entire runs. An occasional "Side Man" notwithstanding, they rarely transfer to Broadway and their only hope for national dissemination is if they are mounted in new productions by local companies around the country.
On its face this seems a workable system: a two-tiered theater just as there is a two-tiered film culture divided between Hollywood blockbusters and independent art-house films. But nonprofit theaters don't have the reach or the financial clout of even the movie industry's small fry; the most successful of these theaters still need serious philanthropic subsidies (public or private) just to meet costs.
Now, the new corporate theater giants are knocking at their door with bigger and bigger checks. This season alone three major nonprofit theaters -- Lincoln Center Theater in New York (Livent's "Parade"), the Alliance Theater in Atlanta (Disney's "Elaborate Lives: The Legend of Aida"), the Alley Theater in Houston (SFX/Pace's "Civil War") -- are collaborating with the new behemoths, exclusively on musicals. Are these Faustian bargains that will lead to other commercial collaborations that will change the character of such theaters and ultimately wipe tough new plays off their schedules, too? Or are they benign, one-shot deals? It is too early to tell.
An even larger open question is how corporate theater will affect nonprofit theaters indirectly -- by shaping the taste of their future audiences. If the new generations of theatergoers coming up now are mostly weaned on the esthetics of "Lion King" and "Riverdance," will they want the same limited theatrical diet when they become the new audience pool for the Roundabout Theater Company or the Goodman Theater in Chicago or Arena Stage in Washington?
A new Theater Development Fund survey released last month reported the good news that the under-18 theater audience is increasing for the first time in more than a generation. But there is chilling news buried in the fine print: almost all of these new theatergoers were attending "Beauty and the Beast" and the like, with the under-18 component of straight-play audiences numbering a minuscule 1.1 percent. (Even for 25-year-olds, the figure rises only to 6.4.)
BUT what keeps me optimistic about the theater, and always has, is that the influx of talent never stops. If companies that were vital when I was a drama critic, like the Circle Rep and Negro Ensemble Company, vanish, new ones like the Atlantic, New York Theater Workshop and Drama Dept. still come along to take their place. These are the theaters that find and nurture the individual voices that produce our best plays and musicals -- and they are the antithesis of the new corporate theater, which is run by committee. No corporation is ever going to create a "Death of a Salesman" or a "How I Learned to Drive" or a "Bring In da Noise" or a revival that makes you look at Shakespeare or Williams or Ibsen anew. But will the nonprofit theaters that do this work be heard against the forbidding din of giants like Disney and SFX and the other media conglomerates certain to follow?
At this point, as I recall, a drama critic ritualistically reminds readers that the theater is a fabulous invalid, destined to rise once more from its deathbed. But our theater, a bigger business than ever as measured in dollars, is hardly dying. The real question about a theater overrun by cartoon characters and scripted by marketers is what, over the long haul, will be its quality of life.
I never would have guessed as I watched a defiant Joe Papp, the great O'Neill actress Colleen Dewhurst beside him, fight big commercial interests to save hallowed old playhouses in the early 1980's that his struggle was quixotic. Even if he had saved those theaters, what would he have been saving them for? Not for the theater of language and intimacy and passion. Not for anything he or many of the rest of us back then would have recognized as plays.
