HEADLINE: Troubled Times Arise at Southampton Hospital

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

DATELINE: SOUTHAMPTON

 BODY:
IN his four-and-a-half years as president and chief executive of Southampton Hospital, Dr. John J. Ferry Jr. had seemed to be everything that the top administrator of a private hospital in the Hamptons should be.
Energetic, charismatic and ubiquitous, he expanded hospital services, invested in new equipment and added touches of panache like valet parking and official greeters in a main lobby. He was a fixture at social and sporting events that raised money for the hospital. He modeled black satin boxer shorts at a benefit for breast cancer and rode the hospital float in the St. Patrick's Day parade dressed as Peter Pan, green tights and all. 
 And in his dealings with the hospital board Dr. Ferry, a pediatrician with an M.B.A. from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, was always formidable.
In appearances one board member recalled as mesmerizing, Dr. Ferry assertively set forth his agenda and, toward the end of his tenure, convincingly laid to rest whispering that all was not well in the hospital's financial house because of billing problems and a dramatic rise in accounts receivable, among other things. Any problems, he said, were temporary.
But that's where Dr. Ferry was wrong. In August, he and the hospital's chief financial officer, Joseph Zwolak, abruptly resigned and two board members, the newly appointed chairman, R. Peter Sullivan III, and vice chairman, Donald Louchheim, announced startling news: The hospital was in a grave financial crisis, its depths yet to be plumbed.
In ensuing weeks the picture darkened. The hospital's new auditor, KPMG Peat Marwick, replacing Deloitte & Touche, uncovered layer upon layer of chaotic book-keeping and mismanagement. A computer software conversion problem was shown to have crippled billing, money the hospital said it was owed turned out not to be owed at all, and the "outsourcing" of bill collection led to new costs and hospital loss of control.
By last week, the hospital's reported short-fall had nearly reached $50 million for the past three years and was still rising as auditing continued.
Over the same period, a $25 million endowment fund had been used up, leaving the hospital, with an annual operating budget of $65 million, without a cushion in its time of greatest need.
Dr. Ferry had no comment last week about the hospital's troubles, but in a letter to The Southampton Press following his resignation, he said problems had been far greater than he, other hospital executives, the former auditor or board members knew.
"I understand and respect the need for change in leadership not only in finance but in executive management," he wrote, pledging to support the hospital "in any way I can."
The hospital's new acting president and chief executive, Thomas B. Doolan, said last week there was no danger that the 127-bed hospital, which has a staff of about 1,000 doctors, nurses and others, would close. He said streamlining, tighter financial operational controls, renegotiated contracts with managed care companies and possible cutbacks in hospital services would bring a turn-around. But Mr. Doolan said that the quality of hospital care would be maintained and that every effort would be made to retain satellite programs.
Mr. Doolan is also the head of the Peconic Health Corporation, the parent company of Southampton Hospital, Central Suffolk Hospital in Riverhead and Eastern Long Island Hospital in Greenport, which was formed to help the three hospitals compete in the deregulated health industry.
Mr. Doolan and Mr. Louchheim have both said contributions to Southhampton Hospital will be essential for its recovery.
But as news of the hospital's financial problems spread, contributors have had reasons to pause before writing checks. Mr. Louchheim said donations to the hospital were already "drying up."
"You can't go out and ask people to give us money without first creating a climate of confidence in the new management," he said. "People have to feel the contributions they make are not just pouring money down a rat-hole.
"Many people are saying, 'You squandered all our money, if we give you more how do we know you won't waste it?"' he said. "It's very difficult. We know we can turn this ship around, but we need some time."
Some have said the full story of the hospital's finances has yet to be told. The East Hampton Star, a weekly newspaper, suggested in a recent editorial that "the hospital leadership solicit not another penny until they have provided a full and satisfactory accounting."
Critics have questioned whether the board was diligent in overseeing the hospital. Membership on the 35-member board, with 30 seats filled, was, critics said, a social plum for second-home owners who were often absent and inattentive to hospital business.
"I know it seems incredible and I have great difficulty explaining it," said Mr. Louchheim, the former publisher of The Southampton Press. "But this isn't about millions of dollars disappearing. What we're talking about is an overestimation of billing.
"There isn't somebody running away with $30 million," he said, referring to hospital losses in 1997.
In a written statement, Mr. Sullivan said the board had been "stunned by disclosure after disclosure of the faults in our financial accounting and reporting systems" and had been "seriously misled" by auditing and management reports.
James J. Needham of Bridgehampton, a former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange and a former commissioner of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said he has notified the office of New York Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco of the hospital's problems.
Mr. Needham, also a former Southampton Town Board member and an accountant, said he hoped the attorney general would investigate whether board members upheld their responsibilities.
A spokesman for Mr. Vacco, David F. Corvette, said he could neither confirm nor deny that an investigation was being conducted.
Mr. Needham said the board had yet to give an adequate account of how it failed to notice the problems sooner. "It's just hard for me to understand how something like this could get away from them," he said. "Fifty million dollars disappearing like that is a great concern to everybody."
Even those who expected that the hospital would recover under Mr. Doolan expressed astonishment. "I think in a very brief time the hospital will be turned around," Vincent J. Cannuscio, the Southampton Town Supervisor said. "It's just unfortunate that they didn't have control over their own dollars and cents. It's unbelievable, really. If you don't have that, something is dramatically wrong."

HEADLINE: Tenants as Developer's Partner in a Loft Venture

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
UNPLEASANT as it is, a handful of tenants are living through the reconstruction of their building at 285 Lafayette Street, a block south of East Houston Street at the eastern fringe of SoHo. Once it was the Hawley & Hoops candy factory. Now it is an unusual example of an owner-tenant business partnership.
For years the artist-residents who occupy about a third of the building have expected that under one owner or another it would be upgraded and that they would be left peacefully in place in live-work space that many have improved at their own expense. 
 What they could not have expected was a major $16 million reconstruction that includes additional rooftop space as part of a conversion to a residential condominium, with themselves as an integral part of the development process. The completed project will have 21 new condominiums -- finished space selling for $1.4 million and up -- plus the 10 condominiumized spaces that the tenants will own.
In what may be an unprecedented arrangement in Manhattan loft rehabilitations, the upstairs tenants in the 100,000-square-foot building took a 35 percent interest in the owning partnership. They will get deeds to their space after the conversion. They will not share in profits from the sale of condominiums by the developer, and they have no financial interest in the entity that owns the new space in the rooftop addition. But should they eventually decide to sell their own space, they will benefit from the increased value that is being created.
They are not getting a gift. The 10 tenants are putting up a total of $700,000 for their 35,000 square feet, and chipping in about $500,000 more as their share of the construction and other costs associated with legalizing the building for residential use. Like many residentially occupied loft buildings, 285 Lafayette Street never received a certificate of occupancy for residential use, although under the 1980 loft law tenants have been given regulatory protections.
For the tenant living in a 2,500-square-foot quadrant of a floor, the equity contribution is about $100,000 -- $50,000 for the cash contribution and $50,000 more toward the legalization costs. Tenant spaces actually range from 1,000 to 3,000 square feet.
All parties seem to agree that the project would not have gone forward had the developer been unable to reach an agreement with the tenants, who were represented by Paul A. Gulielmetti of Manhattan. At one point they had hoped to buy the building themselves.
"It took us a long time to get used to Eric as our partner rather than Eric as our landlord," said Diane Villani, a tenant leader and a partner in Quartet Editions, a publisher of fine-arts prints, who has lived in the building since 1979. "We have had to get used to not calling him when there's no heat."
Eric D. Hadar is the 33-year-old president of the family-owned Allied Partners, the developer. Five years ago Mr. Hadar left Sonnenblick Goldman, the real-estate investment banking and brokerage firm, to found Allied Partners with backing from his father, Richard Hadar, the former president of a direct-marketing company, American Direct Industries, which was sold to Bankers Trust in 1989.
Allied Partners has become an active Manhattan real-estate investor, acquiring 14 properties that it says has a market value of about $136 million, and providing other investors with short-term loans.
IT acquired, for example, the Studio 54 building at 254 West 54th Street, with its 30,000-square-foot theater and adjacent 16-story office building, in 1994 when the property was in receivership. The office building was gut-renovated and re-leased. Allied also bought the 200,000-square-foot office building at 250 Church Street, again acquiring a mortgage for less than its face value, and renegotiated a lease to keep city agencies in occupancy.
Allied was an investor with William Lie Zeckendorf, Arthur Zeckendorf, Kent Swig and David Burris in the acquisition of Brown Harris Stevens, the brokerage and management firm, and with that firm it participated in the acquisition of 770 Lexington Avenue, at 60th Street. And it took over the management of 545 Madison Avenue, at 55th Street, when it was 70 percent occupied, after acquiring the leasehold mortgage and a limited-partnership interest. The building is now fully leased, Mr. Hadar said.
The Lafayette Street building has a long history as a rehabilitation candidate. Once it was owned by Norman Ferber, a Manhattan real estate investor. Along with other owners of financially distressed loft properties in lower Manhattan in the 70's, he brought in sculptors, painters, photographers and other artists on commercial leases, and they altered their space to live in them. Such tenants were given legal occupancy rights under the loft law.
Another owner, Fred Deutsch, took over in the mid-80's, and obtained an acquisition and development loan. He moved into the building and elaborately renovated 6,000 square feet of space for his residence on the fourth and fifth floors. Architectural Digest pictured the apartment on the cover of its February 1993 issue.
Mr. Deutsch approached Allied Partners in late 1994 about the building's financial plight. Its loan was in default and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation had taken over the assets of the bank that made it. Allied, along with two longtime New York City real-estate investors, Lawrence Friedland and Arnold Penner, acquired the mortgage. For two years Mr. Hadar and his lawyer, Norman Marcus, worked on a rezoning needed for the redevelopment. By the time construction was ready to start, Allied had bought out its financial partners and Mr. Deutsch, whose former apartment is part of the reconstruction.
Meanwhile, Mr. Hadar had negotiated the arrangement with the tenants, who supported the rezoning and the addition of 24,000 square feet on the roof, which was considered essential for the economic feasibility of the project. As owners the tenants will pay their proportionate share of the building's real estate taxes and operating costs, averaging $1,500 a month for 2,500 square feet.
ALLIED PARTNERS is selling 21 finished apartments, ranging in size from 1,780 square feet to 4,060 square feet, and in price from $375 a square foot to $1,244 a square foot. The first six floors -- the original building -- are divided into four apartments a floor. A new finished apartment with 3,235 square feet on the fifth floor, facing south and west, sells for $1.55 million. On the same floor an apartment of 3,365 square feet facing south and east sells for $1.825 million.
In the rooftop addition there are two set-back floors with seven apartments, one a duplex, and above that are two duplex penthouses. All these apartments have terraces. They sell for $1.4 million to $4.2 million. If the apartments are fully sold out at the currently listed prices, the total sell-out would be $41 million. Helene Luchnick, vice president of Douglas Elliman, the sales director, said that there are eight signed contracts so far.
The numerous special features include high ceilings -- three are 26 feet high or more -- terraces, fireplaces, and elaborate kitchens and baths. Many of the fixtures have been purchased from Urban Archeology, a store specializing in antique reproductions as well as originals. Urban Archeology has been a 30,000-square-foot tenant in the building since the 80's, and has a new lease from Allied that runs to 2006.
The architects are WYS Design Partnership Architects, and Costas Kondylis & Associates. Shael Shapiro, the architect in charge at WYS Design Partnership, noted that the development was made possible by the city's decision to rezone the property to a mixed commercial and residential zone (C-6-3) from its former manufacturing designation. Included in the rezoning was the already rehabilitated Puck building, with commercial and office space, a block to the north. The City Council rejected a broader proposal by the City Planning Commission to include in the rezoning an entire triangular stretch east of Lafayette Street between Prince and Bleecker Streets.
Does Mr. Hadar realistically expect people to spend over $1 million to live on Lafayette Street south of Houston Street? "Our average purchase price so far has been $2.5 million," he said. One penthouse apartment, a duplex with 2,890 square feet of interior space and a terrace, sold for $3.1 million.

HEADLINE: Albanian Student Looks Past Asylum

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
AFTER months of fighting for political asylum, Edmond Coku, 18, is breathing easily again. Fearful that if he returned to Albania, the country of his childhood, he would share the fate of his grandfather, Mr. Coku waged a hard-fought battle with the United States Government this summer -- and won.
But now the strapping young man, last year's valedictorian at Lincoln High School in Yonkers and now a scholarship student at Manhattanville College in Purchase, has another hurdle to clear. 
 Mr. Coku is also seeking political asylum for his 63-year-old father, Zef Coku, who still possesses the bullet-riddled coat of his own father, executed in 1945 by a Communist firing squad. As it is for many Albanians, the story of the Coku family is tragic.
"We have suffered for many years," the elder Mr. Coku said recently through a translator. "My father cried out before he died, 'Long life to Albania,' and he made the sign of the cross. But in the end, the Communists had their way."
Zef Coku came to New York from Albania on a visitor's visa in June to attend his son's graduation, and he wants to remain. Unlike other immigrants from his country in recent years who have fought unsuccessfully against stringent immigration laws to remain in the United States, the elder Mr. Coku will likely be granted political asylum, in part because his son has paved the way for him, lawyers said.
A 1997 immigration law denies asylum seekers full hearings with legal representation and the right to Federal appeals unless they quickly convince officials that they have a credible fear of persecution.
Before the law took effect, people who requested asylum were allowed to stay in the United States while their cases were heard by immigration judges. If the judges ruled against them, they could remain while they appealed to the Board of Immigration Appeals and then to the Federal courts.
"For everyone, it is getting more difficult to leave," Edmond Coku observed. "Every day it gets more dangerous in our country, and my father fears for his life because the same people who executed his father are free to kill him, too."
An Albanian, whose lawyers reported that she was gang raped because her husband refused to fight for the Government, escaped to the United States last year. She was detained in Elizabeth, N.J., but was unable to convince immigration officials that she had a credible case. As a result, she was deported under the new law designed to weed out baseless asylum claims. After her return to Albania, the woman's story received wide attention and she became a test case. She was finally able to come back to the United States, in part through the efforts of the American Civil Liberties Union.
In the case of the Coku family, a pattern of harassment and persecution has been shown, dating back to the grandfather's role as a leader in the Albanian War of Independence in 1912, said Adam Dorsky, a lawyer with the firm Wilson & Associates of Manhattan, which represented the student on a pro bono basis.
When the Communists came to power and before they executed Ded Coku in 1945, they labeled him a "kulak," a rich man who exploited peasants. After his death, the family (including Edmond's father who was 10 at the time) was sent to internment camps to live. Edmond was born in such a camp in 1980.
"Our story started with my grandfather's execution," the student said. Zef Coku, as a member of the National Association of the Former Politically Persecuted and an elected member of the Presidency of the District Council of Lezhe in Albania, has continued his family's tradition of political activism. But Edmond Coku does not think he will become politically involved once he graduates from college, preferring other courses of study like computer science, law or finance, he said.
"Perhaps political science," he added, "but I do not think so."
Because the Communists recently returned to power, Edmond's mother and his 23-year-old brother went to Italy, where they now live in detention camps. About the same time, as the political situation throughout the Balkans continued to grow more dangerous, Edmond was sent to live with relatives -- first in Dallas and then in Yonkers.
Measuring only 250 miles in length and 50 miles across, Albania has produced such people as the Roman emperor Justinian, Pope Clement V and Mother Teresa. But for the most part, its people have labored under difficulties as their mountainous country, which lies along the east coast of the Adriatic, was endlessly subjugated and divided by its neighbors, beginning in 1488 with the Ottomans, and then in 1912 with dictators from Serbia. About two-thirds of the Albanians in the Balkans are secular Muslims, and the others are Greek Orthodox or Roman Catholic.
An estimated 500,000 Albanians have settled in the United States, about half of them in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, said Vehbi Bajrami, editor of Illyria, an Albanian-American newspaper in the Bronx, which is published twice a week.
But successful asylum requests are becoming less frequent. Last year, after new immigration rules took effect, officials estimated that more than 1,000 people requested asylum at United States airports and about 80 percent of them were found to have a credible fear of persecution. The rest were deported.
Experts say the number of people seeking asylum has fallen sharply since 1994, when the Clinton Administration first stopped automatically giving asylum seekers work-authorization cards.
In Bayside, Queens, an immigration lawyer, Linda L. Foster, confirmed that it was becoming more difficult for those seeking political asylum because United States officials are now differentiating between those fleeing actual political persecution and those attempting to leave a bad economy.
Also, she said that the Communists had become "very adept" at hiding their true role in any political persecutions because Albania was seeking membership in NATO and wanted to avoid being cast as a nation that violates human rights.
In addition to the Albanians from Kosovo, Macedonia and Montenegro who live in the New York City area, another 50,000 to 75,000 have been living in the Boston area since World War I, said Joseph J. DioGuardi, a former Republican Congressman and now president of the national Albanian American Civic League. Also, close to 75,000 live in Detroit, and the rest are scattered in pockets nationwide, he said.
"Albanians have always felt comfortable looking to the West," observed Mr. DioGuardi, who said they have immigrated mostly to Italy and North America. In the United States, he said, many Albanians have been successful as entrepreneurs, often starting out as waiters, busboys and building managers and "quickly buying property or buildings, restaurants or other businesses." Mr. DioGuardi's forbears on his father's side fled to southern Italy from Albania in 1488.
Many of the buildings in the northern Bronx near the Grand Concourse and Pelham Parkway are owned and managed by Albanian landlords "who get ahead, want good educations for their children and move on to places in suburbs like Westchester," he said. There are enclaves of Albanians in Chappaqua, Ossining, Yonkers and Scarsdale.
Edmond Coku's extended family in Yonkers fits the picture of success that Mr. DioGuardi drew. Mr. Coku's 33-year-old cousin, Alfonse Pali, with whom he lives, came to the United States six years ago with his wife, Vera. After marrying in a civil ceremony in Lezhe because the Communist Government would not recognize their Roman Catholic faith, they fled to Greece, where they had a religious ceremony, and then to New York.
The couple worked in factories until Mr. Pali found a job as a doorman and then as superintendent in the Yonkers building where they now live with their 4-year-old son, Daniel. Mr. Pali is also employed at the Bronx Zoo as a construction worker and has started his own construction business. His wife is attending Lehman College in the Bronx.
Meanwhile, Edmond Coku is continuing his studies at Manhattanville College. After hearing about both his scholastic success and his immigration problems, Richard A. Berman, president of the college, asked him to join Manhattanville's small global community and offered him a full scholarship.
As a point of contrast to his latest accomplishments, Edmond Coku recalled a less happy time in Lezhe eight years ago when his teacher announced that he had won a student of the year award. Two days later, she withdrew the prize upon realizing who the 10-year-old boy was. "She found out that I was the grandson of Ded Coku," he said. "I still am, but now I can again carry the family name proudly."

HEADLINE: Coattails And More In the Races For Congress

BYLINE: By PEGGY McCARTHY 

 BODY:
WHEN Mark Nielsen campaigns, he often introduces himself as the Republican running for John G. Rowland's old Congressional seat. No matter that Mr. Rowland, now the Governor, hasn't been in Congress since 1990, and that there have been two Congressmen in the seat since then.
Mr. Nielsen, who calls himself a "John Rowland Republican," is the challenger in a competitive race for Fifth District Congressman. He is blunt about seeking to benefit from any coattails the popular governor might offer and any association with Mr. Rowland that would entice voters to cast ballots for him, instead of for the Democratic incumbent James H. Maloney. 
 The six Connecticut contests for the United States House of Representatives are taking place this year amid many questions, particularly about coattails. If Mr. Rowland does as well as polls indicate in the gubernatorial race against his Democratic challenger, Barbara B. Kennelly, will that help Republican Congressional candidates like Mr. Nielsen, even though there is no longer a party lever in Connecticut? Will a strong showing by the incumbent United States Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Democrat, against Gary A. Franks, the Republican challenger, offset Mr. Rowland's numbers and boost Democratic Congressional candidates? Will the House's handling of the impeachment inquiry into President Clinton's relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky affect voting for Congressional candidates? Will Democrats stay home on Election Day, Nov. 3, because of an apparent lack of enthusiasm for their party's gubernatorial candidate?
Such questions reflect the fact that this year, "there are so many conflicting moods in the electorate," said Howard L. Reiter, professor of political science at the University of Connecticut.
The State Democratic Party Chairman, Edward L. Marcus, expressed concern about turnout, saying the gubernatorial contest "has not been the most exciting campaign, in general." Much of the outcome depends on the 800,000 unaffiliated voters. There are 700,000 registered Democrats and 420,000 registered Republicans.
In the Fifth District, national Democratic strategists call Mr. Maloney's re-election bid "a major priority." Republicans name Mr. Nielsen, who championed welfare reform legislation, their best shot in the Northeast to pick up a House seat. Both candidates are receiving money from their national parties. The conservative-leaning swing district includes Danbury, Meriden, Waterbury, lower Naugatuck Valley towns, and inland suburbs in Fairfield and New Haven counties. Both the candidates are lawyers from Danbury and Harvard University graduates. Mr. Nielsen is currently a State Senator and Mr. Maloney a former State Senator.
Mr. Maloney, whose advantage as an incumbent is limited because he has served a single two-year term, has made constituent work a priority as a deliberate contrast to his Republican predecessor, Mr. Franks. Known for walking an independent path, Mr. Maloney he took a political gamble when he joined only 30 other House Democrats who aligned with Republicans in voting for an open-ended impeachment inquiry. (He did this after voting for the Democrats' limited proposal, which was defeated.) His opponent is making an issue of 1994 violations of campaign finance laws by Mr. Maloney's brother, in a case that prosecutors found no evidence that the Democratic candidate was involved. Mr. Nielsen also criticized the Maloney campaign for raising money for a primary that didn't occur, leaving open the possibility of allowing the same donors to contribute twice, once for a primary and once for a general election. The Maloney camp called the matter an honest mistake.
Five incumbents are seeking re-election to the House in Connecticut. All but Mr. Maloney voted with their parties' positions on the impeachment inquiry. There are independent or minor party candidates in all six districts.
The First District in the Hartford area is getting more than usual attention because there is an open seat for the first time since 1982 when the Democratic incumbent, William R. Cotter, died. Mrs. Kennelly, now the gubernatorial candidate, won a special election and easily won re-election in the district, which has a two-to-one Democratic plurality over Republicans. There hasn't been a Republican elected in the district since 1956 when Edwin H. May Jr. was swept into office with Dwight D. Eisenhower's Presidential landslide.
Despite the history of the Democratic bastion, state and national Republican organizations are giving money, campaign help and enthusiastic support to their candidate, Kevin J. O'Connor, a 31-year-old lawyer from Wethersfield. In the First District, "he has the best chance of any Republican I've seen in my political lifetime," Christopher DePino, chairman of the State Republican Party. Mr. O'Connor is emphasizing education as a major issue and what he considers complacency by Democratic officeholders on the issue. And, in acknowledging the lopsided registration in the district, Mr. O'Connor promised that he would be an independent lawmaker in the style of Representative Christopher Shays of Stamford and the Fourth District.
John B. Larson, of East Hartford, is the Democratic candidate for the First District seat, having won a four-way primary last month. Mr. Larson is a former State Senate President pro tempore who spent 12 years in the Senate. His most important legacy is family leave legislation, one of the first in the country. He ran an unsuccessful primary in 1994 to be his party's gubernatorial candidate. His expensive primary this year has put a drain on his campaign finances, which could hamper his activity in the final weeks of the campaign.
The race in the Sixth District for the third time pits the Democratic challenger, Charlotte G. Koskoff, against the incumbent Republican, Nancy L. Johnson. In 1996, Ms. Koskoff lost by just 1,587 votes despite having so little money; she could not afford television commercials. Since then, Mrs. Johnson, who is seeking a ninth term, has been spending more time in her district and is running an aggressive campaign, heavy on television advertising.
Paul R. Petterson, assistant professor of political science at Central Connecticut State University, observed that "there is no critical weakness Nancy Johnson has at this point other than being identified with Republicans." The district covers the northwest section of the state.
Ms. Koskoff, a former college professor and a lawyer from Plainville, said she expected to get financial help in the final weeks of her campaign from the national Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, help that she said facilitates other mainstream donations. And this time she has money for television advertising. In the last election, she strongly criticized the incumbent for her handling of an ethics investigation into House Speaker Newt Gingrich's fund-raising activities, which resulted in a House reprimand and a fine. She still reminds voters of that and also criticizes Mrs. Johnson's sponsorship of an amendment that allowed Stanley Works of New Britain to make parts overseas and label the finished product as made in this country. She points out that Mrs. Johnson has received campaign donations from Stanley Works.
Mrs. Johnson, a former State Senator from New Britain, has countered that she has worked to increase jobs in the district. She lists among her accomplishments passage of measures to improve mammogram standards and guarantee health care for uninsured children of welfare recipients and points to endorsements, usually handed to Democrats, from the Sierra Club and the Connecticut Education Association.
Elsewhere, the incumbents are considered by most political analysts to be in strong positions. The Second District Democratic incumbent, Sam Gejdenson, of Bozrah, has prevailed in tight elections in the past in his eastern Connecticut district, which includes New London, Middletown and Norwich. This year, he is seen to be in a better position in his bid for a 10th term. He is promising to work to make the Social Security system solvent.
Gary M. Koval, the Republican who is challenging Mr. Gejdenson, is critical of the incumbent's opposition to tax-cut legislation proposed by Mrs. Johnson. Mr. Koval, a Mansfield resident, is a State Liquor Control commissioner and owns a computer supply business. When he lived in Columbia, he served on the Board of Selectman, the Zoning Board of Appeals and was Republican Town Chairman.
In the Third District, in the New Haven area, the incumbent Democrat, Rosa L. DeLauro, is seeking a fifth term in a race against a poorly-financed Republican opponent, Martin T. Reust. Ms. DeLauro, a House Minority Whip, has maintained a high profile criticizing the Republican majority in the House. Television viewers witnessed a dramatic confrontation when she was gaveled by Speaker Gingrich and heckled by Republicans while she was attempting to debate the impeachment inquiry matter. She has been vocal in her complaints that the Republicans have not moved legislation through Congress. She cites her proposal to require insurance coverage for two-day hospital stays after mastectomies and coverage for one day for lymph node operations, which was not given a public hearing despite having 219 co-sponsors.
Mr. Reust, a Madison resident, is a computer software designer and consultant. He is a member of the Madison Board of Assessment Appeals who supports requiring a two-thirds majority vote for a Federal tax increase, overhaul of the Social Security system, and giving parents more choice over where their children attend public school.
In lower Fairfield County's Fourth District, Mr. Shays, who is seeking his seventh term, was in the national limelight with his co-sponsorship of a campaign finance reform bill with Representative Martin Meehan, a Massachusetts Democrat. It did not succeed, though, as the Senate killed campaign finance reform.
Mr. Shays's opponent is Jonathan Kantrowitz, a former Board of Education member in Fairfield, who ran four years ago and again has refused to accept money in the race. He has limited his message to a few issues, mainly fighting crime and drug use, improving education and helping to stabilize the world's economy by strengthening the International Monetary Fund. In a recent candidates' forum on Connecticut Public Television, when he was asked a question concerning health maintenance organizations and their treatment of elderly people, he responded that he is running "a very limited campaign focusing on a few issues, and that's not one of them."
Mr. Shays, who prides himself on bipartisan efforts, co-sponsored with Mr. Maloney legislation designed to restore contaminated, former industrial sites, called brownfields. It was signed into law by President Clinton.
While voters' sentiments across the country appear to be swinging daily, and with two weeks left until Election Day, nothing is certain, says Mr. Reiter of UConn. Backlash from the Clinton-Lewinsky scandal and the handling of impeachment proceedings have shifted from favoring Republicans to more recent polls concluding they would favor Democrats.
In Connecticut, voter reaction taken in late September by the Quinnipiac Poll showed 49 percent of respondents saying a candidate's position on impeachment wouldn't affect their vote in a Congressional election.
At the same time, 35 percent responded that they would be less likely to vote for a a candidate who favored impeachment and 14 percent said they would be more likely to support such a candidate.
"It could come back to haunt Republicans if they're perceived as strongly against the president," said Douglas Schwartz, director of the poll.

HEADLINE: Tribes to Revive Language

BYLINE: By SAM LIBBY 

 BODY:
IN 1908, the Mohegan elder Fidelia Fielding -- the last speaker of the Eastern Algonquin language spoken by the Pequots as well as the Mohegans -- died. Ninety years latter leaders of both the Mohegan and Mashantucket Pequot tribes say reviving their dead language is their most important long-term cultural goal.
"Today the Mashantucket Pequot regret the loss of their language and would like to see it become a part of the community again," reads the legend on an exhibit about the Algonquin languages in the recently opened $200 million Mashantucket Pequot Museum and Research Center. But the economically resurgent tribes have no immediate plans, programs or money allotted to make their language live again. 
 "Language defines a people," says Kevin McBride, director of research at the museum and research center, and an anthropology professor at the University of Connecticut. "A language expresses a people's national and ethnic identity. A people's language tells of their political, cultural and social life. Language articulates a people's world view. Surviving Eastern Algonquin languages such as Micmac, Passamaquoddy, Abenaki and Ojibwe show the fundamentally different way that Indian peoples and Europeans viewed the physical and spiritual worlds," said Dr. McBride.
The Mohegan-Pequot Language was documented by missionaries and scholars. In 1690, a Pequot vocabulary list was compiled by Rev. James Noyes in Groton. In 1717, Experience Mayhew, a Congregational Minister translated the Lord's Prayer into Mohegan-Pequot. Ezra Stiles, president of Yale University collected Pequot linguistic data in Groton in 1762.
Fidelia Fielding was born in 1827 and raised by her maternal grandmother, who spoke only Mohegan-Pequot. Ms. Fielding recorded her diary in the Mohegan Pequot language during the latter half of the 19th century.
To demonstrate their interest in making the Mohegan Pequot language part of their community again, the Mashantucket Pequot show a menu in the museum that was used during the tribe's 1992 attempt to translate such words as hamburger and hot dog into Mohegan-Pequot.
There should be enough documentation of the Mohegan-Pequot language to give linguists the ability to create a Mohegan Pequot-English dictionary, says Dr. McBride.
Words to describe aspects of the modern world such as computer and casino could either incorporate the English word or a Mohegan-Pequot construct that would describe the modern technology. A similar process took place in the 17th and 18th centuries when the Mohegans incorporated English words or Mohegan language constructs for chickens and other livestock as well as for firearms and technology introduced by Europeans, says the Mohegan tribal historian, Melissa Fawcett.
In the Mashantucket Pequot Museum and Research Center an interactive language exhibit allows traditional stories and common words in the Micmac, Passamaquoddy, Abenaki and Ojibwe language to be heard and read with English translation. The exhibit shows how similar and how different the vocabularies could be in the Eastern Algonquin languages; at the same time, basic similarities can be seen in the grammar and language construction.
Words in the Eastern Algonquin languages tend to be lengthy, consisting of many meaningful parts that could designate whether the word is singular or plural, animate or inanimate. Words often change according to context. A short sentence can convey many subtle meanings.
A trader crossing Connecticut in the 16th century would have encountered at least four different Indian languages, says Dr. McBride. Mohegan Pequot language speakers could not necessarily communicate in that language with the Niantics, Narragansetts, Nipmuck and Quiripi. This indicates that Connecticut Indians must have been able to speak more than one language since members of the different tribes did intermarry and socialize, he said. Eastern Algonquin Indians also could communicate with each other using a common sign language.
Because of the common grammatical rules of the surviving Eastern Algonquin language, and the documentation of the Mohegan-Pequot language, linguists should be able to establish the language's grammatical rules, says Dr. McBride. The museum's interactive Eastern Algonquin language exhibit promises the Pequot language will soon be included.
"It is a sacred obligation," says the Golden Hill Paugussett Chief, Big Eagle. "Indian people must keep their languages alive. If the language is not spoken, it must be made to live again."

HEADLINE: A Grand River Widens Its Circle of Friends

BYLINE: By ROBERT DUBROW 

 BODY:
THE 410-mile Connecticut River was recently designated an American Heritage River under a Clinton Administration initiative. The designation should give a boost to as many as 29 projects in natural resource and environmental protection as well as in economic revitalization, historic and cultural preservation.
The river, the longest in New England, begins in a tiny pond at the northern tip of New Hampshire and flows southward to serve as the Vermont-New Hampshire border. It traverses western Massachusetts then enters Connecticut. Bisecting the state, it flows past Windsor Locks, Hartford, East Hartford, Middletown, East Haddam and Essex, among others. Then it joins Long Island Sound at Old Saybrook and Old Lyme, providing an estimated 70 percent of the Sound's fresh water. The American Heritage Rivers Initiative was created to help communities use Federal programs better. "It's really the people who live and work in a particular place who understand what they need," said Whitty Sanford, of the Connecticut River Watershed Council. "We're the ones that are making the decisions and directing this." 
 Each sponsor of the river's successful nomination will be involved in some aspect of the action plan submitted with the nomination. Ms. Sanford said that "some projects are quite new and others have been in the works for quite some time but need to have specific assistance from Federal agencies."
The No. 1 issue facing the river in the state is urban sprawl, said Tom Maloney, of the watershed council. One project in the plan aims to protect prime agricultural soil, groundwater, floodplain habitats and the rural character of the river valley north of Hartford, said Mr. Maloney. The worry is, he said, that "malls, the strip developments are taking over. It's basically a planning issue; we're going to work to craft some planning strategies for the communities, hopefully, to implement on their own." Riverfront revitalization projects in Hartford, East Hartford and Middletown should also help contain urban sprawl, Mr. Maloney said. "There are terrific opportunities to focus attention on the livability of our cities and their connection to the river," he said.
Restoring pedestrian access to the river in Hartford and East Hartford as well as creating parks and recreational centers has been the work of an organization called Riverfront Recapture for 17 years, said Joe Marfuggi, the group's president.
Though much of the work is finished, slated for completion by next summer are a landscaped plaza over Interstate 91 connecting downtown Hartford with the river as well as grassy terraces at the river's edge, a stage at the base of the terraces, a bulkhead for excursion boats and water taxis serving downtown Hartford, and a new pedestrian promenade on Founder's Bridge.
Riverfront Recapture has worked to bring in visitors to spend time and money, mainly through major sporting events, including a professional bass fishing tournament, the United States Rowing Association's national convention and a triathlon with 1,100 competitors that included swimming in the river. "These kinds of events have an economic impact and depend upon a clean and healthy river to succeed," Mr. Marfuggi said.
Middletown's restoration effort includes Harborpark, a small park, said James Sipperly, a planner for the city.
But, he explained, access to Harborpark is difficult because Route 9 lies between the downtown business district and the river.
A pedestrian plaza over Route 9, reconfiguration of Route 9, and renovation of a pedestrian tunnel underneath the highway are the access options being considered. There are also plans to expand Harborpark, to develop additional areas for walking, picnicking, fishing, biking and boating, as well as to improve water quality.
Combined storm and sanitary sewer overflow and polluted runoff, Mr. Maloney said , are the river's two major water quality problems. As well-drained soil is replaced with pavement, rooftops and storm drains, he said, "everything just washes down into the river."
Road sand and salt, sedimentation and erosion from construction sites, motor oil, metals and animal waste are ingredients of the runoff.
In older cities, where storm sewers are connected to sanitary sewers, raw sewage in combination with a significant rainfall is a serious problem.
Mr. Maloney explained that "you get a big pulse, millions of gallons of water coming in with all that sanitary sewage and overwhelming the sewage treatment facilities. Any one of those August thunder storms that everybody loves will cause a combined sewer overflow event."
The Metropolitan District Commission in Hartford is now planning the second phase of its program to cope with such overflows, said Neil Geldof, director of engineering and planning. The city invested $80 million the first phase; strategies have included separating storm sewers from sanitary sewers and expanding and upgrading the sewage treatment plant.
But Connecticut needs the help of Massachusetts, where the Springfield area, just north of the state line, requires almost $400 million, officials estimate, to fix its combined sewer overflow problem.
"It's not good for the river in Connecticut," said Mr. Maloney. "It's probably the major upstream impact." A Connecticut-Massachusetts coalition is working to get a Federal budget appropriation for the clean-up.
Additional projects include one to restore fish that spend their lives at sea and return to fresh water to spawn, another to inventory river bank erosion, and a process to determine whether the four-state Connecticut River valley should be designated a National Heritage area by the National Park Service (the last would be in order to better manage the historical and cultural resources of the valley).
One of the benefits of the American Heritage River designation is communities in the four-state watershed coming "to understand that when somebody does something up river, it has an impact down river," said Mr. Marfuggi.
"We also have to understand the importance of the diversity of the communities on the river.
"By creating this group that will be working together, we'll improve that kind of understanding."

HEADLINE: The Ties That Bind: Thinking Globally At the Local Level

BYLINE: By DIANE NOTTLE 

 BODY:
DOES Margate, England, have an elephant?
Do tigers roam the streets of Colmar, France? 
 Do rock stars play outdoor concerts under the stars at an amphitheater in Zhejiang Province, China?
Well, no, to all of the above. Even so, these communities have some common threads with Margate, Princeton and Holmdel, respectively.
Margate, England, is a seaside resort at the end of the Thames estuary 15 miles northeast of Canterbury; a few years ago the mayor of Margate, N.J., paid a visit, bearing gifts of T-shirts and a proclamation of friendship. Colmar, in the Alsatian lowland near the German border, has no university, but it does have a music school and an art museum, a dedication to historic preservation and some sense of being a barrel tapped at both ends. Zhejiang County may not have a PNC Bank Arts Center, but it is a coastal province near China's largest city, Shanghai; nicknamed "Land of Fish and Rice" and "Home of Silk and Tea," it may be China's answer to the Garden State.
It is hardly surprising that New Jersey, with a population that is nearly one-eighth immigrant and a wealth of companies and educational institutions, has extensive international connections that bring the state a rich array of economic and cultural benefits.
Foreign consulates are usually in major cities like New York and Philadelphia, but New Jersey has several. Portugal, for example, has a consulate in Newark near the heavily Portuguese Ironbound district; Ecuador has one in Jersey City; Italy has vice-consulates in Newark and Trenton. And this year, the French consul general in New York City appointed an honorary consul for New Jersey: Caroline Lareuse of Princeton, one of 38 honorary French consuls throughout the country named with the blessing of the State Department.
Mrs. Lareuse, who is married to a Frenchman, holds dual citizenship and has long been active in many Franco-American activities, exemplifies the kind of personal ties that have developed through programs that let public officials and private citizens reach out to people around the world.
One such program is Sister Cities International, a Washington-based independent nonprofit organization founded in 1951 by President Dwight D. Eisenhower. "His idea was that if people would interact with other ordinary people, it would create an international understanding that would someday bring world peace," said Jane L. Tublin, director of international programs in New Brunswick's Department of Economic Development, who is on the board of Sister Cities International. The organization has linked 1,200 communities in the United States to 2,100 partners in 125 countries.
Currently, more than a dozen communities in the state are participating, and the New Jersey League of Municipalities plans to meet with Sister Cities International next month to establish more relationships abroad. Some communities have several siblings: New Brunswick and Elizabeth have three each; Montclair and Newark have four.
This weekend, officials from Jersey City and Princeton are leaving on trips to their sister cities in Europe. And communities here welcome visitors from abroad -- everyone from the 29 Austrian high school students who arrived in Montclair last week to the three young white tigers in residence at Cohanzick Zoo in Bridgeton, on loan from the Parken Zoo in Bridgeton's sister city, Eskilstuna, Sweden.
 New Brunswick's ties to Japan -- where it has two sister cities, Fukui, northeast of Kyoto, and Tsuruoka, about 200 miles north of Tokyo -- are especially strong and venerable. In 1867, Kusakabe Taro of Fukui came to America to study English and enrolled at the school that would become Rutgers University. The first Japanese member of Phi Beta Kappa, he finished his studies in just three years, but he died just before graduation and was buried in Willow Grove cemetery. Takagi Saburo of Tsuruoka, like Kusakabe a son of the samurai class, followed him to New Brunswick; he was later a member of the Japanese consulates in New York and San Francisco.
They were only the first of about 500 Japanese who passed through New Brunswick in the late 19th century, Ms. Tublin said. Those ties were rediscovered by Dr. Ardath W. Burks of Basking Ridge, professor emeritus of Asian studies at Rutgers, when he traveled to Japan in the 1950's on a Fulbright Fellowship.
Today, the partnerships are primarily cultural and educational. Each year, New Brunswick and Fukui exchange student artwork for exhibition; here, the art has been shown at schools, the public library and the Bristol-Myers Squibb company. In August, a delegation of 65 visited, including the 45-member Fukui Soave Children's Choir, who performed at the McKinley School en route to Brazil. Tsuruoka sends students to New Brunswick for two weeks each summer, and New Brunswick has now sent two teachers there for two-year assignments.
Because of the large Hungarian population, New Brunswick also began a sister-city relationship with Debrecan, Hungary, in 1987. Debrecen, 120 miles east of Budapest, was selected from a list of five cities profiled for common factors. "It has two teaching hospitals, a medical school, an important museum and a university that was very much related to Rutgers, although it's much smaller," Ms. Tublin said. "And the biggest industry is pharmaceuticals. For all these reasons, it looked like a perfect match." Programs so far have included Trade 2000, a conference to promote business partnerships at the World Trade Center in Manhattan last October; "Healthy Families Healthy Children," in which doctors examined issues like immunization and nutrition, and an exchange of folk dance troupes.
And now, a committee of about 25 is working with Irish Sister Cities Committee to form a third sister-city relationship, with Limerick.
 
JERSEY CITY
Bagpipes in Spain: A Cultural Triangle
The Irish are also becoming involved in a three-way relationship with Jersey City and Oviedo, Spain, thanks to Jose Arango, a senior adviser to Mayor Bret Schundler.
Oviedo, the capital of Asturias province on the Bay of Biscay in northwestern Spain, with a population of about 200,000, already had an American sister city, Orlando, Fla. But Mr. Arango is a native son, more or less. Born in Cuba of parents from Asturias, he moved to Oviedo with them when he was 7 and lived there until the family came to West New York in 1973 for six months when he was 17. Those six months have stretched to 25 years in New Jersey.
He called on a friend -- "we played soccer together in Spain" -- whose father is the chief of protocol in Oviedo. When Oviedo's Mayor, Gabino de Lorenzo, came over to visit Orlando in February, he traveled via New York and stopped by Jersey City.
Mr. Arango describes Oviedo, a city of 275,000, as "a beautiful town, surrounded by mountains." Its university is among the oldest in Europe, and the city also has a medical school and a Gothic cathedral.
Asturias has a strong Celtic tradition, being in the region where one of the seven Celtic tribes migrated before the time of Christ, Mr. Arango said. "In the northern region, they have bagpipes," he said. "All the food is based on potatoes and fish and cabbage. If they send their kids to learn English, they send them to Dublin. There's the Catholic tradition. And Spain is still fighting the English influence in Gibraltar."
Since Jersey City also has a large Irish population, Mr. Arango is now working to involve the County of Dublin, too. This weekend he is leaving on a trip to Madrid, Toledo and Oviedo. "Part of the delegation is Irish people in the administration because they understand right away," Mr. Arango said.
With a population that is about 35 percent Hispanic, Jersey City also has sister cities in Puerto Rico, Peru and the Dominican Republic -- all former colonies of Spain. "There's always that hate-love relationship with Spain," Mr. Arango said. "But the bottom line is, they feel proud. We all got some part of the culture from there."
And in September, during Hispanic Heritage Month, "we had a visitor from Barcelona," Mr. Arango said. "Now, everybody wants to come to Jersey City."
 
MONTCLAIR
A Provider of Hope In Hard Times
Montclair is the twin city (the British term) of Barnet, England; the Schwesterbezirk of Graz, Austria's second largest city; the goroda pobratimy (brother city) of Cherepovets, Russia, and the ciudad hermana of Laguna de Perlas, Nicaragua.
Barnet has a Montclair Park, where New Jersey irises have been planted, and Montclair has a Graz Park. Cherepovets has named a street for its sister city -- "the only street in town with freestanding two-family homes" in a nation of large apartment blocks, said Linda Wanat, Montclair's municipal clerk. In 1992, when Austria celebrated the 500th anniversary of the Columbus's voyage to America, the United States was represented by a display of American Indian art from the Montclair Art Museum.
The relationships with Barnet and Graz are approaching their 50th anniversaries, said Ms. Wanat, who coordinates the sister city programs endorsed by the town. Each is run by a volunteer committee and financed through donations, and each grew out of humanitarian aid.
Friends of Barnet was officially founded in 1949, but the towns' relationship actually dates to World War II, when the mayor's wife, Helen Barrett Speers, headed a committee to evacuate English children to Montclair. Fifty-two came over from Barnet, a borough of London, and a longstanding friendship was born. In 1994, for the 45th anniversary of Friends of Barnet, twin plaques showing parades of English and American schoolchildren were placed in the two towns' municipal buildings.
Overseas Neighbors, the group in touch with Graz, began sending medical supplies and Care packages to Austria "even before the Marshall Plan," said its president, Juliana Belcsak. "The initiative has always been people to people," she added. "We try to stay away from politics as much as possible. "
Mrs. Belcsak simply laughed when she was asked how many foreign visitors she had housed. "It's uncountable at this point," she said. "Sometimes we have entire delegations coming."
Humanitarian aid continues, in new forms: Montclair has sent food and medical supplies like insulin to Cherepovets since their relationship began in 1990, and medical supplies and books to Laguna de Perlas. So does the parade of children in need of help. At least four children from Cherepovets have come to New Jersey for life-saving medical treatment through the Rotary Club that Montclair helped establish there. "When they come, they're really deadly ill; there's no hope for them," Mrs. Belcsak said. "We're pleased to send them back in first-class shape."
What does Montclair, an affluent suburb of 38,000, have in common with Cherepovets, a heavily polluted industrial city of 350,000 that produces mainly steel and fertilizer? "A lot," Ms. Wanat said. When she visited Cherepovets, she was given "a very formal tour" before she asked if she could just sit down and talk with some local women. "I didn't want the tour for the visiting fireman," she said. "I wanted to really get to talk to the people. Once I made that clear, we stopped doing all the ceremonial things, and they let us talk directly with the people we wanted to meet.
"In the middle of this conversation, I realized we had everything in common. One woman's son was a star football player. He didn't want to go to college; he just wanted to be a pro. Another was bemoaning that her family had a small apartment and her mother-in-law had come to live with them. I saw them reflected in my life and my friends. They're the same as we are. They have the same desire for peace, for financial security. What I loved was, when they invited us in, they gave us the very best they had to offer. And sometimes that wasn't much."
 
HOLMDEL
A Partnership In Progress
David Chai, the deputy mayor of Holmdel, has long been a human bridge between Eastern and Western cultures. Born in Nanking "before Japan invaded China" in 1937, he attended high school in Japan for six years before coming to the United States in 1955. "But I still have some memory of the old country and speak the language," he said. "It's been quite helpful."
Helpful, that is, in his work to establish a sister-city relationship between Holmdel and Zhejiang Province, following up on an effort in 1981, under Gov. Brendan Byrne, to make Zhejiang Province into New Jersey's sister state.
Zhejiang province, south of Shanghai on the Yangtze River an the East China Sea, is "a coastal state very much like New Jersey," Mr. Chai said. "It's like us in that it's next to a major financial and metropolitan area. Geographically, it's very similar to us. It's about five times the size and five times the population, so it has a similar density. To think of any city or province in China, it's usually a lot denser than anywhere here. And economically, we have a number of coastal industries -- fisheries, shipbuilding, export-oriented businesses." He is coordinating efforts with the state Department of Commerce to promote trade, noting that Governor Whitman was planning to visit Zhejiang Province on her trip to Asia next year. "There's quite a bit of excitement over that," he said.
 
PRINCETON
All the World's A Stage
Not all international relationships involve governments. This year, the McCarter Theater in Princeton established a partnership with the Market Theater in Johannesburg, recognized worldwide for its challenges to racism in the apartheid era.
In May, Athol Fugard, the renowned South African playwright, actor and director, brought the Market Theater's production of his latest play, "The Captain's Tiger," for its American premiere, to close the McCarter's season. In exchange, the McCarter sent "Having Our Say: The Delany Sisters' First 100 Years," written by its artistic director, Emily Mann, to Johannesburg in July for a four-week run.
"It was a huge success, both critically and in audience response" said Jeffrey Woodward, the McCarter's managing director, who was among the delegation that traveled to Johannesburg.
"Having Our Say," the story of two centenarian black sisters, is "very much a play about American history," Mr. Woodward said, "but the issues of race and overcoming discrimination are, of course, resonant in South Africa, so the response was quite loud and moving."
Although the McCarter and the Market have no firm plans for another project, Mr. Woodward met with John Kani, a longtime collaborator of Mr. Fugard's who now heads the Market Theater, when Mr. Kani lectured in Princeton this month. In the meantime, the McCarter extended its hands across the ocean once again for this season's first play, "Electra," produced in association with the acclaimed Donmar Warehouse in London starring the British actress Zoe Wanamaker.
The McCarter's hometown has had an especially rewarding relationship with Colmar, its partner in France, said Mayor Marvin R. Reed. "It's one of the nicest places, and that's what they say about Princeton; that's why we get along so well," Mr. Reed said. Situated in the center of Alsace just west of the German border, Colmar, which dates to medieval times, is considerably larger than Princeton, with a population of about 65,000. "But because of its location between Strasbourg and Mulhouse, it has somewhat the same flavor we have, being between New York and Philadelphia," Mr. Reed said.
Residents of Princeton and Colmar have been "going back and forth for the last 12 years," the mayor said. Those trips have included offical visits by elected officials; exchanges of groups ranging from youth soccer teams to musical groups (the American Boychoir and the Westminster Choir have performed in Colmar), and business trips to discuss investment possibilities. In April, Mayor Reed is expecting a delegation of public utility officials -- covering gas, water, electricity, cable television and Internet access -- from the Colmar area.
The Mayor himself is leaving for Colmar today with a group of 30 from the Princeton Arts Council on an art-and-architecture tour that also includes Strasbourg and Basel, Switzerland. While in town, he may want to stop in at Princeton News, a stationery store, or Princeton Coiffeuses for a haircut. Its owner once spent time at a salon in Princeton, teaching the staff the art of French braiding, Mayor Reed said, and later the owner's daughter paid a return visit to Colmar.
The French may also come to Princeton for the services of Mrs. Lareuse, the French honorary consul. She could not estimate how many French citizens might constitute her client base; "they don't all matriculate at the French consulate," she said. But with about 100 French companies doing business in New Jersey, the number is probably considerable.
Her duties include "almost anything that comes your way," she said. She helps French families living here for extended periods place their children in schools; assists with passports, visas and other paperwork, and, in best diplomatic tradition, attends receptions at the consulate in Manhattan. She works a flexible schedule, for which she is paid "a very small stipend."
As for Colmar, "it's a charming city, with beautiful architecture, beautiful restaurants and excellent vineyards," she said. She should know; she has a family tie. During World War I, her uncle served there as a liaison between the French and American armies and eventually rode in the victory parade through the streets of what is now her hometown's sister city.
Small world, isn't it?

HEADLINE: Commercial Property;
Vornado's Chairman on Why Its Gusts Have Abated

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
STEVEN ROTH, the chairman of Vornado Realty Trust, hit New York's office market like a whirlwind last year, buying Bernard Mendik's portfolio of 4 million square feet of Manhattan properties for $650 million as the Mendik Company was preparing to become the city's first real estate investment trust.
The deal came as a surprise, because Vornado was best known as the operator of suburban shopping centers. 
 But having decided to move into the Manhattan office market, Mr. Roth went on a tear, spending an additional $1.7 billion to acquire such properties as the building known as One Penn Plaza, which occupies most of the block bounded by 33d and 34th Streets and Seventh and Eighth Avenues.
In all, Vornado bought all or the large majority of the ownership positions in 20 buildings in the city including most of the buildings on both sides of Seventh Avenue between 31st and 34th Streets. The company has said it plans to transform the area into the urban equivalent of entertainment-oriented shopping mall, with Macy's at 34th Street and Penn Station-Madison Square Garden complex serving as anchors.
But lately, Mr. Roth has been less active. Since announcing an agreement to acquire the 1 million-square-foot building at 770 Broadway at Eighth Street and a smaller structure in June, little news has flowed from Vornado's headquarters in Saddle Brook, N.J. Last week, the company did announce that Mr. Mendik, who had been co-chairman of Vornado, had resigned to pursue private interests and said that it had acquired some property from Mr. Mendik's partners for $104 million.
Some real estate executives have speculated that the steep decline in the price of Vornado's stock (the name comes from a fan company taken over by Mr. Roth's predecessor as a tax shelter) have made it impossible for the company to issue operating partnership units, which eventually convert into common stock, to pay for properties.
Vornado's stock, which reached almost $50 a share earlier this year, has been trading recently in the vicinity of $30 a share. Most REIT industry shares have, of course, taken a pounding in the stock market in recent months. The argument is that if a REIT meets an owner's price with the devalued stock, it will be perceived to have overpaid if the stock price rises to what the REIT managers consider a "normal" level.
Mr. Roth does not appear much in public. Indeed, he proclaims in Vornado's annual report that "we will continue our policy of almost never talking to the press."
But Mr. Roth did appear at a recent state-of-the-market meeting organized by Insignia/ESG, the current corporate form of the old Edward S. Gordon Company.
At that meeting, Mr. Roth conceded that his company's acquisition pace had slowed considerably in recent months. But he said that the ability to pay was not an issue because the company had over $1 billion available to finance purchases.
The reason, he said, is that owners' expectation of what their properties are worth have become overly inflated.
"We have just gone through a period of participating at auctions held by institutions," he said, "and we have been coming in third and fourth. The pricing is wrong. That is why we have not bought a building in six or seven months."
In spite of the big numbers involved in the company's entry to the Manhattan office market, he said, Vornado's cost basis for its buildings is $175 a square foot in a market where new construction costs from $400 to $450 a square foot. Noting that many of the properties were occupied by tenants with rents below the current market rate, he said that the company would be supplied with increasing cash as the leases expired and rents moved up toward market levels. "We have $30 space in a $40 market," he said.
As the rents roll over, he said, they will add $130 million a year to Vornado's cash flow over the next 10 years.
Mr. Roth said the suspicion that some aggressive buyers overpaid for property was reflected in the capital markets. In the early 1980's, he said, interest rates were high, but lenders were willing to finance all of an acquisition. "You could borrow 105 percent of a piece of real estate," he said.
HE said that rates had generally declined from that period until now, but that lenders were willing to finance only a smaller part of a deal. "The rates are low, but you can't borrow more than 60 percent of the cost of an asset," Mr. Roth said. "My theory is that the lenders suspect that the value of the buildings will go down."
Mr. Roth described the debt markets as being "in chaos," apparently referring to the market for commercial mortgage backed securities, where as much as $20 billion in loans has piled up awaiting sale. He said the lack of debt financing would choke off a lot of new building.
As a result, he told the group of real estate brokers and executives, in a time of economic uncertainty caused largely by events in Asia and other overseas markets, , " for the first time real estate's not the bad guys."
"Most people have a stunningly reasonable amount of debt," he said, "and there are almost no defaults in real estate."
In the late 1980's, the recession was preceded by a wave of real estate development, particularly in Manhattan. As a result, many developers could not fill their properties with tenants at rental rates anticipated in their financial projections. Some defaulted, losing the buildings to lenders, who absorbed losses when they were sold.
Of course, tough times can also provide buying opportunities, Mr. Roth noted. That's what he did in 1980, gaining control of Vornado and its valuable real estate, as the Two Guys retail chain the company was then operating faded. He repeated the trick later in the decade, taking control of Alexander's Inc. and its real estate as the retail operations became unprofitable.
Although Vornado has extensive exposure to the retail market, with 59 shopping centers with 12.4 million square feet of space as of the end of last year, Mr. Roth said he "lost faith in retail as an investment in the mid-1990's."
"The retail market is saturated and the retailers are mature and non-differentiated," he told the real estate group. "They are all selling the same products. Retail is going to get murdered in the next recession."
Although best known for its shopping centers and, more recently, for its incursion into Manhattan, Vornado is a broadly diversified company. Mr. Roth said he seeks to invest in "fortress" or "franchise" properties whose very size or unique position in an industry protects them from competition.
One example, he said, is the company's 60 percent interest in Americold Logistics, which operates 80 refrigerated warehouses, with 394 million cubic feet of space. The company accounts for 25 percent of the refrigerated public warehouse space in the country and Mr. Roth said anyone buying a frozen turkey in this area was getting a bird that probably spent some time in one of those warehouses.
Another is the Merchandise Mart in Chicago, a 5.4-million-square-foot building that Vornado bought in April for $630 million. Mr. Roth said the facility was the major trade show building for the furniture industry and that 65 percent of all the contracts for office furniture are signed there annually.
Mr. Roth may have something similar in mind for the fortress he has assembled along Seventh Avenue in the Penn Station area. The properties, which include the 1,700-room Hotel Pennsylvania, had largely been individually owned. Mr. Roth had remarked in a previous interview that "there is a lot you can do when ownership is concentrated in one strong hand."
He told the real estate group that he expected the trend toward public ownership of real estate to continue, but at slower rate than that of the last few years because of the dip in REIT stock prices and unavailability of public capital. Because REIT's are required to pay out 95 percent of their income to shareholders in dividends, they have little in the way of retained earnings and must return to public markets to finance growth.
Mr. Roth said that real estate companies considering adopting the REIT structure would just have to accept the fact that stock prices fluctuate in unpredictable ways. "Our stock dived six months ago when the business was never better," he said.
He said that there was at least one way in which running a public company was not that much different from the family-controlled real estate companies, which are a hallmark of New York real estate.
"Public companies have to deal with analysts and family companies have to deal with cousins," Mr. Roth said. "And they are both pains."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 653 words

HEADLINE: THE RIGHT THING;
In Dismissals, Silence Has Its Perils

BYLINE: By JEFFREY L. SEGLIN; Jeffrey L. Seglin is a visiting fellow at Harvard University's Center for the Study of Values in Public Life. His column on business ethics will appear the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: righthng@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
YOU walk into the office, and as the day goes on you realize that the guy who sat in the cubicle next to you for years isn't there. It's not just that he hasn't come in to work. There is no trace of him. The family pictures, the plants, the cartoons he liked to clip and post are simply gone. Office scuttlebutt has it that he has been dismissed. But there is no official word: no memo, no department E-mail.
Welcome to the modern workplace, where companies are so concerned about wrongful-termination suits that silence often replaces honest communication. Most managers with power to dismiss have faced the problem:whether to let people know why a colleague has been let go or to lie low. 
 A consequence of the first option is obvious: the risk of being sued for what may be seen as defamation. A consequence of the second may be subtler, but no less serious: creating a climate of fear and being labeled a boss who does not level with the staff.
Who can blame companies for choosing the silent route? In 1997 alone, more than 50,000 wrongful-termination suits were filed in state and Federal courts, according to Edgewater Holdings, an insurer in Chicago.
"The upshot is you get a workplace where the law has made speech dangerous," said Walter K. Olson, a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute and author of "The Excuse Factory: How Employment Law is Paralyzing the American Workplace" (Free Press, 1997).
One casualty on this battlefield was Paul J. McCarthy, dismissed in January 1994 by a Rochester division of Unisource Worldwide, a big marketer of paper and packaging systems. Mr. McCarthy had sold the unit's packaging machinery for almost four years. Unisource bought the company midway through his tenure. After initially being given no explanation for his dismissal, he said, he later was told he failed to meet "performance related criteria."
Mr. McCarthy contends that he was dismissed because he told supervisors about conduct by a fellow employee that had put a Unisource vendor at a significant safety risk by taking him to a bad neighborhood. The vendor confirms that account, but did not report the incident to Unisource and declined to be identified.
"We sold over $1 million worth of product through his company," the vendor said. "I didn't want to risk losing the business." But he did tell Mr. McCarthy, who was a friend. "He went ballistic on it," the vendor said. "Paul's a pretty righteous person."
 MR. McCARTHY reported the incident to a regional vice president. The vice president told Mr. McCarthy's boss to dismiss him, according to Mr. McCarthy and others involved.
Mr. McCarthy, 39 at the time, was not part of a "protected class," like members of a minority group or older workers, that can sue over a retaliatory dismissal, if that is what occurred. Given New York law's adherence to the notion of "employment at will," Unisource did not need to give a reason for dismissing him.
Patrick Farris, senior counsel at Unisource Worldwide's headquarters in Berwyn, Pa., said, "The company is very comfortable with the decision that it made with respect to his termination."
If there is no legal issue, where is the ethical problem? It's simple. Fear of being sued has led to a situation in which people treat one another badly. They don't talk, or they talk but don't say anything. But this may backfire, said Mary Dollarhide, a management lawyer. Consider a situation, she said, in which a worker in a protected class has been "a lousy performer," and there has been no employer discrimination. "You don't counsel them because you're afraid you're going to get stuck with some bogus lawsuit having to do with their protected status," she said. "When things deteriorate to where you have to fire this person, you're going to end up with an empty personnel file without a lick of evidence that anything was ever wrong."
Not a lot of winners in that picture.
