HEADLINE: On the Eve of Glenn's Shuttle Flight, Concerns Over a Lull in Launchings

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD 

 BODY:
Behind the excitement of the coming spaceflight of Senator John Glenn is quiet apprehension about hidden dangers.
Safety experts agree that the space shuttles, like temperamental hot rods, must run regularly or become balky and their launching crews rusty. But the shuttles have flown little of late. So Senator Glenn's flight is seen, at least in theory, as unusually risky. 
 In response, the space agency is taking precautions like having ground crews do many more dry runs meant to sharpen their skills. It says these rehearsals will offset any dangers, though some private experts say the odds of disaster still might be unusually high.
"We've been concerned," Dr. Seymour C. Himmel, a senior member of NASA's Aerospace Safety Advisory Panel, said in an interview. "When you have a hiatus like this you have to keep your skills honed."
Dr. M. Granger Morgan, head of engineering and public policy at Carnegie Mellon University, agreed. "There are concerns whenever an organization that has to perform a high-reliability job stops engaging in continual practice," he said.
The thunder of Mr. Glenn's blastoff aboard the shuttle Discovery, set for Oct. 29, is to occur after an unexpected silence of nearly five months at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida.
This is the longest time between shuttle launching attempts since the recovery from the 1986 Challenger disaster, when the spaceships were grounded for more than two years. The first crew to fly thereafter, in 1988, consisted of all shuttle veterans, mostly former military test pilots used to putting their lives on the line.
The current gap in flights was caused by unforeseen delays in building the international space station, a global effort whose payloads are to dominate the shuttle agenda for years. The delays stem from Russia's financial woes and have raised concerns among Federal and private safety experts, especially given the high visibility of Mr. Glenn's flight.
The space agency itself has changed its public stance on the dangers posed by a flight slowdown.
A year ago, before the gap opened up, Wilbur C. Trafton, then head of space flight for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, told Congress that inactivity was dangerous. If work on the station is delayed, he warned, then "the shuttle quickly drops below what we think is a safe flight rate, which is about five flights a year."
That problem has come to pass in that the five-month gap, if repeated over the course of a year, would amount to an annual rate of fewer than three flights. Even so, NASA officials dismiss it as minor. They say that better analyses show that the shuttle can safely fly fewer times a year and that the rigorous exercise of ground crews and managers is removing any possible peril.
"We normally launch every six to eight weeks," said Dave King, a shuttle official at the Kennedy center at Cape Canaveral, Fla. "But when summer brought a five-month pause between launches, we went to work developing a practice schedule that would keep the team fresh."
Robert B. Sieck, head of shuttle operations in Florida, said that he had talked with Mr. Glenn about the slowdown and that the Senator, a veteran of the astronaut corps, was unruffled by it.
"We're going to be just as safe as ever because we have the rules and requirements and procedures that protect us," Mr. Sieck said in an interview. "The teams are going to make sure that nothing bad happens."
Mr. Glenn himself has repeatedly played down shuttle risks.
"Of course there is a small danger," he said when his flight was announced in January, but he added, "NASA's done an outstanding job" of keeping the risks as low as possible.
On his nine-day flight, Mr. Glenn, 77, and six other astronauts are to conduct more than 80 scientific experiments. The Senator's are to center on the aging process.
The shuttle is, by far, the most complicated machine ever to fly into space, and therein lies the danger -- there are more things to go wrong. It has 230 miles of wiring, 417 circuit breakers, 600 fuses, 950 switches and 2 million parts, half of which are meant to move.
The shuttle's three main engines release energy equal to 23 Hoover Dams and loom as a safety factor because they work at dangerously high heats, pressures and speeds. Its twin booster rockets are a special worry because one of their kind leaked blistering hot flames that touched off the Challenger explosion, which killed six astronauts and a high school teacher.
Fueling and launching the fleet of four winged spaceships and refurbishing them between flights takes a standing army at the Florida spaceport, which employs about 14,000 people and pumps a billion dollars into the state's economy every year.
The current break in shuttle flights came as the space station project fell on hard times. Originally, orbital construction of the big outpost was to have started in November 1997. But as that date neared, and as Russia's problems multiplied, NASA pushed back the launching of the first station component.
The flight of Mr. Glenn was announced on Jan. 16 of this year, as the space agency was struggling to reduce the repercussions from the station's delay on the shuttle, which is to be the main transporter into orbit of the outpost's many parts. Among other things, the agency was planning hundreds of layoffs at the Florida spaceport.
Things got worse. On May 31, NASA announced that the start of the station's orbital construction would be postponed even further, from June to November, making the orbital outpost overdue by a full year.
That schedule still holds, barely. And it has thrown planning for all shuttle flights into disarray.
As silence at the launching pads was forecast to last for five months, NASA analysts got edgy, as did the agency's overseers. So a wide program of safeguards was undertaken in Florida.
For instance, on Aug. 20, some 150 launching team members labored through a mock countdown bedeviled by troubles like false sensor readings and bad weather.
"The test plan and problem scenarios are kept secret," Debbie Frostrom, a shuttle expert who helped draw up the drill with senior engineers known as gremlins, said in a statement.
During the overall slowdown, the spaceport is doing three times as many mock launchings and four times as many fueling simulations as normal, said Mr. Sieck, the head of shuttle operations. It is also conducting its first comprehensive assessment of all procedures and systems since the restart of shuttle flights a decade ago.
Astronauts, the ultimate beneficiaries of such care, have made their presence felt in Florida in the slowdown. On July 16, C. Gordon Fullerton, a former shuttle commander, gave the keynote address when the entire center stopped regular work for a day to focus exclusively on heightening safety.
Private experts said it was conceivable that all the extra practice and precautions would actually make the Glenn flight safer.
"They've had time to fix all the small things," said Dr. Elizabeth Pate-Cornell, head of industrial engineering and engineering management at Stanford University.
But Dr. Charles Perrow, a Yale sociologist and author of "Normal Accidents," a study of high-tech risk, said the slowdown and all the attendant changes could add complexity to an already complex equation, undercutting safety.
"It's certainly going to heighten the difficulty," he said. "Whether that means new danger, nobody probably knows."
Dr. Himmel of NASA's Aerospace Safety Advisory Panel, a team of independent experts, said he was confident that the heightened precautions were sufficient to ward off unusual perils.
"The important thing is to realize that when you get into something that is extraordinary, everybody has to be made aware of that fact and to do the job right," he said.
The lull is to ease up a bit after Mr. Glenn's flight. The first station launching is set for Nov. 20 when a Russian rocket is to lift the initial element of the outpost into orbit.
The shuttle Endeavour is to carry aloft the shuttles' first station payload on Dec. 3, in theory paving the way for dozens of other shuttle trips in service of the station over the years, helping to keep launching teams sharp and the fleet safe.

HEADLINE: Internet Filter Makes Bad Censor

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Prof. James Heckman of the University of Chicago is right when he points to early intervention programs for preschool children and early elementary students as a better investment than tax credits for higher education (Economic Scene, Oct. 15). 
 While Mr. Heckman points out that college students in four-year public universities pay only 20 percent of the cost of their education, unmentioned was that parents pay far more for child care and other early education programs: an average of 60 percent of the cost of all forms of child care and up to 100 percent of the cost of care in many cases.
Despite the fact that numerous studies have shown the societal benefits of good-quality early education, the large public and private investments that have reduced a college student's portion of tuition to 20 percent have not been made in early education.
 
FAITH WOHL
Pres., Child Care Action Campaign
New York, Oct. 16, 1998

HEADLINE: Kroger to Buy Fred Meyer, Creating Country's Biggest Grocer

BYLINE: By DANA CANEDY

 BODY:
The Kroger Company said yesterday that it would acquire Fred Meyer Inc. in a deal that would create a supermarket giant with $43 billion in annual revenue and 2,200 stores in 31 states.
Kroger will pay about $8 billion in stock for Fred Meyer and assume $4.8 billion of the company's debt, further consolidating the grocery business and creating the largest supermarket chain in the country. With the latest transaction, Kroger regains the spot it lost to Albertson's Inc. as the nation's largest supplier of eggs and milk. 
 The acquisition gives Kroger the status of the leading chain, stretching from the fast-growing Western markets, where Portland-based Fred Meyer is strong, to the Midwest and the Southeast, where the Cincinnati-based company has many stores and much visibility. The move also gives Kroger even greater purchasing power and substantial economies of scale.
The combined company will retain the Kroger name and continue to be run from Cincinnati. Both chains' stores will retain their names and local management teams.
Fred Meyer shareholders will receive one newly issued share of Kroger stock for each Fred Meyer share, which puts the value of the shares, based on Friday's closing price, at $48.75. After the stock swap, Fred Meyer shareholders will own 38 percent of the combined company.
Fred Meyer shares declined $4.8125 yesterday, to $44.1875, and Kroger shares closed at $45.4375, down $3.3125. The market's inital reaction indicated that investors might have concerns about the logistics of integrating the companies, while some might have expected Kroger to acquire the much larger Safeway Inc.
Still, managements of both companies called the transaction a "powerful strategic combination." Joseph A. Pichler, chairman and chief executive of Kroger, said, "Together, we will have the No. 1 or No. 2 market share in 33 of the nation's largest markets."
The acquisition is not expected to affect Kroger's earnings per share in the 1999 fiscal year and is expected to contribute substantially to earnings thereafter, though the companies did not say by how much. Kroger said it expected to save about $225 million within three years, with approximately $75 million of that in the first year.
"We will achieve economies of scale by leveraging purchasing, information technology, manufacturing and distribution across a much larger store base," Mr. Pichler said. Some of the cost cuts will come from laying off an undisclosed number of office workers, but not from job cuts at stores -- now about 90 percent of the companies' combined work force of 300,000.
Mr. Pichler will continue to run the combined company while Ronald W. Burkle, chairman of Fred Meyer, will become chairman of the executive committee of Kroger's board. Robert G. Miller, vice chairman and chief executive of Fred Meyer, will become vice chairman and chief operating officer of Kroger. In addition to Mr. Burkle and Mr. Miller, four other Fred Meyer nominees will join the Kroger board, which will be expanded to 19 directors from 13.
"I have been a longtime believer in consolidation in the supermarket industry," Mr. Burkle said, adding that teaming up with Kroger helps both companies because it creates a national powerhouse.
The deal was approved by both companies' boards and is subject to shareholder and regulatory approval.
Antitrust problems are not expected. Where there is overlap, as in Arizona, the stores operate different formats. For instance, Fred Meyer operates drugstores as well as superstores that sell everything from jewelry to Jello, while Kroger sticks mainly to bread-and-butter items. Even so, Government regulators may require the company to sell some stores before the deal is approved, but that is not likely to derail the acquisition.
In all, Fred Meyer, which has annual revenue around $15 billion, operates 800 food and general merchandise stores in 12 states from Alaska to Texas. Kroger, with revenue of $28 billion, operates 1,398 food stores and 802 convenience stores, most of them in the Midwest and the Southeast, as well as 34 manufacturing plants.
Analysts said the combined businesses will create an industry leader with strong management, substantial potential for earnings growth and the store formats and locations to compete with nontraditional food retailers, like Wal-Mart, that now sell a range of grocery items, from lettuce to soup.
They added that one concern was whether management would be able to integrate the combined company's far-flung operations, especially when Fred Meyer is still trying to digest the businesses of other chains it recently acquired.
Last year, the company acquired Quality Food Centers and Ralphs Grocery Company in separate deals worth about $2 billion. It also purchased Smith's Food and Drug Centers for $1.96 billion.
"They operate different types of formats and Fred Meyer has different operations in different markets," said George E. Thompson, an analyst who follows the industry for Prudential Securities. "That is going to make it complicated, there is no question about that."
Still, he and other analysts said the benefits of the deal outweighed the potential pitfalls. "Kroger has made investments in technology and systems, and they have done a lot of cost-cutting and elimination of replicated functions throughout the organization from a systems standpoint," said Bonni Z. Bleustein of Credit Suisse First Boston. "They also get an excellent management team in the Fred Meyer group."
In purchasing Fred Meyer, Kroger also regains its long-held bragging rights as the largest industry competitor ranked by revenue. The distinction was grabbed in August by Albertson's when it announced that it would acquire American Stores Company for $8.3 billion, creating a chain with $36 billion in revenue and 2,500 stores in 37 states.
Some other recent deals include Safeway's announcement last week that it would acquire the Dominick's supermarket chain for $1.85 billion, and the acquisition in May by Royal Ahold of Giant Food Inc. for $2.6 billion. Such combinations, which spread a company's costs over a much larger store base, are expected to continue and to make it increasingly difficult for small, independent grocers to compete on price, marketing and store location terms.
"The independents clearly have more and more of a competitive disadvantage," Ms. Bleustein said.

HEADLINE: In Terms of Jobs, A One-Street Town

BYLINE: By Charles R. Morris; Charles R. Morris, a financial consultant, is the author of the forthcoming "Money, Greed and Risk: The Course of Financial Crises."

 BODY:
Middle Eastern oil emirates are the classic one-commodity economies. When oil prices boom, the sheiks build hospitals and air-conditioned palaces, buy fighter jets and import tens of thousands of service workers. When oil prices sink, the hospitals crumble, the service workers are sent home and wrecks of Mercedes rust in the sand.
Manhattan is America's Qatar, but it specializes in paper instead of oil. When the markets boom, youthful bankers in handmade shirts and English shoes chug-a-lug Chateau Margaux, governments go on binges of borrowing and building, and service workers from all around the world crowd into the city. 
 When markets turn sour, lamentations rise from the wreckage of upside-down mortgages and repossessed Jaguars, and everyone vows not to let it happen again.
It would be nice to report that, as Mayor Rudolph Giuliani said last week, "the city is in a better position now than it was in the past" to weather a market downturn. Sadly, that isn't true.
Wall Street's booms and busts are often dizzily disconnected with the rest of the world.
The great 1980's "Bonfire of the Vanities" blowout came at a time when Asian competition was gutting basic industries like cars and steel, and hundreds of thousands of workers found pink slips in their pay packets.
Conversely, the powerful resurgence of American industrial competitiveness that started in the late 1980's coincided with Wall Street's desert years of 1987-91.
The disconnect hasn't been quite as violent in the 1990's, and the stock market didn't get truly giddy until about a year or so ago. Times have been good throughout the American economy, and the long boom on Wall Street was roughly in sync with the solid gains racked up by industries from manufacturing through health care and high-tech.
But markets ventured into uncharted territory when the Dow jumped about 30 percent from January to July of this year despite growing signs of a global slowdown. The average company's stock price leaped to more than 30 times its earnings, which by any historical standard is just silly.
The junk bonds of the 1990's are the Internet stocks, little companies with shaky revenue and no earnings but with stock market valuations in the billions. Reality started to bite in August, and results are sharply down at all the Wall Street companies.
Merrill Lynch and City Group have already announced the first big rounds of layoffs.
This time around, the securities companies claim to have been more disciplined in their hiring in the 1990's, and the boom in tourism, the sprouting of Silicon Alley high-tech companies and flourishing ethnic communities in Queens and Brooklyn all suggest a more diversified economy than in the 1980's.
A comparison of city employment just before the 1987 market crash and at the end of 1997 does show a slight drop in the concentration of jobs in the sector of the economy that is most sensitive to stock market fluctuations -- the so-called FIRE sector: finance, insurance and real estate.
These jobs accounted for 18.3 percent of all city jobs in 1987, but only 16.4 percent of all jobs by the end of 1997. Measured by dollars, however, the concentration has actually gotten worse. FIRE jobs now account for 33.9 percent of all payrolls in New York City, a big jump from 26.5 percent in 1987.
Concentration of jobs and payrolls in the security industry, where cuts are likely to be the sharpest, is much worse on all counts. As of the end of 1997, security industry employment accounted for 5.5 percent of city jobs, up from 5.3 percent in 1987, and for a staggering 19.3 percent of city payrolls, up from just 11.3 percent 10 years before. In other words, here we go again. Does this have to happen?
The answer is no, but it will take 10 years or more of disciplined public policy and enlightened governance to get off the Wall Street treadmill.
The success in reducing New York City's crime rate over the last few years is a hopeful start and in the long run may prove to be the city's most successful economic development program ever. But it is no more than a first step.

By any measure, the burden of doing business in New York is uniquely high: the personal and the business taxes, the cloud of regulations that surrounds everything from painting an apartment to renting a car, the armies of grabby inspectors, the work rules, the payments to "expeditors" to clear the most routine regulatory processes, the extraordinary burden of state and city debt. Is it any wonder that businesses, especially small ones, continue to flee the city?
It was no act of God but neglect and bureaucracy that chased away basic industries like manufacturing and shipping. Even today, Gov. George Pataki spends hundreds of millions to polish up Buffalo's football stadium and the Port Authority plays lower Manhattan real estate mogul, while the Brooklyn waterfront, which offers possibly the finest deep-water harbor on the Eastern Seaboard, is left to the wharf rats.
The problem may be that market crashes just don't last long enough to generate the pain needed for true reform.

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
FREIBERG, SYLVIA

 BODY:
FREIBERG-Sylvia. Died suddenly in Newton, MA., on October 20, 1998, less than three years after the death of Sam, her beloved husband of sixty-one years. Loving mother of Peter and Eileen. Caring mother-in-law of Joe Tom and Barney. Devoted grandmother of Solana and Sabrina. Born in Russia eighty-seven years ago, Sylvia grew up in Williamsburg, Brooklyn and lived most of her life in the Bronx. Short, smart, savvy and very funny, she was a woman who kowtowed to no one, even in pre-feminist times. Her abiding interest in people and politics made her a lively companion and was probably the reason she seemed so much younger than her years. While second to none in her love a good (or bad) joke, and a good (or bad) mah jongg game, her serious side was never far away: She continued to wish for political and economic justice for all people. Her family and friends will miss her, but she would be the first to say, "I had a good run."

HEADLINE: 30 Designs That Changed the Face of the Automobile

BYLINE: By MICHAEL LAMM; Michael Lamm is a co-author of "A Century of Automotive Style: 100 Years of American Car Design."

 BODY:
SCIENTISTS have theorized that biological evolution marches through time not in a smooth, straight line, but by fits and spurts. The same holds true of art. And automotive design, like all forms of art, includes specific works that changed the direction of everything that followed.
Over the last 100 years, dozens of automobiles stand out from the tens of thousands of models that have been produced around the world. Some were decades ahead of their time; others were pioneers of styling trends that swept the industry, for better and sometimes worse. 
 For the first quarter of the 20th century, the most influential automobile designs came from the Europeans. Until the late 1920's, American manufacturers routinely copied them. But the growing influence of American coach builders, who made custom car bodies for the very wealthy, soon prompted the manufacturers to set higher standards, and to copy some styling elements that had been found only on limited-production Packards and Pierce-Arrows.
Furthermore, visionary auto executives like Alfred P. Sloan Jr. of General Motors realized that the relatively inexpensive process of changing a car's appearance could whet the public's appetite for new designs, inducing them to replace old cars before they wore out.
From the late 20's on, American car design led the world except for a brief period after World War II, when Italian designs from Ferrari, Lancia and Alfa Romeo set new standards.
Automobile design did not evolve in a vacuum. It borrowed from other industries and from popular culture. Whatever was handy, trendy or sexy was fair game. Designers incorporated aspects of Art Deco and Art Moderne into their styling in the 30's. Streamlining, a catchword that had much less to do with aerodynamics than with shapes, was applied to everything from pencil sharpeners to toasters and, of course, to automobiles. Locomotives, ships, aircraft and rockets have served as influences, as have fish, birds and other animals, including the human body.
Eighteen months after Charles A. Lindbergh flew across the Atlantic in 1927, Auburn brought out a show car, the Cabin Speedster, that looked like a small, wingless airplane. In 1929, Lincoln offered the LeBaron Aero Phaeton, with winglike front fenders, uncovered cockpits for the front and rear seats and a stubby, upright tail. Designs of the 50's were dominated by tail fins, which Cadillac -- inspired by the Lockheed P-38 Lightning fighter plane -- had introduced on '48 models.
As America embarked on its space program, Oldsmobile made the rocket its styling theme. For 1959, rocket shapes appeared along the tops of the fenders from front end to taillights. The mako shark is said to have inspired the 1963 Corvette Sting Ray. And the front views of mid-70's Lincolns and full-size Mercurys were classic indeed -- their grilles were based on architectural themes from ancient Greece. Angular and immense, these were Parthenons on wheels, mass-produced on the assembly line.
There have been striking, distinctive designs -- from Citroen, for example --that actually had little influence on the look of other cars. There are those now viewed as icons of their era, like the 1955-57 Chevrolets, which were derivative rather than trend-setting. And while some auto makers, like Packard and Duesenberg, had great appeal, they were not imitated too often.
What follows is a selection of cars whose designs did make a difference. Not all are classics; indeed, some are not remembered today. But each broke new ground, popularized a nascent idea or was widely copied. In some cases, their influence is still being felt. The list is not all-inclusive, and there are notable absences. For instance, there are no entries from the late 80's and 90's, a period when the shape of cars often flowed more from Government rules on safety, fuel economy and the environment than from the imaginations of designers. That may be changing, and the late 90's, like the early 30's and mid-50's, could be another golden age of car design. More and more distinctive models keep appearing, many of them -- like the Volkswagen New Beetle and the Plymouth Prowler street rod -- obviously inspired by cars of the past.
Such inspirations are nothing new.

GRAPHIC: Chart/Photos
 
1901 Mercedes racer
 When the engines of most cars were stuffed under the seat, a few pioneers put them up front. Mercedes was not the first to do so, but it popularized this configuration, which included the front-mounted radiator and hood.
 
1904 Packard
 Automobiles looked pretty much the same around this time, but Packard helped to establish the importance of styling touches that made its cars instantly identifiable. Starting in 1904, all Packards had a distinctive "ox yoke" radiator grille in which the central section bowed upward and was adjoined by flat shoulders that tilted downward. In 1906, Packard added hubcaps with a recessed hexagon, and starting in 1930, these premium American cars had a spear along the hood.
 
1911 Panhard Labourdette skiff
 This striking boat-tailed French car was a trailblazer in several respects. Its hood ran smoothly into the cowl at the front of the passenger compartment, when hoods generally ended abruptly against the flat front of the body. The Labourdette was very low-slung for the time, and the front fenders flowed gracefully into short running boards.
 
Mid-1920's Miller race cars
 A California race-car developer, Harry Miller, dominated American racing in the mid-1920's with these very low, long-hooded, innovative cars, which inspired many imitators. The 1932 DeSoto, for instance, proudly copied the Miller grille.
 
1929 Cord L-29
 Front-wheel drive allowed the designer of this American car, Alan Leamy (who was inspired by Miller racers), to make the L-29 just 51 inches high, more than a foot lower than the typical 1929 sedan. Not only did other cars subsequently shrink in height, but the Cord's louvered, chrome-plated, V-shaped grille was quickly copied by Chrysler, Reo and others.
 
1932 Graham Blue Streak
 Even into the 30's, most cars consisted of separate elements: a small house over the passengers, a hood over the engine, fenders over the wheels, an exposed gas tank and a trunk at the rear. The Graham's designer, Amos Northup, broke with tradition by rounding and integrating these elements into one harmonious whole. He hid the radiator cap and gas tank, added more surface to the fenders to hide the mud spatters underneath and painted the entire car one color -- an unusual treatment at the time.
 
1933 Pierce-Arrow Silver Arrow
 The headlights were integrated into the flush front fenders of this American show car, of which only five were built. Thirteen years later, a similar treatment would appear on postwar models.
 
1934 Chrysler Airflow
 This American design was copied overseas by Peugeot and two relatively young foreign companies, Volvo and Toyota. But the design was a failure in the United States, and it taught auto makers that the public cared more about stylistic streamlining than true aerodynamics. But the Airflow did establish some universal trends. By moving the rear seat ahead of the axle, instead of over it, passengers rode much more comfortably. Large gauges were arrayed across the instrument panel instead of being clumped in the middle. And the Art Deco trim added lavish style to the interiors.
 
1936 Cord 810
 Gordon Buehrig, a top designer of the 30's and the man responsible for many of the striking Duesenbergs, devised a completely original design for the Cord, which still looks fresh today. The car's front was squared off in what came to be called a "coffin nose." The 810 was extremely low to the ground and had neither running boards nor a conventional grille -- the air intakes were slits that wrapped around the hood. The headlights were hidden behind lids. The Cord sent designers rushing back to their drawing boards. Although many of its touches were imitated, the car's overall shape was not.
 
1938 Cadillac 60 Special
 The highly successful first design by Bill Mitchell, who went on to direct General Motors' styling in the 60's and 70's, grafted the sloping trunk of a coupe onto a sedan, used thin chrome frames around the windows, fenders that were creased along the top and squared off at the rear, and a roof line that ended in a thick rear pillar resembling a convertible's.
 
1938 Lincoln Zephyr
 Bob Gregorie, Ford's chief designer then, used a low grille with thin bars that flared back like a cat's whiskers. The design was a sensation, and other cars' grilles, previously high and vertical, quickly became low and horizontal. Two years later, Gregorie remade the Zephyr into the Continental, one of the first modern sports-luxury cars. Its clean, unornamented design was capped by an exposed spare tire at the rear.
 
1941 Cadillac
 This car was the first to wear what would become a signature touch for Cadillac: the "tombstone grille." It consisted of an "egg crate" of chrome bars in a wide, bold expanse, which, along with the tall hood, resembled a tombstone. Even today, Cadillac uses variations of this treatment, which has been copied extensively throughout the industry.
 
1947 Cisitalia 202
 This striking coupe by Pininfarina, the Italian design firm and body fabricator, ushered in a new look. The hood was set lower than the long, flowing front fenders, the grille was oval and low, the rounded wheel cutouts framed the tires. The Cisitalia's pure, unadorned form gave designers a new way to look at the automobile.
 
1947 Studebaker
 Virgil Exner, who developed the far-out Chrysler designs of the 50's and early 60's, conceived the tight, simple, squarish lines of postwar Studebakers. The smooth sides were broken only at the rear, where raised fenders made the car look like an animal ready to pounce. G.M. and Chrysler, among others, copied the look.
 
1947 Kaiser and Frazer
 Designed by Howard Darrin for a new car company spawned by the Kaiser steel and aluminum conglomerate, these two brands made their debut in January 1946 and shared the first postwar "envelope body." Without protruding fenders, the sides flowed uninterrupted from front to rear.
 
1948 Cadillac
 The first tail fins -- a trend that dominated the industry for 15 years and lives on in the taillights of today's DeVilles -- were inspired by the Lockheed P-38 fighter plane. Frank Hershey, who later designed the original two-seat Ford Thunderbird, got the credit.
 
1949 Jaguar XK120
 No other car embodied the spirit of the postwar sports-car revolution as well as this one. The XK120 roadster helped to inspire the Chevrolet Corvette, Ford Thunderbird and many others. The car's antecedents were the 1939 Talbot coupe by Figoni and the 1938 BMW 328MM. But it was the Jaguar's subtlety of line -- and the way the coupe's rear roof line flared out and tucked in at the bottom like a "C" -- that inspired imitators.
 
1949 Buick hardtop
 The idea of a two-door hardtop, a coupe without roof pillars behind the front doors, was not original to G.M., which offered the style in 1949 on Cadillacs, Buicks and Oldsmobiles. But Buick's rendition best captured the public's fancy. In part, the car was inspired by Sarah Ragsdale, the wife of a Buick engineer, Edward T. Ragsdale, who always drove convertibles but never lowered the top because she didn't like to have her hair mussed. Instead, Buick hardtops offered the convertible look without the fuss of the wind or the rattles of an open body. The hardtop became the dominant body style of the 50's and 60's.
 
1951 General Motors LeSabre
 This far-out show car was a rolling laboratory for G.M. styling ideas, many of which eventually went into production. The most striking was the panoramic wraparound windshield.
 The LeSabre was also the personal car of Harley Earl, who was probably the most influential car designer ever.
 
1953 Studebaker coupe
 Bob Bourke, a designer working under Raymond Loewy, the pre-eminent industrial designer, lent a sporty Italian edge to this thoroughly American car. As a result, other American designers began to clean up their acts, as evidenced by the simpler, less ornamented 1957 cars from Chrysler.
 
1957 Chrysler, DeSoto and Plymouth
 Virgil Exner's "forward look" emphasized soaring tailfins, thin roofs, lots of glass, clean and simple body sides and restrained ornamentation -- elements that temporarily made the Chrysler Corporation the leader in automotive design, a distinction previously held by G.M. Another '57 Chrysler design, the Imperial, started the trend toward curved side glass.
 
1958 Ford Thunderbird
 The busy-looking second-generation T-Bird was not as graceful as the two-seater it replaced, but it proved much more influential, inspiring a slew of personal-luxury coupes, like the '63 Buick Riviera with its four bucket seats.
 
1961 Lincoln Continental
 Elwood Engel's rectangular, almost austere sides looked as if canvas had been stretched over a wire framework, then formed with compressed air blown in underneath; it was a styling idea used subsequently throughout the industry.
 
1965 Ford Mustang
 Lee A. Iacocca may have gotten the credit, but whoever thought up the Mustang, it proved to be one of Ford's better ideas ever. Affordable, youthful and capable of being outfitted to suit every buyer's taste (thanks to a long list of options), the Mustang introduced the long-hood, short-deck look and quickly inspired a wave of "pony car" copycats, both American and imported, which played off the design.
 
1966 Oldsmobile Toronado
 A modern take on the '36 Cord, with its front-wheel drive, hidden headlights and louvered grille, the Toronado also contributed two much-imitated styling innovations: thick "lips" around the wheels and an imposing rear roof line that flowed into the rear fender.
 
1968 Pontiac GTO
 The grille and bumper became one piece, molded of urethane and painted the same color as the body. The front-end treatments of most modern cars still mimic the GTO's.
 
1969 Jaguar XJ6
 Although the form of the classic E-Type Jaguar form was voluptuous, organic and feline, it was not heavily imitated. The elegant, softly rounded XJ6, however, has been copied for three decades.
 
1974 Volkswagen Golf
 While the Austin Mini had a tremendous effect on small-car engineering, it was the Golf, designed by the Giugiaro design firm in Italy and initially called the Rabbit in the United States, that spawned a number of subcompact, hatchback imitators.
 
1984 Dodge Caravan and Plymouth Voyager
 Volkswagen actually developed the minivan in 1949, but the concept acquired a practical form when it was brought to the Chrysler Corporation by a marketing executive, Hal Sperlich, who had defected from Ford. The minivan wasn't so much a leader in styling as a packaging innovation. The front-wheel-drive van had a low floor, and thereby a low roof, and unlike most vans at the time, it could fit easily in most garages. Growing families loved the spacious cabin, cup holders and four-cylinder engine, which was far less thirsty than the V8's of conventional large station wagons.
 
1986 Ford Taurus
 With the original Taurus, a radical departure from American sedans, Ford's head designer Jack Telnack, tapped into the right combination of Euro and aero. American designers are still using the Taurus's smooth, organic shape. Even Chrysler's two generations of cab-forward sedans contain a lot of Taurus DNA.

HEADLINE: Who Is Served by More Concrete?

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER; Keith Schneider, a former national correspondent for The Times, is executive director for the Michigan Land Use Institute.

 BODY:
ADDISON, VT., which lies on a fertile ridge near Lake Champlain, has long defined itself by two seemingly unchangeable resources: green pastures that feed hundreds of dairy cattle and old state Route 22A, the region's main highway that runs through the center of town.
Five years ago, though, this peaceful balance was upset when the Vermont Agency of Transportation announced a plan to widen the two-lane highway, which was heavily trafficked and needed modernizing. 
 The proposal to add 14 feet of asphalt to the 26-foot-wide road ignited a civic rebellion over small-town values, historic integrity and the quality of life. In a region where space had never been an issue, 14 feet of pavement was suddenly the only issue.
"The problem was, they wanted to take this rural highway and make it like an Interstate," said Margaret Barnes, a member of the Addison board of selectmen. "It would increase speeds. It would invite more traffic. People would go flying through town. It was a big change, and people here said they just didn't want it like that."
While classic in its dimensions, the dispute turned out to be novel in its results. In Addison, Route 22A will grow only six feet. And throughout the rest of Vermont, road building will never again be the same: the state became the first to rewrite road design standards to reflect new public expectations that highways should serve not only cars and trucks, but the surrounding community as well. That change occurred in 1991, when the Federal transportation-spending law was amended to give citizens and local governments more authority to determine how projects were planned.
Such ideas have swirled around the discussion of roads in Vermont and elsewhere since the 1960's, but with limited effect. Highway agencies did not have to consider public opinion until projects were too far along and therefore unstoppable.
"Addison was one of the many places in this state where we were having trouble," said David Scott, the director of project development for the Vermont Agency of Transportation. "With almost every project, people told us, 'No, that's not what we want.' We were at a standstill. It was change or do nothing. We had to remember who we work for. So we changed."
Vermont is by no means alone. Addison's protest and the new attitudes of Vermont's engineers reflect a formidable transition in the setting of transportation priorities. What began a decade ago as a neighborhood movement to open the highway planning process to more public oversight is now influencing transportation policy and spending in countless communities, many state capitals and especially in Washington.
The new approach has led to some surprising line items in Federal highway spending bills. The 1991 law -- a $155 billion, six-year package -- provided billions of dollars to communities to help them develop alternatives to reduce air pollution, and billions more to increase mass-transit ridership. Bus routes in major cities were expanded and new light-rail lines were started in Dallas and other Sunbelt cities.
Then three years ago in Chicago, the Transit Authority thought about shutting down a lightly used, deteriorating subway line that operated from suburban Oak Park through the West Side to the downtown Loop and out to the city's South Side.
Instead, the authority was persuaded to try a different approach: spend money rebuilding the line, develop the areas around the stations and the riders will come. Using Federal transportation money, the authority is working with Bethel New Life, a church-based community development corporation in Chicago, and the Center for Neighborhood Technology, a nonprofit civic organization in the city, to develop a $10 million housing and shopping district around the subway stop at the intersection of Lake Street and Pulaski Road -- in the heart of the city's West Side.
"There is an intimate connection between transportation and how land is used within walking distance," said David Chandler, the manager for economic development at the Center for Neighborhood Technology. "In some sense, this is so obvious. But somehow we forgot until the last few years."
Hank Dittmar, a director of the Surface Transportation Policy Project, a research and advocacy organization in Washington, said that awareness is beginning to work its way through the road-building apparatus. "We needed to think more broadly about our auto-dominated transportation system," Mr. Dittmar said. "It's not working well. It's leading to unbelievable traffic congestion. It's degrading the quality of life. It's resulting in neighborhoods we don't really want to live in.
"Cars are important," he added. "We all use them. At the same time, though, we need to start adding some other choices for people."
Last summer, again with bipartisan support, Congress passed a new $217.3 billion, six-year transportation spending law. It will most likely result in the investment of more Federal money to repair existing roads and constructing alternatives than it will to build new highways.
Indeed, the 1998 law is so flexible in its spending priorities that, of the $169.5 billion directed to Federal aid for highways, more than half can be spent on other transportation options. These include building light-rail lines, increasing urban and suburban bus services, constructing bicycle paths, developing transportation technologies to reduce pollution and paying for land-use planning that encourages healthier downtowns and communities where people can walk around more easily and conveniently.
AUTO companies, oil producers, truckers and developers are convinced that the new direction will lead to more congestion and harm the nation's economy. But they also quietly acknowledge that transportation may be the one area of major domestic policy in which lobbying muscle by the wealthiest industries has failed to deliver what they most wanted.
"Since 1970, the only transportation option that has shown consistent increases in every decade is a single driver in his or her car," said William Fay, the president of the American Highway Users Alliance, a Washington trade association for auto manufacturers, insurance and oil companies and others. "The question is, do you believe the purpose of public policy is to engineer social behavior, or do you believe, as we do, that the purpose of public policy is to facilitate a public need?
"There's no mystery about why roads are congested," Mr. Fay continued. "We aren't building enough new ones."
But Federal policy makers point to two related trends to explain the shift. The first is that years of intensive highway construction has resulted in a distinctively American pattern of sprawling development. A generation ago, many families could function well with one car. Today, more and more families must own and manage fleets of vehicles to survive in the suburbs.
THE second idea is that America has spent nearly $1 trillion over the last decade on transportation, mostly on roads, and traffic snarls are worse than ever.
According to the Department of Transportation, the number of cars and light trucks increased to 193 million in 1995 from 72 million in 1960, a 265 percent increase. During the same period, the population grew just 44 percent. Americans drive a combined 2.2 trillion miles annually, more than double the number of miles in 1970.
"You look at numbers like those, and you reach one conclusion: we can't build our way out of congestion," said John Horsely, the Federal Government's associate deputy secretary of transportation. "The number of miles we are driving is increasing two or three times faster than the population. There is no way we can keep up by building three times as much road capacity."
For the moment, light rail, or modern trolleys, is the hot alternative. Among the 25 cities considering light-rail systems are traffic-choked Sunbelt cities like Austin, Tex., Albuquerque, N.M., and Phoenix.
Though embraced in many communities, the move to invest billions in light rail worries some analysts. According to a study published last summer by Jonathan Richmond, a researcher at the Taubman Center for State and Local Government at Harvard University, most of the nation's new light-rail systems are not attracting hordes of new riders to public transit, as their promoters hoped, and have not relieved traffic congestion very much. The reason, Mr. Richmond said, is that most light-rail passengers were riding the bus.
For instance, an average of 27,000 daily riders used the light-rail line in Portland, Ore., in 1996. But a survey found that just 12,000 of the passengers were new to the mass-transit system.
"We have to get away from an obsession with a particular technology and see how we can improve the entire transportation system," Mr. Richmond said. "We've failed to adequately assess the performance of these rail systems."
George Boulineau, the director of planning and programming at the Georgia Department of Transportation, said the Atlanta subway system has attracted passengers and performed well. But his agency is also intent on constructing a second beltway around Atlanta to relieve congestion. The proposed highway has generated an opposition movement among residents and some local officials.
"There are no silver bullets to solve our problem," Mr. Boulineau said. "Whatever combination you choose, we think new road capacity still needs to be part of the picture."

Boisvert for The New York Times); Atlantans refer to this stretch of highway as Spaghetti Junction. Georgia is considering building a second beltway around the city. (Michael Schwarz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Debate Over Speed, There Are Few Facts, No Limits

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
WHEN Congress imposed a national speed limit of 55 miles per hour after the oil embargo of 1973, it said the move would save billions of gallons of gas. But little did Congress know just how much ink would be spilled debating whether such a speed limit would be good for the nation. 
 Speed limits have become a red-hot topic in which no new study is very likely to change minds. And since states were again given the right to set their own speed limits in 1995, the debate has grown louder.
"It's like gun control, because you have people who want the freedom to drive as fast as they like on one side, and on the other side you have people who are afraid of the speeders," said Edmund J. Cantilli, a forensic engineer and former professor of transportation and safety engineering at Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute.
Sorting through the debate for a semblance of truth can be as tricky as finding the fuel pump in a new car.
The argument for driving more slowly certainly plays well at a gut level. "Because speeding reduces the time drivers have to avoid crashes, it increases the likelihood of crashing and the severity of crashes that do occur," according to the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. In other words, you not only have a greater chance of avoiding a deer if you are going slowly, but if you do hit one, it will probably roll off your car. At a faster speed, it may go through your windshield.
On a more abstract level, many studies have made a connection between higher speeds and a greater number of fatalities. After Congress set a national speed limit of 55 m.p.h., the National Research Council estimated that 4,000 fewer people died in car crashes as a result. A more recent National Highway Traffic Safety Administration study said that speed was a factor in 30 percent of all fatal crashes in 1997. The agency also said that there was an increase in the number of highway fatalities in states that raised speed limits in 1996, while states that did not raise their speed limits did not see a jump.
But there is pressure to go faster in all areas of life, from tennis serves to fastball pitches, from computer modems to microprocessing chips, from faster fast food to even quicker diets. And as more states adopted a 65 m.p.h. speed limit, the pressure to raise it grew on holdout states like Connecticut, which raised its speed limit this month to 65 m.p.h. on 334 miles of highways.
"Our Yankee and puritanical traditions go down hard," State Senator Biagio Ciotto, a co-chairman of the Connecticut Legislature's transportation committee, said recently. "I'm not a nut for speed. But the highways were designed to handle this speed. The time has come."
Certainly many people agree that the time for higher speed limits has not only arrived but is long overdue. They note that roads today can carry cars more safely at higher speeds, and that cars themselves handle better and are safer thanks to features like air bags, stronger door beams and radial tires.
Many people contend that the economy would benefit from people speeding up because goods could get to customers faster, reducing transportation costs. (The counterargument is that the decreased fuel efficiency related to higher speeds will drive up environmental costs.) And more lax speed limits will free police resources to go after drunken drivers. Speed limits, many people argue, are just a source of income for states, insurance companies and makers of radar detectors, and represent a law that makes people feel as if they are criminals for breezing along on the highway at what feels like a perfectly safe speed.
Finally, studies show that raising or lowering speed limits does not really change how people drive. A 1992 study conducted for the Federal Highway Administration said that lowering limits as much as 20 m.p.h. or raising them as much as 15 had little or no effect on actual speeds.
"The majority of drivers did not drive 5 m.p.h. above the posted limit when speed limits were raised, nor did they reduce their speed 5 to 10 m.p.h. when speed limits were lowered," the study said.
Mr. Cantilli, the consultant, said the problem with speed limits is that they are generally no longer set by traffic engineers who, before Congress began chanting "55 Saves Lives," used to study a road's design and traffic patterns to determine a speed limit that made sense.
Today, blanket limits are ordained without much thought, Mr. Cantilli said, and drivers know it.
"It creates a situation in which drivers don't know what the safe speed is for a section of road," he said. "Some drivers will drive too fast, and some will drive too slowly. It all comes back to the fact that people no longer see that someone is trying to figure out what is a reasonable speed for the road."

HEADLINE: Ludicrous! Impractical! Exorbitant! I'll Take It!

BYLINE: By JACK SMITH; Jack Smith is connoisseur at large for The Robb Report, a monthly magazine.

 BODY:
IT'S outrageous, Herb Chambers conceded, to pay $1 million for a McLaren F1 sports car. "It makes no economic sense at all," said Mr. Chambers, who lives on a sprawling estate in Old Lyme, Conn., equipped with a helicopter and a helipad.
As for the McLaren's center-mounted driver's seat, it's totally impractical. "It feels just like a Formula One race car," Mr. Chambers said. "It makes getting a ticket from a toll booth a real adventure." 
 And nobody really needs a car with 600-plus horsepower and a top speed of 230 miles an hour. "I have to send it to Montvale, N.J., to have it serviced," he said. "It costs $500 to rent a runway at the local airport to road-test it." As he said this, he glanced at the car's instrument panel to make sure the oil and water had warmed.
"Are you in?" he asked his passenger, who was struggling with the door of the F1, which slams down like a guillotine.
Hatches and latches secured, Mr. Chambers nudged the shift lever into first gear and gently engaged the clutch as the silvery, wedge-shaped supercar rolled slowly onto a country road and toward a highway. Once the car was on the entry ramp, the genteel tappa-tappa of camshafts and valves suddenly became a high-pitched, metallic scream as the McLaren accelerated onto Interstate 95, pinning its driver and passenger to their seats. The landscape was a blur.
"There's really no way to justify it in ordinary terms," Mr. Chambers yelled above the cacophony about the car. "That's the beauty of it."
Or, to some, the horror. Although there are cars -- a vintage Bugatti or a Delahaye, say -- that cost $1 million or more because they are rare or they have a certain provenance, the McLaren's appeal is more visceral. It is built to do one thing: scream down the road as fast as is humanly, or mechanically, possible.
So, too, are other $1 million-plus rare birds like the Porsche 959, Ferrari 288 GTO and Ferrari F40, though its value has dropped to a third of that amount since 1990.
Soon to come, if not already plying American roads, are street-legal versions of the Porsche GT1, the Mercedes CLK-LM, the Nissan R390 and the American-made Panoz GT-R1, each sleeker, sexier and scarier than anything ever built for the masses.
One reason car makers sell barely domesticated versions of all-out race cars (yes, the McLaren F1 began as a road car, but it also won the 24 Hours of Le Mans in 1995) is the "homologation" rules of racing: to compete in the GT1 class, a minimum number of cars must be sold to the public.
For the last few years, that minimum has been one, but given the economies of scale, if you're going to build one for the street, why not build a couple dozen?
Though Madison Avenue hypes sex appeal and power in the most garden-variety conveyances, mainstream auto manufacturers are reluctant to admit that the most exhilarating and testosteronic cars of all even exist. With good reason, said Dick Fritz, who managed Ferrari's racing team in the 70's. "European car makers are leery of American litigiousness," he explained. "If something happened, it would be easy to convince a jury that cars like these shouldn't be on the road."
The majority would not be if it weren't for Mr. Fritz's company, Ameritech, which specializes in making race-bred road rockets comply with Federal safety and environmental regulations. That means more than adding license plates. Mr. Fritz designs and installs American-mandated catalytic converters, evaporative emissions controls, on-board engine diagnostic systems, passive restraints (air bags), impact bumpers, side impact reinforcements, headlights, center-mounted stop lights and "various warning buzzers and lights." This road prep may cost $100,000 or more.
WHICH raises the question, Who buys these cars?
"Typically, these are dynamic, high-powered guys in their 40's and 50's," said Mr. Fritz, whose clients include Ralph Lauren, Clint Eastwood and David Letterman. "They're not old money. Most of them have started their own businesses and they have a lot of toys: airplanes, racing boats.
"Most of them are good drivers, but," he said with a wince, "some aren't. Frankly, it's scary to think of a McLaren or F40 in the hands of a bad driver."
Fortunately, he noted, it generally takes more than money to acquire a supercar. "The factories don't want one of these cars to wind up in the hands of somebody irresponsible," Mr. Fritz said. "It's usually by invitation."
Herb Chambers was in Biarritz, France, when he got his. "The McLaren factory told me to charter a plane and fly to England to look at the car," he said. "If I bought the car, they'd pay for the plane. That sounded fair. I wanted to see if it was really a $1 million car."
His skepticism was well founded; in the late 80's, rich car buffs were paying $1 million or more for the Ferrari F40 on the presumption that it was worth that much because somebody else would eventually pay more. But during the recession of 1991, the Ferrari frenzy cooled and prices fell to a level of $300,000 to $350,000, where they remain.
Mr. Chambers fits Mr. Fritz's portrait of a typical client. The 56-year-old Boston-born entrepreneur never went to college, but joined the Navy, hoping to become a fighter pilot. (He admits to having a hankering for speed.) When he got out, he used $1,000 to start a copy-machine repair service; when he sold A-Copy in 1983, it was the largest copy-machine sales and service company in the United States.
Into the void came cars. "I decided I always loved cars, so why not buy a dealership?" he said. "I bought my first in 1985. Now I own 13 locations with 23 franchises in three states. I love the business. You can really feel something for a car; it's hard to get excited over a copy machine."
Mr. Chambers had already owned a succession of Ferraris and Rolls-Royces. Nonetheless, he had never seen anything like the McLaren. "I fell in love with it the moment I saw it," Mr. Chambers acknowledged as the F1 rolled up to his helicopter and stopped.
"It was simply spectacular, but there was nothing gaudy about it," he exulted. "Everything is done to enhance performance, with no thought to cost. For instance, most car makers won't cut weight by 10 percent if it costs them 200 percent more to do it. But McLaren does."
THE weight-saving strategies include a body sculptured from carbon fiber, a featherweight tool kit with pieces cut from gold-plated titanium and a miniature battery. Together, they produce a car weighing 2,840 pounds, nearly 400 pounds less than a Corvette.
As for power, it is immediate, with no turbo lag. This is because the McLaren eschews turbo charging; instead, the 6.1 liter V12 incorporates 48 valves and 4 camshafts to produce 627 horsepower -- some 280 horsepower more than the Corvette's -- and 550-foot-pounds of torque.
The F1 remains on the ground at high speeds because of aerodynamics: the body is shaped like an inverted airfoil, with 6-inch diameter fans sucking air from beneath the car and shooting it out the back to enhance the vacuum effect.
The McLaren people took Mr. Chambers for a ride on a test track. "When it was over, I stepped out and I was sweating profusely," he said. "It was the most exciting ride of my life."
He went home with the McLaren and has never regretted it. "There are some things in life you buy, and then you ask yourself, Why did I ever do that? I bought a Lamborghini Countach once, and two days later, I didn't know why I bought it. It had all these wings sticking out of it. But this, I don't even have to drive it to enjoy it. I can just stand there and look at it."
Yet the car is hardly devoid of amenities. "Look," Mr. Chambers said, opening a panel between the door and the rear-wheel well. "Each car comes with its own matching luggage with the serial number on it. They also give you a Tag Heuer watch with the car's serial number on it.
"A watch," he repeated -- and laughed.

HEADLINE: Bound by an Uncommon Love

BYLINE: By BILL DONAHUE; Bill Donahue has contributed to The New York Times Magazine, Outside and others.

DATELINE: CENTRALIA, Wash.

 BODY:
IT'S pouring, of course. The rain is coming down in sheets here at the annual picnic of the Portland, Ore., Edsel Owners Club, and all these unwavering fans of the most ill-fated car in American history are huddled under a tree. Twenty loyalists, scratching plastic forks through the greasy puddles atop their potato salad and shivering, improbably, on an August afternoon.
They are salt-of-the-earth folks. There's a paunchy couple in matching green rain slickers, and a moment ago, celebrating his refurbished Edsel, the husband said, "I done the mechanic work and she done the cooking." Everyone laughed. But now, in the rain, the Edsel people look vanquished, like a baseball team cowering in the dugout, one out from losing the World Series. 
 "Probably it's just a passing shower," someone says.
The downpour persists. For Edsel people, it has been a miserable century, even though their car began with a glimmer of hope. Early on, long before the Ford Motor Company released its first line of Edsels in September 1957, it enlisted the poet Marianne Moore to dream up a brand name. She suggested Mongoose Civique, Aeroterre and Utopian Turtletop -- names that might have enhanced the mystique of the first Edsel ads, with autos covered in sheets traveling, ghostlike, along desolate roads.
Ford chose instead to give its new car the leaden first name of Edsel Ford, the son of the company's founder. Neither the name nor the design inspired middle-class suburbanites to shell out $2,500-plus.
Right away, they understood that the medium-priced Edsel, built on Ford and Mercury frames, was nothing but the same-old same-old festooned with a few gimmicks. The 1958 Edsel had a round speedometer and a signature three-part grille whose middle section resembled (to invoke the ancient slur) an Oldsmobile sucking a lemon. The car also had a "Teletouch" automatic transmission that could be operated by pressing buttons on the steering wheel. Or so Ford said: because of shoddy quality control, a forceful punch was often required.
Amid a recession, chrome-laden Edsels gathered dust in showrooms. The car became so uncool that, the year after it was introduced, beleaguered owners were giving away Edsels at Sunday-school raffles.
In 1959, Ford desperately erased many of the Edsel's Jetsonesque features. It lowered the car's sticker price and rejiggered its ad campaign to pitch the car to working-class Joes. Sales still floundered, and in 1960, after selling a grand total of 109,466 Edsels, Ford threw in the towel. All told, the fiasco cost the company $350 million.
And so the Edsel now oozes that loser charisma. It shines -- like Richard Nixon, Tonya Harding and certain death-row inmates -- as the inevitable target of a most tender affection. The Edsel Owners Club has 25 chapters and a 50-ish membership, which has remained at 1,000 for two decades. Two other rival clubs collectively lay claim to 1,200 Edsel devotees, and the Edsel people retain a small but distinct niche in the vintage car world, a realm that encompasses 500,000 or so restorers bound by their need for parts. "Rolls-Royce people want their cars to be as good as new," said Dave Brownell, the technical editor of Hemmings Motor News, a thick magazine packed with tiny ads. "For Chevy guys, it matters how shiny the engine is. But Edsel people feel the need to save every Edsel they see. It doesn't matter what shape it's in, because they've got a sense of humor. They're not going to grab you by the collar and shout that they have the best car in the world."
Indeed. As the Edselites assemble outside Portland to drive north to the picnic, they are intensely subdued -- murmurous, with their hands in their pockets. Truman King, a 71-year-old former truck driver and the proud owner of a 1960 Edsel Ranger two-door, says almost nothing and drives with both hands on the wheel all the way to Centralia. Slightly built, Mr. King is ruddy and has a raspy voice. He talks quietly about a journey he just took with two friends to the national convention of the Edsel Owners Club in Detroit. "I got the hard-luck award," Mr. King said. "Broke down three times getting there." The fuel pump quit in Idaho, then again in Montana; the generator went dead in Iowa City.
THREE guys traveling around, eating steak and potatoes at diners all over the country. It sounds pleasant enough, but it still is hard to comprehend Mr. King's fervent brand loyalty. He has bought 20 Edsels since a two-door sedan he bought for $150 in 1970. He and his late wife, Bettie, often worked in the garage until nearly midnight, she cleaning parts as he installed new rings and pistons. He points out, with a dewy gleam in his eye, that for 1960, Edsel made only 295 Ranger two-door hardtops. "This car," he exulted, "it's rare."
Mr. King pulls onto the picnic grounds and carefully backs his turquoise Ranger into the long row of Edsels under the trees. The cars are cream-colored and forest green, and some are the color of pistachio ice cream; there is an enchanting music to the whole pastel procession.
"I guess things weren't so hectic back in the 50's," Mr. King says. "And once in a while you kind of wish you could go back to that area of time." He climbs out of the car gingerly and heads for the picnic table.
It is a tame picnic, no beer, no tunes, no squealing tires. Once the rain subsides, everyone wanders toward the cars, where Russ Waterhouse, 53, is lingering beside his gleaming '59 Edsel Corsair convertible. He's wearing an Edsel T-shirt, an Edsel windbreaker and an Edsel golf cap, and he is pensive. Two days ago, his third wife filed for divorce. "This," he says, gesturing, "is the second divorce this car has gone through. She knew when she married me that I'm into Edsels."
Mr. Waterhouse is a disabled iron worker (his ankle was ravaged years ago by gangrene), and he rebuilt his Corsair in 1980 while recovering from testicular cancer and undergoing chemotherapy. "Some days I was so weak I'd just limp out and work for 10 minutes," he recalled. "I'd weld a rust hole, maybe, or sand a fender or clean something." The body work alone took six months of daily devotion, and today he is still assiduously restoring his Edsels.
He keeps three in mint condition (his four others are cannibalized for parts), and his five-car garage is full of grilles, hubcaps, doors, hoods and chunks of chrome trim. And the funny thing is, he said, his friends razzed him back in high school when he drove "the Great White Snail," his parents' new '59 Edsel wagon.
But they were just joking, right? "No," Mr. Waterhouse says, "it kind of stung. And there was this girl, Carol. When I showed up one evening to take her out, her father saw the wagon and said, 'No way.' After graduation, when I went into the service, she sent me a Dear John letter."
In the distance, a few Edsels are pulling out, going home. Mr. Waterhouse will soon leave as well, in search of a small house with a shop large enough to store his cars. Soon, he will find a place of his own. He will start over.
"But eventually the Edsel's back seat -- it, uh, did work for me," he said, smirking. "And the Edsel was the family car, too. I can remember all of us going to the beach in it. I can remember riding there one time and my dad's driving and I'm in the back with a friend and we're trying to stay up all night. We're singing, 'Black Land Farmer,' 'Ballad of Thunder Road' -- all the songs on the radio, and we're singing them loud. We had a ball in that car. Over time, you know, the bad vibes fade away."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Membership in the Edsel Owners Club has held steady at about 1,000 for two decades. Bob Fowler, publisher of an Edsel newsletter, admires the gathering's bounty. A line of Ford's biggest flops arrive for a picnic in Centralia, Wash. (Photographs by Larry Davis for The New York Times)
