HEADLINE: Dave and Audrey Get Down to the Nuts and Bolts

BYLINE: By LESLEY HAZLETON; Lesley Hazleton's new book is "Driving to Detroit: An Automotive Odyssey," from which this article is adapted.

 BODY:
In the summer of 1996, I left my Seattle houseboat and began a 13,000-mile odyssey around the United States, ending up in Detroit the following January for the International Auto Show. My intent was to drive deep into America's national obsession with the automobile and, as a committed environmentalist who loves and writes about cars, to try to resolve some of my own conflicted feelings. I visited places where cars are venerated, despised, built, rebuilt, armored, raced, crashed, crushed -- even buried. Among them was Spring Hill, Tenn., in the hills south of Nashville, where Saturn had become a model of modern industrial relations. I spent a day just before Christmas touring the huge complex. Then, at 5 in the evening, I began making cars. 
 I JOINED three other workers stationed around a huge rotating machine, where our job was to feed a robot. Officially, we were preparing dashboard molds for foam injection. In fact, we were simply loading and unloading the machine for the robot, which injected the foam and then wiped its nozzle as if it were wiping its nose -- an infuriatingly human gesture.
This was one of the simplest tasks on the entire assembly line. Squirt some filler release into a hole. Lift a plastic mold and place it on a protruding lip of the machine. Bang a board with your knee to drop three locks to hold the mold in place. Check the locks. Push a black button to bring the lip down into the right position for the next guy. Wait for the machine to rotate and present you with a new lip.
That was it. A 10-second job to be repeated ad infinitum.
At least there was time to talk. Dave Steadman, a blond, lanky man who usually did this job, stood beside me to make sure I made no mistakes. We connected almost instantly. He used to be in the Coast Guard, part of the time on the 44-foot self-righting motor lifeboats; in the spring, I had spent a week on those boats at the Motor Lifeboat School at the mouth of the Columbia River.
As the machine clanked and rotated, and I shoved on molds and banged buttons, Dave told me how he had left the Coast Guard to work at the Buick City plant in Flint, Mich., only to get laid off in the early 80's. He showed me the crooked middle finger on his right hand, a result of a conveyor belt accident. He had been out of work for 10 years until Saturn started up and he moved South.
"I've just turned 40," he said. "That means 17 years to go."
"To what?" I asked.
"Retirement."
"Seventeen more years of?"
I couldn't finish the question, not wanting to insult him. I couldn't imagine doing this job for more than a hour, let alone 17 years.
He nodded. "You got it," he said. "Why do you think they pay me so well? They pay me to be bored." (With bonuses, Dave said, he makes about $55,000 a year.)
Sure, working at Saturn had its good points. "It's fairly loose," he continued. "We decide within the team when to take a break, determine our own vacations and schedules, do our own quality checks, swap jobs within the team. There are 14 of us and we get on well, but for all that, it's really just another job on the line."
He missed what he called "the old world" back in Michigan. "All my friends are still up there. I know people go on about living down here being basic American values and so on, but the truth is I find it bland. Besides, the fishing's no good. Only bass. No steelhead, no salmon."
The team called a 10-minute break, and a memo detailing the latest contract negotiations was distributed. There would be a $2,000 ratification bonus, an annual college tuition grant for all Saturn workers and their family members, and extra bonuses based on quality and customer-satisfaction surveys. The sticking point was post-retirement health-care benefits.
Dave and I sat down, opened our Diet 7-Ups and got into the issue of quality. I argued that when the average price of a new car is half the average annual income, the least anyone could expect is that it have no defects.
"If you worked on the line," he said, "you'd be a lot more forgiving."
"How so?"
"Say there's a rattle or a loose wire," he responded. "I'd think maybe the guy on the line was hung over that day, or maybe he had an argument with his wife or trouble with the kids. His mind was elsewhere. You see how it is: you can't keep your mind long on this kind of work. You'd be inhuman not to wander off. And that's when mistakes creep in."
"Still, there are fewer of them nowadays," I said. "American cars are much better made. How come? Not as much drugs and alcohol? Higher awareness of quality?"
"Nah," he said. "It's because we're afraid for our jobs. Back in the early 80's, it never occurred to us we could be laid off. You got a union card and the job was yours for life, so there was no reason to work hard or make sure quality was high. Now we know what can happen."
With a half-grin, half-grimace, he added, "Plus, I've got a dozen team members who are going to get on my case if I don't do my job properly."
TWO hours later, I left Dave and moved from one of the simplest jobs on the line to one of the most complicated: assembling the whole instrument panel. Steering wheel, indicator and windshield wipers, gauges, dashboard liner, the lot.
Audrey Rody, who was assigned to teach me this job, was facing a tough challenge.
I guessed she was in her mid-30's. Despite a mass of long, brown curly hair, she had a boyish way, maybe because she was wearing a leather work apron, its pockets so full of connectors and screws and bolts that it took me a while to realize she was six months pregnant.
"Is this your first?" I asked.
She burst out laughing. "Honey, I'm 43 years old. And a grandmother. I married again not long ago, and" -- she spread her arms wide and stared at her belly -- "just look what happened. This sure is the last thing I ever expected."
"How long will you go on working?"
She laughed again. "Do you know how much kids cost? I'm staying right here till the day I pop."
She hadn't stopped working as we talked. She couldn't. The line was rolling, and it was either keep up or stop everything. We were standing on a wide conveyor belt as it rumbled past shelves piled with parts; above us, power tools and bins of screws dangled from a rack. Every six feet or so along the line was a pedestal holding a dashboard shell placed upside down so it was easy to work on. Audrey's job was to turn the shell into a finished instrument panel.
I spent the first half-hour figuring out how to stay out of her way. As far as I could see, Audrey had about 50 separate procedures to complete in a logic-defying sequence of three minutes. Each step had to be performed in perfect timing, so that the right parts and tools were at hand exactly when she needed them. To add to the pressure, this job was called a "show stopper."
Farther down the line, the completed instrument panel would be lowered into the "smile joint," a large lazy U going from one side of the car's frame to the other. If it didn't fit, the line stopped, and the whole plant would start running behind. "You can't go back and do it again," Audrey said. "You got to do it perfect the first time."
I knew I would never be able to do this job. Yet Audrey seemed convinced that I could. She talked me through each movement as she worked, and somehow persuaded me to do a bit here and there. Within an hour, I was beginning to get it down. Here is how it went:
Walk six stands down the line, past other team members at different stages of the job, and read the manifest hanging on the dashboard shell. Pick up different parts from the shelves alongside the line, depending on whether this is to be a sedan or a wagon, an automatic or a manual shift. Jam a leather sheath over a sharp metal edge at the side of the module. Ease the parts into place. Snap-connect electrical wires: gray to the right, blue to the middle, white to the left.
So far, so good. I was feeling quite proud of myself. The trouble was, this was only the very beginning.
The rest began to blur: snap-connect a black fastener, then a yellow one. Don't delay. If you go too slowly, the line will take you past the parts you need and you will have to start running back and forth for them. Pick up the steering shaft from a shelf and ease its 30-pound weight down through the center of the module. Arrange the wires to run over the top of the shaft. Slip on and snap a green fastener.
OR were those last two steps the other way around? "Here," Audrey said, redoing my work.
O.K., now pick up two bronze-colored bolts and screws, two black bolts, a circular piece and two silver bolts from those big bins alongside the line. Insert the silver bolts. Fine. Place the bronze-colored ones in one place, the black ones in another. Great. Pull down a power wrench from the overhead line.
I grabbed for it and missed. It began to recede. I stretched and yanked it down just in time to tighten the bolts. I had no idea what I was bolting to, or why. Neither, it turned out, did Audrey.
Right, I said to myself, you've got those bolts nice and tight. Now pick different bronze-colored bolts from another bin. No, not alongside the line -- right here, hanging overhead. Fine. Insert and tighten them by hand for now. What about the wrench? Not there yet, that comes soon. First, thread the electrical wires through the back of the module and out through this flap, then loop them over and under the shaft like so, and then. . . .
Then what? I couldn't remember. And I was only a third of the way through the job.
"Don't worry," Audrey said. "It takes most people four days to learn this job. You're doing real good."
That was sweet of her to say, but it didn't feel real good. My attention strayed, I lost a beat and suddenly the power tools and screw bins were bearing down on me way before I was ready. I worked as fast as I could, one eye on my hands, the other on the dangling wrench going past. I swore, lunged for it and yanked, thinking that if I pulled hard enough, I could pull back the whole line and slow things down to my pace. I remembered Charlie Chaplin's desperation in "Modern Times," and suddenly there was nothing remotely funny about that movie. I dropped a bolt, reached for the wrong wrench and watched pathetically as Audrey stepped in and put everything right. I hadn't felt quite this incompetent since I was a child trying to thread a sewing machine. I never mastered that.
The Saturn people were crazy to let me even try this job. I anticipated the news reports. "Saturn Cars Recalled," the headline would read. "Instrument-panel problems have led to the recall of 200 Saturn cars after customers complained that the windshield wipers activated the lights. In some cars, the headlight wand turned on the air-conditioning. In others, it came off in the drivers' hands. The problem became apparent when a steering-wheel shaft fell into a driver's lap. Fortunately, the car was not moving, since the ignition was incorrectly wired."
"Try not to get behind," Audrey said, "because that's when mistakes happen."
"Ummm," I said, giving a silent thanks to the person who was checking quality at the end of this section.
EVERY time I thought I had the hang of it, another two steps somehow reversed themselves in my mind, or one slipped out of existence altogether. My ears were ringing, my mind was reeling and my hands had never felt clumsier. I began to fumble with the screws, inserting them at an angle so that they wouldn't tighten properly and had to be taken out and inserted anew. Audrey was working as hard as I was by now; we stood shoulder to shoulder, me fouling things up, she fixing them.
And suddenly it was 10 o'clock. By now, I was squinting to stop from seeing double. I was convinced that if I could just work to the end of the shift at 3 A.M., I would get this job down. But as the line halted and everything stopped moving, a remote part of my brain signaled a weak but decipherable message that the pressure was getting to me. It was time to call it quits before I damaged a car, myself or worse, somebody else.
"Don't you want some lunch before you go?" Audrey asked. But I was too exhausted to even look at food. I needed fresh air. Solitude. Silence. I made some excuses, stuffed my yellow Kevlar gloves into my pocket as a memento and got lost twice trying to find the way out.
Never had a parking lot seemed so beautiful: quiet, peaceful, serene. Even the buzzing yellow sodium-vapor lights felt soothing. Behind me, the plant hummed gently, its skylights glowing in the night.
I found my truck, climbed in and was about to start it when I stopped, hand in midair. Something was wrong. It took a moment to figure it out: I had spent the last few hours working on upside-down instrument panels, and now I was seeing this one the right way up.
I reached out and examined its components, thinking of the man or woman who had assembled it. This thing that I usually took for granted, that I had never paid attention to, was now an astounding complexity of human skill and labor.
I started the truck and drove slowly out of the lot, wondering how long I could keep this awareness that cars are not merely machines, but things put together by real men and real women doing the kind of work that would drive a lot of people crazy. Not long enough, for sure.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Audrey Rody on the assemby line at the Saturn plant. It went like this: The author fouled things up, and Audrey fixed them. Dave Steadman talked of the monotomy and of missing his life back in Michigan. (Photos by Chris Berkey for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: For All Those Towaways, The Trucks Stop Here

BYLINE: By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

 BODY:
FOR motorists in Manhattan, the impound lot at Pier 76 off the West Side Highway is the most unhappy place in the world.
Nearly 65,000 people a year come here to reclaim their confiscated cars. They bring excuses, tears, fists and notes from priests confirming the burial of freshly departed loved ones. There you will find the morose motorist bringing in a live prop in the form of a brother-in-law in a wheelchair to validate his claim that he double-parked while wheeling his relative into the house, leaving his auto unattended for barely 30 seconds. 
 "What was I supposed to do, leave him out at the fireplug?"
"Yeah, I'm not no lawn chair, you know," the man in the wheelchair chimed in.
"You'll have to tell it to the judge" is invariably the response people get from the clerks, who work behind bulletproof glass.
It is not as if the towing officials don't care; your money is usually accepted with a smile. It is just that there are more than 2 million cars a day competing at any given time for the 1.5 million parking spaces in New York City. A result? As many cars are towed in New York -- 185,000 a year, or slightly more than 500 a day -- as are registered in Portland, Me.
City officials will tell you that impounding cars is a necessity. If cars were not towed in Manhattan and in the rest of the boroughs, clogged arteries would seize up completely. "Look, one car in the wrong place can snarl up the whole city," said Alfred Tumielewicz, the supervisor at Pier 76, an old steel-boned terminal at 38th Street next to the Hudson River. "We're not bad guys. But it's our job to keep traffic flowing."
But some skeptics say that the number of confiscated cars has a lot to do with the city's financial health. The heavy trading on Wall Street is why the number of tows to Pier 76 has plunged two-thirds over the last six years, they note.
"When the city was awash in red ink, as in '92, they looked in every corner for every nickel," said Sam Schwartz (Gridlock Sam), the transportation columnist for The Daily News and a former deputy transportation commissioner for the city.
"Although the city claims there is no quota system, ticketing and towing is a half-billion-dollar industry in New York," Mr. Schwartz added. "And if the stock market sours, the city will have to do something to make up for that lost tax revenue."
An extrapolation on Gridlock Sam's reasoning could be as follows: A coal-mine strike in Russia weakens its economy, causing the ruble to tank. This whips up fear among investors, who pull their money from developing economies, causing demand for American products to fall, which puts people here out of work. The American economy stumbles, Wall Street shudders, City Hall searches for new revenue and bingo, your car gets towed. All because a Siberian miner wants fresh bread.
Eugene Parker, the commander of towing operations, says: "A car is illegally parked, and we tow it. There is no quota system that I have heard of in my 25 years in traffic."
Whatever the precise cause, having your car towed is an urban nightmare, with images of angry confrontations, crumpled fenders, endless waiting in line and hundreds of dollars lost. There are some reasons for drivers to take heart, however. The quality of the experience has improved since the police took control of the pounds from the Transportation Department in August 1996.
To start, since the pounds are more secure, so are the contents of your car. And in July, they all began accepting credit cards, saving the carless "customer" a trip to the A.T.M. machine in the dead of night.
Mr. Parker also notes that assaults on tow-truck operators by motorists wielding everything from screwdrivers to soda bottles are down precipitously, as are motorists' claims of theft.
Besides Pier 76, there are three other public impound yards in the city: the Bruckner Boulevard yard in the Bronx; underneath the Kosciusko Street Bridge in Queens, and the Brooklyn Navy Yard. To retrieve your car from any of them, you must pay, in person, at the pound a $150 towing charge plus $15 storage for each day after 24 hours.
Be sure to call ahead. If your car has been towed for a violation and you have neglected to pay parking tickets in excess of $100, you cannot get your car back until you go to a Parking Violations Bureau, pay the fine and obtain a redemption receipt.
THEN again, your car might have been towed by the city marshal or by the sheriff, both of whom comb the streets for scofflaws by running random checks of license plates. It may be a dirty business, but it is a moneymaker. The sheriff's department stores cars in private lots; last year, it impounded 70,000 automobiles. Sheriffs also collect fines from tickets and charge the same as the police do for towing, plus a $45 administrative fee and a 5 percent surcharge.
A simple call to (212) 869-2929 is very likely to prevent headaches, large losses of money and repeat trips across town.
Mr. Tumielewicz, the Pier 76 supervisor, is a short man with a barrel-like physique. He seems like a decent sort, and says that the public is happy to see him. "They love us," he said in his shoe-box-size office. "They think their car is stolen, and when they find out we have it, they are actually happy."
But that good will is both artificial and fleeting. To people who had just paid their towing bills, after losing a day's wage and standing in line at three different municipal offices, the people behind the glass at the pound ranked somewhere between a politician and a person who skins harp seals for a living.
"The joy only lasts a minute," Barbara Taylor LaGoff said through tears, as she recounted her story of just burying her mother and losing her car in a no-parking zone while she stepped into a bank to deposit checks to pay for the casket.
MR. TUMIELEWICZ clucked in sympathy, offered condolences and laid out the steps that Ms. LaGoff needed to take to argue her case successfully in court. She seemed placated, blew her nose, paid her money and disappeared through the side door.
"The poor thing," Mr. Tumielewicz said as he arranged for someone to escort her to her car.
Pier 76 is open 24 hours, Monday through Saturday and a few hours early Sunday morning. People arrive in waves, wearing whiskers, Chanel No. 5, greasy baseball caps and turbans. Few come in their own car.
Despite the fact that Pier 76 earned $9 million in towing fees for the city in the last fiscal year, the redemption shack there is a rundown, gum-stained hot box, where there are no paper cups for the water cooler, no towelettes in the bathroom and the joke is that employees are encouraged to use both sides of the Charmin. There is no clock in the waiting room, just three pay phones, a wooden bench and a ventilation duct smothered in dust.
If you do not reclaim your car within 96 hours of its being towed, auction proceedings begin. After 30 days, it is gone.
At the twice-a-month auctions held at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, there are few Mercedeses or Lincoln Town Cars. Usually there are abandoned Skylarks and Cougars waiting to be chopped up and skinned by a small society of fringe capitalists like Fish Face Freddie, Maria Vargas and Al (Parts-R-Us) Kirschbaum.
One of the most miserable cash cows to lumber through the tow yards in some time was Halfred Shiroma, who ultimately had to pay $30,300 to get his yellow cab out of hock. Recently pulling out reams of documents from a paper valise at the redemption shack, Mr. Shiroma retraced his troubles, which began three months ago when his cab was towed. It seems that Mr. Shiroma owed $600 in parking tickets. That was just the start.
His cab was taken to Pier 76. Within a few days, Mr. Shiroma came to claim his car and was told to go to a marshal's office to pay his parking fines, which he says he did.
He returned to the lot, and the clerks there said he needed a release from the Taxi and Limousine Commission because he also owed fines to that agency.
The T.L.C. said it would not give him a release until he paid those fines, which totaled $6,000 in violations. He paid.
Then the T.L.C. said it could not give him a release form for his vehicle until the car was inspected, since safety inspections are required every four months. His had lapsed while the car was impounded.
But Mr. Shiroma could not get his vehicle inspected because the pound would not release it.
Finally, the police at Pier 76 agreed to release his car if the T.L.C. would relent, which the commission did but only after Mr. Shiroma agreed to purchase a new cab. Taxi regulations require an independent cab driver who is the owner and the sole operator of his cab to replace the vehicle every five years. And Mr. Shiroma's vehicle had exceeded that age limit. Mr. Shiroma said he shelled out $22,000 for a new cab.
He showed up last month to redeem his old cab, with its divider and meter, and was promptly relieved of $1,700 in tow, storage and administrative fees for the three months it sat at Pier 76.
Mr. Shiroma paid in cash, eager to retrieve his car.
Then he saw it. The cab was covered in soot and bird dung. The battery was dead, and to add insult to injury, there were two more parking tickets under the wiper.
Mr. Tumielewicz arranged for a jump, and within an hour, Mr. Shiroma's Caprice was spitting and sputtering toward freedom.
"You know why people in New York live in tall buildings?" he hollered as he drove toward the gate. "So they can jump." Then he disappeared in a cloud of blue smoke.

HEADLINE: Why America's Left Foot Has Less and Less to Do

BYLINE: By MARSHALL SCHUON 

 BODY:
BARBARA CROOK has been driving since she was 14, but she was afraid to get behind the wheel of my Honda Prelude. There was nothing wrong with the little black coupe -- indeed, Mrs. Crook had just bought it to use as her family's second car -- but she was just scared. She is one of a large and growing population of motorists who have never stirred a manual gearbox.
All the same, she told me (and herself) that she was ready to learn. 
 "Back about 1960, I was 14 and in Florida," she said. "It was the first year that ninth graders had to take driver's ed and get their licenses if they wanted to graduate from junior high school. The school intended to order stick shifts in all the cars but one. But the order was mixed up, and they got all automatics and one stick. So each student just got one test-drive in the stick, and my turn happened to be the day after Hurricane Donna roared through. There were trees everywhere in the road, and all of that starting and stopping was a nightmare. This is an excuse, of course, but that was the end of my experience with a stick."
Eventually, Mrs. Crook sailed away in my Prelude -- with her husband, Douglas, at the wheel -- to her home in Manasquan, N.J. But I thought about how many people are in the same boat. And I remembered my mother, 89 and still driving an automatic, recently riding with me, asking about the Prelude and wondering why anyone would buy a car that had to be shifted.
So, was the stick shift really dead?
"Well, Mom," I said. And tried to explain that a shift lever puts you in touch with the car, that it gives you more of a feel for the road and what the vehicle is doing. I looked into the rear-view mirror and saw her shaking her head as I went from second to third, so I don't think I succeeded.
But what I said was true, at least for me. When I was learning to drive in the early 50's, none of us crew-cut macho guys would have been caught dead with an automatic.
Clutchless cars have been around a long time, of course. Cars with semiautomatics were attempted by various manufacturers in the 30's, but Detroit's first successful automatic transmission appeared as a pricey $100 option on the 1940 Oldsmobile. In 1950, the Olds Hydramatic was grafted onto Chevrolets, and Packard introduced its Ultramatic that same year. The rest of the industry followed, but even when I passed my first driver's test in 1952, "restricted" licenses were still being issued to Pennsylvania applicants who had the bad judgment to show up with an automatic, limiting their driving to a wimpy car.
In those days, my crowd thought a real car was an old Ford V8 with a stalk growing from the floor, and the restricted licenses levied what we considered proper sanction against lazy learners. Now, though, most applicants don't know how to shift, and even Ford's sporty Mustang more often comes with an automatic. Scott Davis, a Ford spokesman, said that only one-third of these pony cars are ordered with stick shifts.
For Chevrolet owners, too, the trend is to drive in the "drive" gear. Manual gear boxes account for fewer than 5 percent of Chevy's cars and 20 percent of its trucks. The Corvette, like other flat-out sports cars, is a slightly different story, with about 35 percent of its buyers choosing the computer-controlled stick that decides whether the car is being driven sensibly or by a hotfoot. If it decides you are civil, it eliminates two gears and makes the shifting less difficult.
Detroit's other Big Three name, Chrysler, also offers a compromise with its Autostick, which has manual and automatic modes. But even with economy cars like the Neon in Chrysler's mix, only 8 to 10 percent of the company's products roll out of showrooms with purely manual transmissions.
It should be said, too, that automatics are better than ever, smoother and more economical. And the trend away from what used to be the "standard transmission" is a worldwide phenomenon.
Luxury cars have long been the exclusive province of the automatic, with only BMW bucking the trend. In the case of the 3-Series Bimmer coupes, 50 percent have sticks, and the ultrasporty M-Series cars are almost entirely manual. Even the ritzier 5-Series has more than its share of manual buyers. Rob Mitchell, a company spokesman, attributed that fact to the BMW's image as a "driving machine."
"There are things that make them comparable with other cars, equipment and quality of build," Mr. Mitchell said. "But I think what really separates them is the driving feel. It's not just the numbers -- the 0 to 60 numbers -- it's what you feel, and I think one thing that's integral to that is a manual transmission."
Traditionally, hand-shifting has also been integral to economy, but these days even makers like Honda see a move away from sticks, which means annual orders of only 150,000 of the nearly 1 million cars the company sold in the United States last year. Richard Norton, a Honda spokesman, said research had shown that "age and where you are in life" affect what kinds of transmissions people buy.
"A lot of Preludes have sticks, but most Accord sedans are ordered with automatic," Mr. Norton said. "Then when we came out with the redesigned Accord coupe last year, we saw an upsurge in orders for stick. The coupe has its own lines and became more of a sports car. But if you look at something like our new Odyssey minivan, there was no need even to offer a stick -- everybody wanted an automatic."
That group would include Mrs. Crook. But she has decided to be brave.
"My church recently asked me to be a soloist," she said, "and it terrified me when they asked. But I did it, and it's been so much fun. So then I thought maybe I'd confront another fear, thinking of new precipices to climb. I thought, Why not learn to shift for myself?"

HEADLINE: China Is Host to Human Rights Conference

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Oct. 20

 BODY:
China opened an international conference on human rights today, a sign of its growing confidence in a field where it has faced much criticism.
While not focused specifically on China, the two-day symposium reflected China's greater willingness to entertain discussions on rights issues. 
 More than 80 delegates from 27 countries attended the conference, sponsored by a group marking the 50th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. The Chinese delegation included Government officials and academics, but no known dissidents.
It also offered China an opportunity to promote its view that cultural, historical and economic differences between countries are bound to create arguments over human rights.
"It is only natural that countries in the world do not have complete agreement on how to define, approach and realize human rights," the Deputy Prime Minister, Qian Qichen, said at the meeting. "No country's human rights situation is perfect."
In a statement, Qin Yongmin, a dissident from southern China, attacked the meeting as an effort to "cheat international opinion."
The symposium follows a decision by the United States and the European Union this year to drop efforts to censure China at the United Nations Human Rights Commission.

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Rising Rents in Chinatown Displace Garment Makers

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
These are not the best of times for contract garment manufacturers in Manhattan. Rents are rising and the manufacturers are under other economic pressures as well, says Paul Lau, executive director of the Sportswear Apparel Association, a trade organization for the industry. About 25 have gone out of business in the last year alone, he said.
But for design concerns and other businesses ready to pay the higher rents, the loft spaces they are leaving in buildings south of East Houston Street and north of Canal Street, where many have clustered, have presented a leasing opportunity. Accordingly, some buildings are in the process of transition from manufacturing to office uses as leases turn over. 
 "We're getting computer companies, sound production and film studios, architects and photographers, moving east from SoHo and going south from the East Village," said Bill Lam, president of Longines Realty on Grand Street, a brokerage company that manages about 400,000 square feet of space in 10 buildings, mainly in and near Chinatown.
The adaptation of commercial space to new market conditions has been an aspect of New York City's real estate history for time out of memory.
Not out of Leo Malz's memory, however. Mr. Malz runs Aleda Plastics, an export business, from the ground floor of a five-story building at 425 Broadway, just north of Canal Street, that he has owned since 1950. "It was built in 1879 as the Uptown Hotel," he said. Since then, uptown has moved uptown, taking the hotel business with it. In the 1920's, Mr. Malz said, the building was converted to residential use, and in the 1940's, textile and vinyl plastics companies moved in.
Most of them moved out in the 1970's, and retailing has become more active on Broadway near Canal Street. Aleda Plastics is still in the ground-floor space, but the dress manufacturer on its upstairs floors closed a year ago, when it was on the verge of bankruptcy.
"We are the last of the plastics jobbers of the late 40's," Mr. Malz said. "Now, we're trying to decide how to remodel the upstairs floors. We could convert them to offices, or they could be for light manufacturing. We're not sure."
But next door, at 443 Broadway, a women's clothing designer has already moved in. Tracy Feith Inc., a three-year-old business, took half a floor in the building, owned by Empire Sporting Goods, a uniform manufacturer, which is bringing office tenants to space it does not need, said Hank Widmaier, a Helmsley-Spear broker. The company moved in six months ago and will soon open a retail outlet nearby, at 209 Mulberry Street.
"I looked for over a year," said Mr. Feith, who had been in a small space at Lafayette and Spring Streets. "This is perfect."
Garment manufacturing tenants usually cannot afford rents higher than about $11 a square foot a year, Mr. Lam of Longines Realty said. In the early 1990's, a period of depressed conditions in the real estate market, many came in on five-year leases at about $7 or $8 a square foot a year. Now, they often cannot afford renewal leases at current market rents, which even with minimal upgrading work are about $15 to $16 a square foot, Mr. Lam said. In the best locations, fully restored space in full-service buildings will cost about $25 a square foot, he said. At that price, a tenant in 2,500 square feet (half a floor in many five-story lofts) would be paying $5,200 a month.
One of the buildings with plans to make the transition as leases expire is 197-201 Grand Street, owned by the Lepore family, which also owns Ferraro's, the Little Italy patisserie, in a smaller building next door. Three garment tenants who remain in the 40,000-square-foot seven-story building are expected to move out by the time their leases expire at the end of this year, Mr. Lam said. Two floors have already been committed to new office tenants, he said.
The vibrant activity in the commercial leasing market in the Chinatown and Little Italy areas has promoted real estate careers for Chinese-Americans. Among them is Mr. Lam himself, who came to the Lower East Side in 1969 at the age of 11 when his family emigrated from Hong Kong. He helped his mother in a garment factory when he was young, and as a young adult, worked in the fashion business. Garment business owners he met then helped him when he founded Longines Realty in 1988. "Longines" is an Americanized rendering of "lon gin," Lam said, which means, roughly, "bright development."
One of his clients now is Danny C. K. Li, president of Great Canal Plaza Inc., a developer-owner that built the Holiday Inn Downtown at 138 Lafayette Street, at Howard Street. The 227-room hotel is a conversion of a vacant 11-story loft. It opened as Maria's Hotel in 1992 but soon became a Holiday Inn, a downtown novelty at the time. It struggled with cost overruns and 30 percent occupancy rates at first, Mr. Li said, but now the occupancy rate averages 92 percent and rates average $160 a night.
Mr. Li, 63, was touring the United States as a performer in a Hong Kong Cantonese-style opera company in 1970 when he decided to stay permanently. He worked 18-hour days in a garment factory on East Broadway in 1971, he said. Three years later, he opened his own garment business, with 50 workers. He sold the business in 1978 and invested in real estate.
His financial partner in various ventures was Maria Lee, franchiser of a bakery chain in Hong Kong and Taiwan, who also opened a Maria's at 148 Lafayette Street. With the economic downturn in Asia, Mr. Li has now bought out his partner in two properties, 185 Canal Street and 125 Canal Street, both six-story office buildings, totaling 60,000 square feet of space.
"We are turning them into Chinatown Class A office buildings," Mr. Lam said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Five agency acquisitions are all in a single day's work in these frenzied times for Madison Avenue.

BYLINE: By Courtney Kane 

 BODY:
THE pace of transactions involving agencies specializing in advertising, public relations and other marketing communications services has accelerated again, this time with the announcement of five acquisitions. Financial terms of the deals were not disclosed.
The frenzy reflects how the dynamics of traditional advertising and marketing keep changing as independent shops are rapidly snapped up by larger agencies. 
One deal involved the communications and marketing division of the MDC Communications Corporation in Toronto, which further expanded its presence in the United States by acquiring a majority interest in Source Marketing, a strategic promotion agency in Westport, Conn.
Source, founded in 1989, has 24 employees and billings estimated at $7 million from clients including the Campbell Soup Company, the Eastman Kodak Company, Home Box Office and Reckitt & Colman. Howard Steinberg, 40, president, will continue to head Source, owning a minority stake in the agency.
"We had been approached by a number of organizations looking to acquire us over the years," Mr. Steinberg said. "However, we agreed to partner with MDC because of their philosophy of independence and autonomy and their ability to bring additional resources to enhance the growth prospects for our business going forward."
The Source deal is the third this year in the United States for MDC, which owns three agencies in Canada including a sales promotion shop, Accumark Promotions in North York, Ontario. In August, MDC acquired a majority interest in Margeotes/Fertitta & Partners in New York and in May, the company bought 75 percent of Cyber Sight, an Internet marketing agency in Portland, Ore.
"Sales promotion is an $80 billion sector of marketing services that is growing 11 percent per year," said Miles S. Nadel, president and chief executive of MDC. "The acquisition of Source Marketing represents an important step for us to swiftly obtain a significant presence in this market in the United States."
MDC also said it had signed letters of intent to buy another American advertising agency, a public relations agency and a corporate design company, but did not identify them.
The second deal involved the acquisition of a Canadian agency.
Euro RSCG Worldwide in New York, part of Havas Advertising, bought Sharpe/Blackmore in Toronto, which has been renamed Sharpe/ Blackmore Euro RSCG. The agency, which was founded in 1996, has 25 employees and billings estimated at more than $20 million from clients including Absolut vodka, Dell Computer, RJR Nabisco and Xerox.
Bill Sharpe, 44, chairman and chief executive, and Tom Blackmore, 49, president, will head Sharpe/Blackmore Euro RSCG in those posts.
The third deal also involved a unit of Euro RSCG.
Healthview Euro RSCG, a division of Euro RSCG Healthcare Worldwide, acquired Nethod L.L.C., a strategic on-line communications agency in New York. Nethod has 10 employees and projected revenue of $3 million from clients like the American Cyanamid division of American Home Products, the Perkin-Elmer Corporation and Rhone-Poulenc Rorer. Gregg Trueman, 42, president of Nethod, will continue to head the agency.
"Nethod will provide on-line program development and management of on-line communications services to all of Healthview's divisions," said Ron Pantello, chief executive of Healthview and Lally McFarland & Pantello Euro RSCG.
The fourth deal involved Doremus & Company in New York, the business-to-business agency owned by Omnicom Group, which acquired Colligan Group, a corporate advertising and direct marketing agency in New York.
Colligan has five employees and billings estimated at $8 million to $10 million from clients like Dictaphone, First Union National Bank and the National Geographic Society.
Richard Colligan, 47, president, continues to head Colligan and becomes an executive vice president of Doremus.
Finally, Ogilvy Public Relations Worldwide in New York acquired Alexander Communications Inc., a technology public relations agency in San Francisco.
Alexander will operate as Alexander Ogilvy Public Relations Worldwide. Pam Alexander, 44, president and chief executive at Alexander, continues to head the agency, reporting to Bob Seltzer, president and chief executive at Ogilvy Public Relations.
Alexander has 158 employees at seven offices in cities including Atlanta, Boston, Dallas and Denver, handling accounts with billings estimated at $15 million from clients like Ascend Communications, Hewlett-Packard, Merrill Lynch & Company and Qwest Communications. Ogilvy Public Relations, part of WPP Group P.L.C., has 550 employees in 31 offices worldwide, handling accounts with billings estimated at $55 million; clients including Glaxo Wellcome, I.B.M., Pfizer and Quaker Oats.

HEADLINE: Chase Manhattan Earnings Beat Forecasts of Analysts

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the nation's second-largest bank, reported better-than-expected earnings in the third quarter yesterday, even as trading revenue from emerging markets evaporated. Wells Fargo & Company, which concentrates on the domestic economy, also beat average estimates.
Chase said third-quarter profit from operations fell 32 percent, to $738 million, or 82 cents a diluted share, from $1.08 billion, or $1.19 a share, in the quarter a year earlier because of trading losses and declines in equity investments. The bank exceeded by 5 cents the average estimate of 77 cents a share forecast by analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation, which tracks company earnings. 
 Chase's net income fell 15 percent, to $837 million, or 94 cents a share, from $982 million, or $1.08 a share, in the quarter a year earlier.
Wells Fargo, based in San Francisco, exceeded analysts' expectations of $3.93 a share by 6 cents. Net income for the bank, the nation's ninth largest, rose 20 percent, to $347 million, or $3.99 a share, from $290 million, or $3.23 a share, in the quarter a year earlier.
Shares of Chase jumped $1.8125, to $53.0625.
Chase was the second big bank this week after J. P. Morgan & Company to stir optimism that the worst may be over after last month's flurry of profit warnings stemming from trading losses in emerging markets, anemic capital markets and signs that domestic economic growth may be slowing.
J. P. Morgan, which reported earnings on Monday that were better than many analysts had expected, and Citigroup, which reports tomorrow, both led the Dow Jones industrial average higher. J. P. Morgan climbed $2.50, to $96.375. Citigroup rose $2.5625, to $45.3125.
Chase said it had $200 million of unsecured trading and lending business in Russia and a $2.7 billion hedge fund investment, of which only $300 million was unprotected.
The bank's noninterest revenue fell 6 percent, to $2.2 billion, because of lower trading revenue. Total trading-related revenue fell 60 percent, to $259 million, as the bank lost $146 million from trading in bonds. A year earlier, it made $264 million from trading in debt securities.
A strong domestic economy helped temper the loss of revenue from overseas markets, analysts said. Chase's consumer businesses gained, with revenue from card-member services rising 17 percent, to $979 million, and regional consumer banking increasing 5 percent, to $591 million.
Wells Fargo and other banks, which primarily focus on domestic activity, also experienced strong earnings growth while reducing expenses. Wells Fargo, which is expected to complete its $30.7 billion merger with the Norwest Corporation next month, said net interest income rose 1.8 percent, to $1.15 billion. Noninterest income rose 8.9 percent, to $737 million, bolstered by service charges on deposits and higher fees and commission income.
Shares of Wells Fargo rose $11.0625, to $378.5625.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Deutsche BankIs Reportedly Seeking U.S. Acquisition

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
Deutsche Bank, eager to buy a concern that will enhance its international investment banking business, has been scouting out prospects, including the Bankers Trust Corporation, Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. and J. P. Morgan & Company, bankers and analysts said yesterday.
Ronaldo H. Schmitz, a member of the board of the Frankfurt-based Deutsche Bank, recently visited with executives from some New York financial companies, including Bankers Trust, said a Deutsche Bank executive who insisted on anonymity. 
 Mr. Schmitz, 59, who oversees Deutsche Bank's investment banking strategy as well as its North American business, was traveling in the United States recently for the annual meetings of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund in Washington, Macy W. Egerton, a spokeswoman for Deutsche Bank confirmed yesterday. She refused to say what banks Mr. Schmitz had met with on his visit.
Deutsche Bank and Bankers Trust declined to comment on reports published yesterday in The Financial Times of London that their banks were in "preliminary talks" about a possible merger.
Even so, the time may be ripe for Deutsche Bank to begin such discussions, whether with Bankers Trust or some other United States concern, analysts said yesterday.
The declines in the American stock markets in recent months have ravaged the stocks of several big banks and brokerage firms, making them cheaper potential acquisitions. While shares of Bankers Trust rose $4.1875 yesterday, to $58.9375, on the report of a possible deal, they are still well below their price of about $100 two months ago. Deutsche Bank's stock, however, has fallen less.
Deutsche Bank has signaled in recent months that buying an American investment bank is its preferred route onto Wall Street, after an expensive strategy of building by hiring bankers and traders proved unsuccessful.
"Deutsche has publicly stated they want to buy" a bank, said Evangelos Kavouriadis, European banking analyst at Sanford Bernstein & Associates, "and they have plenty of financial reserves," more than 44 billion marks ($27.14 billion).
"So the will and the money is there," he said. "The question is from the available candidates, who is the best fit?"
Deutsche Bank is looking for American investment banking expertise to counter growing international competition.
"It would appear that what Deutsche and the big European banks are worried about," said Guy Moszkowski, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, "is that if they don't rapidly improve their capital markets capabilities, firms like Morgan Stanley, Merrill Lynch and Goldman, Sachs" will reap the rewards as capital markets in Europe shift to stocks and away from bank financing under economic and monetary union.
Some American banks may also be more eager now to draw closer to a powerful outside partner like Deutsche Bank. Russia's default on its debts, the gloomier international financial outlook and the sudden contraction of liquidity in many markets has unnerved many of those who manage big American financial companies that deal in the more speculative markets.
Bankers Trust, for example, has been the subject of negative rumors in recent weeks in part because of its big businesses in several markets that have recently done poorly, notably junk bonds, derivatives and growth companies. It also has had some rude shocks lately, having to put up $300 million as its part in the rescue of Long-Term Capital Management L.P., the hedge fund in Greenwich, Conn., that nearly collapsed. In early September, Bankers Trust said that it had trading losses totaling $350 million in its business with Russia. This Thursday, Bankers Trust is expected to report its results for the quarter ended Sept. 30, with analysts generally expecting layoffs and losses.
But some analysts yesterday were scathing about the wisdom of any such merger by Deutsche Bank in this uncertain and volatile climate.
"It is probably one of the worst investment banking decisions I could imagine," said Mark Hoge, bank analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston in London. "It is the worst possible environment to be buying an investment bank at this time, given the market uncertainties, and that you don't know how many gremlins are hiding inside."

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Recent surveys find airline fares are stabilizing -- somewhat -- as corporations trim travel budgets.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
BUSINESS travelers can take some comfort that the typical domestic business fare rose only 3 percent in the 10 months ended August, to $458, according to the latest American Express Business Airfare Index. By contrast, comparable fares increased 16 percent in all of 1997 compared with 1996. A typical business fare generally means the lowest fare available with the least restrictions. But business fares in August, the latest month for which data were available, were 9 percent higher than in August 1997, when the comparable fare was $421.
In its most recent survey, the Air Transport Association reported on Monday that the average fare, which includes economy and first-class fares, fell 1 percent in September, compared with September 1997, and rose only 1.8 percent from January through September 1998, to $138.74 
 But whether because of the rise in business fares the last few years, because of the recent economic downturn or both, corporate America has begun to rein in spending on business travel. A survey of 450 Fortune 1,000 companies by the National Business Travel Association found that 56 percent have cut back the number of employees who travel, 53 percent have replaced some travel with video conferencing and teleconferencing and 40 percent have altered corporate travel practices and policies to save money. On average, the corporations surveyed will reduce overall domestic and international travel by 17 percent.
 
Hotel Update
 With New York City hotels jammed practically every night, the 242-room Peninsula New York hotel at Fifth Avenue and 55th Street will reopen on Nov. 1, some 10 months after closing for a $45 million overhaul. Room rates are $535 a night, a junior suite is $800 and the Peninsula suite is $5,500.
Managed by the hotel and marketing arm of ultra-upscale Hongkong and Shanghai Hotels Ltd., the Peninsula, as those rates suggest, is hardly your ordinary hotel. Amenities include built-in remote-controlled televisions, which can be viewed from the tub; three telephones in the bathroom, including a hands-free unit at the tub, which automatically mutes the radio and television; double-glazed windows and a personal fax number.
There are other specialties of the house, including a control panel that displays up-to-the-minute temperature and humidity readings from the hotel's own rooftop weather station.
 
Conde Nast Winners
Singapore Airlines has done it again. The November issue of Conde Nast Traveler rates the airline the best international carrier for the 10th time in the 11 years the magazine has conducted its readers' choice awards. The best United States carrier was Midwest Express, the rare airline that actually leaves a few inches between passengers' knees and the seat in front. Other winners included the Windsor Court Hotel in New Orleans, voted the best hotel in the world; Crystal Cruises and Silversea, the best large cruise line and small cruise line, respectively; Sydney, Australia, the top foreign city, and San Francisco, the top United States city.
 
Airline News
Americans who buy the Europe Flight Pass can now add Paris, Prague, Venice, Vienna and 25 other European cities for $90 a flight. That is the result of three more airlines' joining the network: Cityjet, based in Dublin; Alpi Eagles, a regional carrier based in Venice, and Croatia Airlines of Zagreb. Other airlines include Icelandair, Virgin Express and Spanair, a Spanish carrier that for almost a year has been operating nonstop flights between Washington Dulles International Airport and Madrid. Flight coupons, sold in packets of three or more, are valid for 120 days. They are available from travel agents or by calling (888) 387-2479.
To celebrate a year of flying to the United States, Spanair has a $299 round-trip fare between Dulles and seven Spanish cities, including Madrid, Barcelona and Palma de Mallorca. The round-trip fare to the Canary Islands is $369. Travel must be completed by Dec. 14 and other restrictions apply.
Sabena Belgium World Airlines also has a bargain fare: $750 a couple to Brussels from New York, Newark, Boston, Chicago or Atlanta. The price includes round-trip fare, departure taxes and two nights at the Brussels Hilton International or a similar hotel. The package is good only over Thanksgiving weekend, Nov. 26-29, and restrictions apply. In a refreshing break with the airline tradition of never disclosing the number of seats available to frequent fliers or in fare sales, Sabena said it was limiting the number of seats for this promotion to 350, or 50 for each of the seven flights -- including two flights each from New York and Atlanta.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Fall As Investors Turn Elsewhere

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices tumbled yesterday as investors moved some money into stocks and scouted for opportunities in corporate bonds. Many were emboldened by the Federal Reserve's reductions in interest rates, which have eased concern that the economy will enter recession.
"People have been scared to death in the past couple of months" and have sought the safety of Treasury debt, said Vic Thompson, who oversees $150 billion of bonds at State Street Global Advisors in Boston. "To the degree that they get their courage back, some of that money is going to make its way out of Treasuries and into riskier securities." 
 The Fed on Thursday lowered its target rate for overnight borrowing between banks by a quarter-point to 5 percent, its second quarter-point reduction in less than three weeks.
The 30-year Treasury bond fell 1 13/32 to 106 29/32. The decline in price pushed up the yield to 5.07 percent from 4.97 percent Monday.
The selling derailed a rally that had pushed bond yields to a series of 31-year lows earlier this month, as investors bought the world's safest securities because of economic turmoil overseas.
"We saw money flow into the safe haven of bonds, and we're seeing the reverse of that now," said Randy Bateman, who helps oversee $1 billion at Sun Trust Private Capital Group in Orlando, Fla.
The Fed's decision to lower rates before its planned Nov. 17 meeting -- the first time since April 1994 that policy was changed outside a scheduled meeting -- increased speculation that it was willing to cut further to forestall a slowdown.
In the corporate bond market, Saks Inc., the nation's sixth-largest department store operator, plans to sell debt to take advantage of low interest rates and improving demand.
The gap in yield, or spread, between investment-grade corporate bonds shrank by 2 to 3 basis points yesterday, traders said. The Ford Motor Company's three-year global bonds, sold Friday at a spread of 113 basis points over Treasuries, were quoted today at a spread of 108-111 basis points, according to traders.
Investors are starting to dabble in corporate bonds after a lull of more than two months, "another concern for Treasuries," said Tony Crescenzi, head of government trading at Miller Tabak Hirsch & Company in New York.

HEADLINE: Making Its Marque at the Top;
Toyota's Lexus Offers a Lesson in Brand Development

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Ellen Passe sat in the passenger seat of an RX 300, the new Lexus midsized sport utility vehicle, while her 2-year-old son, Alex, fiddled with the steering wheel. Outside the car, her husband, Michael, spoke with a salesman at a midtown Manhattan Lexus dealership.
"Where are my heated seats?" Ms. Passe asked good naturedly. The salesman quickly pointed to a small button near the CD player. Ms. Passe smiled. 
 For the Passes, it had come down to a choice between a Jeep Grand Cherokee and this Lexus, both priced at roughly $32,000. But based on their experience owning a Lexus sedan, Mr. Passe seemed fairly sure of what their final decision would be. And they did later buy the Lexus.
"We love the Lexus experience," Mr. Passe said. "And the service? Well, there isn't any comparison."
Since the Toyota Motor Corporation created the Lexus brand a decade ago, families like the Passes have gradually developed a fierce loyalty to it, transforming this upstart -- initially seen as an unlikely threat to BMW, Mercedes-Benz, Lincoln and Cadillac -- into a major automotive success story.
How did Lexus, even with designs that are often called bland, become one of the top-selling American luxury cars, behind only Lincoln, Cadillac and Mercedes?
Its quick ascent provides a vivid lesson in how a mass marketer can carve out new territory. For one thing, Toyota created a distinct identity for Lexus by making it one of the first brands to focus on more than just the car, providing owners a level of service that had not been seen in the industry but that is now emulated by competitors.
Toyota kept Lexus dealerships separate and did not dilute the brand with low-priced, less luxurious vehicles to attract buyers. And thanks to Toyota's deep pockets, Lexus could respond quickly to changing tastes by offering new models.
A look at the Lexus strategy, in fact, points up the missteps made by the Honda Motor Company and the Nissan Motor Company, which brought out their own upscale brands, Acura and Infiniti, in the United States at about the same time. From the start, Lexus took aim at the status-conscious Mercedes driver, while its Japanese rivals offered a broader lineup, making it harder for them to crack the top end of the market later.
Infiniti and Acura are still recovering. In the first nine months of 1998, Lexus sold about 112,000 cars and light trucks in the United States, a 59 percent increase over the corresponding period a year earlier -- and more than BMW, which sold about 98,000, up 4 percent. Mercedes has sold 124,000 vehicles this year, up 56 percent. But Infiniti sales fell 11 percent, to 44,000, and Acura's sagged 7 percent, to 82,000, even as they both offered hefty discounts to increase sales.
Of course, if the long economic boom does falter, sales of all luxury cars will surely suffer. But for now, Lexus is thriving. "Of all the Japanese luxury brands, Lexus is the only one that could be called a success," said Eric Noble, an analyst with AutoPacific, an automobile marketing and product consulting company in Santa Ana, Calif.
"Infiniti, Lexus and Acura all do a pretty good job of handling the consumer," he said. But, he noted, "Lexus has products that are what the consumer wants."
By striving from the outset to match Mercedes's prestige, Lexus took hold more quickly in this country, said Susan Jacobs, president of Jacobs & Associates, a consulting company in Rutherford, N.J.
On top of that, Lexus's focus on service earned it loyal customers. Lexus was one of the first to offer a replacement car while a customer's car was being repaired, showroom breakfast buffets and free lifetime car washes. The company also sponsored opera and jazz events.
Because of its connection to Toyota, Lexus inherited a reputation for value and reliability, said Scott F. Merlis, president of Merlis Automotive International Inc., a Westport, Conn., investment bank.
"They were able to tap into Toyota's product development system and broaden the line quickly," he said. Lexus, which began with two sedans, now has eight models.
The element of surprise also worked to Lexus's advantage, according to Ms. Jacobs. When the first Lexus models hit showrooms in 1989, existing luxury-car makers, especially the Europeans, took little notice. "They didn't believe that a start-up luxury brand could threaten their 100-year heritage," she said.
To be sure, all the Japanese auto makers -- Lexus included -- made missteps in the mid-1990's that hurt sales. Lexus mistakenly increased prices just as the Europeans slashed theirs by as much as 15 percent. Lexus also relied on its reputation too heavily for too long and was slow to make noticeable design changes, said John Casesa, an analyst at Schroder & Company.
"The Europeans so effectively responded to the initial Japanese attack," he said, "that it's taken Lexus nine years of slugging away with the same message and the same product positioning" to gain sales from those who previously owned European luxury cars.
In the past, some critics said, Lexus also updated cars by copying style changes from other makers. A Lexus sport model brought out in the fall of 1997, for instance, offered oval headlights similar to those introduced by Mercedes two years earlier.
At the same time, Acura, initially somewhere between a Honda and a full-scale luxury line, tried to revamp its image as a true luxury-car maker. But it merely confused customers by altering its model names in 1995, switching from brand names to a European-style mix of letters and numbers.
In addition, its plan to retire the name Integra, just when the car was the best-selling and most widely known Acura model, was quickly abandoned. Yet the very existence of the Integra, starting at a humble $16,000, and the lack of a powerful V-8 flagship model has made it difficult for Acura to gain true luxury status.
"By having a vehicle like Integra, it isn't clear it's a luxury car," said Lincoln Merrihew, an analyst for J. D. Power & Associates, a marketing information company. "It's about image."
Infiniti has tried to stake out its own territory in a crowded field, mimicking BMW by focusing on unique design and superior handling and performance. But because of financial problems at Nissan, the company, whose exterior designs differed the most from then-current luxury models, was least able to update models and expand its product line to respond to competitors' lower prices. Infiniti's early advertising campaign, widely considered bizarre because it did not show any cars, also hurt its introducation.
Each auto maker has had some success revamping its lines and introducing new models. Acura's redesigned TL sedan, for example, nudged ahead of a comparable Lexus in sales in September. Backed by Honda's strong reputation as an engine maker, Acura now plans to focus on building high-performance cars aimed at enthusiast drivers, said Jeff Conrad, Acura's national vice president for marketing.
Infiniti, taking a similar tack, plans to introduce a high-performance car aimed at empty-nest baby boomers. The company will also introduce one new car each year for the next four years, said Steve Kight, Infiniti's marketing director.
Lexus, which had initially sold itself as a lower-cost answer to Mercedes but then let prices balloon, charged back by refocusing on value, introducing new models like the GS 400 sport sedan. It also redesigned several models, like its entry-level ES 300 and top-of-the-line sedan, the LS 400, adding features while maintaining or cutting prices.
And Lexus is only now beginning to redesign some models in response to criticism that its cars are dependable but unexciting, Mr. Casesa and Mr. Noble said.
Now, with the introduction of the RX 300 -- which even Cadillac's general manager, John F. Smith, calls the best blending of car and truck attributes -- Lexus is seeking to establish a name as a trend setter as well.
Lexus's midsized model follows closely on the heels of Mercedes's new small sport utility vehicle, the ML 320, which has sold extremely well. Both appeal to drivers who want the comforts of a luxury car along with the best attributes of sport utilities. But the Mercedes is more rugged than the Lexus, and thus closer in feel to larger American sport utilities.
The smaller Lexus sport utility vehicle, available only since March, and the LX 470, an upgraded version of the Toyota Land Cruiser, now account for about 30 percent of Lexus sales in the United States and makes Lexus the only luxury brand offering two models in one of the fastest growing and most profitable corners of the market. In July, it also helped make Lexus briefly the best-selling luxury brand in this country. Lexus sold 14,673 vehicles that month.
The appeal of the RX 300 seems to be that it offers the high perch and four-wheel drive of a sport utility vehicle without some of the drawbacks, like poor ride and truck-like handling. It is also lower to the ground than most larger sport utilities and thus easier to climb into.
"It's an example of their willingness to push the envelope," Mr. Merrihew said. "It's luxury applied to a part of the market that hasn't seen it before."
And in luxury cars, a stable of fresh, exciting products is key.
"Product is about 90 percent of the game," said Mr. Smith of Cadillac, which pushed out its large sport utility model, the Escalade, in 10 months. The Escalade, a version of GMC's Yukon Denali, will appear in showrooms this fall.
Right now new models, like sport utility vehicles, "drive a lot of showroom traffic," bringing in customers who may end up buying cars instead.
Cadillac plans to introduce one new car model each year as it works to develop its own hybrid sport utility, which will be available in a few years. BMW is about two years away as well.
Lexus's efforts to rev up its image, moving from dependable stalwart to maker of vehicles offering a more exciting driving experience, is a tack other luxury-car makers are taking to appeal to younger buyers.
BMW, whose cars have always had a reputation for high performance and driving excitement, already has an edge here.
"We want to be a moving target," says Bryan Bergsteinsson, the Lexus group vice president and general manager. Speaking of the company's competition, he said, "If they can follow us, when they get there, we'll be gone."
But this time around, it will not be as easy, Ms. Jacobs and other analysts forecast.
"They're finding the right ideas to make themselves stand out," she said. But "Lexus now is playing on a much more level playing field than in the early 1990's. The Europeans are more aware of the threat Lexus can pose."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Home builders begin to see the advantages of consolidation.

BYLINE: By Andrew Pollack 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
IS a consolidation coming in the home-building business? That could be one message drawn from the announcement yesterday that the Kaufman & Broad Home Corporation will buy the privately owned Lewis Homes, a leading builder in California and Nevada. The price is $409 million in cash and stock, plus the assumption of $135 million in debt.
Already the largest home builder in California and the West, Kaufman & Broad said the transaction would make it the largest in the country, based on its plans to deliver 21,000 homes in 1999. The current leader, the Pulte Corporation, is now building about 15,000 homes a year. 
 The deal was not officially announced until after the close of trading, but Kaufman & Broad's stock surged $1.0625, or 4.7 percent, to close at $23.625.
For 1998, Kaufman expects revenue of $2.4 billion based on delivery of 15,000 homes. Lewis, based in Upland, Calif., expects to deliver 3,500 homes in 1998 and to show revenue of about $685 million. It is the largest builder in fast-growing Las Vegas, and is strong in northern Nevada, Southern California and Sacramento.
With low interest rates and a strong economy, home builders have been flourishing. But fears that a recession is coming have dampened share prices until the most recent week, when they have rallied somewhat. Kaufman & Broad has been expanding in the last few years outside California into other Western states. But the latest acquisition will strengthen it on its home territory, where it is being challenged by the Lennar Corporation, a Miami-based builder that is expanding aggressively in California through acquisitions.
Kaufman & Broad and some other builders "are trying to focus less on how many markets they can enter and concentrate on building bigger share in the markets they are in," said John Stanley, an analyst at Warburg Dillon Read, which represented Kaufman & Broad in the Lewis acquisition. Having a big market share gives a company an edge in procuring land and subcontractors and provides economies of scale in purchasing and advertising.
Bruce E. Karatz, the president of Kaufman & Broad, said that the push for size and market share meant that more deals would be in the offing, both for his company and for others in home building, traditionally an industry run by small, locally focused entrepreneurs. "People have figured out that you can successfully combine builders," Mr. Karatz said in an interview. "It was the unwritten rule that you couldn't, because they were entrepreneurs and everyone had their own way of doing things." Randall Lewis said he and his three brothers, who run Lewis Homes, decided to sell when they saw the benefits of size. "The bigger companies were getting benefits in terms of purchasing, borrowing on Wall Street and buying land," he said.
Still, a consolidation might not offer much opportunity for investors. So far, most acquisitions have been of small, privately held companies. One exception was the purchase earlier this year of the Continental Homes Holding Corporation of Scottsdale, Ariz., by D.R. Horton Inc. of Arlington, Tex., a transaction valued at $467 million on the day it was announced.
Growth through acquisition is only part of Mr. Karatz's strategy. He has started a program called KB2000 that aims to make home building more of a disciplined business. Instead of building houses and hoping to sell them, as many builders do, Kaufman & Broad is trying to build to order, much like Dell Computer does. It does not offer completely customized homes, but does extensive consumer surveys and has built big showrooms to allow buyers to pick out the fixtures and designs they like.
Mr. Karatz said that KB2000 is improving the company's sales and margins. But he concedes it is hard to isolate the effects of KB2000 on the company's results from the effects of the generally strong market in California and the West.
The real test of KB2000 is likely to be when there is a downturn. That could also be when more mergers occur. "A downturn in the housing market will force a greater amount of consolidation," said Steve Percoco, an analyst with Lark Research in Rahway, N.J.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Back in Redmond, Microsoft's Profit Machine Keeps Humming

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

 BODY:
Demonstrating yet again the power of its franchise, the Microsoft Corporation reported yesterday that its quarterly earnings had risen 58 percent over their level a year earlier, far exceeding Wall Street estimates.
Microsoft, the world's leading maker of computer software, said demand for the Windows 98 operating system exceeded its projections, particularly in Japan and Europe. 
 Microsoft's improved performance coincided with the beginning stages of a landmark antitrust trial in Washington that could threaten its dominance in computer software. The company, which the Department of Justice has portrayed as a ruthless and unfair competitor, said its strength in the latest quarter was derived mostly from Windows 98, which was released just last June, and the Windows NT corporate operating system.
The results for Microsoft, which is based in Redmond, Wash., were released after the stock market had closed. In Nasdaq trading, Microsoft shares closed at $100.25, down $2.69, which may have reflected the opening of the antitrust trial on Monday. But in after-hours trading, the shares traded as high as $103.75.
"Business is good, so the doom-and-gloom scenario of some economic prognosticators certainly hasn't come to pass," Greg Maffei, Microsoft's chief financial officer, said in a telephone interview. "This is not just for Microsoft, but the whole PC industry."
Despite the widespread economic problems in much of the world, Mr. Maffei noted, the six largest software companies and eight largest computer and chip companies that have reported earnings have all beaten estimates.
While continuing to urge caution about the outlook, as Microsoft executives do each quarter, Mr. Maffei said the company was likely to do better than expected in the second fiscal quarter as well. He said he would advise securities analysts to adjust their estimates upward.
For the quarter ended Sept. 30, Microsoft earned $1.68 billion, or 62 cents a diluted share, more than twice the $663 million, or 25 cents a share, reported in the period a year ago. Revenues rose 26 percent, to $3.95 billion from $3.13 billion.
The latest results included a $160 million one-time gain on the sale of Softimage, while in the quarter last year the company took a previously announced $296 million write-off related to the purchase of WebTV Networks Inc. Without these one-time items, Microsoft's earnings rose to $1.52 billion, or 56 cents a share, compared with the previous year's $959 million, or 36 cents a share, to record the 58 percent gain.
Analysts surveyed by First Call Corporation, which tracks earnings results, had expected Microsoft to earn 49 cents a share.
"It was a terrific quarter, a real blowout, a very pleasant surprise for Microsoft shareholders," said Rick Sherlund, an analyst with Goldman Sachs. Microsoft's results "benefited from much higher margins," he said. "We had a combination of better- than-expected revenues and lower- than-expected expenses in the quarter," he said.
Mr. Maffei said the improved profit margins were partly a seasonal phenomenon because the company does less hiring during the summer and the marketing costs associated with the start of Windows 98 were largely in the third and fourth quarters of fiscal 1998. Also, service costs are lower for Windows 98 than for Windows 95. "We had better-than- expected revenues, and we were at the low end of our spending," he said.
Although the antitrust suit brought against Microsoft by the United States Department of Justice did not affect earnings, Mr. Maffei said, it does have a direct cost in increased legal spending.
"That's a large cost, but not a material cost," he said. "We do worry about the continued cost of the D.O.J.'s image blasting."
Unearned revenue, the portion of sales Microsoft sets aside to reflect the long-term deployment of many of its products, grew to $3.13 billion in the quarter, up $245 million from a year ago. Cash and short-term investments totaled $17.24 billion, compared with $13.93 billion a year ago.
On a cautionary note, Mr. Maffei said fallout from the Asian economic crisis remains a concern and the company is uncertain about future performance in Latin American countries. Corporate spending for computer issues related to the year 2000 may divert revenues away from some Microsoft products but could benefit others, he said.

HEADLINE: Profit Rises 10% At Phillip Morris

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Philip Morris Companies, the world's largest tobacco concern, said yesterday that its third-quarter profit rose 10 percent as higher cigarette prices in the United States offset a worldwide drop in demand for Marlboros, Virginia Slims and other brands.
Profit from operations rose to $2.05 billion, or 84 cents a diluted share, from $1.87 billion, or 76 cents a share, a year earlier. Analysts expected the company to earn 83 cents a share, according to the First Call Corporation, which tracks estimates. 
 Unit sales, or the number of cigarettes sold, fell for the first time since 1993, in both the United States and international divisions. Philip Morris has seen slower demand as a result of economic slumps in Asia and in Russia.
The company's Kraft North America unit, the nation's largest food company, said operating profit rose 5.1 percent, helped by increased unit sales and cost savings.
The Miller Brewing unit, the nation's No. 2 beer company, said operating profit rose 1.7 percent, to $118 million, mainly because of lower brewing costs. Unit sales fell 4.2 percent, the company said.
Shares of Philip Morris rose $2 yesterday, to $49.875.
